103
Detention
Centres
Attendance
Centres
Criminological
Research
allocation or recall. In England, Wales and Northern Ireland the period of
training ranges from six months to two years and is followed, in England and
Wales, by supervision for two years and in Northern Ireland for one year
from the date of release. In Scotland, where there is no minimum period of
detention, the maximum is two years and the supervision period is for one
year from the date of release. The system is essentially remedial and educa¬
tional, based on personal training by a carefully selected staff. Emphasis is
placed on vocational training in skilled trades; there is much freedom of move¬
ment and many borstals are open establishments.
Detention centres provide a means of training, and are intended to deter
from further crime, young offenders for whom a long period of residential
training does not seem necessary but who cannot be taught respect for the
law by such measures as fines or probation. In England and Wales four junior
centres are available for boys of not less than 14 and under 17, and 13 senior
centres for young men aged 17 and under 21. In Scotland there is one senior
centre. Detention in England and Wales may be for not less than three and
not more than six months for those over 17; if consecutive sentences are passed,
the total term may not exceed nine months at any one time. Remission of up to
one-third of the sentence may be earned for good conduct. In Scotland the
fixed period for all detention centre sentences is three months and the age
ranges from 16 to 21.
The regime at detention centres, which is brisk and firm, with strong
emphasis on hard work and high standards of behaviour, provides a normal
working week of 44 hours, including one hour daily devoted to physical
training. Boys of compulsory school age have day-time and evening classes,
and further education is provided for others in the evenings. Nearly all young
offenders discharged from detention centres are subject to statutory super¬
vision for 12 months.
Sixty attendance centres have been established in England and Wales for boys
between the ages of 10 and 17 found guilty of offences for which older people
could be sentenced to imprisonment. Boys ordered to attend must do so
during their spare time on Saturday mornings or afternoons; they may be
required to attend for up to three hours on any one occasion and for a total of
not less than 12 hours (with certain exceptions) and not more than 24. The
activities include physical training and instruction in handicrafts or some other
practical subject. Efforts are made at the centres to induce the boys to join a
youth club or other suitable organisation.
In Northern Ireland there is one attendance centre; it operates on the same
lines as the centres in England and Wales, but caters for boys between the
ages of 12 and 17.
Criminological research, particularly research directed to the question of the
treatment of offenders, is carried out by the Home Office Research Unit
(which also serves the Scottish Home and Health Department), by university
departments and by various other research organisations; much of it is
financed by the Home Office and the Scottish Home and Health Department.
Studies undertaken by the Home Office Research Unit are mainly concentrated
on subjects of direct interest to the home departments. Research and teaching
in criminology are provided at the Institute of Criminology at Cambridge
University and at Edinburgh University, at both of which postgraduate
courses are available. Courses in criminology are also available at the univer¬
sities of Durham, Reading. Oxford, Manchester and Southampton; the London
BRITAIN 1973- AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
School of Economics, and University College in the University of London;
and the universities of Glasgow, Edinburgh and Strathclyde in Scotland.
These institutions likewise conduct research.
THE POLICE SERVICE
The police service of Great Britain is organised in a number of large forces
linked with local government and subject to the influence and eventual control
of the Home Secretary in England and Wales and the Secretary of State for
Scotland in Scotland. In Northern Ireland, it is organised in a single force.
POLICE IN There are 67 regular police forces in Great Britain: 47 in England and Wales
GREAT BRITAIN an(j 20 jn Scotland. Each police force is responsible for a separate police area,
but there is constant co-operation between them.
Police Forces In England and Wales the forces are defined according to area of res¬
ponsibility as: county forces (5); county borough forces (6); combined forces
which are forces whose area of responsibility extends over two or more coun¬
ties or county boroughs (34); the Metropolitan Police Force, which is respon¬
sible for an area of approximately 15 miles radius from Charing Cross, but
excluding the City of London; and the City of London force. In Scotland
there are four burgh forces, 15 combined forces, and one county force.
The strength of the regular police force in Great Britain is over 108,000, the
size of individual police forces depending on the area and population which
they serve. In England and Wales, outside Greater London, establishments
range from about 700 to 7,000, the average being 1,850 officers. The strength
of the Metropolitan Police Force is about 21,400. In Scotland forces range in
strength from about 100 to 2,650.
In addition to the regular police forces, there are constabularies maintained
by the statutory transport and other public authorities, and by the Ministry
of Defence.
Police
Authorities
and Chief
Constables
Each of the regular police forces is maintained by a police authority. In the
counties of England and Wales the authority is a police committee and in the
county boroughs a watch committee. Both are committees of the local council
and consist of councillors and justices in a proportion of two to one. Com¬
bined police authorities, which also consist of councillors and justices, contain
representatives from each constituent area covered by an amalgamation
scheme*
The police authority for the Metropolitan Police Force is the Home Sec¬
retary. In the City of London the Court of Common Council is the police
authority, although it usually appoints a standing committee to deal with al
police matters on its behalf. .
In Scotland the police authority for the county is the county council; in
the burghs it is the town council; and where there are combined forces there
is ajoint police committee.
The primary duty of the police authority is to provide an adequate and
efficient police force for the area for which it is responsible. To enable it to
carry out this duty, it is empowered, subject to the approval of the Home
Secretary or Secretary of State for Scotland, to appoint the chief constable
and the deputy and assistant chief constables of the force, and fix the authorised
establishment. It may also retire the chief constable in the interests of efficiency,
if the Home Secretary or the Secretary of State for Scotland agrees, and
must keep itself informed of the way in which chief constables deal with
Central
Authority
Police Officers
LAW AND ORDER IO5
complaints from the public against police officers. In addition, police authori¬
ties, with the consent of the Secretary of State, provide the buildings and
equipment needed for their forces. In the Metropolitan Police District the
chief officer of police and his immediate subordinates are appointed by the
Crown on the recommendation of the Home Secretary.
Chief constables are responsible for the direction and control of police
forces and for the appointment, promotion and discipline of all ranks below
deputy or assistant chief constable; they are, however, generally answerable
to the police authorities on matters of efficiency, and are required to submit
a written annual report.
The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scotland, who have a
general responsibility for the preservation of law and order throughout Great
Britain, are concerned both in the overall organisation of the police service
and in its administration and operation. In this regard, they not only approve
the appointment of chief constables, but may require a police authority to
retire a chief constable in the interests of efficiency, call for a report from a
chief constable on any matters relating to the policing of his area, or cause
a local enquiry to be held. They are also empowered to make regulations as
to the government, administration and conditions of service in police forces.
The police regulations cover such matters as rank; qualifications for appoint¬
ment, promotion and retirement; discipline; hours of duty, leave, pay and
allowances; and uniform and equipment. Some of these are first negotiable
on the Police Council; the others are discussed on representative advisory
bodies together with any general questions affecting the police service.
The Home Secretary is advised on all matters concerning police efficiency
by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary and five inspectors, of whom
one has a special responsibility for traffic. The inspectors are individually
responsible for the inspection of a number of forces, and must be satisfied of
their continuing efficiency through formal annual inspection, and informal
visits and consultations when particular problems arise. The inspectors report
to the Home Secretary on the condition of all the forces, with the exception of
the Metropolitan Police Force. The Secretary of State for Scotland is similarly
assisted by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary in Scotland and one
other inspector.
All police authorities receive a government grant equal to half their net
expenditure, except the Common Council of the City of London, which
receives one-third. The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scot¬
land are empowered to withhold the grant, in whole or in part, permanently
or for such time as they may determine, if they are not satisfied that a police
area is efficiently policed, that a force is properly maintained and administered,
or that the rates of pay or allowances are as prescribed or approved by them.
In general, entry to the regular police force is open to men between the ages
of 19 and 30. Women entrants in England and Wales must be between the
ages of 19 and 35, and in Scotland between 19 and 30 years old. In England
and Wales men over 30 years old, and women over 35, may, however, be
appointed on the recommendation of the appointing authority in special
circumstances approved by the Home Secretary. In Scotland the individual
chief constables may approve appointments of both men and women over 30
years old.
There are nearly 300 graduates serving in the police forces of Great Britain,
and some 80 police officers reading for university degrees.

BRITAIN 1973: an OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The standard police ranks in Great Britain, except in the Metropolitan
Police District, are: chief constable, chief superintendent, superintendent, chief
inspector, inspector, sergeant and constable. Intermediate ranks may also be
adopted in areas where varying degrees of responsibility make them necessary.
In the Metropolitan Police District the chief officer is the Commissioner of
Police of the Metropolis. He is assisted by a deputy commissioner and four
assistant commissioners. Next in rank are deputy assistant commissioners,
commanders, chief superintendents and chief inspectors; the other ranks are
the same as in the rest of the country. In the City of London the ranks are the
same as in the regions except that the chief officer is the Commissioner of
Police and the second in command is an assistant commissioner.
No member of the police service may belong to a trade union since it is a
basic principle of the service that its members must not only be free from
political bias, but must also be seen to be free of it. All ranks, however, have
their own associations which can make representations to ministers or to
police authorities on matters of interest or concern to their members.
Police cadets are recruited by most forces from among boys between 16 (15
in Scotland) and 18 years of age. They have no police powers but are given
some training in police work, partly as useful preparation for subsequent
appointment as constables and partly to give them sufficient insight into police
duties to enable them to decide whether or not they wish to make a career
in the police service. Some forces also recruit girl cadets.
Police authorities employ a large number of civilians on administrative (pay,
records, finance, and other general subjects) and other duties (fingerprint,
scenes of crime and control room work) in order to release as many police
officers as possible for operational duties. In addition civilian staff is employed
on catering and domestic duties.
All police forces have an attachment of special constables, who are volunteers
willing to perform police duties without pay in their spare time. In England
and Wales the function of special constables is to act as auxiliaries to the
regular force when required. In Scotland they are employed only in emer¬
gencies although they may be assigned for duty for training purposes.
Traffic wardens are extensively employed to discharge specified duties con¬
nected with road traffic and vehicles, normally undertaken by the police. In
this connection they may be authorised to serve fixed penalty notices1 for
minor offences to which the fixed penalty system applies; to man police car-
pounds ; to enforce the vehicle excise laws; and to obtain the name and address
of people thought to have committed a traffic offence of the type with which
traffic wardens are competent to deal. They may also be employed to direct
traffic, to act as parking attendants at street parking places, and as school¬
crossing patrols, if the police agree. Traffic wardens remain under the control
of the chief constable of the force to which they are attached, whatever duties
they may perform.
Police Duties A police officer in Great Britain is an independent holder of a public office
and exercises his powers as a constable, whether conferred by statute or by
common law, by virtue of his office; he is an agent of the law of the land, not
of the police authority nor of the central Government and although his chief
1 A fixed penalty notice gives the recipient the option of paying a specified sum to the
clerk of the appropriate magistrates* court, instead of having his case tried in the
ordinary way.

officer of police has a vicarious liability for any wrongful act he may commit
in the performance of his functions as a constable, he himself may also be sued
in respect of his own wrongful act.
The many and varied functions of a police officer as a constable range from
the protection of persons and property, road or street patrolling and traffic
control to crime prevention, criminal investigation and the apprehension of
offenders.
The main departments in all police forces are the uniform department and
the criminal investigation department; many forces also have specialised depart¬
ments, including traffic departments, river police (in districts which include
long stretches of navigable waterway), a mounted branch (for maintaining
order and safety in large crowds), and police dogs.
In all aspects of police work, the application of scientific aids has reached
an advanced stage: nearly £14 million is spent annually on police equipment,
including upwards of £2*5 million on radio communications; the police have
30,000 personal radio sets operational; and a police computer project is being
developed for rationalising the keeping of records and speeding up the
dissemination of information.
A number of common services are provided by the central government depart¬
ments for the benefit of all forces to supplement those provided by the police
authorities for their own use and by communal arrangements made between
the forces themselves. The most important of these services are: training
services, which in England and Wales provide training centres for recruit
training and a central police college for higher training and in Scotland a
central police college with courses of recruit training and higher training; a
forensic science service in England and Wales which provides eight regional
laboratories (in addition to the Metropolitan Police Laboratory); regional
wireless services and wireless depots, which in England and Wales supply and
maintain wireless equipment for the police; and central and provincial criminal
records which are available to all forces. In addition, regional crime squads,
consisting of teams of experienced detectives from several forces, operating
under a committee of chief constables, are employed in England and Wales to
investigate major crimes involving enquiries in more than one police area. In
Scotland the Scottish Crime Squad assists Scottish police forces in the investi¬
gation and prevention of crime and in the collection and maintenance of in¬
formation concerning criminals. Arrangements are also made for everyday
assistance by one force to another.
There are three inter-related branches of the Home Office Police Department
devoted to scientific research and medium- and long-term planning. The Police
Scientific Development Branch and the Police Research Services Branch,
which are staffed by senior police officers, are concerned with operational
research into police methods and the development of equipment for police
forces throughout Great Britain; the Police Management and Planning group,
which is composed mainly of economists and accountants, is responsible for the
development of a planning-programming-budgeting system for the police, and
for the medium- and long-term planning of police resources.
Services provided by the Metropolitan Police Force for other forces include
(1) the publication of the Police Gazette,1 which contains particulars of people
wanted for crime and details of stolen property, and is supplied without charge

of the criminal investigation department at New Scotland Yard, whose duties
include the protection of royalty, some ministers and distinguished foreign

Metropolitan Police Force is also available, on request, to assist any other
police force in England and Wales in criminal investigations. Similarly, the
services of the Fraud Squad, run jointly by the Metropolitan Police Force

(Interpol) on behalf of Great Britain and the British dependencies, is part of

Police Force receives an additional Exchequer grant.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC) operates under the direction of a
chief constable who is responsible to the Police Authority for Northern
Ireland. ,
The RUC, which has a strength of over 4,000 (all ranks) operates through¬
out the Province on a divisional basis. Ranks, conditions of service, pay and
general duties follow closely on the lines of the police service in Great
Britain. The Police Authority, which consists of a chairman, a vice-chairman
and between 14 and 20 other members appointed by the Governor of Northern
Ireland, has the same powers and duties as the police authorities in Great
Britain.
The RUC is assisted in its police duties by the Royal Ulster Constabulary
Reserve, the members of which receive nominal remuneration. While on duty,
they have the same powers, privileges and duties as, by the law for the time
being in force, may be exercised by, or are conferred upon, members of the
regular force.
4 DEFENCE
POLICY
Europe Britain’s basic security depends on the strength of the North Atlantic Alliance,
and it is to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) that by far the
greater part of Britain’s military forces is committed. Britain makes a major
contribution to the full range of deterrent capabilities, both conventional and
nuclear, required by the present NATO strategy of flexible response. At the
same time the British Government supports the Alliance’s efforts to engage the
Soviet Union and its allies in discussions which could lead to a real and lasting
relaxation of tensions between East and West, and hopes that the successful
conclusion of the negotiations on Berlin will make improvements possible over
a wider field in Europe.
Within NATO Britain has felt that the European countries should seek to
co-operate more closely on defence and to establish a greater identity of view.
Britain has played a leading part in the efforts of the European members to
assume increased responsibility for Europe’s defence. In the European Defence
Improvement Programme and their national programmes Britain and nine
other of the European members of the Alliance have made a significant contri¬
bution to the improvement of the Alliance’s conventional capabilities. Cur¬
rently engaged in a number of collaborative equipment projects with European
allies, Britain hopes that such co-operation might be extended to help to meet
Europe’s needs.
Beyond Europe At the same time it is recognised that British interests and responsibilities
are not confined to the NATO area, and that Britain has a shared interest in
the stability of such areas as the Far East and Gulf. Britain is therefore willing
to play, on a scale appropriate to national resources, a part in maintaining
stability outside Europe. Britain is a member of the Central Treaty Organisa¬
tion (CENTO) and the South-East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO). In
South-east Asia, Britain contributes, with Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia
and Singapore, to the Five-Power defence arrangements in Malaysia and
Singapore; this involves the continuing deployment of British forces in this
area. In the Gulf, Britain is willing to help to maintain stability in the area
by the loan of British personnel to assist local forces, and by training and
liaison visits from units of all three Services. Britain is also responsible for the
defence and internal security of its remaining dependencies. In addition,
Britain’s armed forces assist civil communities, particularly in such activities
as disaster assistance and development work.
Northern At home the armed forces have been engaged since 1969 in the task of assisting
Ireland the civil authorities in Northern Ireland in the maintenance of law and order:
in particular they have operated to counter the terrorist campaign pursued by
the Irish Republican Army (IRA).
The United Britain supports the peacekeeping and other efforts of the United Nations
Nations and other international authorities working to eliminate the sources of tension
and conflict between nations and to promote arms control and disarmament.
no
Expenditure
Service
Organisations
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain played a leading part in the negotiations for the 1968 Non-Proliferation
Treaty and the 1971 Sea-Bed Treaty, and Britain’s proposal for a convention
for the prohibition of biological methods of warfare led to the conclusion of a
further international arms control agreement.
Information about defence policy and the armed forces is provided by the
Government in an annual Statement on the Defence Estimates (Cmnd. 4891 in
1972) usually published in February. The defence budget for 1972-73 totalled
£2,854 million, which represents about 5-5 per cent of the gross national
product. Projections of expected defence expenditure for the next five years
are published each November (Cmnd. 4829 in 1971): a rise by an average of
1-4 per cent between 1971-72 and 1975-76 is planned. As compared with
the figure published in 1970 the projections involve an increase of some
£80 million for an accelerated programme of naval shipbuilding and
some £70 million a year for four additional infantry battalions.
PLANNING AND CONTROL
Supreme responsibility for national defence rests with the Prime Minister and
the Cabinet, who are responsible to Parliament. Defence problems and their
implications for foreign and economic policy are dealt with on the Cabinet s
behalf by the Committee on Defence and Oversea Policy, under the chair¬
manship of the Prime Minister.
The formulation of defence policy is the responsibility of the Secretary of
State for Defence. In recent years the emphasis in defence organisation has
been on a greater degree of Service co-ordination, and on overall functional
planning of the defence effort as a whole. Since the unified Ministry of Defence
was created in 1964) the central organisation for defence has been regularly
reviewed and a series of changes made to increase efficiency and economy, the
most recent being the rationalisation of machinery for the procurement of
equipment. The Secretary of State is assisted by two Ministers of State, one
responsible for the Armed Forces and one for Defence Procurement. The two
ministers together with the three Under-Secretaries of State for the Navy,
Army and Air Force respectively, the Chief of the Defence Staff, the three
Service Chiefs of Staff, the Chief of Personnel and Logistics, the Chief Scienti¬
fic Adviser, the Chief Executive of the Procurement Executive and the Per¬
manent Under-Secretary of State for Defence, sit on the Defence Council,
which deals with major defence policy under the chairmanship of the Secretary
of State. The Chiefs of Staff Committee, comprising the Chief of the Defence
Staff as chairman and the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services, is responsible
for giving professional advice on strategy and operations, and on the military
implications of defence policy. The day-to-day management of the three Ser¬
vices is the responsibility of the Admiralty, Army and Air Force Boards of the
Defence Council.
The Royal Navy has four main arms. These are: the Naval General Service,
which mans and maintains the surface fleet; the Fleet Air Arm; the Sub¬
marine Service; and the Royal Marines, who provide a seaborne and airborne
land striking-force.
The Army is organised into some 30 arms and services which include the
Household Cavalry, the Royal Armoured Corps, the Royal Regiment of
Artillery, the Guards division and divisions of infantry, the Corps of Royal
Engineers, the Royal Corps of Signals, the Army Air Corps, the Royal Corps

of Transport, the Royal Army Medical Corps, the Royal Army Ordnance
Corps and the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers.
The Royal Air Force is organised in commands, on a functional basis at
home and on a geographical basis overseas.
The three women’s services, the Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), the
Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and the Women’s Royal Air Force
(WRAP), are integral parts of the Navy, Army and Air Force respectively.
Servicewomen serve alongside servicemen in Britain and overseas. Nursing
services are provided by Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service,
Queen Alexandra’s Royal Army Nursing Corps and Princess Mary’s Royal
Air Force Nursing Service.
The home and overseas commands of the Services are set out below.
Under a phased programme shore commands have been reorganised under a
single Commander-in-Chief, Naval Home Command, Portsmouth, with sub¬
ordinate Area Flag Officers at Plymouth, Chatham and Rosyth. In November
1971 the various sea commands were brought together under one unified
command, Commander-in-Chief Fleet.
During 1972 the previous home commands were replaced by a single command,
United Kingdom Land Forces; for operational reasons there are separate
command arrangements for Northern Ireland. The overseas commands are:
British Army of the Rhine (BAOR); Near East Land Forces; Land Forces
Hong Kong; and British Troops Malta and Gibraltar.
At the end of 1972 a single operational command for units in Britain will be
formed from the main elements of the previous Strike and Air Support Com¬
mands: in addition there are Training and Maintenance Commands. Overseas
commands are Royal Air Force Germany and Near East Air Force.
The assigned British forces in Malaysia and Singapore, along with the forces
of Australia and Newr Zealand, are under the operational command of an inte¬
grated ANZUK command in Singapore.
Britain’s armed forces consist entirely of volunteer personnel. Engagements
available to non-commissioned ranks range from three to 22 years, with a wide
variety of options. In 1972 a new type of engagement was introduced for non¬
commissioned ranks of all three Services, under which recruits will be com¬
mitted for only a minimum period of productive service (about three years)
and, subject to that minimum, may leave at any time at 18 months’ notice.
Commissions may be granted for short, medium and long terms.
Entrants to the non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given basic
training, and further training is given during the course of their careers. Young
servicemen have the opportunity to read for secondary school qualifications
(see p. 152). Trade and technical training, though primarily designed for
Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally recognised qualifications;
completion of many Service trade or technical courses followed by experience
is recognised by trade unions as a qualification for membership by men who
have left the Services.

BRITAIN 1973* AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Promotion from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three Ser¬
vices. In the Royal Navy, the largest entry is through the Britannia Royal
Naval College, Dartmouth; in the Army through cadetships in the Royal
Military Academy Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training which
may include degree courses. The RAF has a direct entry scheme to com¬
missioned service. There are also schemes in all three Services for the award
of University Cadetships, which enable young men to take a degree before
commencing their Service training, and for the entry of graduates and other
qualified specialists.
All three Services provide training facilities for the armed forces of Common¬
wealth and foreign nations.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff College
at Bracknell (Berkshire) go to the National Defence College (formerly the
Joint Services Staff College) at Chesham (Buckinghamshire). Here, in an
intensive and broad-based programme of courses, particular attention is paid
to the inter-Service aspect of staff work. Specially selected and more senior
officers from the Services, the Civil Service, and from the Commonwealth, the
United States, and allied European countries attend the Royal College of
Defence Studies (formerly the Imperial Defence College) in London. Con¬
siderable training is done through Joint-Service and inter-allied exercises, on
which increasing emphasis is placed.
In the defence estimates for 1972-73 £47 million is allocated to reserve and
auxiliary forces. Apart from their essential military role, these are considered
to form an important link between the Services and the civil community.
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency: in particular the Royal Fleet Reserve
of men with recent experience of active service. The Volunteer Reserves com¬
prise the Royal Naval Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the
Royal Marines Reserve; they carry out regular part-time training and man a
number of operational minesweepers and reinforce the Royal Marine Com¬
mandos. f
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed ot
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Army Reserve to complete normally a total
engagement of seven or 12 years, according to the initial commitment and are
liable to recall. The Army General Reserve consists of certain former National
Service specialists.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (TAVR) consists of indepen¬
dent and sponsored units. Independent units are raised on a territorial basis
and each is based on one or more training centres. Sponsored units consist of
specialists and have to be recruited on a nation-wide basis. These units are
divided, for administration purposes, into Group A, which has a liability for
call-out when warlike operations are in preparation or in progress; and Group
B, which consists of miscellaneous units (for example, University Officer
Training Corps) with various liabilities. The establishment of the TAVR has

CIVIL DEFENCE
been increased to provide an uncommitted reserve of infantry units and an
additional armoured car regiment.
The Ulster Defence Regiment is a locally recruited, part-time force under
the General Officer Commanding Northern Ireland, whose role is to support
the regular forces in the Command.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen who
serve in accordance with the terms of their original engagement or have volun¬
tarily extended their contractual period of service in the reserve; they have a
statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting of three
maritime headquarter units and the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve, which
includes the 16 University Air Squadrons, are liable for part-time training
and for recall in an emergency.
Civil defence arrangements are principally based on the extended and adapted
use of existing public services operated by nationalised industries, by local
authorities, police authorities and government departments. Supplementary
effort from individual volunteers and voluntary organisations would be brought
in either at the discretion of local authorities or in response to a national appeal
in time of crisis. Within a total annual expenditure of £10 million emphasis is
placed on a high level of training for officials of the various authorities and
departments and planning at local level.
Arrangements include an emergency system for decentralised governmental
control and communications. The United Kingdom Warning and Monitoring
Organisation, including the Royal Observer Corps, is organised to provide
public warning of an attack, of the location and power of nuclear explosions,
and of the distribution and level of radioactive fall-out. Central training courses
are arranged by the Home Office on staff college lines.
NATO COMMITMENT
The basis of the present NATO strategy of flexible response, which retains
the principle of forward defence, is that credible deterrence of military actions
of all kinds is necessary: this can be secured only through a wide range of
forces equipped with a balanced mixture of conventional and tactical and
strategic nuclear weapons and thus able to respond to aggression at a variety
of levels. While NATO must be ready to use nuclear weapons if necessary, the
number and capabilities of its conventional forces must be maintained at a
level which would give NATO an alternative to a nuclear response against
anything but a major attack. This would permit a flexible range of responses,
able to meet aggression in the first place with direct defence at the appropriate
level, to gain time for negotiations to end a conflict, and to reassert deterrence
through the possibility of escalation to a higher level of conflict.
The strategy, with its emphasis on the need to be prepared to meet attacks of
varying scales in any region of the NATO area, requires a comprehensive
range of mobile and well-equipped conventional forces, and tactical and
strategic nuclear v/eapons. Britain makes a contribution to the forces required
by NATO’s present strategy unmatched by any other European member of
the North Atlantic Alliance. The British Polaris force forms the contribution
to the Western strategic deterrent. Virtually the whole of the Royal Navy is
earmarked for assignment; the British Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and RAF
Germany (a tactical air-force) are assigned; and most of the air and ground
combat units based in the United Kingdom are also formally committed, from

which an important part of NATO’s mobile reinforcement capability is pro¬
vided. As part of its contribution to the European Defence Improvement Pro¬
gramme, Britain is improving the capabilities of air and naval forces committed
to the Alliance.
DEPLOYMENT
Elements of the Fleet operate in European sea areas; frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and fishery protection, and
ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All major ships have
NATO commitments in the Channel, Eastern Atlantic, and Mediterranean;
a frigate or guided missile destroyer is assigned to the Standing Naval Force
Atlantic. Submarines of the British Polaris force are on continuous deterrent
patrol.
Of the Army units stationed in Britain the land elements of the United
Kingdom Mobile Force (of which No. 38 Group, Royal Air Force, provides
the air element), the British contribution to the land element of Allied Com¬
mand Europe Mobile Force (Land), and the Special Air Service Regiment
all have primary roles in support of NATO. Other field force units and train¬
ing organisations are stationed in the United Kingdom together with units
engaged on logistic tasks. A number of units have been deployed in Northern
Ireland to assist in the maintenance of law and order (see p. 109).
The combat units of the Royal Air Force in Britain provide strike and
strategic reconnaissance squadrons, interceptor squadrons for the air defence
of Britain, long-range maritime reconnaissance squadrons and forces for
maritime air defence and strike/attack. Plans to transfer the remaining fixed-
wing air support to the Royal Air Force from the Royal Navy have been
deferred until the late 1970s. These forces are all committed to NATO. Also
based in Britain are strategic and tactical transport forces, and the force of
Phantoms and Harriers in No. 38 group designed to provide close support for
the army in the field and tactical reconnaissance. The Phantoms and short-
range transport aircraft in No. 38 Group provide the RAF part of the UK
Mobile Force which is committed to NATO, while the Harriers provide the
main British contribution to NATO’s Allied Command Europe Mobile Force
(Air). There are also units of the Royal Air Force Regiment, responsible for
airfield defence and available for service overseas as required.
Ground forces in the Federal Republic of Germany consist of the British
Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and an independent brigade in West Berlin.
BAOR is organised as a corps of three divisions each of two brigades, plus corps
troops including two artillery brigades and an armoured reconnaissance force.
The BAOR brigades have been reorganised to produce a better balance
between armoured units and mechanised infantry. Royal Air Force Germany
is a tactical air force including strike/attack, reconnaissance, close support, and
air defence aircraft, all assigned to Supreme Allied Commander, Europe
(SACEUR). Helicopters for army support are also committed to NATO.
Surface-to-air missiles and light anti-aircraft squadrons are deployed for the
defence of RAF Germany’s airfields.
In the Mediterranean Britain’s maritime presence includes two frigates and a
guided missile destroyer or a cruiser which are earmarked for assignment to
SACEUR, one of which participates in the NATO ‘on call’ force; these are
reinforced by the occasional deployment of an aircraft carrier, a commando
Far East

DEFENCE 115
ship, and frigates and submarines earmarked for other NATO commands. A
Royal Marine Commando is deployed in Malta.
Royal Air Force units in the area consist of strike/attack, maritime recon¬
naissance, photographic reconnaissance, air defence and transport squadrons;
surface-to-air missiles; and RAF Regiment squadrons. These forces are based
in Malta and Cyprus; support for NATO is provided from the forces in
Malta while support for CENTO comes from forces in both locations. Britain
supplies at its own expense about 900 men for the United Nations Peace¬
keeping Force in Cyprus (the largest national contingent). There are also small
garrisons in Cyprus and Gibraltar.
Britain continues to declare forces to certain contingency plans of the South-
East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO). Garrisons are maintained in Hong
Kong and Brunei. A force of six ships on station in the area contributes towards
the Five-Power defence arrangements (see below), and maintains the Beira
patrol, a guard-ship at Hong Kong, as well as providing a presence in the
Indian Ocean and South-east Asia areas. Other ships deployed in the area
include patrol vessels for maritime policing duties at Hong Kong and Royal
Fleet Auxiliaries.
The British contribution to the Five-Power defence arrangements for Malaysia
and Singapore, which is designed to complement the forces of the other four
countries, consists of a battalion group, with appropriate staff and logistic
elements, in Singapore; a detachment of long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft and support helicopters; two frigates or destroyers and a submarine
attached to the Royal Australian Navy.
Two frigates, equipped with helicopters, one of which carries a detachment of
Royal Marines, operate in the Caribbean. A detachment of Royal Marines and
a Royal Navy hovercraft unit are maintained in the Falkland Islands, and the
Royal Navy’s ice-patrol ship, HMS Endurance, operates there seasonally. A
small Army garrison remains in British Honduras.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces may be functionally divided as described below.
Responsibility for the British contribution to the Western strategic deterrent
now rests with the Royal Navy Polaris submarine force whose four nuclear
submarines—Resolution, Repulse, Renown and Revenge—are now in service
and provide a continuous deterrent patrol. Each has indefinite underwater
cruising range and carries 16 Polaris A3 missiles (with a range of about 2,800
miles and thermonuclear warheads). The cost of the force for 1972-73 is
estimated at £38 million.
The Polaris and other submarines operate from the Clyde submarine base
completed in 1968. Britain also provides facilities for a depot ship for United
States Polaris submarines at Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde.
Britain’s nuclear strategic force is assigned to NATO. Within the Alliance
Britain has played an active part in the discussions designed to associate the
non-nuclear members of NATO with the Alliance’s nuclear planning. Political
guidelines for the defensive use of tactical nuclear weapons have been approved,
and procedures for consultation on the possible use of nuclear weapons have
been refined.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR, an independent
brigade in West Berlin, and the forces stationed in Britain, the main elements
of which have primary roles in support of NATO (see p. 114). Their cost in
1972-73 is estimated at £412 million. Armoured regiments have completed
re-equipment with the Chieftain main battle tank, which incorporates new
features in protection and mobility and mounts the fully stabilised 120 mm gun,
and with the Szvingfire anti-tank guided missiles on a version of the armoured
personnel carrier. A new family of lightweight armoured combat reconnais¬
sance vehicles is under development, and the first of these, Scorpion, is entering
service. The field artillery has been re-equipped; its weapons now include a
new British 105 mm light gun, the British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm gun,
and the American self-propelled 155 mm and 175 mm guns; the issue of the
new Field Artillery Computer Equipment (FACE) gives improved accuracy
and response times, as will the Cymbeline lightweight mortar-locating radar.
Surface-to-surface tactical nuclear support is provided by the Honest John
free-flight missile and the 8 in. (203 mm) howitzer. Infantry units are highly
mobile with tracked armoured personnel carriers (FV 432), some of which are
modified to carry the 81 mm mortar or the Wombat 122 mm anti-tank gun,
and the Stalwart high mobility cross-country load-carrying vehicle. Mech¬
anised infantry battalions have been equipped with a new 66 mm anti-tank
rocket. Surveillance and target acquisition capability has been improved by a
new drone (unmanned reconnaissance aircraft) and by the issue of ground sur¬
veillance radar and additional night-fighting devices. For chemical defence an
improved range of clothing is being issued. Air defence is provided by Thunder-
bird and Rapier anti-aircraft guided missiles; both systems are fully mobile.
Other Army combat forces consist of the ground forces deployed^ outside
Europe to meet Commonwealth and treaty commitments. Their cost in I972-
73 is estimated at £52 million. Equipment is in general similar to that of the
European theatre ground forces. The force of helicopters is being increased
and will be equipped with the Anglo-French Gazelle and Lynx. Canadian
Beaver light aircraft are used for liaison purposes. The Landing Ship Tank
(LST), for support operations, has been superseded by the faster and more
advanced Landing Ship Logistic (LSL). Winchester SRN6 hovercraft are
operated by the Royal Corps of Transport.
The naval general purpose combat forces comprise amphibious and naval air
forces, submarines (excluding the Polaris force), helicopter-cruisers, destroyers,
frigates, and mine countermeasure forces; and support and other ships. Any
of these ships can be sent to other theatres if needed in an emergency, either
as reinforcements or to carry out joint operations with the Army and Royal
Air Force. Their cost in 1972-73 is estimated at £330 million.
The aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal will operate until the late 1970s. HMS
Eagle and Hermes have been phased out of the fixed-wing-flymg role; Hermes
is undergoing conversion to the commando ship role, to replace eventually
HMS Albion. HMS Ark Royal operates Buccaneer and Phantom aircraft.
The Buccaneer Mk2 is a long-range, low-level strike aircraft, its equipment
including the Bullpup air-to-surface missile; the Phantom is equipped with
Sparrow and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles in the air defence role. Gannet
aircraft provide airborne early warning.
Amphibious forces are provided by the commando ships HMS Albion and
Bulwark, with Royal Marine Commandos, helicopters and landing-cralt and
the assault ships HMS Fearless and Intrepid, both of which have been fitted
DEFENCE
II?
with a communications satellite terminal, working through the Skynet system.
The command-helicopter-cruisers HMS Blake and Tiger are equipped with
Sea King anti-submarine helicopters. The County class series of eight
guided missile destroyers is completed; they are equipped with Seaslug and
Seacat ship-to-air guided missiles (both of which have a capability against
surface targets), an anti-submarine helicopter and underwater detection
equipment, and four 4-5 in. (i 15 mm) fully automatic quick-firing guns with
appropriate control equipment. The 26 Leander class general purpose frigates
are equipped with advanced anti-submarine equipment, including sonar and
mortars. They and the Tribal class carry Wasp anti-submarine helicopters and
Seacat anti-aircraft guided missiles. Some 23 anti-submarine frigates are
operational. Most ships of frigate size and above carry helicopters; the Sea
King is deployed on major fleet units; the Lynx will replace the Wasp in the
mid-seventies. These helicopters have an anti-submarine role and a capability
against surface vessels. The strike capability of surface ships will be improved
by the introduction of the French Exocet, a surface-to-surface guided missile
system.
Three classes of advanced surface ships will be introduced during the
seventies. Eight of the new Amazon class frigates (Type 21), to be equipped
eventually with the Seawolf surface-to-air missile system, are under con¬
struction, and seven of the new destroyers (Type 42) to carry the Seadart
surface-to-air missile (with a surface-to-surface capability) are under con¬
struction. HMS Bristol, the new Type 82 guided missile destroyer, with Sea-
dart and Ikara, an anti-submarine missile, is entering service. Some of the
Leandei class frigates are being equipped with Ikara. A new type of cruiser,
to carry helicopters, with a ‘through-deck’ design giving the option of operat¬
ing V/STOL aircraft, is being designed; it too will be armed with Seadart.
A new general purpose frigate is also being designed.
Seven nuclear fleet submarines (hunter-killer) are now in service—Dread¬
nought, Valiant, War spite, Churchill, Conqueror, Courageous and Swiftsure;
three more are under construction, and an eleventh has been ordered. A force
of 24 conventional patrol submarines is also in service. Studies are in hand
for submarine-launched anti-ship missile systems.
Maintenance and repair facilities are provided by a submarine depot ship,
and a mine countermeasure support ship manned by naval personnel. Ships
of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat logistic support such as
fuel, food, ammunition, stores and spare gear. These ships fly the Blue Ensign
and are manned by civilian personnel. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devon-
port, Chatham and Rosyth provide the Navy with major repair and supply
facilities in Britain.
Royal Air Force The Royal Air Force general purpose combat forces comprise all front line
General formations and units except those designated Air Mobility Forces (transport
Purpose and tanker forces). They fall into the following categories: air defence; strike/
Combat Forces attack; reconnaissance; close support and tactical reconnaissance; maritime
patrol and anti-submarine warfare; and RAF Regiment field squadrons. Their
cost in 1972-73 is estimated at £410 million.
Equipment Interceptor squadrons are equipped with Lightning, which is supersonic and
can carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles, and Phantom FGi aircraft
equipped with Sparrow and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles. Bloodhound and
Tiger cat surface-to-air missiles and light anti-aircraft guns are also available
for air defence. Work continues on the centralised data handling facilities for
the Linesman/Mediator control and reporting system for air defence and air
Il8 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
traffic control. The Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station at Fylingdales
would provide warning of a missile attack on Britain; it also detects, tracks
and identifies objects in orbit.
Vulcans, Buccaneers and Phantom FGRas operate in the strike/attack role;
Victors, Canberras and Phantom FGR.2S in the reconnaissance role; Harriers
in the close support and tactical reconnaissance role; and Nimrods in maritime
patrol and anti-submarine warfare. RAF Buccaneers and Phantom FGis also
provide maritime strike and air defence; a number of Shackletons have been
converted to provide airborne early warning over the sea. The Jaguar aircraft
will enter service in the close support and reconnaissance roles.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, support helicopters and
communications aircraft. Their cost in 1972-73, together with that of associ¬
ated stations and other support, is estimated at £114 million.
The strategic transport force is equipped with Comet 4C, Britannia, Belfast and
VC10 aircraft. Tactical transport support over medium ranges is provided by
the Hercules (which also has a strategic capability), while for short-range tasks
the Wessex and Puma helicopters and the Andover aircraft are available. A
force of Victor tanker aircraft provides in-flight refuelling, which gives added
range and flexibility to the operations of air defence, maritime strike and
other aircraft.
DEFENCE PROCUREMENT
Responsibility for the procurement (that is, research, development and
production) of defence equipment, including aircraft, ships, ordnance, guided
weapons and electronics, lies with the Procurement Executive within the
Ministry of Defence. The Executive was set up in August 1971 following a
reorganisation of the government departments responsible for defence
procurement and civil aerospace. It combines the defence procurement
responsibilities until then carried out by the Ministry of Defence and the
former Ministry of Aviation Supply (an interim department which took over
the defence and civil aerospace role of the former Ministry of Technology in
late 1970).
Under the Chief Executive there are four systems controllers responsible
for development and production, one in each of the main areas (land, sea and
air systems and guided weapons). There are three additional controllers for
policy, personnel and research. The Head of Defence Sales also reports to the
Chief Executive on certain aspects of his work, while on the remainder he
reports to the Permanent Under-Secretary of State.
Research The 1972-73 estimate for research and development was £330 million. The
and Development major part of the research is undertaken by the Ministry of Defence’s research
and development establishments, but the Ministry also sponsors a sub¬
stantial amount of research by industry and the universities. The research and
development establishments have a very wide technological capability, which
has civil as well as military applications: for example, support is given to civil
aerospace projects such as Concorde and advanced aeroengines. On the
development side, the establishments collaborate closely with the Ministry’s
contractors by monitoring their progress, assisting in testing programmes, and
in solving particular technical problems.
The development programme can be divided into those projects on which

Britain is collaborating with its allies, and those which are being developed
on a national basis. To maintain a sound industrial base for defence procure¬
ment in this country, close consultation is maintained between government
and industry both in the National Defence Industries Council and through
other specialised machinery. However, the complexity of modern defence
equipment and the high initial investment required means that in certain cases
a more practical solution is to share the cost of development by collaboration
with allies or, if need be, to undertake a direct purchase of an existing foreign
military equipment or system without further development.
Collaboration between Britain and her allies, particularly in Europe, continues
to grow in importance. The Multi-Role Combat Aircraft, being developed in
co-operation with Italy and the Federal Republic of Germany, remains the
most important single project in the programme. Collaboration with France
on the Jaguar combat aircraft, the Martel air-to-surface missile and three
helicopters, the Lynx, Gazelle and Puma, is at an advanced stage. Germany and
Italy are collaborating with Britain in the joint development and production
of two major artillery systems: a 155 mm towed medium gun and a self-
propelled 155 mm howitzer. In 1970 Belgium became a partner in the pro¬
gramme for the development and production of the family of air-portable,
tracked, aluminium armoured combat reconnaissance vehicles.
A considerable number of projects are being developed by industry and the
Ministry of Defence. They include the following major projects: aircraft
(HS 1182—a new advanced jet trainer, and Jetstream—a multi-engined pilot
trainer); guided weapons (Seawolf and Seadart—ship-to-air short- and
medium-range missiles, Rapier—an air-portable surface-to-air missile for the
Army and Air Force, Swingfire—a long-range anti-tank missile, and Blowpipe
—a man-portable air defence missile); electronics (Clansman—a net radio
communications system, Linesman/Mediator—a control and reporting system
for air defence and air traffic control, new aircraft search radars, and defence
communications satellites); ships and naval weapons (Type 22 frigate, Type
42 destroyer, nuclear and gas turbine propulsion systems, anti-submarine
torpedoes, and new sonar systems); ordnance and military vehicles (amphi¬
bious combat engineer tractor, and wheeled, air-portable, aluminium armoured
vehicles).
Following the development of defence equipment, either nationally or in
co-operation with allies, production is usually undertaken by private industry
on a contract basis or by the ordnance factories and naval dockyards. Produc¬
tion may also be taken on a collaborative basis. The Defence Sales Organisa¬
tion helps British firms to secure overseas orders, and promotes sales of
products of the ordnance factories. In 1972-73 the total value of exports of
British defence equipment was estimated at some £345 million.
In addition to research and development, there is support of a general nature
supplied in Britain to the Services as a whole. The major items include:
general training; the overhead costs of naval dockyards, ordnance factories
and repair, maintenance and storage units; Ministry of Defence and local
administrative services in Britain; and military pensions. Work continues to
rationalise and reorganise these support services. The total estimated cost for
1972-73 is £1,097 million.

5 SOCIAL WELFARE
Voluntary

STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain central and local government are responsible for a wide range of
health and social services. Central government is responsible directly for the
hospital service of the National Health Service and for social security, includ¬
ing family allowances, national insurance and financial help to those in special
need, and has a supervisory responsibility for the rest of the National Health
Service and many local authority services. Local authorities are directly
responsible for public health and for a variety of personal health and social
services for children and mothers, the chronic sick and handicapped (physically
or mentally), the elderly and the homeless (all described in this chapter); and
for education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter 8). Public authorities
in Britain are spending about £ 12,000 million a year on this range of services,
that is, over £200 a year per head of the population.
The publicly provided services are supplemented by those provided by
voluntary organisations and by individual voluntary workers. Voluntary
organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of nearly all the
social services. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics, dispensaries, and
social and recreational clubs before these were provided by the State. They
made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very young and the very
old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the State accepted the
primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing the voluntary
services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured a minimum
standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-operative.
Both central and local authorities make grants to the voluntary social services.
The officers of central and local government plan and carry out their duties
taking account of the voluntary help available and co-operating with the
voluntary agencies, which have specialised in meeting particular needs, while
the residential provision made by central and local authorities for the care of
children, the chronic sick, the mentally disordered, the disabled and the aged
is supplemented by voluntary homes of various types.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote co¬
operation between charities and State services.
In 1972 the Home Office took on the responsibility for the co-ordination of
government interests in voluntary social service.
The number of voluntary organisations in Britain runs into thousands, they
range from national organisations to small individual local groups. Most
organisations, however, are members of larger associations or are represented
on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees. Some are chiefly
concerned with giving personal service, others in the formation of public
opinion and exchange of information. A number are concerned with giving
help to immigrants.
SOCIAL WELFARE
123
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems include the
voluntary family casework agencies like the Family Welfare Association,
Family Service Units, and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty
to Children; marriage guidance centres affiliated to the National Marriage
Guidance Council; the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her
Child; and the Samaritans, who help people near to committing suicide.
Community service of many kinds is given by young people, particularly
those belonging to a number of national and local organisations, for example,
the Young Volunteer Force Foundation, Community Service Volunteers,
Task Force, Scouts, Girl Guides and school groups.
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given by—among
others—the British Red Cross Society, the St. John Ambulance Association
and Brigade, the Women’s Royal Voluntary Service and the Leagues of
Hospital Friends, but an increasing number of societies exist to help people
with particular disabilities and difficulties. Such societies, most of which are
constituent members of the Central Council for the Disabled, include the
Royal National Institute for the Blind, the Royal National Institute for the
Deaf, the National Association for Mental Health, the National Society for
Mentally Handicapped Children, the Spastics Society, Alcoholics Anonymous,
Narcotics Anonymous and their Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specifically religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the Com¬
mittee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of England
Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work, the
Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian Associa¬
tion, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of St. Vincent
de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish Welfare
Board.
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women’s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty, brings
‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, provides flatlets
and residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and assists in
hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
The main voluntary body in England and Wales providing central links
between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned with social
service is the National Council of Social Service, which brings together most
of the principal voluntary agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a
whole or in groups of those concerned with particular aspects, such as youth
work or work among the handicapped. There are also the Scottish Council of
Social Service and the Northern Ireland Council of Social Service, which
perform similar functions. The Citizens’ Advice Bureaux, of which there are
now some 540 in Britain, are steadily increasing in number. The primary role
of the bureaux is to give explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt
about his rights or who does not know about the State or voluntary services
which could help him.
Urban
Programme
A four-year urban programme providing for government-aided local authority
expenditure of some £20 million-^25 million was launched at the end of 1968
to assist areas of special social need, in particular to relieve problems resulting
from overcrowding, inadequate housing and schools, and other forms of
deprivation. In 1970 the programme was extended to 1976 with total expendi¬
ture for the period 1968-76 of £60 million-^65 million. Projects being under¬
taken include help for playgroups and the provision and improvement of
124
Reciprocity
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
nursery schools and classes, day nurseries and playgrounds, language classes
for immigrants, in-service training courses for teachers, children’s homes,
family advice centres, housing aid services, family planning clinics, help for
community centres and summer holiday schemes for deprived children. A
particular aim of the programme is to support the work of voluntary bodies.
An experiment in community development is also being undertaken by the
Government. This involves bringing together those services, both statutory
and voluntary, which are concerned with relieving various forms of social
handicap and encouraging the resources of self-help within the community.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances, family
income supplements and supplementary benefits together with (in a special
category) war pensions constitute a comprehensive system of social security in
the United Kingdom.
The Department of Health and Social Security administers these services
in Great Britain; within the Department the Supplementary Benefits Com¬
mission is responsible for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern
Ireland the first five of these schemes are administered by the Ministry of
Health and Social Services which contains the Supplementary Benefits Com¬
mission for Northern Ireland. Pensions and welfare services for war pensioners
and their dependants are the responsibility of the Department of Health and
Social Security throughout the United Kingdom. Appeals relating to claims
for the various benefits are decided by independent authorities.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may
be regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system
of comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non¬
contributory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first con¬
tributory pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory
National Health Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year
a scheme of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was
extended to cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of the
second world war social security provision in Britain was among the best in
the world, but lacked co-ordination because of its piecemeal development, and
not everyone came within its scope. In the immediate post-war years a series
of Acts introduced the present comprehensive system, which became fully
operative in July 1948. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes back to
the end of the sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present war pension
provisions were laid down during the first world war with further develop¬
ments during and after the second world war.
Family allowances and national insurance and industrial injuries benefits
or allowances, other than maternity, unemployment, sickness, invalidity,
injury or disablement benefit, are included in the taxable income on which
income tax is assessed. On the other hand, various income tax reliefs and
exemptions are allowed on account of age or liability for the support of
dependants. Family income supplements, attendance allowance and war dis¬
ablement pensions are not taxable.
The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate as a
single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family allowances
SOCIAL WELFARE
125
FAMILY
ALLOWANCES
FAMILY INCOME
SUPPLEMENT
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Austria, Belgium,
Denmark, Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Jersey and Guernsey,
Norway, Sweden, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. Agreements with Cyprus,
France, the Republic of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the
Netherlands and Turkey cover industrial injuries and most national insurance
benefits. With Australia and New Zealand there are agreements on family
allowances and most national insurance benefits. There are limited agree¬
ments with Bermuda, Canada and the United States. Northern Ireland and
the Isle of Man are also party to most of these agreements with other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of 1945-64), and in Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. They are being paid in Great Britain to about 4-3
million families with over n-2 million children, and in Northern Ireland to
some 137,000 families. The allowances are payable to families with two or
more children who are under minimum school-leaving age or under 19 and
either in full-time education or apprentices with low earnings.
The rates of the allowances are £o-go a week for families with two children
below the age limits and a further ^1 a week for each additional child.
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to benefit
the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid either to
the mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for title to the
allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
Family Income Supplement is designed to help families (and single people)
with small incomes where the wage-earner is in full-time work and there is at
least one dependent child. It is payable when the weekly sum of a family’s
resources falls below a prescribed amount, fixed at £20 a week where there is
one child plus £2 for each additional child. The weekly rate of the supplement
is half the difference between the family’s income and the prescribed amount
up to a maximum of £5. Some 70,000 households containing about 300,000
children and including about 23,000 single people with children are receiving
benefit under this scheme.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts 1946-64.)
The national insurance scheme provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. The benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation.
The original system was based on contributions varying only with the sex,
age (under or over 18 years), and insurance class (see p. 126), while benefits
were at standard rates for people over 18. Additional earnings-related contribu¬
tions and benefits were subsequently introduced in two stages (1961 and 1966).
In November 1970 pensions were introduced for elderly people who had
been over pension age when the scheme started, and in April 1971 for widows
aged between 40 and 50 when widowed or when entitlement to widowed
mother’s allowance ended. From September 1971 an old person’s pension
became payable to all other non-pensioners aged 80 and over; at the same time
an invalidity pension was introduced for anyone who had received sickness
126
Contributors
Contributions
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
benefit for six months, with an additional invalidity allowance for people
becoming chronically sick more than five years before retirement age. An
attendance allowance for severely disabled people needing attendance or
supervision both night and day became payable in December 1971. Over the
next two years an allowance at a lower rate will be extended to those needing
attention or supervision either night or day.
Under government proposals published in September 1971 and aimed to be
introduced in 1975 everyone would have two pensions—a basic pension from
the government and an earnings-related pension from his job.
Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three
classes:
Class 1. Employed people. Most of those who work for an employer under a
contract of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.
Class 2. Self-employed people. Those in business on their own account and
others who are working for gain but do not work under the control of an
employer—about million.
Class 3. Non-employed people. All those insured who are not in class 1 or
class 2—about a quarter of a million.
There is a general liability to pay flat-rate contributions according to this
classification but certain people are excepted. These include full-time students,
prisoners and most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. Self-
employed and non-employed persons whose income is below £469 a year can
apply for exception. Married women can choose to pay contributions and
receive benefit in their own right or not to pay flat-rate contributions (if they
are working they must pay graduated contributions) and rely upon their
husband’s insurance for maternity grant, retirement pension (at a lower rate),
widow’s benefit and death grant. If a married woman works for an employer
he must pay his full share of the flat-rate contributions even if she has chosen
not to pay flat-rate contributions.
Flat-rate contributions are credited to students up to the age of 18, and
to most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. People who are
excepted from liability to pay but are not entitled to credits may pay con¬
tributions at the non-employed rate if they wish to safeguard entitlement to
retirement pension and widow’s benefit.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 (for a man, 65 for a woman), or when he retires from regular
employment after reaching minimum pension age (65 for men, 60 for women),
whichever is the earlier. If he does any work as an employed person thereafter,
he must pay an industrial injuries contribution; the employer still has to pay
his full share of the flat-rate contribution.
Flat-rate contributions are normally paid by means of national insurance
stamps bought from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single
contribution card. All three classes pay flat-rate contributions (see Table 9).
The stamps for class 1 contributors also include the employer s redundancy
contribution (to help to provide for payments in certain circumstances to
employees whose work is terminated, see p. 374) and the selective employ¬
ment tax paid by employers (see p. 210); and for all contributors the national
health service contribution (which for convenience is paid with the national
insurance contribution although the two services are separate). It is the
employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1 contributions
are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their wages. The self-
SOCIAL WELFARE

employed and non-employed must stamp their own cards. Flat-rate contribu¬
tions are usually credited for weeks of unemployment, sickness or injury, or if
certain widow’s benefits are being paid.

In general graduated contributions are payable by employed people (in¬
cluding married women but not retirement pensioners) aged between 18 and
70 (65 for women) who earn more than ^9 a week. The range of graduated
contributions is given in Table 9. Employees whose job provides them with
an occupational pension of at least £3'48 a year for each year of service (^2-90
for women) may be ‘contracted out’ of part of the graduated pension scheme.
Contracted out employees pay graduated contributions at the rate of 0*5 per
cent of that part of their weekly pay lying between £9 and ^18 and 4-75
per cent on earnings between ,£18 and ^48 > their employers pay the same
amount. Employees who are not contracted out pay graduated contributions
at the rate of 4-75 per cent of the part of their weekly earnings between £9 and
^48. Their employers pay the same amount.
Graduated contributions provide a graduated addition to retirement pension
and meet the cost of earnings-related supplements to sickness and unemploy¬
ment benefit and to widow’s allowance. The contributions are collected
through the same machinery as is used to collect pay-as-you-earn (deduction
at source) income tax.
