The Roman
Catholic Church
Jewry
189
(with some 143,000 regular communicants in Northern Ireland); the Pres¬
byterian (or Calvinistic Methodist) Church of Wales, which arose from the
revivalist movement led in 1735 by Howell Harris and now numbers some
108,000; the Free Church of Scotland; the United Free Church of Scotland;
the Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland; the Reformed Presbyterian Church
of Scotland; the Reformed Presbyterian Church of Ireland; and the Non-
Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland.
Other Protestant denominations in Britain include: the Unitarian and Free
Christian Churches; the Churches of Christ (known also in the United States
of America as Disciples of Christ), which have been an organised community
in Britain since early in the nineteenth century; the British Province of the
Moravian Church, which is an international missionary church; and the Free
Church of England (or Reformed Episcopal Church), which was formed in
1844 as a direct result of the Oxford Movement. The Society of Friends
(Quakers)—with some 20,000 members in Britain—came into being in the
middle of the seventeenth century under the leadership of George Fox and
works for peace and the relief of suffering in many parts of the world.
The Salvation Army, founded in Britain in 1865, has since spread to 76
other countries. Within Britain it has some 175,000 active members operating
from more than 1,000 centres of worship and a total community strength of
about 350,000. Believing in a very practical expression of Christian concern, the
Salvation Army also has 191 centres providing help for some 10,000 people in
need.
Also there are a number of other religious organisations with churches or
assemblies in Britain, including the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day
Saints (the Mormon Church) with about 100,000 members, and the Christian
Scientists with some 304 branch churches and societies in the British Isles.
The Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales, which became tem¬
porarily extinct during the sixteenth century, was restored in 1850; the Scottish
hierarchy became extinct in the early seventeenth century and was restored in
1878. There are now 7 Roman Catholic provinces in Great Britain, each under
an archbishop, 20 episcopal dioceses, and nearly 4,500 parishes. In Northern
Ireland, there are 9 dioceses, some of which have territory partly in the Irish
Republic. It is estimated that there are some 5-3 million adherents (including
children) to the Roman Catholic faith in the whole of Britain.
The Roman Catholic Church attaches great importance to the education of
its children in their own faith, and requires that the children of marriages
between its own members and members of any other denomination should be
brought up as Roman Catholics. Many schools for Roman Catholic children
in Britain are staffed by members of the religious orders for men and women,
who also undertake other social work such as nursing, child care, and the con¬
duct of homes for old people.
Jews first settled in England at the time of the Norman conquest, but were
expelled at the end of the thirteenth century by an edict of Edward I. The
Anglo-Jewish community in Britain dates from 1656; consisting of some
410,000 people, including both Sephardi (originally from Spain and Portugal)
and Ashkenazi (from Germany and Eastern Europe), it has become one of the
largest groups of Jews in Europe. The community is divided into two schools
of thought—the Orthodox, to which about 90 per cent of practising Jews
belong; and the Reform, which originated in 1840 and was followed in 1901 by
the Liberal Jewish movement. The Chief Rabbi is the head of the largest group
190
Other Religious
Communities
Co-operation
among the
Churches
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
(Ashkenazi) within Orthodox Jewry; the Haham is the head of the Sephardi
group. Synagogues in Britain number about 350. There has been an increase
in the number of Jewish denominational schools, which are now attended by
about one in five Jewish children.
Immigrants to Britain from overseas Commonwealth and foreign countries
have established centres of worship, especially in London, for their own com¬
munities. Among the Christian communities represented are Orthodox,
Lutheran and Reformed Churches of various European countries and the
Armenian Church.
The principal non-Christian communities in Britain, apart from the Jews,
are the Muslims and the Buddhists. The Muslims are the more widely repre¬
sented, their number in Britain being estimated at several hundred thousand.
There are mosques or Islamic centres in London, Manchester, Liverpool,
Bradford, Cardiff and in many of the other larger cities in Britain. The
community’s headquarters are at the London Central Mosque and Islamic
Cultural Centre.
Buddhism has several thousand adherents in Britain. The Buddhist Society
has its headquarters in London, with a Shrine Room and a Buddhist library
claimed to be one of the finest in Europe; there are also Shrine Rooms in the
three Viharas in London, one of which is run by Thai monks and supported
by the Thai Government. In Scotland there is a Shrine Room at the Tibetan
Centre.
The British Council of Churches, composed of representatives or consultant
observers from all the main Christian churches in the British Isles, facilitates
common action among the churches and seeks to further Christian unity. It
works with the Conference of Missionary Societies of Great Britain and
Ireland.
The Free Church Federal Council (which has a concordat with the British
Council of Churches) comprises most of the Free Churches in England and
Wales and aims to promote unity and joint action among the Free Churches
and to provide a channel for communication with central and local govern¬
ment authorities.
The Anglican-Roman Catholic Permanent Joint Commission explores points
of possible unity between the two Churches.
The Anglican and the main Free Churches in the British Isles also partici¬
pate in the World Council of Churches (of which the British Council of
Churches is an associate national council), which links together some 252
churches in 80 countries for co-operation and the study of common problems.
The Council of Christians and Jews works for better understanding among
members of the two religions and deals with problems in the social field.
The New English Bible, a translation into modern English completed in
1970, is the result of co-operation among many of the Christian churches in
Britain.
The Sharing of Church Buildings Act 1969 enables agreements to be made
by two or more churches for the sharing of church buildings.
10 THE NATIONAL
ECONOMY
Two features of fundamental importance to Britain’s economy are the con¬
tribution of manufacturing industry to national output—accounting for
one-third of the total—and the associated significance of trade. Britain ranks
third in world trade (after the United States and the Federal Republic of
Germany) and accounts for over 7 per cent of the total. It takes 9 per cent of
the world’s exports of primary products, and provides n per cent of the
world’s exports of manufactured goods.
As a result of a high level of agricultural productivity, Britain provides
just over half the food it needs from its own soil (no other major industrial
country has such a small proportion of its working population engaged in
agriculture—about 2-5 per cent). The remaining agricultural supplies are
imported, Britain being among the world’s largest importers of such products
as wheat, meat, butter, fodder grains, fruit, tea, tobacco and wool. Other
imports include raw materials (such as metallic ores, crude oil and timber) and
semi-manufactures (for example chemicals and textile yarns).
The imports are paid for by exports of (mainly) manufactured goods and by
invisible exports—earnings on overseas investment, travel, civil aviation,
British-owned shipping, financial, banking, insurance and other services.
Britain is one of the world’s largest exporters of aircraft, motor vehicles,
electrical equipment, finished textiles and most types of machinery. The
country’s competitive ability strongly influences the economic growth rate and
the standard of living. The gross national product per head of population rose
in real terms by over 22 per cent between 1961 and 1971.
The significant contribution made to export earnings by invisibles is in
large measure a reflection of Britain’s position as a major financial centre.
Its banks, insurance underwriters and brokers and other financial institutions
provide financial services throughout the world. The City of London provides
perhaps the most comprehensive and advanced service for a capital market
in the world.
Earlier
Development
of the Economy
During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker and investor and supported a rapidly
increasing population at a rising standard of living. In the period from 1870 to
1890 British industry had a clear lead over that of other countries. Between
1890 and 1914, industrial competition from Europe and North America grew,
but its effects on Britain’s export industries, particularly cotton textiles and
coal, were offset by a number of factors including the rise in world trade and
the returns on Britain’s large overseas investments.
Following the first world war Britain’s older industries met increasing com¬
petition, for example, in coal and iron and steel from other European countries
and textiles from some eastern countries where labour was cheaper. The result
was heavy unemployment.
After 1932 levels of production and employment improved. The decade saw
a strong expansion in the vehicles, electrical, chemicals and aircraft industries,
192
Recovery
from the Second
World War
Later
Developments
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
while the construction of 3 million houses brought about a large growth in the
building and ancillary industries.
In spite of generous aid from the United States and Canada, the second
world war ran down British domestic capital by about £3,000 million, through
shipping losses, bomb damage, and arrears of industrial maintenance and
replacements. Some £1,000 million worth of overseas investments were sold,
nearly half in North America, and new external debts of £3,000 million were
accumulated. By 1944 exports had fallen to less than one-third of their 1938
volume.
After the second world war rationing and other war-time controls were
relaxed gradually as civil production expanded and trade recovered. The
abolition of quantitative restrictions on imports, other than from the dollar
area, was largely completed by 1955. Exchange controls on transactions
between the sterling area and the rest of the world were also for the most part
lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling on current account for all non¬
residents was introduced.
The period since 1945 has been one of rising production and living standards
and, until 1970, a low level of unemployment (generally 2-5 per cent or lower).
Economic growth, however, averaging nearly 3 per cent in the decade up to
1965 and over 2 per cent from then to 1971, has been rather slower and more
intermittent than in most other western Europe countries and there have been
certain persistent economic problems, especially repeated crises in the balance
of payments particularly during periods of relatively rapid economic growth.
In spite of the contribution from invisibles, there were in a number of years
substantial deficits on current account transactions with the rest of the world
and a low level of reserves meant there was little room for manoeuvre.
In the 1960s successive governments sought to deal with these difficulties
in a number of ways, restraining the growth in home demand and implement¬
ing policies designed to hold down rises in incomes and prices. During 1967,
however, the reserves fell to dangerously low levels and in November the
Government devalued sterling from $2-80 to $2-40 = £1. It then proceeded
to take a number of fiscal, monetary and administrative measures to bring about
a major reorientation of the economy.
Between 1967 and 1971 exports of goods and services increased in real terms
more than four times as fast as the gross domestic product. Visible trade,
which was in deficit throughout the 1960s, showed a surplus of £12 million
in 1970 rising to £299 million in 1971 when, on the balance of payments as a
whole, there was a record surplus on current transactions of over £1,000
million. By the end of May 1972 the reserves of gold and convertible currencies
stood at £2,740 million, the highest level recorded up to that time.
Inflationary trends, which gathered momentum in Britain as in most other
industrial countries during the 1950s and 1960s, became a cause of major
concern, although the pace of increase in wage rates moderated slightly towards
the end of 1971 and fiscal measures taken by the Government helped to lower
the rate of price increases (see p. I94)- While the underlying rate of unemploy¬
ment rose to a peak of about 4 per cent early in 1972, physical output remained
steady and there were marked gains in productivity.
As part of the realignment of the exchange parities of major currencies at
the Washington Conference in December i97I> which the main changes
were the devaluation of the United States dollar and the revaluation of the
Deutsche mark and the Japanese yen, the dollar-sterling parity was raised

ECONOMIC

Guidance of the
Economy
from $2.40 to $2.6057 = j£i, representing a sterling revaluation of 8-57 per
cent against the dollar (see p. 194).
The principles of the Government in managing the economy are to extend
and encourage opportunities for profitable enterprise and to promote industrial
and regional development. Its executive policies are carried out by the main
government departments with economic responsibilities on a national scale:
the Treasury with its responsibility for public and national finance; the Depart¬
ment of Trade and Industry which is responsible for government policy on
most aspects of industry and trade and for regional policy; the Department
of Employment; the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food; and the
Department of the Environment with its specific responsibilities for transport
and building and its general responsibility for all the relevant factors of en¬
vironment and amenity.
An important advisory body on general economic policy is the National
Economic Development Council, which brings together representatives of
government, management and trade unions under the chairmanship of the
Prime Minister. It has an independent but publicly financed secretariat and
has established a number of economic development committees dealing with
different industries and services and different aspects of industry. Other
bodies responsible for advice on specific aspects of policy include the National
Joint Advisory Council (on labour matters), the Monopolies Commission (on
action to prevent the abuse of monopoly power, see p. 251) and the Office of
Manpower Economics (which provides the secretariat for bodies advising on
certain wages and salaries in the public sector and undertakes research on pay
questions generally).
On matters of major public policy such as the broad economic strategy,
and problems such as inflation and industrial relations, the Government makes
known its purposes, and keeps in touch with developments throughout the
economy, by means of informal and continuous links with the chief industrial,
financial, labour and other interests.
Final responsibility for the broad lines of economic policy rests with the
Cabinet (see p. 45) which alone can take into account all the political, social
and economic considerations. There has for some time been a system of inter¬
departmental committees designed to help in co-ordinating departmental
policies in each of the main areas of government concern and to ensure that
final decisions command the agreement of the Cabinet as a whole. In 1970 a
Central Policy Review Staff, a small multi-disciplinary body, was established
within the Cabinet Office itself to work under the supervision of the Prime
Minister on the formulation and review of the Government’s general strategy.
The Government’s central economic purpose is to ensure that the economy
grows at a sustained and faster rate, bringing permanent improvement in the
level of employment and in living standards. In facing the problem of a
relatively high rate of unemployment it embarked, in July 1971, on a refla¬
tionary policy which was continued and extended in the 1972 budget. Follow¬
ing the earlier removal of hire purchase controls, consumer spending was given
further stimulation in the budget by reductions in the higher rates of purchase
tax and increases in personal income tax allowances and national insurance
pensions. Free depreciation (allowing the full expenditure on certain forms of
investment to be written off against profits in the first year for tax purposes)
was introduced in July 1971 for the development areas, and made available
I94
Effects of
Government
Policies
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
nationally in 1972. The Government took powers to provide financial assist¬
ance on a selective basis to promote regional and industrial development, and
new regional development grants for the assisted areas were introduced
(see p. 262).
Within the framework of planned public expenditure (an increase at an
annual rate of about 3 -2 per cent in real terms between 1971-72 and 1975-76—
see p. 201) certain capital spending programmes, including infrastructure
works in areas of high unemployment, were brought forward in 1971 to make
use, in the short term, of resources that were under-employed.
To reduce the rate of inflation, measures have been taken to slow down the
rate of rise in prices. A policy was initiated by the Confederation of British
Industry (see p. 383) and agreed to by many of its member firms and the
nationalised industries for a 15-month period ending in October 1972, to keep
price increases of goods within a limit of 5 per cent—or, after July 1972, 5 per
cent on average for each firm. Other measures having a direct effect on prices
included the cuts in indirect taxation, such as the halving of selective employ¬
ment tax in 1971 and reductions in purchase tax in the 1972 budget.
Although the Government has taken no powers to act directly on the level
of wage settlements it has sought to reduce the rate of increase in both public
and private sectors as the basis for greater price stability.
Monetary policy has been in general expansionary. Interest rates declined in
1971-72 following reductions in the bank rate in April and September 1971
(from 7 to 5 per cent) but rose towards the middle of 1972, and bank rate was
increased to 6 per cent in June. There was a strong growth of bank lending
and consumer credit, and an increase in the rate of growth of money supply
(by 7^ per cent in the second half of 1971, and I2|- per cent in the first half of
1972). New methods of credit control introduced by the Government in 1971,
including the abandonment of quantitative controls over bank lending and the
conventional liquidity ratios observed by the clearing banks (see p. 212),
involved a shift to more flexible controls placing greater reliance on interest
rates.
In spite of the continuing high level of the reserves, international short-term
capital movements in June 1972 brought sterling under pressure. The Govern¬
ment announced that as a temporary measure the £ sterling would be allowed
to float, and exchange control would be applied to transactions with the sterling
area (see p. 228).
By the middle of 1972 the achievements of the Government’s policies had
included: a reduction in the rate of price increases, some moderation in the
average level of wage settlements, and a rise in spending on consumer goods,
including cars, and on house purchase. In May the first fall for 18 months in
the number of wholly unemployed was recorded, bringing the level down
to 3-6 per cent of the labour force. There were strong indications of a general
improvement in business optimism and in the outlook for production and
employment. The underlying trend in the growth of output between the
first halves of 1971 and 1972, excluding temporary dislocating factors, indi¬
cated a rise to the 4 to 4^ per cent annual level to which the Government’s
policies for the period had been directed.
The balance of payments on current account was very strong throughout
1971 and remained broadly in balance in the early part of 1972, although there
was some falling away owing to special factors. In April 1972, with the support
of the record high level of gold and convertible currency reserves, Britain was
able to repay the last of its debt to the International Monetary Fund and, for
Longer-term
Policies
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY 195
the first time since 1964, had no short- and medium-term official debt out¬
standing.
The Government launched a major programme to strengthen the economy
in preparation for Britain’s entry into the European Communities with effect
from January 1973 (see p. 459), which will bring participation in a much larger
domestic market.
As a first step towards closer co-ordination in monetary matters Britain
began, in May 1972, to take part in the European Economic Community’s
scheme for narrowing exchange margins between the currencies of member
countries (see p. 233), although this participation was temporarily suspended
following the decision to allow the £ to float. The step was regarded as comple¬
mentary to the broader objectives of world monetary reform on which the
Government is engaged in international discussions. The Chancellor of the
Exchequer took the lead in 1971 in suggesting a development of the Special
Drawing Rights (SDR) system of the International Monetary Fund that would
make the SDR the unit in terms of which parities would be expressed, and the
main asset, in place of reserve currencies, in which countries would hold their
reserves. The Government has stated its willingness to envisage a gradual
rundown in the reserve role of sterling.
In 1971 the Government embarked on a reform of taxation (described by
the taxation authorities as the most comprehensive undertaken in the present
century) in order to increase its fairness and to reduce the economically
distorting effects of the present system. The reforms announced so far include
a unification of income tax and surtax into a more evenly graded system of
personal taxation, the introduction of a value added tax in place of purchase
tax and selective employment tax, and a new system of corporation tax (see
p. 208). The Government is also studying the possible replacement of estate
duty by an inheritance tax and (one of the most far-reaching of all the pro¬
posals) a tax credit system combining features of a negative income tax, to
supersede social security payments, with a new system of personal direct
taxation (see p. 206).
Policies are also being implemented to deal with the human and economic
problems arising from the under-employment of resources. With the expansion
of some sectors of industry (such as petrochemicals, electronics and man-made
fibres) and the contraction of others, including traditional industries such as
cotton textiles or certain types of heavy engineering (notably shipbuilding),
there is a need for workers to move to new types of employment and for
additional, expanding industries to move in to the regions of declining employ¬
ment opportunities. The Government’s measures to broaden the economic
base of these regions and to improve the infrastructure, described by the
Prime Minister as the most comprehensive and extensive programme of
regional regeneration ever undertaken in Britain, have involved heavy capital
spending and the introduction of regional development grants towards in¬
dustrial investment in plant, machinery and buildings (see p. 262).
Associated with regional policies, but of wider national significance also,
is the Training Opportunities Scheme (see p. 372). The Government regards
an adequate supply of trained manpower as essential to its strategy for achiev¬
ing sustained economic growth. It also seeks to provide easy access to training
in new skills as a means of giving people the chance to improve their economic
prospects and to achieve satisfaction in their working lives. The modernisation
of employment policies (see p. 370) and of the system of industrial relations
(see p. 382) is also regarded as essential to economic expansion.

A revision of the policy on monopolies and mergers is being undertaken

THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years.
In 1971 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled £48,200 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the 10 years since 1961 was
nearly 29 per cent.
About a third of total output can be attributed to manufacturing industry
and this proportion has remained more or less constant for a number of years.
The expanding industry groups are gas, electricity and water, communications
and services (financial, health and educational, professional and personal).
Agriculture, forestry and fishing account for a small and slowly declining
share, and mining for a small and more rapidly declining share. The relative
contributions of the distributive trades and transport are also declining. Table
10 summarises the contribution of each industry group to the gross domestic
product (at current prices).

The main trends since 1961 are a fall in the proportion of total available
resources devoted to personal consumption and to public authorities’ current
expenditure and a significant rise in the proportion devoted to exports.
Personal incomes before tax at current prices rose rapidly and fairly steadily
from some £22,890 million in 1961 to nearly £47,090 million in 1971—a
compound rate of about 7-5 per cent a year. The increase in consumer expen¬
diture at constant prices has, however, been very much lower—under 2-5 per
cent per annum. The difference is accounted for mainly by rising prices and
to a lesser extent by a higher incidence of direct taxation and increased personal
savings.
Income from employment in 1971 totalled £33,491 million and accounted
for 71*1 per cent of total personal income (compared with 717 per cent in
1961). The three other main sources of personal income were self-employment
(8-4 per cent), income from rent, dividends and interest (10-3 per cent), and
grants from public authorities (iO’2 per cent). The general pattern of income
distribution is thus dominated by the pattern for income from employment.
The effects of income from rent, dividends and interest, which tends to add to
the income of the already affluent, are relatively slight and to some extent
counterbalanced by the effect of grants from public authorities to those in need.
British direct taxation falls heavily on the rich and the combined effect of
taxation and transfer payments and benefits in kind is a redistribution of
income on more egalitarian lines. According to studies by the Central Statis¬
tical Office, the effect in 1970 was to raise the highest income among the poorest
fifth of households (that is, the income at the lowest quintile) from 34 to 54
per cent of the median income of all households. There are a number of
theoretical and practical limitations to these studies, but the broad result is
too marked to be in dispute.
The rise in the volume of consumers’ spending has been accompanied, in
Britain as in other advanced industrial countries, by changes in its pattern.
The proportions of expenditure devoted to food, and clothing and footwear
have been falling while the proportions spent on housing, fuel and light, and
cars and their running costs, have risen.

Current expenditure on goods and services by the central Government
(including the national insurance funds) and local authorities rose by 124 per
cent at current prices over the period 1961 to 1971 when it amounted to
about 21 per cent of the gross national product. The main cause of this increase
was the continuing growth of the social services, especially education. Defence
has recently accounted for a declining share of public expenditure on goods and
services—27 per cent in 1971 compared with 37 per cent in 1961 and a post¬
war peak of over 50 per cent in 1953.
In addition to their expenditure on goods and services, public authorities
transfer large sums to other sectors, mainly the personal sector, by way of
national insurance and other social security benefits, grants, and interest and
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
199
subsidies (see pp. 128 and 181). The Government also makes grants to local
authorities to finance about 50 per cent of their current expenditure.

Fixed capital formation represents nearly 21 per cent of the gross national
product at factor cost. The total value of fixed assets in Britain, valued at
constant replacement cost, is estimated to have increased by 46 per cent
between 1961 and 1971 when their current replacement value, net of deprecia¬
tion, was some £135,000 million, of which about two-thirds was accounted for
by buildings and one-third by plant and machinery, and vehicles.
Of total investment in 1971, 90-2 per cent was accounted for by domestic
fixed capital formation, 0-3 per cent by physical increase of stocks and work in
progress and 9-5 per cent by investment overseas. Table 13 shows gross

domestic fixed capital formation by sector and type of asset. By industry group
about 21-4 per cent of gross domestic fixed capital formation was in manu¬
facturing industry, and about 16-4 per cent in the social and other public
services. Within the manufacturing sector, the largest investments were in the
chemical and allied industries, the engineering industries and the food, drink
and tobacco industries. The most marked trends in recent years have been
the increases in investment in the chemicals and textile industries (reflecting
respectively the expansion of petrochemicals and the growth of synthetics),
and the gas supply industry (mainly provision for natural gas).
Saving has made a significant contribution to the rising levels of investment
in all the main sectors of the economy. The extent to which each sector
contributed on balance, by way of lending, to the capital formation of the other
sectors (and to net investment abroad) in 1961 and 1971, or drew on the saving
of the other sectors is shown by the sector’s net acquisition of financial assets
(see Table 14).
The personal sector’s net contribution to capital formation rose by two-
thirds between 1961 and 1971. Increasingly, the main financial assets which
it acquires are insurance policies, interests in pension funds and deposits with
building societies and banks. National Savings reached the record level of
nearly £9,220 million at the end of 1971, net savings during the year totalling
over £580 million (see p. 214). The purchase of new dwellings constitutes the
main type of net fixed capital formation undertaken by the personal sector.
The companies’ sector, though a large gross saver, is also a large investor;
in 1970 its gross fixed investment considerably exceeded its saving, but in 1971
the two were broadly in balance.

Within the public sector, the central Government’s policy of restraining
home demand in the late 1960s is reflected in a large increase of £2,680
million in its saving between 1967 and 1970 to £3,723 million, while the fall to
£2,841 million in the following year is a consequence of the expansionary
policy after July 1971.
The level of local authorities’ fixed investment is three to four times that
of their saving, their capital needs being otherwise met by short- and long¬
term borrowing from the Government, banks and elsewhere.
The big investment programmes of the public corporations have been run¬
ning at over twice the level of their saving and, as with the local authorities,
the bulk of their remaining capital is borrowed from the Government.

THE PUBLIC SECTOR
Public expenditure comprises the current and capital expenditures of central
Government and local authorities, together with the debt interest and capital
expenditure of the nationalised industries and other public corporations. In
1971 total expenditure for 1971-72 was estimated at £24,470 million, of which
62 per cent was by the central Government, 29 per cent by local authorities,
and 9 per cent on the capital expenditure of the public corporations.
The wide range of function and purpose of this expenditure and its distribu¬

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Between i960 and 1970 total public expenditure grew in real terms at about
twice the rate of the economy as a whole. The social services programmes now
take 41 per cent of the total, whereas in i960 they represented just over 35
per cent. On the other hand defence budget expenditure has declined from
17 per cent to 11 per cent.
Of the £24,470 million in 1971-72, £14,654 million represented direct
purchases of goods and services. Some 68 per cent of this expenditure was
for current purposes, for example, salaries and wages of the armed forces,
police, teachers, nurses and civil servants, and the running expenses of, foi
example, schools, prisons, the health service, and the armed forces. Capital
expenditure, on the hospitals and schools as well as on services such as housing
and roads, accounts for the remaining 32 per cent. Apart from the direct
purchases of goods and services public expenditure includes substantial trans¬
fers of money to individuals, companies and other institutions in the private
sector. The largest item of transfers is retirement pensions (£2,051 million
in 1971-72) but substantial amounts are paid also for supplementary benefits,
sickness benefit, family allowances, unemployment benefits and for a range of
subsidies, the largest being the agricultural subsidies to farmers, and grants
and loans. In total, transfer payments amounted to £7,204 million in 1971-72,
29 per cent of all public expenditure. These transfer payments, unlike public
authorities’ direct purchases of goods and services, do not represent a direct
demand on the nation’s product, but form part of the expenditure incurred
by the recipients; this transferred expenditure will be smaller than the amount
of the gross sums transferred, because of the tax incurred on the payments and
of any savings that take place. Thus, while the total of public expenditure is
the equivalent of half the gross national product, the public sector’s expendi¬
ture accounts for about one-third of the nation’s output.
Up to i960 discussion of public expenditure centred on the expenditure of the
central Government departments, including grants to local authorities, set
out in the annual Estimates which were presented to and approved by Parlia¬
ment for one year ahead. These Estimates did not (and do not) cover certain
major areas of public expenditure, such as the nationalised industries capital
expenditure, the bulk of the payments from the national insurance fund, and
local authorities’ expenditure financed from the local rates on property.
Following the recommendations of the Plowden Committee on the Control
of Public Expenditure in 1961, surveys were instituted of the whole range of
public expenditure, for the period five years ahead. The surveys take place
each year, rolling forward the period to be covered. They are carried out by
officials in the spending departments and the Treasury, under the direction
of the Public Expenditure Survey Committee.
The primary purpose of the survey is to present to ministers an up-to-date
assessment of the cost of their existing policies as a basis for decisions about
the total and the composition of public expenditure over the whole area over
which the Government has control or influence. The five-year period covered
by the surveys gives the Government the opportunity to plan ahead significant
changes without causing wasteful disruption in existing services.
The initial recosting normally takes place in the first half of the year, to be
followed by ministerial consideration of the survey report. Since 1969 the
public expenditure plans as settled by the Government have been published
towards the end of the year, forming the basis of an annual public expenditure
debate in the House of Commons.
Early in 1971 the Expenditure Committee of the House was created, replac-
FINANCE
203
Estimates
Treasury Control
The
Comptroller
and Auditor
General
ing the Estimates Committee, to consider public expenditure, and its reports
will provide further information on which the debates can draw. The Expendi¬
ture Committee has formed sub-committees, one to consider general Govern¬
ment financial control and the presentation of information about public
expenditure, and others considering public expenditure in particular areas:
defence and external relations; education and the arts; employment and social
services; trade and industry, and environment; and the Home Office. These
committees can question departmental ministers as well as their officials, and
can take evidence also from witnesses outside Government.
The Estimates are submitted by the departments concerned to the Treasury
in the December preceding the 1st April commencing the financial year to
which they relate. This ensures that they fit satisfactorily into the public
expenditure plans.
The Estimates are presented to Parliament shortly before the presentation
of the Budget (see p. 204) and are approved by Parliament, by means of an
annual Appropriation Act, in July (expenditure to this date from 1st April is
covered by a Vote on Account approved by Parliament before the beginning
of the financial year). The Estimates are debated by the House of Commons
during 29 days (known as Supply days) allocated for this purpose. The choice
of subject for debate on these days rests with the Opposition, and normally
general questions of policy relevant to the Estimates are discussed, although
members can discuss the detail of the Estimates if they wish.
Certain expenditures are not approved annually, but are covered by Acts
of Parliament allowing payments to continue from one year to another. These
include the financial provision for members of the royal family, and salaries
and pensions of judges. Further, Government lending and service of debt are
carried out on a continuing basis by Act of Parliament through the National
Loans Fund, a fund separate from the general fund, known as the Consolidated
Fund.
The Treasury’s control of expenditure is closely linked with Parliamentary
control through the requirement laid down by Act of Parliament in 1861, that
Treasury approval should be given for all expenditures in excess of Estimates,
or outside Estimates. The Treasury’s authority is required for any new item
of expenditure, for any increase in expenditure beyond that originally author¬
ised, for any change in policy which means an increase in expenditure, and
for extra-statutory payments. This requirement is, however, subject to any
delegated authority which may be given to departments to deal with particular
types of expenditure. Treasury control does not imply final sanction by the
Treasuiy—in the last resort the decision is taken by the Government as a
whole, and carried out subject to Parliamentary consent.
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, a permanent officer of
the Crown. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he controls
receipts and issues of public money to and from the Consolidated Fund and
the National Loans Fund, and as Auditor General he audits departmental
accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts and other
accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory function is to
ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example, that no payments
are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority, and that Treasury
sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition, however, he has
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees to examine
departmental expenditure for cost-effectiveness with a view to drawing their
attention to any cases of apparent waste or extravagance.
The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a select committee
called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up in 1861, for the
purpose of ensuring that expenditure was properly incurred in accordance
with the purpose for which it was voted and with any relevant Acts of Parlia¬
ment. The terms of reference of the committee are simply to examine the
accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by successive com¬
mittees which have investigated whether full value has been obtained for the
sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which the administra¬
tion appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee has therefore
become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and inefficiency. It
embodies the findings in reports which may be debated in the House of
Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury in consulta¬
tion with departments and put into effect, so far as they are accepted, according
to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is submitted to Parliament by
Treasury Minute and both documents are debated at the beginning of the
following session.
THE BUDGET The Budget (an old word which meant a bag containing papers or accounts)
is a set of proposals, made annually, normally in April, for financing Govern¬
ment expenditure. They are described by the Chancellor of the Exchequer in
the Budget speech, against the background of a statement of the Government’s
past and prospective revenue and expenditure, and the Chancellor s assess¬
ment of the position and prospects of the economy as a whole.
The Budget speech is followed by the moving of a set of Ways and Means
resolutions, in which the proposals are embodied. These resolutions, when
passed by the House, become the foundation of the Finance Bill, which expresses
the proposals in statutory form.
The Budget is principally an instrument of economic management, and the
annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion for a review of general
economic policy. The scale of Government expenditure and taxation has an
important influence on the general level of output and distribution of resources.
The Budget judgment is therefore concerned with the balance between the
total of goods and services which are likely to be available to the nation and
the total claims which are likely to be made on them. Taxation provides the
Government with a means of exerting a considerable influence on the overall
pressure of demand. Taxation measures can also have a broader influence on
the pattern of demand and the long-term performance of the economy.
The Budget deals with the means of financing expenditure and particularly
with changes in taxation and not primarily with expenditure itself. On occasions
changes affecting expenditure, such as increases in pensions and family
allowances, have been announced in the Budget speech as have financial and
monetary measures not related to the Finance Bill, such as changes in Bank
Rate and exchange control policies. Such measures, however, are not reflected
in the resolutions or the Finance Bill but are applied by whatever procedure
is appropriate to implement them—separate legislation, statutory instruments
or administrative action.
The scope of the Budget and that of the Finance Bill which follows it are
different although they are closely interrelated. The Budget is essentially
204
The Public
Accounts
Committee
FINANCE
205
concerned with the measures that give effect to the Chancellor’s decision to
increase or reduce to an appropriate extent the predicted level of demand on
economic resources by use of the instruments at the Chancellor’s disposal, and
especially by increasing or reducing the yield of central government taxes.
The tax changes made necessary by the Budget judgment are enacted in the
Finance Act. But the Finance Act also provides the annual opportunity for
non-Budgetary changes in the tax system and for certain other financial
matters, such as provisions relating to Government borrowing.
The bulk of the taxation proposals in the Budget are concerned with changes
in the rates or coverage of existing taxes, the introduction of new taxes or the
abolition of existing ones, and changes in the administrative machinery relating
to taxation. In two cases however—income tax (including surtax) and corpora¬
tion tax—annual Ways and Means resolutions followed by a Finance Bill clause
are necessary to maintain the taxes in existence at all, since they are in form
annual taxes. It is this which makes an annual Budget at or about the beginning
of each financial year a necessity.
New taxes and changes in certain existing taxes, like other changes in statute
laws, do not come into effect until the Finance Bill has received Royal Assent
(in the case of the annual Budget, normally at the end of July) or at some other
date laid down in the Bill. Some changes, however, come into effect earlier,
usually from Budget Day or from the start of the tax year, under the Provi¬
sional Collection of Taxes Act. This enables the Government to collect certain
taxes provisionally, income tax for example, either at the rates previously in
operation or at new rates following the passing of the appropriate Ways and
Means resolutions. Tax proposals are not limited to the annual Budget. They
may be made at other times in the year, to meet changes in economic circum¬
stances. To this end the Treasury may activate the ‘Regulator’, a power to
increase or reduce by up to 10 per cent the principal Customs and Excise
revenue duties and purchase tax. Alternatively the Government has separate
powers to alter purchase tax rates by Order.
The economic background to the Budget and the transactions of the central
Government and the public sector as a whole are presented in the Financial
Statement and Budget Report (see Bibliography, p. 477) which is laid before the
House of Commons by the Chancellor of the Exchequer when opening the
Budget. The report is in three parts: the economic context of the Budget;
the accounts of the public sector; and the accounts of the central Government,
for the past financial year and the one immediately ahead. The accounts are
designed to assist in assessing the impact of changes in revenue and, where
relevant, public expenditure on the economy.
The accounts of the public sector show the transactions of the central
Government, local authorities, nationalised industries and other public corpora¬
tions combined into a consolidated account covering the whole of the public
sector. The transactions within the public sector cancel out on consolidation
and the net balance on the consolidated account represents therefore the
borrowing required by the public sector from the private and overseas sectors.
The accounts of the central Government show transactions both on the
conventional cash basis of exchequer accounting and in accordance with the
framework of the national income accounts.
Central government borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the
public either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 214) or by
borrowing on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of
government securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinancing
206
Budget Changes
Sources of
Revenue
1972-73
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
maturing issues (conversion loans) or to raise new money (issues for cash).
The capital requirements of the nationalised industries are met by the central
Government while those of the local authorities are met partly by the central
Government through the Public Works Loan Board (see p. 74) partly
by borrowing direct from the public, although some nationalised industries
and local authorities have obtained statutory power enabling them to borrow,
with Treasury consent, in foreign currencies.
After allowing for the Budget changes in 1972, the central Government’s
borrowing requirement for 1972-73 is expected to be £2,933 million, compared
with £659 million in 1971-72, and that for the public sector as a whole £3,358
million compared with £1,336 million in 1971-72.
Table 16 shows total revenue from taxation and other sources anticipated
in 1971-72 and 1972-73 together with the effects of the Budget changes.
Far-reaching changes in the structure of personal and company taxation and
in taxes on expenditure were announced in the 1971 Budget. The changes
will constitute the most comprehensive reform of the British tax system in this
century. The present system of income tax and surtax will be replaced by a
single graduated personal tax. Company taxation will be reformed so as to
remove the discrimination against distributed profits. As from April 1973 b°th
selective employment tax (SET) and purchase tax will be abolished and a
value-added tax (VAT) will become operative. Unlike purchase tax, which is
collected at a single stage, VAT is collected in instalments with liability to
tax arising on the ‘value added’ at each stage in the production and distribution
process. VAT, like purchase tax, falls on imports. VAT is not charged on
exports and unlike purchase tax it enables tax entering indirectly into export
costs to be rebated. Further information about these changes was given in the
1972 Budget, notably the choice of an imputation basis for corporation tax and
of a single basic rate, provisionally set at 10 per cent, for VAT. Also announced
were the new and longer-term proposals for a tax credit system to improve and
simplify the PAYE system of taxation and the system of social security.
The over-riding aim of the 1972 Budget was to sustain a higher rate of
economic growth in Britain. Tax reductions were made amounting to £1,200
million in the financial year 1972-73. These measures, together with a new
combination of national and regional investment incentives, were designed to
raise the rate of economic growth to 5 per cent (second half 1971 to first half
1973 annual rate). .
Full details of Budget proposals are published each year in the Financial
Statement and Budget Report.
The three principal sources of tax revenue are first, taxes on income, which
include income tax, surtax and corporation tax; second, taxes on capital,
which include estate duty and capital gains tax; and third, taxes on expendituie
(including taxes on the ownership or use of certain assets) these include not
only customs and excise duties and the purchase tax, but also the selective em¬
ployment tax, local rates, stamp duties and licence duties (for example, on
motor vehicles). Taxes on individual (but not corporate) incomes are progres¬
sive taxes in that larger incomes and estates bear a proportionately higher rate
of tax. The Board of Inland Revenue collects the taxes on income and capital
and the stamp duties; the Board of Customs and Excise collects the most im¬
portant taxes on expenditure, the customs and excise taxes and the purchase
tax, while a variety of authorities is responsible for the collection of the
Income Tax

1971- 72 and
1972- 73

remainder, including the Department of Health and Social Security for the
selective employment tax.
Income tax is imposed at a standard rate for the year of assessment beginning
on 6th April, which is at present 3875 per cent. The effective rate on earned
income, after taking two-ninths earned income relief into account, is approxi¬
mately 30 per cent. The tax imposed on an individual is graduated by means
of personal allowances and reliefs, and by the surtax. Married couples receive

BRITAIN 1973* AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
higher allowances than a single person. Husband and wife may choose to have
the wife’s earnings charged separately for tax on condition that the former
receives the single personal allowance instead of the married allowance.
A single person earning £1,500 a year pays £273 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays £219; if he has two children
under the age of 11, his tax falls to £115; when the children are between the
ages of n and 16, the tax is £96; if the children are over 16 and receiving full¬
time education, £76. The range of tax (including surtax where applicable)
payable by a single person varies from, for example, £123 on an earned income
of £1,000 a year to £3,859 on an earned income of £10,000; if the income is
entirely from investment, tax liability on £1,000 will be £209 and £2,271 on
£5,00°.
Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay as
You Earn’) system whereby tax is deducted (and accounted for to the Inland
Revenue) by the employer, thus enabling them to keep as up to date as possible
with their tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons resident in the
United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that interest on certain United
Kingdom government securities belonging to persons not ordinarily resident
in the United Kingdom is exempt; and income from certain classes of posses¬
sions abroad is chargeable not on the amount of income arising but on the
amount of income remitted to the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom has
entered into agreements with many countries providing for relief from double
taxation; where such agreements are not in force unilateral relief is allowed.
The surtax, which is essentially an income tax at higher rates, is charged on
personal incomes exceeding £3,000 a year after deducting certain personal
allowances in excess of the single person’s basic allowance. In addition, the
same earned income relief as for income tax and a special earnings allowance
(not exceeding £2,000) are deductible from earned income only. Surtax is
imposed at rates which increase progressively until, on the portion of taxable
income above £15,000, the combined rate of income tax and surtax payable
in 1972-73 (being income tax for 1972-73 and surtax for 1971-72) reaches
88-75 per cent.
Companies are liable to corporation tax on both their profits and their capital
gains. In addition, a company deducts income tax from dividends and other
distributions and pays it over to the Inland Revenue as a separate matter from
its own liability.1 The rate of corporation tax is fixed retrospectively in the
Budget for the past financial year; for 1971 it is 40 per cent. The tax is assessed
on the profits of accounting periods, the rate of tax being the rate for the
financial year in which the accounting period falls. The basic rule for the
calculation of income for corporation tax purposes is that, except for special
provisions, it is computed in accordance with income tax principles.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of all property which passes at death.
The charge to duty is not limited to property owned by the deceased but may
1 From April 1973, a company will pay corporation tax at a single rate on all its profits,
whether distributed or not. Income tax will no longer be deducted from dividends but a
company which distributes profits to its shareholders will be required to make to the
Inland Revenue an advance payment of corporation tax. In general, that advance pay¬
ment will be set against a company’s corporation tax bill and the recipient ot the
distribution in respect of which the advance payment was made will be entitled to a tax
credit.
FINANCE
209
extend to other property, for example, to trust funds from which the deceased
received income in his lifetime and to gifts made by the deceased within seven
years of his death (one year in the case of a gift for public or charitable pur¬
poses). Since the 1972 Budget estates not over £15,000 are exempt from duty.
On estates of a higher value duty is chargeable by reference to rates ranging
from 25 per cent to 75 per cent, applied to successive slices of the estate. In
addition, property going to a surviving spouse up to a sum of £15,000 is left out
of account for estate duty purposes, so that where a man leaves his whole
estate to his widow no duty is payable at all unless the estate exceeds £30,000.
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the case of companies, to corporation tax. The rate of tax for persons other
than companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less,
depending on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax including
the principal private residence, chattels worth less than £1,000 (and any
chattels, except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of
less than 50 years), private motor cars, and National Savings Certificates. The
1971 Finance Act also exempted an individual from capital gains tax where the
total proceeds of disposals do not exceed £500 in any year. All gains are now
subject to long-term capital gains tax whatever the length of period of ownership
except for gains on gilt-edged securities which continue to be exempt from
capital gains tax if held for more than 12 months.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely, the duties on tobacco, hydrocarbon
oil, alcoholic drinks, purchase tax, protective duties, betting and certain
miscellaneous items.1 In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or pro¬
duced in Britain (excise duties). These taxes are sometimes known as indirect
taxes since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or whole¬
saler, who adjusts the prices charged to customers accordingly. In 1972 the tax
burden was equivalent to about £0-22^ on a gallon of petrol, £0-24 on a packet
of 20 standard plain cigarettes, £2-20 on a bottle of whisky, and £o-o\% on a
pint of beer of average strength.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by Order by up to 10
per cent the rates of purchase tax and any of the other main groups of customs
and excise duties (that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil and the minor revenue
duties). This power, known as the ‘regulator’, requires annual renewal.
Purchase tax is charged on a wide range of goods, nearly all of them consumer
goods, at three rates, which are currently 11^ per cent, 18 per cent and 25 per
cent of the wholesale value. Articles subject to revenue duties of customs and
excise are in general exempt from this tax; other goods free of purchase tax
include food (other than confectionery, soft drinks, ice cream and crisps), fuel,
books and newspapers, young children’s clothing and footwear, certain non¬
proprietary drugs and medicines, and some household appliances. Purchase
tax is to be abolished after April 1973 (see p. 206).
The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 33^ per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged at the
rate of 6 per cent of stake money except for on-course betting which is charged
at 5 per cent. Gaming is taxed at different rates mainly by licence fees.
1 The duties other than purchase tax and protective duties are known as revenue duties

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected by the local taxation authorities (the
county or county borough councils in England and Wales and the correspond¬
ing councils in Scotland); the proceeds are paid by the local authorities into
the Consolidated Fund. The licence duty on a private motor car is £25 a year;
motor cycles and three-wheel vehicles, etc., pay £2-50, £5 or £10 a year
according to engine capacity.
The selective employment tax was introduced in the 1966 Finance Act. Its
rates were halved in the 1971 Budget when it was also announced that the tax
would be abolished as from April 1973 (see p. 206). Following the 1971
Budget reduction, which took effect on 5th July 1971, it is paid by all em¬
ployers throughout Britain at a rate per week of £1*20 for men, j£o-6o for
women and boys and £0-40 for girls. The tax is refunded to eligible employers
in manufacturing industries, most of transport and communications, agri¬
culture and the extractive industries. Most activities of the nationalised
industries and local authorities also receive repayment of the tax. Employers in
construction, distribution, insurance, banking and miscellaneous services pay
the tax without refund, except that two-thirds of the tax is refunded for all
employees aged 65 and over for part-time staff working fewer than 21 hours a
week.
The National Debt increased rapidly during and immediately after the first and
second world wars. It rose from £650 million in 1914 to £7,435 million at the
end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in 1939 to £23,637 million
in 1946. On 31st March 1972 the total National Debt (provisional) was £35,854
million, of which £1,883 million was repayable in currencies other than
sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian Governments. Of the
£33,971 million of internal debt, £4,089 million was short-term debt, mainly
in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long-term loans included a
variety of stocks, bonds, loans and certificates carrying fixed rates of interest
(ranging from 2^ to 9 per cent) and with fixed or indeterminate dates of re¬
payment.
The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole, under
which public revenues, with a few minor exceptions, are paid into the Ex¬
chequer Account, from which no money can be withdrawn except on the
authority of Parliament. That authority is expressed in the case of Consolidated
Fund charges in permanent legislative form, and in the case of Supply Services
by annual Appropriation Acts1 based on estimates prepared by departments
and sanctioned by the Ministry of Finance.
The major sources of revenue flowing into the Northern Ireland Exchequer
are the main national taxes imposed by the United Kingdom Parliament over
the whole country and paid, in the first instance, into the United Kingdom
Consolidated Fund. These taxes, which are referred to in the Government of
Ireland Act 1920 as reserved taxes, comprise the Inland Revenue group
(income tax, surtax, corporation tax and capital gains tax) and customs and
excise duties on goods. After the cost of collecting these taxes in Northern
Ireland (and the cost of some other reserved services) and an Imperial Contri¬
bution have been retained in the United Kingdom Consolidated Fund, the
balance, termed the ‘Residuary Share of Reserved Taxes’, is paid to the
Northern Ireland Exchequer where it joins up with the transferred taxes
1 Under the Northern Ireland (Temporary Provisions) Act, Orders in Council take the
place of Appropriation and Consolidated Fund Acts.
FINANCE
211
(that is, where taxation powers have been transferred to the Northern Ireland
Parliament) to form the public income. Among items of Transferred Tax
Revenue are estate duties, stamp duties, betting duties, various excise licence
duties, motor vehicle duties and selective employment tax.
A Joint Exchequer Board, representative of the Treasury and the Ministry
of Finance for Northern Ireland, was constituted in accordance with the
Government of Ireland Act 1920, to determine the amount of Reserved
Revenue and the cost of Reserved Services attributable to Northern Ireland
for each year, the amount of the Imperial Contribution, and such other ques¬
tions affecting the financial relations of the two Governments as may be
referred to it.
In the Northern Ireland Financial Statement for 1972-73 (year ending 31st
March), total revenues were forecast at £442 million and expenditure at £441
million. After allowing for the Imperial Contribution, provisionally estimated
at £500,000 there was a Budget surplus of £21,200 on the assumption that
some £26-2 million of capital expenditure shown in the Estimates will be met
from available balances or be charged to borrowing.
The Public Debt of Northern Ireland, totalling £452 million on 31st March
1972 is covered by repayable advances and investments held by the Ministry
of Finance.
Outside the Exchequer system in Northern Ireland, various funds have been
established, in addition to statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific
purposes. In general, these funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the
principal funds being those relating to National Insurance and government
loans. The latter constitutes a pool of capital money available mainly for local
and public authority borrowings; on 31st March 1972 a sum of approximately
£319 million was outstanding against such borrowers.
THE CENTRAL BANK
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It comprises
a central bank; commercial banks which carry on the usual main banking
services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business is in other
countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England was established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and
Royal Charter as a corporate body; the entire capital stock was acquired by
the Government under the Bank of England Act 1946. As the central bank,
the Bank acts as banker to the Government, to overseas central banks and to
commercial banks; it is the note-issuing authority and the registrar for some
200 government, nationalised industry, local authority, public board and
Commonwealth government stocks. As agent for the Government the Bank
administers exchange control. On behalf of the Treasury it manages the
Exchange Equalisation Account (EEA), which holds Britain’s official reserves
of gold and foreign exchange; using the resources of the EEA the Bank designs
its interventions in the foreign exchange market both to prevent undue
fluctuations in the exchange value of sterling and to conserve the means of
making payments abroad.
As banker to the Government the Bank examines and seeks to anticipate
banking and financial problems and to undertake the appropriate operations
in the money, capital and the foreign exchange markets; consequently the Bank
has a major responsibility for advising the Government on the formulation of
monetary policy and for its subsequent execution (see p. 212).
In implementing monetary policy the Bank is ready to act daily in the money
212
The Deposit
Banks
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
market, by buying or selling Treasury bills, and similarly in the market for
government stocks. A prime concern is to maintain orderly conditions and,
when necessary, the Bank also exerts influence on interest rates; an important
instrument in this context is Bank Rate, which is the minimum rate at which
the Bank will discount approved bills of exchange for the members of the
London Discount Market or will normally lend to them; a wide range of other
short-term interest rates is related to it.
The Bank is the recognised channel of communication between the commer¬
cial banks and other financial institutions of the City of London on the one
hand, and the Government on the other.
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and Wales of issuing
bank notes. The note issue is fiduciary, that is to say, it is no longer backed by
gold but by government securities and other assets. The Scottish and Northern
Ireland banks have limited rights to issue notes; these issues, apart from an
amount specified by legislation for each bank, must be fully covered by Bank
of England notes and by coin. The provision of coin for circulation is the
responsibility of the Royal Mint, a government department.
Following discussions by the Bank of England with the banks, the hire pur¬
chase finance houses and the discount houses, new arrangements for the
control of credit came into effect from September 1971. While it is still neces¬
sary for the Government, as an indispensable part of economic management, to
regulate the development of credit and the money supply, the new system has
replaced rigid quantitative controls over lending in sterling with policies for
influencing bank and finance house lending which combine effective control
with greater flexibility and freedom for these institutions. The techniques now
in operation involve more reliance upon changes in interest rates. The ceiling
controls on lending by the banks and finance houses have been removed and
the London and Scottish clearing banks have abandoned their collective
agreements on interest rates. Greater scope for competition and innovation
by these institutions has thereby been introduced into the domestic economy.
THE PRIVATE SECTOR
The primary business of the deposit banks is the receipt, transfer and encash¬
ment of deposits. The principal deposit banks are the six London clearing
banks, three Scottish banks and two Northern Ireland banks. Mergers have
resulted in the formation of six banking groups, four based in London and two
in Scotland. The two Northern Ireland banks are owned by London clearing
banks, but two groups of banks based in the Republic of Ireland also operate
in Northern Ireland. _
At the end of 1971 current and deposit accounts with deposit banks operat¬
ing in Britain totalled £14,547 million, and accounted for nearly 40 per cent
of the total deposits (in sterling and foreign currencies) of the banking sector,
which also includes the National Giro, the accepting houses, overseas banks,
other banks and the discount market. The deposit banks provide full banking
services throughout Britain, and operate through over 14,000 branches.
Several of them have interests in British overseas and Commonwealth banks,
and in other banks which have been formed specially to compete in inter¬
national markets. They have also acquired substantial interests in hire-purchase
finance houses, and some have set up their own unit trusts.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up the
membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1971 cheques, drafts,
FINANCE
2I3
bills and bankers’ effects passing through the interbank debit clearing system
averaged in value £70,363 million monthly, while the average monthly value
of the credit transfer clearing was £1,552 million.
Current account balances with the deposit banks are repayable on demand
and no interest is paid on them, but on deposit account balances interest is paid
at a rate generally 2 per cent below individual banks’ base rates. The deposit
banks’ more liquid assets consist of: cash, balances at the Bank of England,
money at call (mainly loans to discount houses), and their holdings of Treasury
and commercial bills; the banks also hold a proportion of their assets as port¬
folio (mainly British Government securities) or trade investments.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or without
collateral security). The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total
deposits in 1971 averaged 53 per cent.
The bank giro, originally introduced as the credit transfer scheme, and the
direct debiting system, by which a creditor with the prior approval of the
debtor may claim money due to him direct from the latter’s banking account,
have helped to improve the money transmission services. Another banking
innovation has been the introduction by some banks of automatic cash dis¬
pensing machines. Credit cards have become popular for the settlement of
accounts in retail shops; and cheque cards enable the card holder to cash a
cheque up to £30 at any office of the major British and Irish banks.
The Post Office National Giro which was opened in October 1968 to provide
a low-cost current account banking and money transfer service, is operated
through most post offices in Britain. All accounts and transactions are main¬
tained by means of a computer complex at the National Giro Centre at Bootle,
near Liverpool. Giro now has more than 450,000 accounts with total balances
in excess of £55 million. The level of weekly transactions had risen from 500,000
in September 1969 to 1-35 million by September 1971. Following a review of
its operations in 1971 the service will be reshaped so that it can profitably offer
a competitive service to the public, to commerce, to local authorities and
government. All gas and electricity boards operate Giro accounts as do all major
local authorities. More than 500 firms are using the Giro’s cash collection
service making more than 25,000 deposits a day. Seven of the ten largest
companies in Britain now hold Giro accounts.
There are also some 37 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of
which have their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive
banking service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing of
trade not only between Britain and other countries but also between third
countries. There are also currently in London about 37 United States banks,
50 European banks, 13 Japanese banks and over 30 other foreign banks.
The merchant banks have an influence on Britain’s financial affairs which is
much greater than their size in relation to other financial institutions might
suggest. Traditionally merchant banks have been primarily concerned with
acceptance credits1 and with the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf of their
1 Acceptance credits have been defined as fundamentally three-month operations
financing exports from and imports to Britain and to other markets. The expression is
derived from the method of financing trade by which commercial bills are ‘accepted’ or
guaranteed by a merchant bank against documents, after which they may be discounted
for cash by a discount house.
The Discount
Market
The National
Savings
Movement
National Savings
Securities
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
customers. Today they have a widely diversified and complex range of activi¬
ties with an important role in: international finance and the short-term capital
markets; the provision of expert advice and financial services to British
industrial companies especially where mergers, takeovers and other forms of
corporate reorganisation are involved; and the management of investment
holdings, including trusts, pensions and other funds.
The Money or Discount Market is an institution which is unique to the City of
London. Its function in the monetary system is to provide a financial mecha¬
nism designed to promote an orderly flow of short term funds. The market
consists of 11 discount houses which borrow money ‘at call’ or short notice and
lend for somewhat longer periods. They have recourse to the Bank of England
as lender of last resort and normally the Bank lends to the houses at Bank Rate
for seven days, although it may charge a higher rate and has also at times lent
overnight, or for short periods, at the rates of interest prevailing in the market.
Most of the market’s borrowed funds come from the commercial banks, which
are thus provided with a flexible means of earning a yield on surplus funds
which they have at any given time.
The assets of the discount houses mainly consist of Treasury and commercial
bills, government and local authority securities and negotiable certificates of
deposit denominated in both sterling and US dollars. The market accepts as an
informal responsibility that it should cover the Government’s need to borrow
on Treasury bills which are offered on tender each week.
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread invest¬
ment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the National Savings Bank
(see p. 215) and in National Savings securities. The movement is led by the
National Savings Committee for England and Wales and similar committees
for Scotland and Northern Ireland. The committees are comprised of represen¬
tatives of the voluntary savings movement in the Regions and of various
national institutions connected with finance, industry and education. They
have a staff of civil servants. Voluntary local savings committees, often sup¬
ported by local authorities, co-ordinate the work of voluntary local savings
groups.
The administration of the National Savings Bank and other forms of national
savings is carried out by the Department for National Savings. Five forms
of National Savings securities are currently on sale: National Savings Certifi¬
cates, British Savings Bonds, Premium Savings Bonds, National Savings
Stamps and Gift Tokens. National Savings Certificates, in units of £1, are
encashable at par at any time; interest, which is free of income tax, surtax
and capital gains tax is paid only on encashment; the limit on individual
holdings is 1,000 units of the current ‘decimal issue’ introduced in October
1970. Seven per cent British Savings Bonds (Second Issue), sold in units of
are repayable at par on one month’s notice. If the bonds are held to maturity (five
years from the date of purchase) they are repaid with a bonus of £3 per cent
tax free. Maximum holding of the current issue introduced in May 1971
£10,000. Premium Savings Bonds are in units of £1 (minimum purchase £2)
and individual holdings are limited to £2,000. After a qualifying period of three
months the bonds give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes instead of
receiving interest. There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25 )000 and a
