A contractual savings scheme, known as ‘Save as You Earn’ (SAYE), enables
savings to be made in regular monthly amounts within a minimum of £1 and a
maximum of £20 in deposits with the Department for National Savings or
Trustee Savings Banks by means of deductions from pay or by other regular
payments. At the end of five years, savings will qualify for a bonus equivalent
to one year’s savings free of tax. Completed savings which are not withdrawn
will qualify for a double bonus at the end of seven years, that is, two years’
savings. For example, contributions totalling £60 payable over five years at a
rate of £1 per month will qualify for a bonus of £12 at the end of that period,
or £24 if left on deposit for a further two years. Savers who wish to stop pay¬
ments will be able to withdraw the total sum saved (but there cannot be partial
withdrawals). Tax-free compound interest will be paid at the rate of 2^ per cent
per annum on amounts withdrawn after the first but before the end of the
fifth year, or at 4^ per cent where the contributions cease but the savings are
left invested for the remainder of the five years or where the saver dies before
the contributions are completed. A separate ‘Save as You Earn’ scheme (with
the same maximum limit) is operated by the building societies.
The National Savings Bank provides a countrywide system for depositing and
withdrawing small savings and has over 22 million active accounts. Ordinary
Accounts bear interest at 3^ per cent and the first £21 of interest is tax free. Up
to £20 can be withdrawn on demand at any savings bank post office, but a few
days’ notice is required for larger amounts. The moneys are lodged with the
National Debt Commissioners and are invested in government securities.
Deposits up to a limit of £10,000 bearing a higher rate of interest (at present 7^
per cent) may be made in Investment Accounts where investors have a quali¬
fying deposit of £50 in an Ordinary Account. All deposits carry a government

The Trustee Savings Banks, most of which were founded in the nineteenth
century, operate under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provi¬
sions and National Debt Office surveillance. There are 73 individual banks with
over 1,500 Trustee Offices and 12 million active accounts. Deposits can be
made either in the Ordinary Department, the Special Investment Departments
or the Current Account Department. Savings in the Ordinary Department earn
interest at 3^ per cent and the first £21 of interest is tax free. Withdrawals can
usually be made on demand though notice is required for large sums. Deposits
are invested with the National Debt Commissioners and both capital and
interest are guaranteed by the Government. The Special Investment Depart¬
ments offer a higher rate of return, which is taxable. Deposits are limited to
£10,000, but are not government guaranteed. At the end of May 1972 total
sums in the Ordinary Departments of the Trustee Savings Banks were £1,237
million and in the Special Investment Departments £1,756 million. Most
Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque services on deposits in the Current
Account Departments. In January 1968 the Trustee Savings Banks set up their
own unit trust (see p. 218).
At the end of July 1972 National Savings totalled £9,841 million. The
diagram on p. 215 shows the distribution of National Savings between the
different outlets in 1958 and 1971.
It has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of many
special financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities, which
are supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are mainly
provided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-purchase
finance companies, the stock exchanges, investment trusts, building societies
and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activities are in the main
highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance houses, stock¬
brokers, insurers, insurance underwriters and brokers.
Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited (FCI) and
the Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited (ICFC), were
set up in 1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction
and development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited (CDFC), was established in 1953 to assist development projects in
the Commonwealth.
The FCI was formed in the national interest to assist in the provision of capital
(in amounts of £200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development
of industry.
The FCI has an authorised and issued capital of £25 million and may
borrow up to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of
£125 million. The share capital is held by insurance companies, by invest¬
ment trust companies and by the Bank of England. At 3 Ist March 1972
capital called and paid up was 10 per cent (£2-5 million); the Bank of England
paid £5 million in advance of call in 1958. The liability of the shareholders
in respect of the uncalled capital represents security to the banks providing
loans for the corporation’s working capital. The value of its loans and invest¬
ments at 31st March 1972 was £85 million.
FINANCE
217
Industrial and
Commercial Finance
Corporation
Limited
Commonwealth
Development
Finance Company
Limited
The Stock
Exchanges
The main function of the ICFC is to provide capital, financial advice, and
computer bureau and other services to small- and medium-sized companies in
the British Isles. It has a number of subsidiaries, including Technical Develop¬
ment Capital Ltd. established in 1962 to provide venture capital for the com¬
mercial development of technological innovation. The shareholders of ICFC
are the Bank of England, the English Clearing and the Scottish Banks. At 31st
March 1972 the ICFC had more than £170 million invested in 2,250 British
companies.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company is no longer confined to
the Commonwealth in its activities. It supports business enterprise overseas
by providing finance in the form of share capital and loans on mutually
acceptable terms. Its authorised share capital is £30 million, of which about
14^ million ‘A’ ordinary shares of ^1 (^o-io paid) are held by industrial,
shipping, mining and banking interests in the United Kingdom, and nf
million ‘B’ ordinary shares of ^1 (^0-50 paid) are held by the Bank of England
and certain central banks in the Commonwealth. At 31st March 1972 the
CDFC held investments worth -£30 million spread over a wide range of
industries placed in more than 35 countries.
There are seven stock exchanges in the British Isles. In addition the Provincial
Brokers’ Stock Exchange operates in many cities and towns throughout Britain
and the Irish Republic. The Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great Britain
and Ireland, comprising with one exception all these organisations, was set up
in July 1965 to co-ordinate their work. Proposals have been put forward for
the unification of the United Kingdom exchanges and the Irish Exchange, and
it is hoped that amalgamation will be complete by March 1973. The new body
will be known as The Stock Exchange.
The number and variety of securities officially listed on the London Stock
Exchange is greater than in any other market and its turnover of company
securities is roughly equivalent to that of all the European Bourses combined.
Some 9,000 securities are quoted on the London Stock Exchange; at the end
of March 1972 these had a total market value of £149,531 million. About 7,580
securities of companies are quoted, including a number of leading overseas
companies. Company issues represented more than four-fifths of the securities
at market valuation, the remainder being United Kingdom and overseas
government and corporation stocks.
The London Stock Exchange is linked by cable or telephone with stock
exchanges all over the world. A quoted company has a world-wide market for
its issues subject to any limitations imposed by the exchange control regula¬
tions. This is an important factor in the raising of new capital by government
and commercial borrowers.
The stock exchanges do not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand for
the securities concerned. All the stock exchanges operate under strict rules of
conduct which they formulate themselves.
There has been substantial growth in demand in the post-war period for
ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares will maintain
or increase their real value in periods of rising prices. There is a growing level
of institutional investment on the London market by insurance companies,
pension funds, and by investment and unit trusts. The percentage of total
market holdings of United Kingdom quoted ordinary shares held by these
four groups of institutions together rose from 25 per cent to 31 per cent over
the six-year period March 1964-70.

Investment
Trusts and
Unit Trusts
The Insurance
Market
Insurance
Companies
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
It is estimated that in 1966 about 2^ million individuals in Great Britain
owned shares and that direct private clients now account for 45 per cent of the
number of total bargains made on the Stock Exchange.
Investment trusts and unit trusts enable investors to spread their risks and
obtain the benefit of skilled management.
The ordinary type of investment trust is constituted as a public company
registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business is
to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies,
it may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits
to build up reserves. Investment trusts grew to importance in the latter half
of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital towards
overseas investment.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the securities. Normally, the managers
sell units to the public and invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of Stock
Exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly by an
initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit and partly by a semi¬
annual service charge which is usually taken out of the income of the trust.
The level of both charges is controlled by the Department of Trade and
Industry, whose authorisation is required before units can be offered to the
public; this is only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at £80 million. This medium of saving has
grown considerably since 1957- A* the end of April 1972 there were 2-29
million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts rose
from £60 million in 1958 to ,£2,419 million at the end of April 1972; it has
nearly trebled since the end of 1967' There is now a wide variety of trusts,
both as to the range of investments covered and the ways in which they cater
for the differing needs of investors.
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of mutual or
joint stock companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
There are about 590 insurance companies incorporated in the United Kingdom.
This figure includes companies which became subject to the provisions of the
Insurance Companies Acts 1958-67 as a consequence of the extension of
those Acts to all classes of insurance business. Most British insurers write
several classes of business although some specialise in one class, particularly in
life assurance, where about 125 companies write only that type of business. A
few specialise in re-insurance.
In addition about 160 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, thus emphasising the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British com¬
panies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.
In 1969 the total assets of the British insurance companies amounted to
about £16,750 million, the bulk of which is life assurance business.
There is no government control over the investment policy of insurance
funds at home and these represent one of the most important sources of funds
for investment in commerce and industry. About one-half of the total assets
of British insurance companies is now invested in equity shares and deben¬
tures.
FINANCE
219
Lloyd's
Insurance Brokers
International
Insurance Services
Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of private insurers in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting business
and intelligence of shipping movements. Although in its earlier history the
activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine insurance business,
there has also been built up at Lloyd’s a very considerable world-wide market
for the transaction of other classes of insurance business in its non-marine,
aviation and motor markets.
Lloyd’s is regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting in 1871;
the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are administered
by the Committee of Lloyd’s, which does not itself transact insurance business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business is
transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and in
competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through Lloyd’s
broker’s, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the insured.
Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact insurance
with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent financial regula¬
tions laid down by the Committee of Lloyd’s, are permitted to transact
business at Lloyd’s; these financial safeguards give a security behind the
Lloyd’s policy which is second to none. Since 1969 non-Commonwealth
underwriters have been admitted to membership of Lloyd’s, if they satisfy the
requirements.
Today there are about 6,000 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped
into some 280 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents
who accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping intelli¬
gence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on behalf
of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and a
valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London representa¬
tives of the latter.
About two-thirds of the general insurance business (that is non-life) is carried
on overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly through
branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. The basic principle
of this international business is that resources capable of meeting any potential
loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the deposits, underwriting trust funds and other re¬
sources of Lloyd’s underwriters.
In accordance with the Treaty of Rome insurance and re-insurance in the
European Communities are regulated by directives addressed to the govern¬
ments of member states. The purpose of such directives is to harmonise the
legislation of the various member countries, thus providing a ‘common
market’, which would avoid distortion of competition. The programme of work
in the field of insurance and re-insurance has been delayed and only one direc¬
tive has so far been adopted which deals with re-insurance and retrocession.
220
Building
Societies
BRITAIN I973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
A draft directive dealing with the freedom of establishment in non-life
insurance (that is, the freedom of insurers in one member state to set up an
agency or branch in another member state on the same conditions as insurers
of that member state) is nearing completion. This directive would impose certain
requirements on United Kingdom insurers additional to those imposed by the
Insurance Companies Acts 1958-67. The EEC Commission is also preparing
draft directives on life insurance, insurance contracts, taxation of insurance
policies, and on the freedom of non-life insurers to transact services (that is,
to offer insurance cover from a head office in a Community country to another
Community country without being established there).
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation,
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. The amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares, which have a fixed value, are not dealt
with on the Stock Exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
The Building Societies Act 1962, which consolidated a number of earlier Acts,
prescribes the general way in which societies must conduct their business.
The Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies has discretionary powers to stop
a society either advertising or accepting money from investors if he considers
that the way in which the society’s business is conducted is jeopardising
investors’ money. The rapid expansion of building society activity in the
twentieth century has been accompanied by a concentration of most of the
business in the hands of a few large societies. At the end of 1971, 467 societies
were in operation, with total assets of ,£12,919 million; half of this amount
being accounted for by the five largest societies. The amount advanced on
mortgage in 1971 was £2,705 million, 38-5 per cent more than in 1970.

OVERSEAS TRADE
Although relatively small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of
the world’s population, the United Kingdom is the world’s third largest trading
nation, conducting over 7 per cent of international trade in 1971.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
Britain’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and nearly all the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods represent nearly one-fifth of the gross national product.
It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal manufactures,
electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is the world’s largest market for
foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores, textile raw materials,
petroleum and many other products.
Changes in value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
In 1971 Britain’s exports on a balance of payments basis were valued at about
£8,882 million (f.o.b., that is, excluding the cost of freight and insurance
outside the United Kingdom) and imports at about £9,834 million (including
the cost of freight and insurance to the United Kingdom). Valued on the
same basis as exports, imports in 1971 were about £8,585 million. Since 1961
the value of imports has more than doubled while that of exports has increased
by 132 per cent. In both cases the volume of trade has risen by 62 per cent.
The growth in trade has not, however, been even. There was a particularly
rapid expansion of imports in 1964 (14 per cent in value and 11 per cent in
volume) and again in 1968 (23 per cent in value and 10 per cent in volume)
after the devaluation of the pound in November 1967. In 1971 imports rose by
9 per cent; about half of the increase was attributable to higher prices. Exports
increased steadily from 1961 to 1966, but in 1967 they declined slightly in
value as well as in volume. Following devaluation, they proceeded to rise
rapidly (see Table 17). In 1971 they rose by 13 per cent in value and 5 per cent
in volume. From 1964 to 1967 there was a steady improvement in Britain’s
terms of trade, that is, export prices rose faster than import prices. Although
after devaluation both export and import prices in pounds sterling rose
sharply it was not until May 1970 that export prices were higher in dollar
terms than in 1967.
The value and volume of exports and imports in selected years from i960
to 1971 are shown in Table 17.
The expansion of domestic agricultural production has reduced Britain’s
dependence on imported food supplies and the ratio of imported foodstuffs
to total imports has fallen from 39 per cent in 1954 to 22 per cent in 1971 when
imports of foodstuffs were £1,970 million. There has been a similar down¬
ward trend in the proportion accounted for by basic materials—from 30 per

Imports of crude petroleum and lubricants are by far the biggest single item
by value, having risen to 12-7 per cent of the total value of imports during
1971 when their value was £1,249 millkm-
The most marked change in recent years has been the rise, in Britain as in
other industrial countries, in the proportion of imports of finished manu¬
factures, particularly capital goods and industrial components. Such imports
rose from under 6-5 per cent of total imports in 1957 to 24-7 per cent in 1971,
worth £2,432 million, when three-quarters were of capital goods (including
industrial components). Imports of semi-manufactures have also been in¬
creasing steadily and since 1962 have formed a larger part of the total import
bill than basic materials, partly because the countries producing the basic
materials tend to embark upon the subsequent stages of manufacture them¬
selves. Imports of semi-manufactured goods (including chemicals) totalled
£2,577 million in 1971 and accounted for 26 per cent of total imports.
About 85 per cent of Britain’s exports consist of manufactured goods. By far
the most important group are engineering products—in 1971 45 per cent of
total exports. Within this group, exports of many types of machinery, electrical
equipment, road vehicles, tractors and scientific instruments have been
increasing rapidly. The share of chemicals has grown fairly steadily, reaching
9-7 per cent of total exports in 1971. The share of metals has been fairly steady

Trade between Britain and Western Europe has been increasing in recent
years, and conversely there has been a decline in the proportion of Britain’s
exports going to primary producing countries. In 1958, 27 per cent of exports
went to Western Europe, but in 1962 these exports began to exceed those to
the sterling area and by 1971 they formed over 40 per cent of the total. Their
growth rate, which had approached 20 per cent in 1968 and 1969, fell to 10
per cent in 1971 when they accounted for just under 40 per cent of the total.
The decline in the rate of growth was a part of the general slow-down in the
growth of world trade during 1971. Exports to the European Economic
Community (EEC) increased by 10 per cent in 1971 compared with 15 per
cent in 1970, and to the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) they in¬
creased by over 8 per cent compared with 18 per cent in 1970.
Imports from Western Europe increased by 13 per cent in 1971, about the
same rate as in 1970, and formed nearly 40 per cent of total imports.

market and source of supply. The proportion of total exports going to North
America in 1971 was just under 16 per cent. Exports to Latin America rose by
19 per cent in 1971 but imports were unchanged having fallen by 8 per cent in
1970. Britain’s trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe fell in 1971
after growing rapidly since i960. Trade with Japan continues to grow; exports
rose by 6 per cent in 1971 while imports rose by 50 per cent to exceed £200
million for the first time.
For nearly two centuries Britain has usually been able to earn a surplus from
its invisible overseas transactions, that is, transactions in services, including
the provision of finance. This has provided it with the means to pay for part
of its imports of goods and to finance the purchase of capital assets overseas.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government services and transfers; transport (shipping and civil
aviation); travel; other services (which covers a variety of items including
royalties, films and television transactions, financial services, and other
commercial and miscellaneous services); interest, profits and dividends; and
private transfers (migrants’ funds, legacies and private gifts). Table 19 shows
the breakdown of the figures from 1966 to 1971. Some of these figures are
reliable (for instance, for government transactions), others are only approxima¬
tions. The total invisible balance in 1971 was ^,’741 million (in the five years to
1970 the annual surplus averaged £406 million). Excluding government
expenditure on services, transfers and interest, profits and dividends, the net
balance was a surplus of £1,268 million. Private invisible receipts in 1971 rose
to £5,276 million. Gross earnings from invisibles were well over half the total
from visible exports.

Tourist Trade
COMMERCIAL
POLICY
BRITAIN I973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
rapidly rising net surplus on ‘other services’ and another large surplus on
interests, profits and dividends. Nearly half of Britain’s receipts under this
heading comes from investments in the sterling area. There has also been a
surplus on civil aviation services throughout the past decade. Shipping
transactions which had been roughly in balance between 1965 and 1967, have
been in deficit since 1969. Travel credits have exceeded debits since 1968.
Over half the net deficit in respect of government expenditure relates to
military expenditure overseas; other substantial items of expenditure are
grants to developing countries, expenditure on the diplomatic service, and
subscriptions to international organisations.
Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1961-71
overseas visitors spent nearly £2,928 million in Britain. For 1971 these travel
and tourist receipts, excluding fares, are estimated at about £469 million.
United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business or other
purposes overseas, spent about £443 million (excluding fares) in the same
year. The continuing increase in both the average expenditure per visitor and
in the number of travellers visiting Britain have produced the surpluses on
travel credits mentioned above since 1968. The estimated total number of
visits to the United Kingdom in 1971, including visitors from the Republic of
Ireland, was a record figure of over 7 million—more than twice the level of
1956 and an increase of 4 per cent over the 1970 level.
Britain’s national tourist organisation consists of four independent govern¬
ment-financed statutory bodies—the British Tourist Authority, which is
responsible for the overseas promotion of tourism in Britain and for certain
general matters affecting the country as a whole, and the English, Scottish
and Wales Tourist Boards which are responsible for encouraging the develop¬
ment and improvement of facilities and amenities for tourists in their respective
countries, and for tourist promotional work and publicity within Britain.
There is a separate statutory Tourist Board for Northern Ireland.
The English, Scottish and Wales boards administer a scheme of incentives
for hotel investment for projects started before 31st March 1971, and also
offer financial assistance to selected tourist projects in Development Areas.
Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy its exports
which in turn depends on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Britain
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in the setting up and subsequent activities of such
organisations as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the Organisation for Economic
Co-operation and Development (OECD). It played a full part at the three
plenary sessions of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Develop¬
ment held in 1964, 1968 and 1972 and is a member of the Trade and Develop¬
ment Board which acts on behalf of the conference between sessions.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax
(to be replaced by Value-Added Tax in April 1973, see p. 206) is chargeable
on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the charge on
imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a non-registered
trader. In the financial year 1971-72 revenue duties charged on imported
goods yielded about £2,780 million, by far the greater part of which came
from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The yield from

protective duties was ^270 million, or about 2*6 per cent of the value of all

At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with foreign
countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral trade
negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the level of
protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase and
import controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as
the main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced existing legislation relating to the
protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. The tariff was
recast into an internationally agreed form (the Brussels Nomenclature), which
came into use from 1st January 1959. Under the Customs Duties (Dumping
and Subsidies) Act 1969, the DTI is empowered to impose duties on imported
goods of any description which are being dumped or subsidised, if it is satisfied
that this is causing or threatening material injury to a particular industry and
that such action would be in the national interest. The Act also empowers the
DTI to take provisional action where a prima facie case of dumping or subsi¬
disation and consequent material injury has been made out.
The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
recent years as a result of a series of international tariff negotiations held under
the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest series of GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy
Round’ (May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent have
been made by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods.
The reductions made between 1968 and 1972 in the British tariffs on dutiable
industrial goods imported from the EEC, the United States and Japan
amounted to about 37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively. This
is closely in line with the reductions made by these countries, which affect
well over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these
countries. Some reductions were also made in the tariffs on agricultural goods.
Reciprocal preferential tariff treatment for trade between Britain and other
independent Commonwealth countries dates from the Ottawa Conference of
1932. Although levies may be charged on imports of certain foodstuffs from
the Commonwealth most imports from the Commonwealth preference area
enter free of duty.
In 1964 at the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff
preferences on a non-reciprocal and non-discriminatory basis to all the

developing countries if other major industrialised countries would do the
same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned would agree and provided
that preferences were not given in such a way as to impede the continuing
reduction of tariffs on a most-favoured-nation basis. The establishment of a
system of generalised preferences for manufactures and semi-manufactures
exported by developing countries was agreed in principle at the second
UNCTAD in New Delhi in 1968. Britain’s scheme came into effect early in
1972; it provides for relief from import duty for practically all industrial goods
and raw materials imported from certain developing countries (the major
exceptions are certain textiles and goods subject to revenue duties). The scheme
also provides for relief or partial relief from import duty on a range of pro¬
cessed agricultural products.
From 1st January 1973 Britain will be a member of the European Communities
(see p. 459). The accession of Britain and certain other members of the
European Free Trade Association (EFTA) to the European Economic
Community (EEC) will mean their withdrawal from EFTA which was set up
under the Stockholm Convention of January i960 with the objects of creating
an industrial free trade area between the members and of working towards a
wider European settlement. Protective tariffs and quotas on trade in industrial
products between members of EFTA were eliminated with certain minor
exceptions by 31st December 1966. EFTA was the first completed free trade
area in the world, forming a single market of almost 100 million people.
A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Republic of
Ireland came into operation on 1st July 1966 when Britain removed the few
remaining duties on imports from the Republic of Ireland and the Republic of
Ireland agreed to progressively eliminate by 1st July 1975 duties on most
British goods.
Methods of export trading, virtually all of which is conducted by private
firms, vary considerably, according to the firm, the industry, the product and
the market. Much of Britain’s export trade, especially of the smaller manu¬
facturing firms, is conducted through export merchants in Britain; many
firms, however, sell to importers and consumers abroad through their own
agents or resident representatives in the countries concerned; in other cases,
sales are made through a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations
or subsidiary companies established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms.
There are now very few restrictions imposed by Britain on the movement of
goods and services.
Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area.1 The
latter may settle transactions between themselves in sterling, and to comply
with Britain’s obligations to the IMF regarding freedom of current inter-
1 Temporary restrictions on transactions within the sterling area were imposed following
the decision to float the pound sterling in June 1972. Arrangements for non-sterling
area countries were not altered.
Import and
Export Control
Import Licensing
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 229
national transactions, any sterling held on an external account is freely
convertible into other currencies.
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling area countries. Because of balance
of payments problems, exchange control requirements for investments outside
the sterling area have, since 1961, been designed to limit or defer any cost to
the reserves. The improving balance of payments position in recent years,
however, has made some relaxations possible. Exchange control policy is not to
discourage investment abroad but to regulate the manner in which investment
outside the sterling area is financed. Official exchange is more readily available
for projects which directly promote British exports and for investment in
EEC countries (including Norway and Denmark) than it is for other invest¬
ments. Where the use of official exchange is not permitted investors can
finance their project, either by borrowing abroad or by making use of the pool
of investment currency which is bought and sold by residents at a premium
over official market rates of exchange. Exports of goods to destinations outside
the sterling area have, in general, to be paid for within six months in foreign
currency (except Rhodesian currency) or by sterling from an external account
unless they are covered by an approved export credit arrangement. Control is
also exercised over imports to ensure that currency authorised for their pay¬
ment is used for that purpose. The programme of voluntary restraint on invest¬
ment in the other developed countries of the sterling area which had been in
operation since 1966 was abolished in the 1972 Budget.
There are certain restrictions on dealings in gold bullion and on the use of
gold for manufacturing and industrial purposes. The buying, selling and
holding of gold coins does not require Exchange Control permission, although
their export remains controlled.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but the
detailed administration is delegated to the Bank of England as agent of the
Treasury; in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the commercial banks
a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.
Under the Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 the
Department of Trade and Industry is empowered to prohibit or regulate the
import or export of goods.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GATT and the
IMF, the British Government has progressively removed quantitative
restrictions from almost all its imports from the countries of the free world.
There has also been a continuing substantial relaxation of quantitative
controls on imports from the Soviet Zone. The very short list of goods on
which controls remain includes some items of special difficulty and a few
where restrictions are recognised internationally, such as arms, ammunition
and radioactive materials. They require a specific import licence and quotas
have been set up for many of them. Some quotas refer specifically to individual
countries and are usually shared out among exporters by the authorities of the
countries concerned. Others are accorded on an overall or global basis, and
are generally allocated by the British authorities to British importers, usually
on the basis of their share of the trade in the commodity in the past. Apart
from these quantitative controls, some further restrictions or prohibitions are
applied on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants and drugs). There
is also a general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outside

the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner most British exports are
not subject to any government control or direction. The few controls that are
in operation are imposed to supervise exports of military and strategic import¬
ance; to conserve materials which may be in short supply; to assist exchange
control operations in preventing the export of capital in the form of valuable
goods; to ensure the humane treatment of cattle, sheep and pigs; and to
prevent the export of antiques (including works of art) on grounds of national
importance. Normally, individual licences are required for specific consign¬
ments of goods subject to export licensing control. Goods controlled for
strategic reasons, not included in the category of atomic energy materials and
appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with certain exceptions, be exported
to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic, the Republic of South Africa and
the United States of America without licence. There is also a general export
restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.1
Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes.
Information
and Advice to
Exporters
Export Credit
Insurance
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult DTI offices throughout
Britain and, through these offices, the commercial posts of the British
Diplomatic Service overseas. There are over 200 posts located in all the
principal cities and trade centres abroad and they supply the DTI with
information of every kind affecting trade with their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and enquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to British exporters in appointing agents and locating
potential importers. From records kept up to date in London by reports from
its overseas commercial officers, the Export Services Division of the DTI can
provide information concerning any country on the prospects for exports and
requirements of particular markets, government regulations affecting trade
(including import restrictions and tariffs and duties on particular com¬
modities), methods of trading, local tastes and preferences in design, and the
commercial standing of firms with which an exporter contemplates business
relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas are used extensively
to promote Britain’s export trade.
The Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD) (see p. 52) provides
credit insurance for more than a third of the country’s export trade and for
much of the external trade of British merchants.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,
governmental action which stops the British exporter receiving payment, new

Cover may commence from the date of contract or (at lower premiums) from

Government, the bulk of this being in turn refinanced by the ECGD.
Britain stages many exhibitions and trade fairs which attract both the general
public and trade buyers for domestic and overseas markets and provide an
important means of advertising and selling British goods.
British products are shown at most of the large international trade fairs
throughout the world and British manufacturers have been prominent at the
many specialised fairs held in Europe and North America.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
financial assistance and, in certain cases, free facilities. (‘British weeks’ differ
from trade fairs and exhibitions in that they are primarily designed to promote
sales of consumer goods in shops overseas.) In 1971 the DTI assisted nearly
5,30° British firms at 270 specialised and general trade fairs in 38 countries;
and gave practical help to 1 major British Week, 1 British Trade Week,
3 ‘British Shopping Weeks’, and some 38 overseas store promotions. The
amount allocated to the DTI for these purposes has risen from £0-5 million in
1962-63 to £5-5 million in 1971-72.
Export promotion is among the functions of the British Overseas Trade Board
(previously the British Export Board) which in 1972 took over the full range of
activities formerly divided between the Department of Trade and Industry
(DTI) and the British National Export Council.
The board directs export intelligence work, the work on trade fairs and
other promotional activity overseas, the schemes for financial support for
firms to participate in missions overseas and for inward commercial visits to
Britain. It consists of businessmen and DTI and Foreign and Commonwealth
Office representatives and operates under the general authority of the Minister
for Trade who is the President.
In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
the site for the chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight,
insurance and precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a
flexible system of central bank control have been built up, while specialised
institutions such as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the
stock exchanges, investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to
satisfy particular needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities
provided by merchant banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been
used to finance shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also
between other overseas countries.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL FIANDBOOK
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
were able to assist in raising finance for longer-term ventures. British capital
invested in overseas countries has furthered their development, increased
their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured goods. A
number of specialised institutions provide financial services for overseas
countries.
Britain remains the principal international centre for transactions in a large
number of commodities. The bulk of sales negotiated in these markets relates
to consignments which never pass through the ports of Britain. The need for
close links with sources of finance and with shipping and insurance services
often determined the location of these markets in the City of London. Among
the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market for shipping and air
transport), the London Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Terminal Exchange and the London Metal Ex¬
change. A soya bean oil futures market opened in London in 1967 and a
coconut oil futures market in 1969. These markets not only cater for the
import of goods for home consumption but do much business in effecting
transactions between buyers and sellers in other countries. In addition to
these formal markets, there is scarcely any product which cannot be traded
through an intermediary in Britain.
The market consists of about 200 authorised banks and 11 firms of foreign
exchange brokers which act as intermediaries between the banks. The market
provides those engaged in international trade with foreign currencies for their
transactions. The foreign exchange banks are in close contact with financial
centres abroad and are able to quote buying and selling rates for both spot and
future delivery. An important function of the market is to engage in arbitrage
transactions which serve to eliminate differentials in exchange rates between
different centres. The forward market enables traders, who at a given date in
the future are due to receive or make a specific foreign currency payment, to
determine in advance the precise sterling equivalent of the foreign currency.
All authorised banks may deal in gold but, in practice, dealings are largely
concentrated in the hands of the five members of the London gold market.
The five members meet twice daily to fix a price for all transactions which
customers ask to have executed at the fixing. Since March 1968 most monetary
authorities have ceased dealing in gold in the market, and officially held gold
is now used only to effect transfers between monetary authorities.
As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for intei -
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the sterling aiea ,
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer freely
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes (see p. 228). Sterling
became convertible again in December 195^ kvrt there is still exchange control
on transactions, effectively capital transactions, with the non-sterling area.
The sterling area at present consists of all the Commonwealth countries
(except Canada and Rhodesia), together writh Bahrain, Iceland, the Republic of
Currency
Realignment
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 233
Ireland, Jordan, Kuwait, The Maldives, Nauru, Oman, Pakistan, Qatar,
South Africa, South West Africa, the People’s Democratic Republic of
Yemen, and the United Arab Emirates. The main features of the sterling
area are that much of the overseas trade of member countries is financed in
sterling, while much of their international reserves is held in sterling.
(Transactions between residents of the United Kingdom and the overseas
sterling area—except the Republic of Ireland—became subject to exchange
control on 23rd June 1972.1)
The reduction in the balances of sterling area governments in 1968 led to
the series of agreements concluded between the United Kingdom and the
countries of the sterling area in September 1968 by which each country under¬
took to maintain an agreed proportion of its official reserves in sterling, and the
United Kingdom undertook to provide a dollar-value guarantee of the bulk
of official sterling holdings. The majority of these arrangements expired in
September 1971 when nearly all of them were renewed to September 1973.
The new terms provide for a uniform reduction in the proportion of sterling
which the countries concerned undertake to hold in exchange for the dollar
value guarantee.
Britain has declared its willingness to see an orderly and gradual run down
of official sterling balances after Britain’s accession to the EEC. Such a run¬
down would have to avoid imposing undue strain on the balance of payments,
contribute to the smooth functioning of the international monetary system,
and be acceptable to sterling holders.
A general realignment of exchange rates, involving the revaluation of main
currencies against the US dollar, was agreed at the ministerial meeting of the
Group of Ten countries and Switzerland which was held in Washington in
December 1971. Provision was made for 2^ per cent margins of exchange rate
fluctuations above and below the new exchange rates. The United States
undertook to raise the dollar value of monetary gold from $35 to $38 per fine
ounce. This change represents a 7-89 per cent devaluation of the dollar in
terms of gold. A new middle rate for sterling against the US dollar of
£1 = $2-6057 was announced after the meeting.1
In May 1972 Britain began to participate in the EEC scheme for narrower
exchange margins (participation was temporarily suspended following the
decision to float the pound—see p. 194). Under the scheme the central banks
of participating countries ensure that the spot rate of each participating
currency against any other participating currency does not diverge by more
than 2^ per cent from its parity cross-rate against that currency.
BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
Estimates of Britain’s balance of payments and its main constituent items are
given in summary since 1965 in Table 20 and in greater detail since 1969 in
Tables 21 and 22. The balance of payments statistics contain two indicators
of particular importance. The first is the balance on current account, covering
both visible (exports and imports of goods) and invisible (trade in services,
investment income and transfers) transactions, which provides a measure of
how far Britain is paying its way abroad and thus adding to or using up over¬
seas assets. (Traditionally Britain has had a deficit on visible trade and a
surplus on invisible earnings.) The second indicator is the total currency flow.

This is the net result of all external flows, that is the current account, invest¬

banking and money market liabilities in sterling) and other flows which are
unidentified transactions reflected in the balancing item. The total currency
flow shows the impact of all external flows on the reserves and debt position,
that is how much is available to add to the reserves and to repay any official
borrowing in the case of a net inflow or how much must be financed by draw¬

actions as a whole. In 1970 exports continued to rise in value faster than
imports and there was, for the first time for many years, a small surplus on

The total currency flow was outward in each of the years 1963-68 and in¬
ward in 1969, 197° and 1971. In the period 1963-68, there was an outward
flow of ,£3,778 million (including a gold subscription of £44 million to the
IMF) financed mainly by official borrowing totalling ,£3,134 million, but also
by transfers to the reserves of the dollar portfolio totalling ^£520 million; and a
reduction of ,£124 million in the reserves. Approximately one-quarter of the
outflow stemmed from current account deficits. In 1969 there was a reversal of
the net currency flow, and a rapidly increasing currency inflow reached very
large proportions in 1971. During this period almost all short- and medium-
term official borrowing was repaid, and there was a substantial increase in the
reserves.
Britain’s official reserves fluctuated during the 1960s, but stayed on the
whole a little above f 1,000 million. In 1971 Britain’s reserves rose from

EXTERNAL

External

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
£1,178 million to £2,526 million. The end-December 1971 figure is calculated
at the new middle rate of £1=$2-6057. The effect of the valuation changes
consequent upon the realignment of exchange rates agreed in Washington in
December 1971 on the end-December level was to increase their sterling
value by considerably less than the equivalent of the increase in their dollar
value (see p. 233).
Britain is a participant in the Special Drawing Rights scheme which came
into effect in 1970 in order to supplement world reserves as necessary. Special
Drawing Rights are reserve assets created and distributed by decision of the
members of the IMF. Any member of the IMF may join the scheme, and its
share is based on its IMF quota. Participants in the scheme accept an obliga¬
tion to provide convertible currency, when designated by the IMF to do so,
to another participant in exchange for SDRs up to a total amount equal to
twice the net amount of their own allocation of SDRs. Only those countries
with a sufficiently strong balance of payments are so designated by the IMF.
SDRs may also be used in certain direct payments between participants in the
scheme and for payments of various kinds to the IMF.
Britain has drawing rights in the IMF based on its IMF quota which was
raised at the end of 1970 to $2,800 million.
Britain has also taken part since 1961 in the international network of re¬
ciprocal credit (swap) facilities arranged between central banks. Facilities
available to the United Kingdom include one of $2,000 million with the
Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Under these arrangements each central
bank is able to exchange on request its own currency for the currency of an¬
other country up to a maximum agreed for a limited period. It agrees to reverse
the transaction at a specified date at the same rate of exchange. The currencies
so obtained can be retained in the reserves or used in exchange operations.
The significance of any inventory of Britain’s aggregate external assets and
liabilities1 is limited because a variety of claims and obligations are included
that are very dissimilar in kind, in degree of liquidity and in method of valua¬
tion. The inventory for the end of 1971 shows that Britain had a substantial
net creditor position estimated at some £4,135 million.
Identified external liabilities at the end of 1971 totalled some £19,650 million,
against assets of about £23,785 million. Total official short- and medium-
term liabilities to the IMF and other monetary authorities were £415 million.
Inter-governmental loans to the United Kingdom and other official liabilities,
mainly a consequence of the second world war and its aftermath, totalled
£1,906 million of which £1,503 million was owed to the United States and
£345 million to Canada. Other public sector liabilities of £3,465 million com¬
prised overseas holdings of United Kingdom government and public corpora¬
tions sterling securities, holdings of Treasury bills and notes, local authority
mortgages and stocks, and foreign currency borrowing by United Kingdom
public corporations and local authorities. United Kingdom banking and com¬
mercial liabilities including liabilities in sterling, and in foreign currencies,
totalled £5,405 million.2 Liabilities in the form of overseas investment in the
United Kingdom private sector totalled £8,655 million.

Kingdom Balance of Payments, produced by the Central Statistical Office (see Biblio¬
graphy, p. 478). .

Liabilities in sterling comprise both public sector and banking and money-
market liabilities within the totals above. Sterling held in the United Kingdom
by foreigners in the form of bank deposits, deposits with local authorities and
hire purchase companies, Treasury Bills and British Government securities
(where these were held by central monetary institutions and international
organisations other than the IMF) totalled £5,596 million at the end of March
1972. Of this, £1,253 million was held by residents of the non-sterling area and
£4,343 million by residents of the sterling area. The total of these liabilities
(excluding the counterpart of borrowing) remained broadly constant between
the end of 1945 and 1970 but rose sharply during 1971. They reflect the
international trading and reserve role of sterling and in part the financial
services of the City.
Overseas liabilities arising from investment in the private sector of the British
economy rose from £3,165 million in 1962 to £8,655 million at the end of 1971.
Overseas investors in Britain are free to repatriate the proceeds of the sale
of their investments, including any capital gains that they may have accrued.
Earnings and dividends are transferable irrespective of their size. In 1971
the inflow of direct, portfolio and other private investment, including oil,
amounted to £921 million.
The value of overseas investment in the United Kingdom private sector at
the end of 1971 comprised: the book value of direct investment in Britain by
companies incorporated abroad—£3,650 million (excluding oil, banking, and
insurance); portfolio holdings of British securities—£2,840 million; the book
value of the net assets in Britain of overseas oil companies—£1,600 million;
and the balance of £565 million which included borrowing by United King¬
dom companies overseas and identified investment in real estate and in the
insurance industry in Britain.
About three-quarters of the direct investment of £3,650 million came from
North America and about one-fifth from Western Europe. Of the £360 million
inflow of direct investment into Britain in 1971 £335 million originated in the
non-sterling area and £25 million from the overseas sterling area. Foreign
investment inflow presents British industry with many opportunities to match
new competitive standards which in turn will strengthen the economy and its
balance of payments position.
Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment, that
is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the establish¬
ment of subsidiary companies abroad; or by acquiring an interest in an over¬
seas enterprise.
Following the 1972 Budget, investment in the sterling area is in general free
from control. Approval is readily given for financing projects in the non¬
sterling area by borrowing abroad on appropriate terms, and for financing from
Britain where the project is expected to yield substantial and continuing
benefits to the United Kingdom balance of payments. There is also consider¬
able scope for the investment of retained profits of subsidiary companies
overseas and in recent years about 60 per cent of net direct investment outflow
has been financed in this way from unremitted profits.
Estimates prepared by the Department of Trade and Industry show that
direct investment outflow, excluding oil, was £508 million in 1970, £213
million of this being placed in the overseas sterling area and £295 million in
non-sterling countries. Within the latter figure the flow to the EEC area was

Britain’s assets arising from private investment overseas are estimated to have
been £14,855 million at the end of 1971. This compares with a figure of

United Kingdom banking and commercial claims at the end of 1971 totalled
£4,047 million. Within this total banking claims in sterling and overseas
sterling area currencies were £2,098 million; suppliers export credit to un¬
related firms was £1,447 million. With the increase in recent years in British
aid to developing countries, inter-governmental loans of £963 million form the
largest item among official external assets, which at the end of 1971 were
£1,492 million. The latter figure, together with official reserves of £3539°
million, £4,047 million in banking and commercial claims and private invest¬
ment overseas of £14,855 million resulted in aggregate identified external
assets at the end of 1971 of £23,785 million.
Britain’s aid programme to the developing countries consists of loans and
grants for economic and social development, technical assistance, budget
support and contributions to multilateral agencies providing financial aid and
technical assistance to these countries. To complement the official programme
private investment is encouraged by the provision of government insurance
to private investors by the ECGD (see p. 230). In addition an important
contribution is made to economic development by private voluntary organisa¬
tions engaged in relief, development and educational work.
Since 1945 total official aid disbursements have amounted to nearly £3,300
million. The average gross annual disbursement over the four years 1968-71
was about £229 million (see Table 23). In 1971 the total was over £277
million, of which bilateral aid accounted for £247 million including £53
million technical assistance; assistance provided through multilateral agencies
was £30 million. Repayments of capital and payments of interest during the
year on loans made previously came to £42 million and £32 million respec¬
tively. The strategy for the Second UN Development Decade, adopted in i97°>
included a recommendation that each developed country should devote 1 per
cent of its GNP at market prices to total net financial flows to developing
countries by 1972, or i97t> ^ latest. Britain has undertaken to do its best
to reach this target by 1975- In British flows to developing countries have
exceeded 1 per cent of GNP since 1969. The Government does not accept the
need for a separate target for official aid within the 1 per cent target, though
it has announced its intention to maintain official aid as a substantial part of
total flows. Private investment is also expected to play a substantial part, and
the Government has introduced measures to stimulate this flow to developing
countries. . .
Total net British official and private flows in 1971 amounted provisionally to
1*15 per cent of gross national product; official flows were 0-42 per cent. Public
expenditure on economic aid is to be increased and plans published in Public
Expenditure to 1975-76 (see Bibliography, p. 477) show an increase from £205

method of aid determination, introduced in 1971, gross expenditure in each
year will be calculated in current prices. After allowing for price increases and
the deduction of expected amortisation receipts, decisions can then be imple¬

volume of private flows, although influenced by government policies, is not
determined by the Government and is difficult to predict, as also is the future
level of the gross national product.
Bilateral financial aid in 1971 totalled ^247 million; over 41 per cent was in
grants and the rest in loans. Budgetary aid, £6 million in 1971, is provided in
the form of grants. Development aid is in grants or loans, depending on the
economic and constitutional circumstances of the recipient countries; the
greater part of it is in loans. The terms of new development loans from Britain
have been progressively softened since 1958 and a policy of making interest-
free loans to lighten the repayment burdens of the poorer developing countries
was introduced in June 1965. In 1971 the total value of bilateral loan commit¬
ments entered into by the British Government, excluding investments by the
Commonwealth Development Corporation (see below), was ^132 million and
of this over 69 per cent was on interest-free terms. The recipients included
India, Pakistan, Ghana, Turkey, Guyana, Sri Lanka and Indonesia.
Where loans bear interest it is at fixed concessionary rates ranging from 2
per cent to 7J- per cent, and both kinds of loan may carry grace periods during
which repayments of capital are not made. Of all loans committed in 1971,
the average grace period was six years and the average maturity 24 years.
Britain more than fulfils the recommendations of the Development Assistance
Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
(OECD), made in February 1969, on easing the terms of financial aid.
Loans and grants are tied to the purchase of goods, equipment and services
from Britain, although there may be a limited element for local costs and for

procurement from third countries in appropriate cases. Between 1958 and the
end of 1971, 343 loans were negotiated involving a commitment of £1,044
million, of which £890 million has been disbursed. The recipients of the
largest amounts have been India and Pakistan. During the same period bilateral
grants amounted to around £1,077 million.
Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of its
responsibilities towards dependent territories, and the main emphasis remains
on Commonwealth countries. In 1971 million (88 per cent) of the bilateral
programme was disbursed to Commonwealth countries and dependencies.
In the past, development aid to the dependent territories was given under
the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W) Acts, largely in the form
of grants but also in loans. Expenditure on economic and social development
up to the termination of the Acts on 31st March 1970 amounted to some £450
million. The aid requirements of the few remaining dependencies, which are
regarded as a first charge on aid funds, are now provided under the authority of
the Overseas Aid Act 1966. In 1971 the territories received £19 million in
bilateral financial aid and technical assistance.
An important role in development assistance is played by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (CDC), set up by the British Government
in 1948, which provides finance and management for development projects
in Commonwealth countries and dependencies, often in partnership with
governments or private enterprise. In 1970 the CDC’s borrowing powers
were increased and the area of its operations was extended to non-Common-
wealth countries. By the end of 1971 sorne £I5I million had been invested
out of a total commitment of £190 million. Of the latter, £35-7 million was in
the Far East, £46 million in the Caribbean and virtually all of the remainder
in Africa. New investment approved in 1971 totalled over £29 million.
Expenditure on bilateral technical assistance (the provision of skilled person¬
nel, advice and training) has increased in recent years and was £53 million,
23 per cent of total aid, in I971, The largest component of expenditure (£26-1
million in 1971) was on sending or maintaining experts, including volunteers;
the next largest was for students and trainees in Britain (£8-4 million).
Under the Overseas Service Aid Scheme (OSAS) and associated schemes
Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced expatriate British
personnel in the public services of developing countries. The schemes cost
£16 million in 1971.
At the end of 1971, of the 11,214 British persons other than volunteers who
were working in developing countries and financed by the British Govern¬
ment, some 3,140 were engaged in the field of education, 2,338 in public
works and communications, 1,200 in public administration, 1,022 in agriculture
and allied fields, and 881 in health services.
In addition, under the British Volunteer Programme in 1971 there were
1,850 volunteers, mainly graduates or otherwise qualified, working in develop¬
ing countries, the majority of them teaching. Recruitment, training and placing
overseas is undertaken by a number of voluntary bodies; 75 Per cent of tl16
British costs (£o-8 million in 1971) are met by the British Government.
Britain receives large numbers of students and trainees from developing
countries. Over 13,500 were financed in Britain in 1971 under regional pro¬
grammes of technical assistance, by awards under the Commonwealth Educa¬
tion Co-operation Scholarships and Bursary Schemes, and under the various
schemes of the British Council.
