241
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the World
Bank group of institutions—the International Bank for Reconstruction and
Development, the International Finance Corporation and the International
Development Association (IDA). The British commitment to IDA in the
three years 1968-70 was nearly £65 million; the proposed contribution for the
three years 1971-73 is nearly ^130 million. Britain has contributed, or has
agreed to contribute, to the Asian Development Bank, the Inter-American
Development Bank, the Caribbean Development Bank and the African
Development Bank. Britain has contributed £58 million to the United Nations
Development Programme since its inception in 1950 and has provided more
experts and training places under multilateral schemes than any other country.
Some 1,825 British nationals were serving in developing countries under the
United Nations and its specialised agencies in 1971. Other contributions
include those to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine
Refugees (UNRWA), the World Food Programme and the United Nations
Children’s Fund (UNICEF).
INTERNAL TRADE
Internal trade can be divided into two broad categories: trade in raw materials,
capital goods and intermediate products (for example, vehicle components)
and trade in consumer goods, involving the network of distributive trades by
which home produced or imported goods reach the consumer. (For the pattern
of consumers’ expenditure, see p. 197).
Estimates of the value of trade flows at current prices, to intermediate as
well as final customers, relating to 1968 show total sales of goods and services
in that year to intermediate buyers amounting to ^26,616 million and total sales
to final buyers of £47,154 million, divided between private consumption
(£23>i29 million), public authorities’ current expenditure (£7,373 million),
gross domestic capital formation (£7,928 million) and exports (£8,723 million).
The metals, metal goods, mining and chemical industries sold predominantly to
intermediate buyers. The engineering industries sold mainly components to
intermediate buyers and capital goods to final buyers. About 70 per cent of the
output of the textile industries was divided almost equally between inter¬
mediate buyers and private consumption, while over a quarter went to exports.
Agricultural output was divided equally between intermediate buyers and
final buyers (mainly private consumption), while the food and clothing
industries sold predominantly for private consumption.
There have been a number of official statistical enquiries into the distributive
trades. The latest censuses taken in Great Britain refer to the wholesale trades
in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966. Sample
monthly and annual enquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample enquiries. A full census of retail distribution is being
taken in 1972 for the year 1971.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965 (see p. 244).
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through wholesalers:
sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling organisations
(including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses); and other sales
are made directly by producers to retailers. The 1965 enquiry showed that a
242
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
total of 23,643 business units were engaged in wholesale distribution in Great
Britain; 3,435 dealt in clothing, footwear and textiles, 2,007 in grocery and
provisions, 2,630 in vegetables and fruit, and 3,469 in other food and in drink.
In addition, there were 8,282 dealers (wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’
materials, grain or agricultural supplies, and 9,117 dealers in other industrial
materials and machinery. The value of stocks held by wholesalers and dealers
at the end of 1971 is estimated at £1,770 million; expenditure on capital assets
during the year was about £17° million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchandise
handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers (who
sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, increasingly, is
sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers. Fruit and
vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who dispose of the
produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the grower may deal
only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural products is regulated
by statutory marketing boards (see p. 322).
London’s wholesale markets play a leading part in the distribution of food¬
stuffs, particularly imported supplies. Every year Covent Garden (see p. 326)
handles over 1 million tons of fruit and vegetables, and about 300,000 tons
of meat and poultry pass through Smithfield market; Billingsgate is the princi¬
pal distributing centre for fish. Others in London include Leadenhall Market
(poultry) and Spitalfields Market (fruit and vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of £539 million in 1971 and
the SCWS had sales of some £90 million.
Since the early 1950s, many wholesalers have joined, either singly or in
groups, with numbers of retailers to form voluntary groups to help to preserve
the existence of retail outlets for the wholesaler and to give to retailers the
advantages of the lower costs of large-scale trading without significant loss of
independence. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per
cent of the turnover of independent grocers was attributable to wholesaler-
sponsored voluntary groups and chains.
The number of Cash and Carry wholesale warehouses is increasing. By
bulk purchasing and little spending on attractive surroundings or credit and
delivery facilities they can offer large price discounts to bulk-buying retail
traders. The numbers of this type of store have grown rapidly from 400 in
1967 to an estimated 578 in May 197L with a turnover of some £53°
a year. Cash and Carry wholesalers account for about two-fifths of all grocery
warehousing. Some warehouses permit the general public to buy in bulk on
trade terms.
RETAIL TRADE
Types of
Retailers
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under four headings: (1) multiple
traders with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see below),
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small multiple
stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches) and (4) department
stores. Other retail outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the
area gas and electricity boards, and mail order houses (see p. 245).
The 1966 Census of Distribution (Table 24) showed that, in comparison
with 1961, a larger volume of trade had been handled by rather fewer shops.
A notable feature is the continuing expansion of large multiple firms relative
Multiples and
Large Establish¬
ments
Retail
Co-operative
Societies
Independent Shops
Department Stores
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 243
to other types of shop. Independent shops, however, still account for about
half of Britain’s retail trade.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. Four
shops had sales in 1966 exceeding £10 million (equivalent to takings of more
than £4,000 an hour) at the other extreme there were more than 16,000 shops
with sales of less than £20 a week. In addition there were market and street
traders, whose volume of business may be very small.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 74,000 shops owned
by multiples (including multiple department stores) in 1966 with a total
turnover of nearly £4,000 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1961 and 1966 and their share in total sales
went up from 29 per cent to 34 per cent. Their turnover increased faster than
that of independent businesses between 1966 and 1971, and in 1971 their
share of total sales rose to over 38 per cent.
The share in total retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 11 to 9 per
cent between 1961 and 1966 which was rather less than the relative decrease in
the number of stores. Between 1966 and 1971 their turnover rose by 15 per
cent but their share of retail trade fell a little further.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary organisations controlled
by their members. Membership is open to anyone paying a small deposit
on a minimum share, which entitles the member to an equal voice with other
members in the society. Share investment by individual members is limited
to £1,000 (less in some societies) and only a low rate of interest is normally
paid on the shares. One large society is introducing a scheme of bonus shares
carrying a higher rate of interest than the ordinary shares.
Traditionally the trading surplus was paid out to members in the form of a
dividend in proportion to their purchases. Recently a large number of societies,
accounting for over four-fifths of total co-operative sales, have introduced
dividend stamps redeemable for cash, other goods, or credit to a share account,
at different redemption rates.
In February 1972 there were about 260 retail co-operative societies.
Amalgamations are rapidly diminishing the number of societies (the total in
1958 was 1,015). The largest single society in Britain is Co-operative Retail
Services Limited with 1 -36 million members and a turnover of £132 million in
1971. Total sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1971 amounted to about
£1,200 million and accounted for 8 per cent of total retail trade compared
with 11 per cent in 1961.
Independent shops have been giving ground gradually in the face of increased
competition from the larger undertakings. The number of independent shops
fell by about 10 per cent between 1957 and 1966, but the decline has been
partly reduced by the existence of voluntary buying groups (see p. 242). The
proprietors of many of the smaller shops often have other means of livelihood.
Average turnover per shop has continued to increase, though by less than for
the retail trade as a whole.
There were 760 department stores in Britain in 1966 with a turnover of
£653 million; 214 were owned by multiples and 308 by independents.
Department stores were defined for the purposes of the census as having 25 or
more persons engaged in selling a wide range of commodities notably clothing
and household goods. Co-operative societies owned a further 238 department
stores in 1966, with a turnover of £118 million. Sales of all department stores
in 1971 were estimated to be £730 million.

Out of a total of over 500,000 establishments recorded by the 1966 Census
of Distribution, and shown in Table 24, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 227,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬
wear group over 83,000.
Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (inclusive of electricity
and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by a quarter between 1961
and 1966, rates of growth (measured in turnover) varied appreciably between
different types of trade. The slowest growth was in general stores, in the food
and clothing sectors, and department stores. The fastest growth was in radio
and television hire, mail order business, gas and electricity showroom sales of
durable goods, sports and leisure equipment, chemists’ and photographic
goods and sales of automatic vending machines.

However, the actual trends are blurred by the introduction into specialised
shops of other specialities, for example, clothing multiples opening food
sections, and vice versa. Though gas and electricity showroom business was
buoyant between 1961 and 1966, their combined turnover is relatively small,
amounting in 1966 to ^186 million.
The real expansion in the volume of sales in Great Britain between 1961 and
1966, taking into account the exclusion of market traders (included in the 1961
Census) and a general increase in prices of 15 per cent, was about 10 per cent,
or an average of 2 per cent a year. Sales by all kinds of retail business increased
in real terms by 5 per cent between 1966 and 1971, when they were valued at
some £15,500 million.
The Northern Ireland 1965 Census of Retail Distribution and Other

The development of self-service trading has been a feature of the last two
decades. In 1969 there were some 23,000 stores operating wholly or partly
on self-service lines, compared with about 9,500 towards the end of 1961 and

less than 500 in 1950. This development has been accompanied by a trend to

Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1971 nearly 5>000 bad been opened and were handling over
half of all grocery shop sales.
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since 1955.
About 400,000 machines are in use. Sales from automatic vending machines
totalled j£i55 million in 1971; about £79 million was accounted for by
sales from cigarette machines. Machines now sell not only cigarettes, sweets
(£9 million) and stamps but also hot and cold beverages (about £56 million),
prepared foodstuffs, stockings, paper-back books and other commodities,
including various types of fuel. Total sales through machines fell by some £15
million in 1971, largely because of a fall in the number of machines following
Britain’s conversion to decimal currency. Organisations operating automatic
vending machines (not otherwise engaged in retail trade) numbered 56 in
1966, and sales of machines totalled nearly £11 million.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 16 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per cent
and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only about 6 per
cent were non-food shops, and these specialised mainly in paraffin supplies
and hardware.
A number of large ‘out of town’ stores are being opened, providing a range
of goods under one roof, associated with extensive car parking facilities, away
from established central shopping areas.
Forms of consumer sales promotion include reduced price offers, competitions,
gift schemes, and stamp trading. The stamps can be exchanged for goods but,
by law, have to be marked with their cash value and redeemed for cash on
request.
The ‘credit card’ is now widely used in Britain. The cards enable users to have
their signatures accepted on bills in participating shops, hotels and restaurants.
The issuers, which include banks, then meet the bills and recover from the
card-holder through a single account presented periodically. Users of certain
cards are also required to pay a regular subscription.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that the
sales of retail mail order businesses had almost doubled in five years from
£227 million to £429 million. Turnover continued to rise strongly between
1966 and 1971, when at £570 million it accounted for 4 per cent of total retail
1 Excluding roundsmen and vans selling ice-cream.
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
sales. Turnover in 1971 showed little further increase as a temporary result
of the postal strike in the early months of the year.
Sales by manufacturers direct to the public totalled ^144 million in 1961,
compared with £70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per
cent of the former total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for
work done for 9 per cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door
salesmen, accounted for the balance. Included in these sales were items as
various as carpets, washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
The Direct Sales and Service Association consists of 18 companies which
sell all their products directly to the consumers. Sales by members of the
association amounted to about £300 million in 1970.

Other
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those which offer a service
directly to the public, notably catering and hotel trades, laundries and dry
cleaners, garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot and shoe
repairers.
In 1964 there were 149,000 establishments concerned with catering (defined
to include public houses, canteens and fish and chip shops, as well as licensed
hotels and restaurants) with a total turnover of nearly £2,000 million. Hotels
and holiday camps had receipts of about £286 million, of which ^124 million
was from residential accommodation; in addition over £100 million was spent
on accommodation in unlicensed hotels and boarding houses. Nearly half the
total turnover of the catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks.
Between 1964 and 1971 the catering trades’ turnover increased by 49 per cent,
rising by 13 per cent in 1971 alone. In addition, about 100,000 offices and
factories have installed coin-operated beverage and snack machines.
There were about 5,600 commercial laundries, launderettes, linen and overalls
hire businesses and dry-cleaning businesses with an annual turnover of £170
million in 1966. Between 1961 and 1966 turnover increased by 53 per cent
with particularly marked growth in launderettes and linen and overalls hire.
Between 1966 and 1971 turnover of traditional laundries and dry-cleaning
businesses rose by only 10 per cent.
There were nearly 43,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain in 1967
with 51,000 establishments. Total turnover amounted to £4,198 million, of
which sales of new vehicles accounted for £1,475 million and sales of used
vehicles for £766 million. The value of sales of accessories and receipts from
repairs and servicing was £982 million; sales of petrol and oil amounted to
£849 million. Between 1967 and 1971 motor trades turnover increased
rapidly by about 47 per cent and in 1971 was 17 per cent more than in i97°-
Of the total turnover of about £6,170 million in i97I> sa^es °f new vehicles
accounted for some 37 per cent, sales of second-hand vehicles for 17 per cent
and other sales (including over £600 million for servicing and repair work)
for the remainder.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million), and between 1961 and 1966 to £136
million. In 1966 there were about 48,000 hairdressing establishments.
In 1966 there were some 8,800 boot and shoe repair establishments (excluding
repairs by footwear shops); they had takings of £26 million.
Other establishments offering a service to the public include those of radio and
television rental companies (over 3>8oo shops), about 14,500 licensed betting
offices and over 3,500 funeral undertaking businesses.
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
247
British industry’s expenditure on packaging in 1971 has been estimated at
about j£i,ooo million, a rise of some 11 per cent over the 1970 level. The expan¬
sion of self-service shops, the spread of branded and standardised products,
and developments in partly prepared foods, for example, ready-washed vege¬
tables and ready-made cake mixes, have been major factors in the great changes
which have taken place in packaging methods. Paper packaging, including
cartons and boxes, remains the most extensively used (turnover of some £442
million a year), the fastest growing sector being paper sacks (£38 million in
1971). Other important materials are tinplate (£180 million), plastics (£120
million), glass (£103 million) and cellulose film (£12 million). New uses are
being found for tinplate, especially in sales of soft drinks and beer; sales of glass
bottles and jars for newer packaging uses at £63 million greatly exceed sales for
their traditional use as containers for wines, spirits, beer and cider (£39 million).
The use of plastics continues to develop; output of plastics films is some
100,000 tons per year and that of polypropylene about 1,600 tons, while the
annual output of low-density polythene bottles has risen to about 550 million,
providing further competition for the traditional glass bottle.
The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Total new credit extended in
1971 amounted to over £2,000 million, 17 per cent more than in 1970; nearly
half was advanced by finance companies and half by durable goods shops,
department stores and other instalment credit retailers (mainly mail order
businesses).
The DTI has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase, credit sales
and rental agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
In July 1971 all restrictions on terms were removed.
Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance
houses operating from offices in Northern Ireland amounted in 1971 to
£26-2 million.
About £591 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1971; as a proportion of the gross national product (1 - 2 per cent) and of con¬
sumer expenditure (i’7 per cent), it has fallen slightly over the last ten years.
About £409 million was spent on display advertising and ^182 million on
classified, financial and industrial advertising. Most of the advertising is carried
out by agencies, which, in some cases, also provide marketing, consumer
research and other services; their representative organisation is the Institute of
Practitioners in Advertising. The trade association for the whole industry,
including agencies, advertisers and media owners, is the Advertising Associa¬
tion. It was responsible for the setting up of the Advertising Standards Authority,
an independent body whose objective is the promotion and enforcement of the
highest standards of advertising, in particular through the British Code of
Advertising Practice.
Industry and commerce pay great attention to improving public understand¬
ing of their work and objectives. Public relations consultancy firms and the
public relations departments of advertising agencies provide general services,
apart from the increasing employment by industrial organisations and trade
associations of staff specialists in public relations. Their professional body,
founded in 1948, is The Institute of Public Relations which has members in
commerce, industry, the professions, national associations, and central and local
government.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
consumer against specific abuses. The most important are the Weights and
Measures Act 1963 and the Trade Descriptions Act 1968, which are enforced
by local weights and measures authorities; the Food and Drugs Acts 1955 and
1956 which control the purity, hygiene and description of food and are en¬
forced by local food and drugs authorities; and the Consumer Protection Act
1961 which empowers the Government to make regulations to ensure the
safety of any class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to £2,000 although
most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for less than £30.
Similar legislation operates in Northern Ireland. As a precaution against
fraud, virtually every hire-purchase agreement on a car is registered with
H.P. Information Ltd., a non-profit-making company whose members are car
dealers or finance companies concerned with car sales.
The British Standards Institution (see p. 260) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Design Council (see p. 260) helps to
foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
A number of private organisations exist to further the consumer’s interests.
The largest is the Consumers’ Association (CA) with a membership of over
600,000. The CA conducts an extensive programme of comparative testing of
goods bought on the open market. Its views and test reports are published in
its monthly bulletin Which?, issued to members.
Work of this kind is also carried out by some 80 local consumer groups,
whose representative body is the National Federation of Consumer Groups.
Other private consumer organisations include the Housewife’s Trust and the
Research Institute for Consumer Affairs. A general advisory service dealing
with individual consumers’ problems is provided by the Citizens’ Advice
Bureaux (see p. 123).
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by cutting off
supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964; some limited
exemptions for certain classes of goods (notably pharmaceuticals) have been
granted by the Restrictive Practices Court (see p. 251).
13 INDUSTRY
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today 28 people work in manufacturing, mining and building
for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s third largest exporter of
manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures reflects its
position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 355,000 employees, Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd. and the General Electric Company Ltd., which, with labour
forces in the United Kingdom of 137,000 and 205,000 respectively, are among
the largest limited liability companies; and the Co-operative Wholesale Society
Ltd., with about 33,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by two statutory companies,
iron, steel and a small range of chemicals from the plants of the British Steel
Corporation, aero-engines made by Rolls-Royce (1971) Ltd., locomotives and
rolling-stock built in the workshops of British Railways and military equipment
and supplies made in establishments of the defence services. Staff of the
Stationery Office do some printing and bookbinding. Certain factories giving
employment to the severely disabled are operated by Remploy Ltd., a non-
profit-making public company financed on the Vote of the Department of
Employment, which appoints the directors (see p. 370). The Government holds
about 49 per cent of the equity of a major oil company, British Petroleum
Limited, and has a controlling interest in a few other companies.
The most recent analysis of the size distribution of establishments and
enterprises in manufacturing industry, and of the degree of concentration, is
contained in the Report of the Census of Production 1963. This shows that some
57 per cent (52,000) of the 90,000 or so establishments which submitted returns
had fewer than 25 employees each, and accounted for only 6 per cent of total
employment; some 30,000 establishments, one-third of the total, had between
25-500 employees, and accounted for over two-fifths of the total labour force;
2,400 establishments, each with between 500 and 2,000 employees, were
responsible for 28 per cent of employment; while 19 per cent was in the hands
of the 430 leading groups each with over 2,000 employees. A high proportion
of the biggest establishments were in the heavy industries; the average size of
establishments in industries making consumer goods was smaller than in
manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results obtained in
earlier years suggested a slow but significant trend towards increased average
size of establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities.
250
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
An enterprise, as defined in the 1963 census, normally consists of either a
single firm or a parent company together with its subsidiaries. Just over 60 per
cent of all employment in British manufacturing industries in 1963 was
accounted for by about 975 large private enterprises employing 1,000 or more
people, the largest 100 or so accounting roughly for a third. A further indica¬
tion of company size is the value of capital employed (net assets). In the case
of three companies the Imperial Chemical Industries group, British Petroleum
and Shell Transport and Trading, the figure exceeds £1,500 million; about
75 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
With intensified competition in the economy and, in many branches of
industry, the growing dependence of profitable operation on concentration and
an increasing scale of production, the trend towards mergers and regrouping
gathered momentum throughout the last decade. Larger units of control have
been established in almost all the leading industries and in some a small
number of big companies and their subsidiaries are responsible for most of
total production. Examples are oil refining, non-ferrous metal smelting, motor
vehicles and aircraft, heavy electrical engineering, electronics, machine tools,
brewing, textiles, basic chemicals, tobacco and magazine publishing. Shares
in these companies are usually distributed among a great number of holders
and it is rare for a few large holders to have a controlling interest. For example,
six of the largest public companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 286-310.
Large-scale building and civil engineering work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Department of the Environment (see p. 51)
is the largest single employer of building labour while some two-fifths of the
industry’s output is for public authorities. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those con¬
cerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as well as
inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms; almost
three-quarters of the firms employ fewer than 25 employees. For a fuller
account of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 284.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
Britain’s coalmining industry is operated as a single co-ordinated enterprise
under National Coal Board direction. Nearly all other mining and quarrying
(sand, gravel, chalk, limestone, salt, tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is under¬
taken by private enterprises, usually owned and operated by limited liability
companies; about 55,500 workers are employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by an
independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the judicial
examination of restrictive trading agreements.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Acts 1956 and 1968 govern the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. They require the entry in
a public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. Proposed agreements of national importance
which promote efficiency or provide for new productive capacity, can be
exempted from this requirement for a specified period by the Secretary of
State for Trade and Industry (see p. 258). The Registrar of Restrictive Trading
Agreements is responsible for keeping the register and for bringing the agree-
INDUSTRY
251
Role of Public
Enterprise
ments before the Restrictive Practices Court set up under the 1956 Act. The
Court, which includes laymen but is presided over by one of Her Majesty’s
judges, is, in effect, responsible for deciding whether an agreement is in the
public interest. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court that
special circumstances set out in the legislation exist, and that the restriction is
not unreasonable, having regard to the balance between the benefit it confers
and any public detriment likely to result from its operation, that restriction
must be found contrary to the public interest. Agreements are void in respect
of restrictions so found. The Court can make orders preventing the parties
from operating their agreement, or from making new arrangements having the
same effect. Agreements relating exclusively to exports are not subject to this
procedure but have to be notified to the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance was
prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce minimum resale
prices in the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price
maintenance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for
which temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify to
dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision
by the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has
been made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of
Restrictive Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of
which the Court has refused to make an Order exempting them from the
terms of the Act. Only two classes of goods (books and maps and medicaments)
have so far gained exemption under an order from the court; nearly 500 classes
have been refused exemption.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope
of the Restrictive Practices Court) may, in circumstances indicated in the
Monopolies and Mergers Act 1948 and 1965, be referred to the Monopolies
Commission by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry for investiga¬
tion and report. If the Monopolies Commission finds that monopoly conditions
operate against the public interest, the Department of Trade and Industry
(DTI) has powers to remedy or prevent harm which in its opinion may result.
These powers are implemented by Order, with the approval of Parliament.
The 1965 Act strengthened and extended the legislation on monopolies. It
reorganised and enlarged the Monopolies Commission; provided for the
investigation, at the reference of the DTI, of services as well as goods and of
proposed or recently completed mergers; made special provision for newspaper
mergers; and improved and extended the Government’s powers—subject to
parliamentary control—for taking action on the basis of the Monopolies
Commission reports including new powers to prohibit mergers and break up
undesirable monopolies and mergers.
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether about 12 per
252
Industrial
Association
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
cent of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and
staffs are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they
are not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring depart¬
ments who are responsible for the management of the corporations. Certain of
the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer grants to help
them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
These corporations are described in their relevant sections.
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members of
each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to how
the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day management.
It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister any in¬
formation, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In practice,
as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy decisions
are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion for him to
issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings. The responsible minister is usually
empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to say what shall be done with any
surplus revenues which may accrue. As regards finance of capital expenditure,
the present system is that finance which cannot be met from internal sources is
provided mainly by interest bearing loans from the Exchequer; bank advances
are used for normal requirements of short-term capital.
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable.
Financial targets have been agreed by the Government with the different
industries (or are under discussion) ranging from 12-4 per cent gross return
on capital employed to ‘breaking even’ after interest and depreciation have
been allowed for. In addition the industries are expected to apply a test
discount rate for new investment of 10 per cent.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House of
Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which examines
the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports to Parlia¬
ment, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the pro¬
vision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with the
Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
INDUSTRY
253
Location
Greater London
and the South-east
Region
(see p. 250); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with varying
completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of industry
where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices. Em¬
ployers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of firms
engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations, concerned mainly with representation to the Government, the
provision of common services and the regulation of trade practice are normally
composed of firms manufacturing a particular product or group of products.
In an industrial sector concerned wholly with an allied group of products, a
single association may undertake all the required functions.
There are about 70 national federations and probably altogether about
1,300 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely but is thought to total
some 1,200, varying greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representatives
of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of European
Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of government
advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies con¬
cerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 13,000 companies and about 210
trade associations and employers’ federations. Nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in the
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which 92 local chambers of commerce (together with 19 British Chambers of
Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland there is an additional
central organisation, the Scottish Chamber of Commerce, and in Northern
Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry to which
local chambers are affiliated.
The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British industry
today, grouped according to the eight standard regions of England, plus Wales,
Scotland and Northern Ireland.
London, lying at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary, is
Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world’s
most important financial centre, and one of the world’s four largest cities
(with Tokyo, New York and Mexico City) and three largest ports (with New
York and Rotterdam). It is the main centre in Britain of printing, cinema film
production and the manufacture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materials
for the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of manu-
254
South-west
England
East Anglia
West Midlands
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
facturing firms (particularly in the central area) is well below the national
average. London is also important, especially in its outer ring, for light
engineering, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering
plants and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of Greater London (population 7,379,014) and in
the new urban development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics
and a variety of consumer goods industries, has expanded greatly; some of the
largest aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge and Hatfield,
as well as factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two of the four
main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor vehicle
manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (109,000), some 50 miles north-west
of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there are large oil
refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works and major
concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 107,000)
and Bournemouth (153,000) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(166,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (197,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (215,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship repair¬
ing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade. Bristol (425,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and important non-ferrous
metals and basic chemicals plants at Avonmouth. Gloucester (90,000), origin¬
ally an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham (70,000), originally a
resort town, and the area between and adjacent to them produce a variety of
manufactures, including machinery, instruments and accessories, and cloth.
Swindon (91,000), besides railway workshops, has important engineering
works. Bath (85,000), originally a resort town and centre of an agricultural
district, has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (99,000) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (123,000) and Peterborough (70,000) are
noted for diesel engines, agricultural machinery and engineering generally;
and Norwich (122,000) for footwear and food manufacture. Food canning and
freezing, based mainly on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly.
The fishing ports of Great Yarmouth (50,000) and Lowestoft (52,000) have
fish processing plants, and have also become important bases for companies
engaged in natural gas exploitation in the North Sea.
The West Midlands conurbation, which stretches from Birmingham (1,013,000)
to Wolverhampton (269,000) and includes parts of Staffordshire, Worcester¬
shire and Warwickshire, has an unusually wide variety of industry, including
the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all kinds and
also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware. The
largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture (including components
and accessories) in Britain are in Birmingham and Coventry (335,000).
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
(265,000), is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
INDUSTRY
255
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (55,000) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (59,000), electrical engineering;
Worcester (73,000), machinery; Burton upon Trent (50,000), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (47,000), carpets.
The industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(284,000), noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (219,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (303,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton (127,000), footwear and engineering; Chesterfield (69,000),
engineering. Corby (48,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a large
integrated steel works. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised
coalfield lies under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coal¬
field, such as Mansfield (58,000), have important manufacturing industries,
particularly textiles.
Manchester (541,000) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textiles industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy engineer¬
ing and the production of machine tools, petrochemicals, dyestuffs, and
pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures. In
the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also pro¬
cessed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton (154,000),
Oldham (106,000), Rochdale (91,000), Stockport (140,000), Burnley (76,000),
Blackburn (102,000), Preston (97,000) and Bury (68,000). In the majority of
these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of printing, paper
making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial vehicles
(especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been expanding while the
cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies in the
Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester and Merseyside. It passes through Warrington
(68,000), with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (57,000) and
Runcorn (36,000) with their chemicals, and Ellesmere Port (62,000) with its
oil refinery installations, before reaching the Mersey estuary. St. Helens
(104,000), to the north of the canal, is famous for glass manufacture. Liverpool
(607,000) is the second port of Britain, a great commercial and insurance
centre and, after London, the greatest centre for processing imported food¬
stuffs and raw materials, noted especially for flour milling, soap manufacture,
sugar refining and rubber products. Among its older industries is ship repair¬
ing; shipbuilding is a major industry across the river at Birkenhead (138,000).
Many new industries, including electrical engineering, manufacture of heavy
industrial equipment and, more recently, of motor vehicles, have been
established around Liverpool. Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used mainly by
chemical works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,000) in the north-west of Lancashire, is well known for ship¬
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (151,000) on the coast is one of
Britain’s most popular holiday resorts.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen industries
are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (294,000) is the com¬
mercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
256
Northern England
Wales
BRITAIN I973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (44,000) and Leeds
(495,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (42,000), Dewsbury
(51,000) and Spenborough (41,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (131,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (91,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the heavy
engineering centre of Sheffield (520,000), famous for its high quality steels,
cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide over one-fifth of
Britain’s coal; Doncaster (83,000), also with tractor and nylon manufacturing,
and Barnsley (75,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (104,000) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (285,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, chemicals and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (71,000),
an important and expanding steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of
Grimsby (96,000) which has a food processing industry and also growing
chemicals and textiles industries close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concentrated
in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees. Within
this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon Tyne
(222,000), Gateshead (94,000), Tynemouth (69,000), South Shields (101,000),
Wallsend (46,000) and Jarrow (29,000); and Teesside (395,000) and Hartlepool
(97,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (217,000), Darlington (86,000) and
in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on
both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ over one-quarter of the male workers. This proportion has
been falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help,
to attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. An aluminium smelter is
nearing completion on the Northumberland coast. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland, with two nuclear power stations and other installations.
Over two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other
specialised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
industry. Rhondda (89,000) and Merthyr Tydfil (55,000) are the largest
centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most
modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and
much of its sheet steel. In the past 35 years many new industries have been
established, often on government industrial estates; they include plastics,
Scotland
Northern Ireland
industry 257
synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light
engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (278,000),
Newport (112,000) and Swansea (173,000). Milford Haven (14,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(39,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (897,000) and Edinburgh (453,000).
Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is a major shipbuilding and marine
engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering enter¬
prises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north Lanark¬
shire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed electronics
equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms in such
centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as well as in
Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding alongside
the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries. Motor car
manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West Lothian there
has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
With the major oil discoveries which have been made in the North Sea (see
p. 271), the area around Aberdeen is becoming a major oil centre and substantial
development by oil-based industries is taking place.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concentra¬
tion in and around Dundee (182,000) and Aberdeen (182,000) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries, while
the paper and metal industries are also important.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 276).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley
towns of the Borders and in the Highlands and Islands. Small engineering and
electronics industries have recently been established in towns in the Borders
and the south-west. Small-scale manufacturing has also been introduced in the
Highlands, and larger enterprises include the experimental atomic reactor
establishment at Dounreay and the aluminium smelter recently commissioned
at Invergordon. (see p. 289).
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and lacking in
minerals, there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and
around Belfast, the capital city (359,000). Britain’s largest single shipyard
incorporating the world’s biggest shipbuilding berth is in Belfast; other long-
established activities include the manufacture of textile machinery and other
engineering products; ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing. Northern Ireland
has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is particularly well
known for linen. The textile industry is now diversified; Northern Ireland is
one of the most important areas in Europe for man-made fibre production and
provides over one-fifth of Britain’s output. There has also been extensive

BRITAIN 1973: an OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
development in vehicle components, oil-well equipment, electronic instruments,
telephone switchgear, toys, shoes and synthetic rubber.
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways—
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and
by the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour
legislation (see Chapter 16) and certain export and import controls over a
small range of products (see Chapter 12), there are few physical controls over
industry—the main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies
and restrictive practices already described (see p. 250) and the operation of
powers to control new industrial and office building and changes in land use.
There is close association between industry and the Government through
such channels as the National Economic Development Council, the main forum
for consultation between the Government, management and the trade unions,
and Economic Development Committees (EDCs) which cover particular
industrial sectors.
The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI), set up in October 197° f-0
combine the functions of the Board of Trade and the Ministry of Technology,
is the first single body with responsibility for all policies affecting production
and trade (both internal and export), and for the Government’s relations with
individual industries. Following a review of the machinery for aerospace policy
and defence procurement, the former, together with civil aerospace research,
has become the responsibility of the DTI, while the latter is handled by a new
procurement executive at the Ministry of Defence.
Policies on labour matters, including industrial relations, industrial training
and manpower in general are the concern of the Department of Employment.
Other departments involved with industrial issues are the Treasury (fiscal and
monetary policy and medium- and long-term economic questions); the
Department of Education and Science, which is responsible for the promotion
of education and for civil science, operating primarily through the research
councils; and the Department of the Environment (relations with the con¬
struction industry and some regional matters).
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Commerce deals with industry and
industrial development.
The Central Statistical Office (CSO), which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
is the central body for government statistics. Although departments them¬
selves compile statistics relating to their responsibilities and may publish them
in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical publications
are prepared by the CSO, which acts as co-ordinator. The Business Statistical
Office, which is responsible to the CSO for policy but is administratively part
of the DTI, will eventually take over the responsibility for compiling a wide
range of statistics relating to industry and commerce.
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 1971 fractionally less
than a year previously, about one-third higher than in i960 and about double
the pre-war level. The course of production and employment from 1963 to
1971 is shown in Table 25.
Among manufacturing industries output rose fastest between 1963 and 1971
in the chemical and allied industries (61 ‘5 per cent), in coal and petroleum

The size of the labour force has fallen slowly in the last five years and the
increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors influencing
productivity, including advances in products, machinery, processes and
methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive competi¬
tion and sales promotion; and improved management.
Although gross fixed capital formation at home has, as a whole, been well
maintained since 1966, the proportion devoted to manufacturing has tended
to fall. The total in 1971 amounted to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product
and was estimated (at current prices) to be more than double the 1959 level.
Part of this rising investment is associated with the introduction of new
techniques and equipment and in particular of machines and instruments
which lessen the demand for human skill and supervision though they may
require more skill from fewer people. This process of automation is giving rise
to far-reaching changes in the pattern of industry and in the internal organisa¬
tion and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been
responsible for consequential increases in production and efficiency which, in
the long run, are likely to be very large. Much investment, however, still con¬
sists of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.
Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives.
Within industry, employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private con¬
sultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency; there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
26o
Standards
Design
Co-ordination
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of productivity. The local organisations arrange meetings, inter-factory visits,
courses, conferences, film shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, among other things, quality, performance, dimensions, testing
methods and codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by
manufacturers, buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies
the specification of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting
of representatives of the main organisations of employers and workers, pro¬
fessional institutions and the larger government departments.
The Design Council, set up by the Government in 1944 as the Council of
Industrial Design to promote higher standards of design in British industry,
is concerned with all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods
to capital goods. The Council, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-aided
body sponsored by the Department of Trade and Industry; its members
include industrialists, engineers, retailers, architects, designers and educa¬
tionists and trade unionists. At The Design Centre in the Haymarket,
London, a selective but changing display of modern British consumer goods
is maintained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index, the Council’s illustrated
record of more than 10,000 well-designed products. Special exhibitions on
particular themes are also arranged regularly. An annual awards scheme,
Design Council Awards, covering capital goods and engineering equipment
as well as consumer products, was introduced in 1967* The Duke of Edinburgh
also presents his annual Design Prize. The Scottish Committee runs the
Scottish Design Centre in Glasgow, and there is an independent regional
design centre, maintaining a duplicate of the Index, at Manchester. The
Council organises temporary exhibitions in regional centres and overseas;
arranges regular conferences and training courses; undertakes industrial study
tours in Britain; and operates a designer selection service which can make
recommendations to any individual or organisation from a list of over 3,000
British graphic and industrial designers. It publishes a monthly magazine,
Design, and maintains reference and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 393), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain, the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Department of Trade and Industry. Their aims are to
improve craft design and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and
industry.
The Department of Trade and Industry is responsible for the co-ordination of
activities related to the improvement of industrial productivity. It is represented
on the EDCs (see p. 258)—which are concerned primarily with the removal of
obstacles to efficiency—by seconded industrial advisers. The DTI is also
charged with extending the introduction of automatic control systems and
advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the BSI, the British Calibration
Service1 and the National Computing Centre, supports the National Data
1 Set up in 1966 to provide reliable calibration facilities for industries producing
scientific instruments and industrial test gear.

Processing Service, and provides technical advisory services. It is concerned
directly with research into such factors as productivity measurement tech¬
niques, group technology, production engineering and fatigue among operators.
The Conciliation and Advisory Service of the Department of Employment
advises firms on aspects of productivity connected with manpower utilisation
and industrial relations. A number of other departments have responsibilities
which bear on productivity.

Industrial and

In Britain, as elsewhere, management is recognised as a subject requiring
special skills and knowledge. This is reflected both in a change in the general
educational qualifications of recruits and in the spread of systematic education
and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national manage¬
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce and public administration. The
BIM receives an annual government grant of about £100,000 to help it expand
services to industry. The Industrial Society works to promote better use of
human resources; it advises members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
p. 161). There are graduate business schools in London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at several universities and
colleges, including the Administrative Staff College, Henley-on-Thames, and
Ashridge College of Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially
those with wide responsibilities, often provide general management courses
for senior executives, and systems of informal training within an organisation
are numerous. There are also bodies concerned with specialised branches of
management, for example, the Institute of Personnel Management, the
Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office Management and the
Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now about 5,000—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are further
indications of interest in the science of management in Britain.
Under the Finance Act 1972 incentives to encourage capital expenditure in
plant and machinery take the form of a system of free depreciation enabling the
whole of such expenditure to be written off against profits for tax purposes in
the year in which it is incurred; there is in addition a 40 per cent initial allow¬
ance on new industrial buildings and structures and an annual writing down
allowance of 4 per cent. To maintain a greater incentive in the development
and special development areas (see below) the tax allowances available nation¬
ally and free depreciation are reinforced by regional development grants of 20
per cent and 22 per cent respectively towards capital expenditure on certain
new plant and machinery and on new or existing industrial buildings. The
building grants are also available in the intermediate areas and—until March
1974—in derelict land clearance areas.
The aim of industrial and regional policy is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to stimulate a faster and steadier
expansion in national output.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Major changes in the administration of policy were given effect by the
Industry Act 1972. A Minister for Industrial Development has been
appointed—under the broad direction of the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry—to take charge of a new Industrial Development Executive which
includes divisions of the Department of Trade and Industry concerned with
regional development. A Development Unit within the executive is responsible
for the appraisal and implementation of regional policies. The Minister is
advised on major specific cases for assistance by an Industrial Development
Board composed of representatives from industry, banking and finance.
Regional Development Boards advise on general industrial opportunities and
on applications for selective financial assistance.
The new machinery supplements and strengthens the regional economic
planning councils and boards set up in Great Britain in 1965. The councils,
comprising part-time members with wide experience of their regions, are
advisory bodies concerned with studying the needs and potentialities of the
regions; the boards consist of senior civil servants and aim at co-ordinating the
regional work of government departments. The councils and boards operate in
each of the standard regions of England (see p. 253). Scotland has its own
council and board, and there is a Welsh council (supported by an economic
planning board), concerned with both economic and social affairs.
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north-east and some other
parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency
for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as
a result, the demand for labour has been high and there have been increasing
problems of congestion. An important aim of the Government s regional
policy is to achieve a better distribution of industrial development betw een the
different parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken
important measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and has
been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
Since August 1966 large parts of Britain have been designated as ‘develop¬
ment areas’ qualifying for particular assistance, with first priority being given
to smaller ‘special development areas’. Following the report of a committee set
up in 1967 to investigate the needs of areas with special economic problems
but situated outside the development areas, the Local Employment Act 1970
designated a number of such regions as intermediate areas and also created
derelict land clearance areas. The extent of the former was increased by the
Industry Act 1972. The boundaries of the assisted areas are shown in the map on
opposite page.
Besides the free depreciation allowances and grants on capital investment
there is a wide range of financial and other inducements available under the
Industry Act 1972 and the Local Employment Act 1970 to encourage industry
to expand in the assisted areas. In the development and intermediate areas the
Department of Trade and Industry may build factories for leasing, in some
cases with an initial rent-free period, or for sale on deferred terms, and provide
selective assistance including loans, and in certain circumstances grants
towards removal expenses.
Factory building and estate management are undertaken on the Department
