Estates Corporations; premises administered by the three Corporations total
over 60 million square feet and give employment to over 250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
grants to local authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for im¬
proving basic services; and help from the Department of Employment with
the cost of training additional labour in development areas and of transferring
workers in connection with establishing new enterprises.
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application
under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning per¬
mission for industrial development involving more than 15,000 square feet
of industrial floor space (or 10,000 square feet in the south-east) must be
accompanied by a certificate from the Department of Trade and Industry
certifying that the development in question can be carried out consistently
with the proper distribution of industry. In considering applications the
Secretary of State pays particular regard to the need for providing appropriate
employment in the assisted areas. In practice this obligation has led to the
refusal of certificates for most projects outside the assisted areas unless it can
be shown that the project could not reasonably be undertaken in such an area
or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this priority, the control is also used to
encourage dispersal of industry to new or expanded towns taking population
from the more congested areas. Under the Town and Country Planning ct
1971 the Department of the Environment has power to control office develop¬
ment in certain areas. Office development permits are needed only for develop¬
ments of over 10,000 square feet in the south-east of England.
Northern Ireland
Under separate legislation capital grants are available at 20 per cent of the cost
of new machinery and equipment and 35 per cent of the cost of new buildings
for the manufacturing, construction and extractive industries in Northern
Ireland. There is also provision for assisting firms by means of loans to carry out
major schemes of re-equipment, to move to another area in particular need of
industrial development or to undertake a rehousing of their business in associa¬
tion with a major scheme of modernisation and reorganisation. Help under the
investment grants legislation is made without regard to how much employment
is created as a result.
As an alternative means of assistance in Northern Ireland there are compre¬
hensive and flexible powers authorised under the Industries Development Acts
for projects which offer a reasonable amount of employment. In such cases
individual development grants are available of up to 40 per cent of expenditure
on new machinery and equipment and 55 per cent of the cost of new buildings.
For those projects which offer exceptionally attractive returns in employment
or location within Northern Ireland, the assistance offered could include
tenancy of a government-built factory at a very low rent, grants towards
operating costs in the initial stages, and grants towards costs of removing
existing machinery and installing it in a factory in Northern Ireland.
Since 1945 over 300 new firms have been established in Northern Irelani
with government assistance, giving employment to some 90,000 people. The
Ministry of Commerce is the department concerned with the administration
of industrial development policies. A Finance Corporation with an initial
capital of /50 million has been formed to aid industrial and commercial
concerns which have short-term liquidity problems but long-term prospects of
viability.

Rural Industries
265
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associations
concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly by local
authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 324). It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land, provide
management and other advisory services and set up and carry on businesses.
The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary association,
promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism in the
rural parts of development areas. In England and Wales this service is pro¬
vided by the Council for Small Industries in Rural Areas acting in consulta¬
tion with the Rural Community Councils through their Small Industries
Committees in the counties; by the Small Industries Council for Rural Areas
of Scotland; and in Northern Ireland by the newly formed Local Enterprise
Development Unit of the Ministry of Commerce. Another service provided
by the Commission is the financing of small factories to stimulate rural
industries and to combat rural depopulation.
FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power;
secondary sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, represents 43 per cent of primary energy
consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share of the total energy
market has been falling. Oil, on the other hand, virtually all imported, has
expanded rapidly, its share of total energy consumption having risen from 20 per
cent in 1958 to nearly 46 per cent in 1971. With the advent of nuclear power and
North Sea natural gas Britain has moved over from two fuels to four. A pro¬
gramme for nuclear power stations has been in progress since 1955 and nuclear
power now provides a significant share of electricity supplies although only
3 per cent of total energy requirements. The share of natural gas is expanding
rapidly from supplies from the North Sea discoveries. Water-power resources
are very small and cannot be developed much further. Trends in primary
energy consumption are shown in Table 26 and in the diagram on p. 268.
The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Secretary of State for
Trade and Industry. Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using
industries. The Secretary of State also has an Advisory Council on Research
and Development.
1 The Development Commission recommends, and the Treasury approves and
administers, advances by grants or loans from the Development Fund, established by
the Development and Road Improvement Funds Acts 1909 and 1910. At the present
time the Fund may be used to help and expand the rural economy (including accom¬
modation of tourists) and also to promote the development and improvement of
fisheries.

COAL

INDUSTRY 267
Million tons coal equivalent
The nationalised fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total some
three-quarters of a million people, or 3 per cent of the working population;
their capital investment in 1972-73 will be in the region of £800 million; their
annual turnover is about £3,000 million; and the value of their net output is
about 5 per cent of the national product. The nationalised industry boards’
investment is financed through internal resources and borrowing from the
Government (long term), the clearing banks (short term), and from overseas
(long term) sources.
The responsible ministers—the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry
in England and Wales and, for Scottish electricity, the Secretary of State for
Scotland—are required by statute to set up consultative councils for each of
the nationalised fuel industries to protect the interests of consumers. National
Industrial and Domestic Coal Consumers’ Councils were set up in 1947 and
Area Electricity and Gas Consultative Councils (supported by district com¬
mittees) were set up in 1948 and 1949 respectively. Each consists of a chairman
and from 20 to 30 unpaid members appointed from nominations put forward
by interested bodies, mainly local authorities. However, entry into the European
Coal and Steel Community (see p. 459) will involve abolition of the Industrial
Coal Consumers’ Council and modification of the terms of reference of the
Domestic Coal Consumers’ Council.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. In 1913—the peak production year—the industry
produced 287 million tons of coal, exported 94 million tons and employed over
a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry. The NCB has, with minor exceptions, exclusive rights over the
extraction of coal in Great Britain, but is empowered to license private
operators to work small pits and open-cast sites. It has no monopoly in
distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private hands, but it has some
retail depots and makes bulk sales to large industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the Secretary of State (and
268
Supply and
Demand
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
ENERGY TRENDS 1961-1971
through him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The Secretary of State has power
to issue general directives on matters affecting the national interest, and to
authorise borrowings to finance capital investment. Under the Coal Industry
Act 1971 he also has power to give directions relating to the Board’s non¬
colliery activities.
At the end of March 1972 there were 289 NCB collieries in operation, each
on average producing some 462,000 tons of coal, compared with 192,000 in
1947. Of these, 286 were grouped into 17 areas, each controlled by a director
responsible to the NCB. The remaining three collieries (in Kent) are controlled
by a general manager who is also responsible to the NCB.
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between
INDUSTRY
Production and
Manpower
TABLE 27
Coal

1950-71
269
1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel, railway transport and other industries con¬
tributed to the fall in demand which is still continuing (see Table 27). Un¬
distributed stocks have recently been run down considerably and at the end
of March 1972 were 7 million tons.
Nearly half of total consumption is by the electricity authorities and over
one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens are other
large users while consumption by the gas industry is falling rapidly with the
switch to natural gas. Consumption by the electricity industry has increased
by 38 per cent since i960 to 71 - 7 million tons in 1971 whereas the requirements
of most other classes of consumer have declined. For domestic users this
fall has been slightly offset by increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have declined for somewhat similar reasons and now average
about 3 million tons a year. The peak post-war figure was 19 million tons in
1949. The biggest customer is the Federal Republic of Germany; over 90 per
cent of exports go to EEC and EFTA countries. Because of the low stock
situation, restrictions on imports of coal, coke and manufactured fuels were
lifted in December 1970. In 1971 imports amounted to over 4 million tons.
The fact that the British industry was developed so early has meant that many
of the best seams of coal are now worked out, but there are abundant reserves of
coal with which production can be maintained well into the next century;
there is also scope for opening new collieries should these be required. The
main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and Nottingham¬
shire field, which produces about half of the total output, (2) the Durham and
Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and (4) the Scottish field.
Other important coal-bearing areas are those of Lancashire and the west Mid¬
lands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

Coal consumption has fallen steadily over the past 20 years as shown in
Table 26, and fell by as much as 23-4 million tons in 1971-72 (due to a pro¬
longed industrial dispute). The fall in demand has been accompanied by
increases in productivity and has resulted in a rundown of the labour force

from some 700,000 to about 274,000. There were 12,363 fewer workers in
March 1972 than in March 1971. Overall productivity has risen by half since
1961 to 2-i tons per manshift in 1971-72. Productivity at the coal face has
doubled over the last 20 years to 6-9 tons per manshift in 1971-72- The
increases have been obtained largely by concentration on the more productive
mines and faces, by increasing mechanisation at the face, and by the use of
multishift working. At mechanised faces, output now averages 8 tons per
manshift compared with 4 tons at non-mechanised faces. Other important
measures which have contributed to increased productivity include new tech¬
niques for obtaining information about the reserves before they are worked,
intensive training of management and men to obtain the maximum utilisation
of equipment on highly mechanised faces, the increasing use of powered sup¬
ports, the use of higher horse-power machines and improvements in the
mechanised handling of coal below ground and on the surface.
The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry. The statutory limit on such borrow¬
ing was raised from £900 million to ^950 million in 1972. Within certain
limits the Board may also, with the permission of the Secretary of State for
Trade and Industry, borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft or otherwise).
The greater proportion of investment is financed from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry from 1947 to March 1972 totalled £1,864
million. The total debt to the Secretary of State at the end of March 1972
amounted to £724 million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and 'Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
In the year ending March 1972 the NCB made an operating loss of £120
million, and after payment of interest there was a deficit of £157 million. The
maximum permitted level of accumulated deficit was raised from £7 5 mil ion
to £100 million following a miners’ strike and subsequent wage award early in
1972; in addition a £100 million emergency grant was made.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the Coal Industry Act 1971 authorised the Secretary of State
for Trade and Industry to make grants on a tapering basis up to a maximum
aggregate amount of £24 million over the three years to 1974-
The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment.
Research associations receiving grants from the NCB and the Department
of Trade and Industry include the British Coke Research Association and the
Coal Tar Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as
the Safety in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the
Board’s problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires,
pneumoconiosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
PETROLEUM
INDUSTRY
27I
North Sea
Production
Land-based
Fields
International

Consumption
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962. At present nearly all of Britain’s oil supplies are imported.
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea for natural gas and oil has been going on
since 1962 and full-scale exploration activities since 1964, following the enact¬
ment of the Continental Shelf Act 1964, and the subsequent award of a first
round of licences. Further licences were awarded in 1965, 1969-70 and 1971-
72. The total area now under licence is 43,415 square miles (112,444 square
kilometres) out of a total area, over which Britain has exercised its rights to
explore and exploit the seabed and subsoil, of 166,000 square miles (430,000
square kilometres).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of five major fields
of natural gas in the British sector all of which are now in production (see
p. 279). Oil in significant quantities was first found in the British sector in
1970; development plans were announced for the Forties field in December
1971, to provide for output of 12-5 million tons a year by late 1975. First
deliveries through a 115-mile (185-kilometre) submarine pipeline are expected
in late 1974. Several other major discoveries have been made including that
of the Auk and Brentfields, planned to come into operation by 1974 and
1975-76 respectively.
A production rate by the mid-1970s of 25 million tons a year has been
estimated, with a possible trebling of this amount by 1980.
Annual production of crude oil from land-based oilfields in Britain now totals
about 81,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the
establishment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Egmanton
and Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough)
and in Dorset (Kimmeridge).
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today production by these companies amounts to about 18 per cent of total
world production and they operate a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and
partly on charter) amounting to over one-fifth of the world’s tanker tonnage.
(British registered tanker tonnage is about 14 per cent of the world’s total.)
In 1971 Britain imported 105-9 million tons of crude oil valued at £931-5
million, the largest single item among imported products. Kuwait, Libya and
Saudi Arabia supplied 20-4 per cent, 19-1 per cent and 19-8 per cent respec¬
tively. Other major suppliers were Iran, Nigeria and Venezuela.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1971 totalled about
96 million tons, having more than doubled since i960. Fuel oil consumption
in 1971 constituted 43 per cent of the total. Demand for gas and diesel oils
(including derv fuel used in road vehicles) rose by 600,000 tons to over 17
million tons in 1971. Sales of motor spirit have expanded by an annual average
of 6-2 per cent since i960 and totalled some 14-7 million tons in 1971.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1971 were for non¬
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways; over 5 million
tons of derv fuel were consumed. Electricity generation accounted for 35-1
per cent of total fuel oil consumption, excluding that used in oil refineries;
272
Refineries
Oil Pipelines
Research
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the steel industry accounted for 11-7 per cent; and non-industrial central
heating for a further 10-6 per cent. Of the remainder, the largest users were the
cement, paper-making, general chemical, glass, engineering, brickmaking and
textile industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economic to refine
at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry has
favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1971 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 120 million
tons a year; capacity is expected to reach an estimated 133 million tons by the
end of 1973. Of the 23 refineries in operation, five have a capacity of under
0*5 million tons. The eleven largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(19 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-5 million tons); Isle of Grain
(11-3 million tons), Shell Haven (10 million tons), and Coryton (67 million
tons), all three on the Thames Estuary; Teesport, Yorkshire (5-3 million tons);
Grangemouth, east Scotland (8-9 million tons); Milford Haven and Pembroke
in Pembrokeshire (6 million tons and 6-8 million tons); Llandarcy near
Swansea (8*2 million tons); and Killingholme near Grimsby (6-9 million tons).
Other important refineries are located at Belfast, Billingham, Heysham (Lancs.)
and second refineries at Killingholme and at Milford Haven. Stanlow is to
be expanded by 7-5 million tons and Shell Haven by 9 million tons. A new
refinery is under construction at Milford Haven; another is to be built at
Canvey Island, Essex. .
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25-5 million tons in 1954, 4°
million tons in i960 and the peak total of 97 million tons in 1971. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at £211 million in 1971. Imports of refined
products (including liquefied gases) amounted to £233 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth; in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Stanlow and
Heysham. Pipelines also carry refined products to major marketing areas; for
example, from the Humber to the Manchester area, from Fawley to Staines and
Heathrow Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-Thames and
Heathrow Airport. A 245-mile (394-kilometre) pipeline, opened in 1969 feeds
refined products to north London and the Midlands from refineries and
installations on the Thames and Mersey; a similar line 265 miles (426 kilo¬
metres) long from Milford Haven to the Midlands and Manchester is under
construction. Pipelines carrying petrochemical feedstocks run from Stanlow to
Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to Severnside, near Bristol, and
from Teeside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The Pipelines Act 1962 is designed
to secure the orderly development of privately owned industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
INDUSTRY
273
ELECTRICITY
Present
Structure
England and
Wales
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
been a feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were
created as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national
scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board
was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual
power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a public
corporation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands. In 1948
all municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern Ireland)
were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested in the British
Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of Scotland
where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two subsequent Acts
(1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and gave the industry
its present structure. Electricity supply employs about 201,000 people, in¬
cluding 5,900 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate area
electricity boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland
generate and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Development Com¬
mission distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with a
general responsibility for promoting electricity supply and for advising the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry; it is also responsible for a number of
common services, principally capital financing, research and industrial rela¬
tions. The council consists of a chairman and two deputy chairmen, the chair¬
man and two designated members of the CEGB, the chairmen of the 12 area
electricity boards and not more than three other members. The CEGB
controls the operation and maintenance of power stations and the main trans¬
mission system (the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12
area boards. The CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and
between six and eight members. Each of the 12 area electricity boards acquires
bulk supplies of electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution
networks and sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area consultative councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective area boards. The Secretary of State
for Trade and Industry appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members
of the Electricity Council, the CEGB, the area boards and the consultative
councils; approves each board’s capital development programmes and the
industry’s research programme; and approves, in consultation with the
Treasury, the industry’s borrowing requirements.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members, one of whom is the
chairman of the other board. The Secretary of State’s responsibilities in rela¬
tion to the boards are similar to those of the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint Electricity Authority,
set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations has, since 1948, been
purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the Belfast Corporation for
Belfast and district, the Londonderry Development Commission for the City
of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern Ireland.
(A single organisation is to be set up to deal with electricity supply in Northern
Ireland as a whole.)
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. In some areas oil or natural gas would provide cheaper
fuel but the rate of conversion from coal to these fuels is controlled to cushion
its effects both on the balance of payments and on employment of coalminers.
Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively recent, water-power
resources being relatively small and in remote areas. Since 19655 nuclear
energy has become increasingly important.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1971 totalled 60,768 megawatts (MW), an increase
of nearly 50 per cent since 1965.
In the years 1965 to 1971 an annual average of 3,400 MW of generating
capacity was installed, including 4,509 MW in 1970, and 8,300 MW in 1971.
About 10,500 MW of capacity is coming into operation in England and Wales
in the period 1971-73. The SSEB’s plans provide for its total capacity of
5,214 MW at the end of 1970 to be increased to some 7,400 MW by 1973. The
NSHEB capacity of 1,830 MW will be increased to 2,140 MW by 1974.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 1,204 MW, 720 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 4,075 million kilowatt-hours in 1971.
Generation for the public supply in Great Britain reached nearly 230,000
million kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1971; conventional steam power stations
provided 88 per cent of the total and nuclear and hydro-electric stations about
10 per cent and 2 per cent respectively. A high rate of expansion of output has
been a feature of the industry since its earliest years; though the rate has
slackened recently the total of electricity generated in 1971 was still over 30 per
cent higher than in 1965. , . .
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively small
—20,280 million kWh in 1971. The major sources outside the fuel industries
themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and paper industries and the
nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority. . • rp ui q

The electricity authorities take nearly half the British consumption of coal and
about 10 per cent of the consumption of oil. The authorities demand foi these

fuels continues to expand, but at a slower rate than was at one time expected,
because of some temporary slowing down of the growth of demand for elec¬
tricity and because of the increasing thermal efficiency of the generating
stations. This has led to some rephasing of the capital programme.
Oil-fired stations of 2,000 MW have been commissioned at Fawley, on
Southampton Water (one of the most fully automated stations in Europe), and
at Pembroke, South Wales, and another is under construction at Inverkip,
Renfrewshire. A dual-fired station of the same size to burn either coal or oil
has been commissioned at Kingsnorth, Kent, and other stations involving some
4,000 MW of plant have been or are being converted to dual-firing; two can
burn natural gas. An oil-fired station of 3,300 MW is to be built at the Isle of
Grain. Average thermal efficiency (that is, the ratio of the electrical energy out¬
put to the heat energy input of the fuel consumed) of conventional steam
stations in England and Wales rose from 2075 per cent in 1947 to 29-1 per cent
in 1971 as new plant was brought into use. The 20 most efficient stations,
containing much of the newest plant, had an average thermal efficiency of 32-86
per cent in 1970-71.

Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
Forty-seven single-shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 13 stations. By
the end of 1971 40 sets had been installed, of which 36 had been commissioned
at 12 stations. Station capacities are also increasing. By 1973, ten stations,
each with capacities of 2,000 MW, with four 500 MW single-shaft generating
units, will be in service. Sixteen 660 MW single-shaft generating units are on
order for installation: three for Drax (Yorkshire); five for Isle of Grain (Kent);
and two each for four nuclear power stations under construction (for locations
see map, p. 266). Units of 1,300 MW are under construction. In Scotland, a
1,200 MW station at Cockenzie was commissioned in 1968 and one of 2,400
MW (four generating units of 600 MW) at Longannet in 1970. A 1,980 MW
station at Inverkip (three units of 660 MW) is expected to be commissioned in
1975-
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 721 MW of such units and a further 1,200 MW are
planned. Many others of 17 to 35 MW capacity are being used in new stations
276
Hydro-electric
Nuclear Power
Stations
BRITAIN IQ73* AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
to safeguard the auxiliary supplies to the large new steam units, and also to
provide capacity for peak operation. Auxiliary units of this kind in service at
the end of 1971 totalled 1,020 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is at present confined to Scotland and Wales. Most of
the water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked the
beginning of an era of intensive water-power development in the Highlands.
In 1971-72, 2,346 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of March 1972 there
were 54 main hydro-electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,049 MW and the largest—the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW from
four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of *9°7-
Construction of a 300 MW pumped-storage project at Foyers, Loch Ness,
began in November 1969. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-turbines
and is planned for completion in 1974. In addition, there are stations generat¬
ing electricity by water-power in the south of Scotland (123 MW) and in
Wales (469 MW). The latter includes the 360 MW pumped-storage station
at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963. (In pumped-storage schemes
electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to pump water to higher levels
from which it descends at peak periods to operate turbo-generators.)
Some 10 per cent of Britain’s public supply generation was in nuclear power
stations in 1971 and the proportion is expected to rise to about one-sixth by
the mid-1970s. Britain accounts for some 25 per cent of world nuclear
generation. Since 1962 Britain has produced over 200,000 million kWh of
electricity from its nuclear stations, much more than any other country, an
about 47 per cent of the world’s generation of electricity from nuclear sources
(excluding the Soviet Union). < . ,
The Atomic Energy Authority (AEA) has three main stations which produce
electricity for the national grid: the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor (AGR) at
Windscale, Cumberland (14 MW electrical output); the experimental fast
breeder station at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating
Heavy Water Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (too MW).
The former AEA stations Calder Hall, in Cumberland (198 MW) an
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (198 MW) are now owned and operated by
British Nuclear Fuels Ltd. (see p. 277). # . Tt j +L
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 but since twice
modified, nine stations with a total design capacity of 4,500 MW were in
operation in 1971: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW design capacity),
and Brad well, in Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in 1962; Hunter-
ston ‘A’, in Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the following year Hinkley
Point ‘A’, in Somerset, Trawsfynydd, in Wales (both 500 MW), and Dungeness
‘A’ in Kent (550 MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580 MW), was commissioned in
1066; and Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW), in 1968. A ninth station,
Wylfa in Anglesey (1,180 MW), was commissioned in 1971. These stations,
like Calder Hall and Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite-moderate ,
carbon-dioxide cooled, using natural uranium metal fuel elements canned in
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a

further 8,ooo MW of nuclear capacity is planned of which about 6,500 MW
will be commissioned by 1976. The reactor design chosen for the programme
is based on the AGR at Windscale, which uses slightly enriched uranium
dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical development of the magnox
system. The first five AGR stations under construction are Dungeness ‘B’
(1,200 MW), Hinckley Point ‘B’, Hunterston ‘B’, Seaton Carew and Heysham
(each of 1,320 MW capacity). Further stations of about 2,500 MW total
capacity have been planned for at Sizewell. They will produce electricity more
cheaply on base load than the best contemporary coal stations.
A large prototype fast reactor (PFR) of 250 MW capacity is to be commis¬
sioned in 1973 at Dounreay (where in October 1962 the experimental fast reactor
became the first of such type to produce electricity for public use and to operate
at a high power level).
British Nuclear Fuels Ltd. was set up under the Atomic Energy Authority
Act 1970 to take over from the Atomic Energy Authority the manufacture and
reprocessing of nuclear fuels for nuclear reactors in Britain and overseas at
Springfield in Lancashire, Capenhurst in Cheshire and Windscale in Cumber¬
land.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1971 those of the CEGB totalled over 8,700 circuit
miles (14,001 kilometres), of which 6,230 miles (10,026 kilometres) were at
400,000 volts, and 2,500 miles (4,023 kilometres) at 275,000 volts. Primary dis¬
tribution in England and Wales is at 132,000 volts, comprising 11,000 circuit
miles (17,700 kilometres) of lines, with secondary distribution at 33,000 volts,
tertiary at 11,000 volts and general low voltage distribution at 415/240 volts
(standardisation of supply to consumers at 240 volts is almost completed). In
Scotland there were some 4,700 circuit miles (7,600 kilometres) of main trans¬
mission lines at the end of March 1971, of which 1,578 circuit miles (2,539 ^^°"
metres) operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts. Primary
distribution in Scotland is at 33,000 volts. Energy movements on the grid in
England and Wales are controlled through the seven operational areas, set up for
that purpose and distinct from the regions in which the generating side of the
industry is organised; each area has a separate control, and the operations are
co-ordinated by a National Control in London. The grid in Scotland is
operated from the control centres at Pitlochry (NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch
(SSEB).
The development of the grid system has made the British system the largest
fully interconnected power network under unified control in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable of
transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been in
operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1972, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other sources,
such as industrial plants, and the nuclear power stations of the AEA. There
are 18-6 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest users of
electricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting, cooking
and for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other domestic
purposes is rising steadily.

The NSHEB has about 482,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies more than 1 -5 million consumers.
Some 5 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United King¬
dom in 1971 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The industry’s
plans for new capital investment are based on a growth in demand estimated at
an annual average rate of about 5 per cent up to 1977-78.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £249 million in 1956 it rose to £720 million in 1966 but has
since fallen to £500 million in 1971-72. About one-half of the industry’s
capital requirements has been financed from internal resources. The statutory
limit to borrowings by the industry in Great Britain has been raised from
£5,200 million to £7,700 million. The Gas and Electricity Act 1968 empowered
the industry to borrow (long term) from overseas sources.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry, is responsible for drawing up a general programme of research,
comprising direct research carried out by the electricity boards themselves,
supported by co-operative research with selected industrial research associa¬
tions and by research contracts placed with universities and other organisations.
The council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the
Electricity Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the
supply industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power
Engineering Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with nuclear
problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on Southampton
Water. Research on distribution technology and electricity utilisation is under¬
taken at the Electricity Council Research Centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, and
by the area boards.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
SSEB undertakes a wide range of research and development work, both
independently and in conjunction with the universities and manufacturers and,
with the NSHEB, is associated with the activities of the Electricity Council
and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the period
between the two world wars when increasing competition from electricity had
to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a supplier of heating
rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
115,000 people are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 area gas boards. The central body is the Gas
Council, appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry. It is both
INDUSTRY

Distribution
Consumption
Domestic Use
a co-ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading
body. Its general duties are to advise the Secretary of State on questions
affecting the industry and promote the efficient performance of their duties by
the area boards. It also has specific duties relating to finance, labour relations
and research.
The area gas boards, which have a large measure of financial and operational
responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies of the
other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for the local manufacture
of gas and its distribution to consumers. The industry’s structure is about to be
adapted to take account of the change from manufactured to natural gas. A
new British Gas Corporation will come into operation on 1st January 1973, to
be formed from the present Gas Council and to take over the assets of the area
boards, which are to be abolished.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The main single source of gas in Britain is now natural gas, supplied either
directly or as feedstock for town gas manufacture, and accounting for well over
90 per cent of the total demand in 1971.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Five
major gasfields have now been located: Leman Bank, West Sole, Hewett,
Indefatigable and Viking, all now in production. A number of smaller struc¬
tures have also been found and exploration continues.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in York¬
shire, was put on flow early in 1967. Since then further pipelines have been laid
to bring gas to the terminals at Bacton, Norfolk, and Theddlethorpe, Lincoln¬
shire. Supplies of gas are obtained from an on-shore field at Lockton, York¬
shire. Natural gas now accounts for about 5 per cent of total energy consumption.
During 1971 the average daily quantity of natural gas received by the Gas
Council amounted to some 1,800 million cubic feet (51 million cubic metres),
with a maximum daily take of 3,000 million cubic feet (85 million cubic
metres) reached towards the end of the year.
In 1971 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
31-5 million therms, most of it for household use.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. The pipeline system then begun has been expanded to form a
national high-pressure pipeline system for distribution of natural gas derived
mainly from British fields in the North Sea. By March 1972, some 2,000 miles
(3,200 kilometres) of the required 2,500 miles (4,000 kilometres) had been
constructed. The central distribution system is fed from the two shore termi¬
nals by five feeder mains.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising
steadily since 1961, after a period when growth was almost negligible and is
now doing so with increasing rapidity. It rose by 17 per cent in 1970-71, and
by 30-4 per cent in 1971-72. Sales reached a level of nearly 7,490 million therms1
fires and cookers accounting for a further 45 per cent.
About 45 per cent of the domestic load is used for central heating, with gas
fires and cookers accounting for a further 45 per cent.

Gas has traditionally been used extensively in industries which require the
control of temperatures to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery
industry and in certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products.
Natural gas is being used as a chemical feedstock and in bulk fuel markets. In
1971 sales of gas to industry totalled 2,720 million therms; they have risen
sharply since the arrival of natural gas.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the area gas
boards was limited to £250 million. Since then the limit has been raised as
necessary. For the British Gas Corporation (see p. 279) borrowing has been
fixed at £2,500 million, to be raised by order if necessary to £2,700 million.
The Gas and Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow (long
term) from overseas sources.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has
increased sharply. Capital needs over the four years to March 1975 are estima¬
ted at over £1,200 million, of which the largest items are £531 million on bulk
transmission and distribution and £371 million on conversion to natural gas.
About half of the total is to be met from internal resources.
Much of the gas industry’s current research and development effort is
concentrated on transforming the industry from one based on manufactured
gas to one based on indigenous natural gas. In 197° the Gas Council estimated
that the switch over to natural gas in Great Britain would be completed in
seven to eight years.
A phased programme of converting the 30 million gas appliances is in
progress. Some 45 per cent of consumers had had their appliances converted
at the end of March 1972. Investigations are being made into projects in¬
volving various methods of storage of natural gas to meet peak load conditions.
Liquefaction and storage facilities for natural gas have been constructed near
Coatbridge, Scotland, and other facilities are planned.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on research policy
at four research centres. The engineering research station at Killingworth,
Northumberland, has concentrated on large-scale distribution problems.
Research is also done on behalf of the Gas Council at a number of universities
and colleges. Work is being carried out on Gas Council processes for manu¬
facture of substitute natural gas, in which there is wide interest overseas,
especially in areas where natural gas is running short. The Gas Council’s total
expenditure on research amounts to some £5 million a year.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users on the
best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the operation
of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 2nd sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.

WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales lies with the Secre¬
tary of State for the Environment and the Secretary of State for Wales
respectively; in Scotland with the Secretary of State for Scotland; and in
Northern Ireland with the Minister responsible for Development.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
(a well-known social reformer) and his colleagues who demonstrated the
dangers arising from inadequate water supply and sanitation. The Public
Health Act 1848 laid the basis for a long series of statutes dealing with public
health. From the middle of the nineteenth century onwards a number of water
undertakings were set up to provide water to the expanding urban population,
and the water supply system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion
and with some overlapping and waste.
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. The householder receives his domestic
water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different areas, which
he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates, on the value
of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according to actual
metered consumption.
The Secretary of State for the Environment and the Secretary of State for
Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of water supplies
in England and Wales respectively and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies.
The Water Resources Acts 1963 (which came into full operation in April
1965) and 1968 created a new administrative structure consisting of a number
of river authorities and a central Water Resources Board to meet growing
domestic, industrial and farm irrigation needs. The river authorities, including
the Thames Conservancy and the Lee Conservancy Catchment Board which
though bodies of much longer standing have similar functions, have a majority
of members appointed by the county and county borough councils in their
areas. The remainder are appointed by ministers mainly for their knowledge of
land drainage, fisheries, the public water supply and water used in industry
and in agriculture. The authorities manage the water resources of river basins
and carry out other functions in respect of land drainage, flood control,
administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are responsible
for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and developing
resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrange¬
ments exist for the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority
control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by
the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the
282
Proposed
Reorganisation
Present Supplies
Scotland
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Department of the Environment and the Welsh Office. It reviews national
water resources and requirements, encourages the transfer of water between
areas according to need, and initiates research. Since April 1969 water con¬
servation has been financed from charges levied by river authorities on the
licensed abstractors and users of water.
Water supply is at present in the hands of over 1,400 separate bodies, in¬
cluding: 22 river authorities in England, three lying across the Anglo-Welsh
border, and four in Wales; 160 water undertakers providing supplies of piped
water for domestic and other uses; and over 1,200 sewerage authorities, which
are mainly local authorities or in some cases joint boards of local authorities.
There are also nearly 2,000 miles of canals and river navigation administered by
the British Waterways Board (see p. 353).
A major reorganisation of water services in England and Wales was proposed
by the Government in December 1971, following a report of the Central
Advisory Water Committee (see Bibliography p. 479)- The present large
number of bodies involved are to be replaced by ten Regional Water Authori¬
ties, including a Welsh National Water Development Authority, to be brought
into operation in April 1974 at the same time as the new local authorities to be
set up under the prospective reorganisation of local government (see p. 74).
A National Water Council is to replace the Water Resources Board. The
proposals involve the abolition of the British Waterways Board. The new
water authorities’ functions would include, in addition to the major task of
water supply, prevention and control of polluting discharge into rivers and
estuaries; augmentation of river flows through storage schemes; treatment of
water for public use; dealing with sewerage; and ensuring full development
for amenity and recreation of rivers, canals and, where appropriate, reservoirs.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 2,960 million gallons (13,471 thousand
cubic metres) a day, out of a total estimated abstraction of nearly 6,000 million
gallons (26,115 thousand cubic metres) a day (excluding water used for cooling
in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure on water
supply, sewerage and sewage disposal is estimated at £280 million in 1971-72;
an annual increase of 7 per cent in real terms is envisaged.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1971. By
March 1972 schemes costing over £120 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in Scotland
were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which the functions
of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional water boards in
May 1968. The Act also established the Central Scotland Water Development
Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven constituent regional water
boards; it does not supply direct to individual consumers. All the members of
these boards are members of town or county councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and less reliance needs to be placed on underground
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general over¬
sight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conservation of
water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to provide
Northern

Barrages

INDUSTRY ^
supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their districts, where this can be
done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply over 99 per cent of the total
population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of
State on general questions relating to resources and supplies and the organisa¬
tion of the water service. The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act i944>
as amended, makes available to Scottish regional water boards and to local
authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of £60 million towards the cost
of water supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Distribution is the responsibility of local authorities,
some of which have combined to form joint boards. About 90 per cent of the
population has a piped supply and some 100 million gallons are supplied daily.
Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern Ireland) 1945 the
Ministry of Development may pay grants towards the cost of water schemes.
Since 1945 over £80 million has been invested, of which over ^40 million
was government grants. It is proposed that the Ministry of Development,
already responsible for water conservation and pollution control, will take over
from local authorities, in April 1973, responsibility for water supply and sewer¬
age services.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number
of rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is
responsible for the collation and publication of hydrological information: the
fieldwork of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water under¬
takings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of water in
specified areas have been published in the series of hydrological surveys which
cover approximately half of England and Wales. General information on rain¬
fall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the responsibility of the Meteoro¬
logical Office, while advice on ground water is the responsibility of the Water
Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station of the Department of
the Environment at Wallingford and the Water Research Association’s station
at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the design and calibration
of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of surface water, and into
other hydraulic problems.
Barrage projects involve dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake
of fresh water, and studies have been carried out for several estuaries in
Britain. A report on a study for Morecambe Bay, Lancashire, published early
in 1972, put forward several suggested schemes, including a barrage and storage
reservoirs. A full feasibility study of the use of pumped storage artificial reser¬
voirs in the Wash has been authorised.
Each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of rivers and
certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before polluting
effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames is exercised
by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland there are nine river purification
boards. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised by the Scottish River
Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting the cleanliness of
Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies co-operate in the
prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.

Structure
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Government’s aim is to improve the quality of water in all the main rivers
by the early 1980s. According to the River Pollution Survey (see Bibliography
p. 479) much progress has already been made in diminishing river pollution
in recent years.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment and
disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and prevention
of pollution of surface water and underground water.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction, altera¬
tion, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage and
sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence works,
electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal prospect¬
ing and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and hydro¬
electric power stations and telecommunications. About 1 -5 million people are
engaged on construction in both the public and private sectors. They repre¬
sent nearly 6-2 per cent of the total civilian labour force and their net output
provides about 11 per cent of the gross national product.
The construction industry is changing to metric from Imperial weights and
measures. Nearly all design work in the public sector is now fully metricated.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities which employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 72,500 firms in the industry,
about a quarter of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the scale
are nearly 200 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 296,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance, valued
at over ^1,430 million annually. The total labour force includes about 661,000
skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under the
industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 87,000 are employed as appren¬
tices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Department of the Environment (see p. 15) is responsible for the
construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government (except for
health and education projects), including work for the armed services, both at
home and overseas. The Department is also responsible for co-ordinating
research and development throughout the government service and seeks to
influence methods and techniques in the building industry as a whole. A
Property Services Agency was set up within the Department in September
1972 to deal with the Government’s property and building functions.

The output of the industry has been rising steadily over many years. The
value of work done in 1971 amounted to £5,435 million, of which £846
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £4,588
million (£3,668 million on new work and £920 million on repair work).
About 358,200 houses were started in 1971 and some 364,400 were completed,
of which 196,000 were for private owners. Of the £1,245 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £667 million, or over half, was
for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Industrialised
building methods employing prefabricated components are used in much of
the work.
The National Building Agency is an independent advisory body, managed
by a board of directors appointed by the Department of the Environment and
the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and at present financed by a
government grant and the fees which it earns. Fee income has increased
rapidly, and the grant is to end by April 1974. Its main function is to encourage
the adoption of advanced methods of house building, and to provide technical
advice and services to government departments, local authorities and other
clients.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1972 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power
stations (see p. 275), dams and reservoirs, hospitals, large-scale housing
developments, such as the Thamesmead (London) project to house 60,000
people, a £10 million office and shop development in Victoria Street, London,
and a £15 million scheme to extend the London underground railway system
to London Airport (Heathrow). Projects for road construction, bridges and
tunnels included about 159 miles (256 kilometres) of motorways under con¬
struction in England alone (see p. 347), and the £28 million second Mersey
Tunnel scheme of which the first of two tunnels was opened in 1971.
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
A British firm acts as consultant to the World Bank on the Indus Basin
irrigation scheme, the largest in the world, and several firms were involved in
the design of the Mangla Dam, Pakistan, which forms part of it. Other design
projects included: a deep-water port at Limassol, Cyprus; irrigation schemes in
Indonesia and Iraq; and road works in Iran and Fiji.
Among important construction projects being undertaken by British con¬
tractors in overseas countries during 1972 were: an underground power station
in Zambia adjacent to the Kariba dam; road schemes in many areas; an £11
million irrigation scheme in Romania; and several airport projects in the

Middle East. A British company is helping to build the ^14 million Bosphorus
bridge.
The value of new overseas contracts obtained by British construction firms,
in a large number of different countries, has been running at about £300
million over each of the last three years. A substantial and growing amount of
overseas business is also being done by British architects and surveyors, as
well as by other types of consultant. British members of the Association of
Consulting Engineers had projects worth about ^2,778 million in hand on 1st
January 1972.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Department of
the Environment (Construction Industries) is responsible for co-ordinating
research and information services to increase efficiency in the building
industry. The Building Research Establishment (see p. 181) which forms part
of the Department was originally set up in 1921 (as the Building Research
Station), thus making Britain the pioneer of organised building research, and
is concerned with all aspects of building. It provides a technical advisory service
for construction firms. An Agrement Board, set up by the Government, tests
and certifies new products and methods.
The Construction Industry Research Association carries on research affect¬
ing all sections of the industry.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by over
one-quarter since 1963, although in 1971 it was marginally lower than the pre¬
vious year; output per head advanced by 3-3 per cent in 1971 bringing the
rise since 1963 to 31 per cent. In 1971 this sector spent £1,503 million on
fixed capital equipment (at 1963 prices), 73 per cent of which was spent on
plant and machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry
(including the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and
other causes, but excluding employers and the self-employed) was 8-6 million
in June 1971, 32 per cent of the total number of employees.
The employment and production figures listed in Table 29 give an indica¬
tion of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly marked in those industries utilising advanced
technologies such as electronics, the newer branches of mechanical engineer¬
ing, instrument engineering, most sectors of the chemical industry and man¬
made fibres.
In the subsequent sections, employment statistics refer to numbers at June
1971, export figures are taken mainly from the Overseas Frade Statistics of the
United Kingdom, and the company populations of various industries are taken
from the Census of Production 1963.
The metal manufacturing industries employ 558,100 persons. Of these, 315,300
are in the iron and steel industry, 105,200 in the manufacture of iron castings,

Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s fifth
largest steel producing nation.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public super¬
vision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public ownership
13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent of Britain’s
crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in the industry.
Their shares and securities were vested in July 1967 in the British Steel
Corporation (BSC), whose specific duties include promoting the efficient and
economic supply of iron and steel products, exports and research and develop¬
ment; it is also statutorily responsible for the finances of the nationalised
industry. Since March 1970, the BSC has been organised on the basis of six
product divisions, four covering iron and steelmaking and two covering
288
Iron Castings
Non-ferrous
Metals
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
constructional engineering and chemicals. The private sector includes some
200 companies accounting for about one-third of the value of the industry’s
sales. Plans for rationalising the boundary between the public and private
sectors were announced by the Government in June 1971.
Output of crude steel in 1971 totalled 23-8 million ingot tons, 13 per cent less
than in 1970 (adjusted for comparison to a 52-week basis); the fall reflected lower
industrial investment and the running down of stocks by the industry’s do¬
mestic customers and stockholders. Pig iron production in 1971 totalled 15-2
million tons. Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 20-3 million tons in
1971. The 5 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported were
worth £402-5 million; the United States (£79-2 million), India (£31-5
million) and Spain (£21-9 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: Wales (33 per cent of total crude steel
output); Yorkshire and Humberside (24 per cent); Northern (16 per cent);
and Scotland (12 per cent). Wales concentrates mainly on the manufacture
of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the output of the north-east
coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel products (plates, sections
and rails), but a wide strip mill for sheet production is also in operation in
Scotland. Production of special alloy and stainless steels is centred on Sheffield,
while Scunthorpe concentrates on heavy and medium products.
Since i960 fixed capital expenditure has totalled some £1,500 million,
reaching £230 million in 1961, due mainly to the strip mill expansion pro¬
gramme. Expenditure in 1971 amounted to £237 million, the largest single
project being the major new steelmaking and finishing complex at Scunthorpe,
which will cost some £230 million by 1973. Between i960 and 1971, steel
production by the converter processes increased from 8 per cent of output to
almost 40 per cent; by electric furnaces from 7 per cent to 18 per cent; while
the share from older open hearth processes fell from 84 per cent to 42 per cent.
The emphasis in recent years has been on improving efficiency rather than
raising total capacity and Britain has some of the most modern plant in Europe.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
a new large-scale basic-oxygen steelmaking plant at Port Talbot with two
converters linked with a deep-water harbour, and a basic-oxygen plant at
Lackenby on Teesside.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, reflecting
increased average size and improvements in efficiency, such as better prepara¬
tion of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of higher
blast temperatures. Industry-wide research and development is carried out by
the Corporate Laboratories of the BSC. Total annual expenditure by the
industry is about £12-5 million.
Some 850 foundries are engaged in the production of iron castings. Output
of castings in 1971—3-29 million tons—was 11 per cent less than in 1970-
The main users of iron castings are the motor vehicle industry, accounting for
nearly one-third of the total tonnage sold and about one-half of the industry’s
turnover, the general engineering industry, the manufacturers of pressure
pipes and fittings, the building and associated industries and the steel industry.
Exports are included in the total for iron and steel in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among Western countries. Output in 1971 included: aluminium, 118,000 metric
tons of virgin metal and 181,200 metric tons of unwrought alloys; refined cop-
INDUSTRY
MECHANICAL

Agricultural
