289
per, 49,200 tons of virgin copper and 138,000 tons of secondary metal; lead,
142,600 tons of secondary metal refined from scrap and 150,400 tons of virgin
lead refined from imported lead bullion; zinc, 116,400 tons of slab metal; and
tin, 21,500 tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the small-scale working of
tin; three mines are operating in Cornwall, and the possibility of reopening
several more is being evaluated. Selective grants to encourage exploration for
a range of minerals in Britain have been introduced by the Government.
In 1971 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at £298 million.
The main products exported, including alloys and semi-finished products,
were copper (£93-5 million), nickel (^57-i million), aluminium (£27-1
million) and lead (^18-9 million). The Federal Republic of Germany (£39'8
million), the United States (£32-2 million), and Switzerland (£22-4 million)
were the largest purchasing countries. Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres in¬
clude south Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth, where one of the
world’s largest zinc smelters (capacity 120,000 tons a year) was opened in
1968. Firms are engaged in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling,
extrusion and drawing and the techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure
diecasting are also employed.
Two of the three major aluminium smelters whose construction was
approved by the Government in 1968 are now operational. When the three
smelters are in full production by 1974 they will provide over half of Britain’s
requirements for aluminium.
Britain is also a major producer of the newer specialised metals including
uranium, zirconium and beryllium for the nuclear energy industry; niobium
for aircraft production; and selenium, silicon, germanium and tantalum for
electronic apparatus. Scientific and technological research for the industry as a
whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering, employing some 1 -2 million people, comprises a
family of industries including all types of machinery, machine tools, industrial
engines, mechanical handling equipment, construction equipment, industrial
plant, and ordnance and small arms. Vehicle engines are included in the section
on vehicles (p. 295). The volume of production from these industries rose by
35 per cent between 1963 and 1971. The aggregate value of the main products
of all sections other than small arms was about £3,450 million in 1971.
Exports of non-electric machinery were valued at £1,945 million in 1971,
18-5 per cent up on the previous year.
There are some 400 firms, employing 30,000 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including six large firms employing well over 1,500
workers. In 1971 deliveries were valued at £66-5 million and exports were
worth £38-8 million; the main overseas markets were the Republic of Ireland,
France, the Netherlands, the United States and Denmark.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1971 included 3,905 combine harvesters, 3,912 milking machines,
9,600 pick-up balers and 786 grain and grass driers.
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to electronically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Almost 4,000
290 BRITAIN I973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Department of Trade and Industry, is assisting the
industry in various ways, including a pre-production order scheme, numerical
control advisory services and the placing of research and development
contracts.
The pattern of machine tool production is highly cyclical; deliveries in 1971
were valued at £190 million, including numerically controlled tools worth
^18-8 million. Exports of complete machines in 1971 had a value of £97‘3
million, 10-8 per cent up on 1970, and of the orders on hand at the end of 1971
(£96 million), 56 per cent were for export; Australia (£9-4 million), the
Federal Republic of Germany (£8-5 million), France (£7-8 million) and Italy
(£6-3 million) were the main overseas markets in 1971. Seven of the industry’s
200 or so companies provide over half of total deliveries, although because of
the high degree of specialisation small firms are numerically predominant.
Centred mainly in London, the Midlands, Yorkshire and Lancashire, the
industry employs about 90,000 people.
The Machine Tool Trades Association is the representative body of most
manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the International Machine
Tool Exhibition held in Britain every four years, the next being due in 1976.
The industry is served by its own research body, the Machine Tool Industry
Research Association.
Pumps, Valves
and
Compressors
Industrial pumps and valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are
vital components in many industrial processes particularly in the chemicals,
oil and electric power industries. The total work force is some 80,000 and
there are 450 companies of which ten employ more than 1,000 people. In 1971
deliveries of pumps and valves were valued at £213-6 million and those of air
and gas compressors and fluid power equipment at £60 million and £55
million respectively. Exports of all types of equipment were worth £133-6
million.
Industrial

Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of internal
combustion engines (including parts) had a value of £146 million in 1971
and exports (including parts and marine engines) were worth £85-j million.
The total brake horse-power of the 263,000 internal combustion engines
delivered was 12-5 million, ranging in size from under 3 b.h.p. to over 4,000
b.h.p. Production is concentrated among the large firms in the industry, and a
total of 30,000 people are employed.
The textile machinery industry, one of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical
engineering trades, produces machines and accessories for the manufacture
and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of natural and man-made
fibres. In 1971, the industry’s exports (,£129-7 million) accounted for roughly
two-thirds of total deliveries. Principal markets were the United States (£16-3
million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£8-3 million), South Africa and
France (£5-6 million each). Comprising about 500 firms—four of which
account for more than one-quarter of total output—the industry has some
47,000 employees and is situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern
Ireland, Dundee, Leicester and Nottingham.
Construction and Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
Earth-moving produced, including crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers, dozer
Equipment equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing, pulveris¬
ing and screening plant. The labour force numbers 44,600.

The value of deliveries from the industry was £250 million in 1971 of which
£161 million was for export; earth-moving machinery accounted for 80 per
cent of total deliveries. France, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany
and South Africa are important markets.
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment, which
extends from individual units and accessories to complete operating systems.
The value of deliveries in 1971 was some £250 million, the main products
being cranes and bridge transporters, lifts, escalators, conveyors, elevators,
hoists and powered industrial trucks. Exports of mechanical handling equip¬
ment (including industrial and works trucks) in 1971 were valued at j£ioi-i
million, 31 per cent more than in 1970. There are some 500 firms in the industry,
four-fifths of which have fewer than 100 employees; the labour force totals
68,500.
The office machinery industry comprises some 70 firms, 11 of which account
for about three-quarters of total output. Deliveries have been expanding
rapidly and in 1971 were valued at ^108-8 million (excluding computers and
copiers). Deliveries in 1971 included 393,000 standard and portable typewriters.
Deliveries of accounting and similar machinery were valued at ^S1’1 m^on
and other office machinery at £26-3 million. Exports of all office machinery
(including electronic computers and data processing equipment) were valued
at £179-6 million. The most important overseas purchasers were France
(£24-4 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£24 million) and the United
States (£16-1 million). British subsidiaries or associates of overseas firms are
prominent in some sectors of the industry. There are 56,800 persons employed.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork and in 1971 the aggregate value of equipment deliveries was £780
million, of which £216 million was for overseas markets. Of particular impor¬
tance are chemical and oil refining (process) plant, steam-raising boilers,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, lime and cement kilns,
nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and fabricated steelwork
for bridges, buildings, and industrial installations, The industry, comprising
both equipment manufacturers and plant contractors, has many large-scale
enterprises, including nine with over 2,000 workers, and in all employs 196,400
people.
British companies delivered shell boilers and other boilerhouse plant to the
value of £46-7 million in 1971. Water tube boilers of advanced design and of
large steam-raising capacity are produced for power stations, whereas shell
boilers are used for steam-raising and heating in factories and buildings.
Exports of steam generating boilers in 1971 amounted to £12-9 million, and of
boilerhouse plant to £10-2 million.
The steelworks plant industry, in association with firms producing rolling
mills, provides almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1971 was £30-6 million. This industry consists of a
small number of firms, which often collaborate or form temporary consortia
to carry out particular projects. Finland, South Africa, Canada and Brazil
are a few of the countries in which British firms have undertaken major plant
projects.

The design, engineering, construction and commissioning of complete process
plants for the chemical, petrochemical, oil refining and gas industries has
expanded rapidly in recent years. There are now 30 process plant contracting
groups in Britain, half of which are United States subsidiaries. In 1971
expenditure on plant in Britain by the process industries amounted to ^178
million and export contracts were worth an additional £100 million.
Two major consortia, consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
were formed in 1968 to build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom
electricity authorities (see p. 276). These replaced the three groups formed
in 1959. The Atomic Energy Authority grants them non-exclusive manu¬
facturing licences and is working in close collaboration with them in research
and development.
A wide range of specialised equipment for industrial plant is produced.
Deliveries in 1971, valued at some 3^119-4 million, included distillation
columns, heat exchangers, lime and cement kilns, refuse disposal equipment
and water treatment plant. Exports amounted to £29-i million in 1971.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in the preceding
section there are about 2,200 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery (deliveries worth £95-3 million in 1971); printing, bookbinding
and paper goods machinery (£59-2 million); non-domestic refrigerating
machinery (^41-7 million); space-heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment (£95-8 million); food and drink machinery (^54-7 million); and
miscellaneous machinery (some ^400 million). There are some 274,000
workers employed in these industries.
Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are about 5,000 enterprises, employing 241,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting, fabricating and repair work.
(Some enterprises are included because the mixed character of their work pre¬
cludes their classification under any single industry.) The sector includes
ten large undertakings with more than 2,000 employees. Ball and roller bear¬
ings, and chains, are important products; exports of the former were valued
at j£27-i million in 1971 and exporters of chains at ^9-3 million.
With a product range extending from scientific instruments to photographic
equipment and timepieces, instrument engineering is the fastest growing
sector of the engineering industry. Aggregate output was valued in 1971 at
some £385 million and has increased, in volume terms, by 60 per cent since
1963. In all, some 157,000 people are employed in this sector.
The scientific and industrial instruments industry has a labour force number-
ing 97,500. Deliveries of scientific instruments in 1971—some £247 million
—comprised: optical instruments, ^14 million; electronic instruments £132
million; and non-electronic instruments (3^101 million).
Exports of scientific instruments have risen from ^27-9 million in i960 to
3^78-8 million in 1971. The Sira Institute conducts research on behalf of the
industry.

INDUSTRY ^
Deliveries of photographic, cinematographic and document copying equip¬
ment in 1971 totalled ^7i'2 million, including ^5°'7 million for export.
The present industry has largely developed since the 1940s. It employs 13,900
people, the majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are located on
new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in Scotland.
Output in 1971 included watches (^6-6 million), clocks million) and
time recorders and parking meters (^i'4 million); export sales, including paits,
were valued at £ i4'4 million.
The electrical engineering industry, with a labour force of 880,500, is engaged
in the manufacture and installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment,
including all types of generating, transmission and distribution equipment;
motors; telecommunications and broadcasting apparatus; specialised labora¬
tory and electronic equipment; and domestic appliances. The volume of output
rose by 55 per cent between 1963 and I971’ an^ total value of production
in 1971 was estimated at over £2,goo million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1971 were
valued at £648 million, 12 per cent more than in 1970. Products are exported
to all parts of the world; in 1971 South Africa (£48 million), the United States
(£39 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (^37-1 million), Australia
(^33-8 million) and the Netherlands (^28-1 million) were the main markets.
The industry’s leading representative organisation is the British Electrical
and Allied Manufacturers’ Association; industry-wide scientific and techno¬
logical research is carried out by the Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today.
In 1971 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at ^477 rnillion,
comprising £98 million worth of generating equipment, £55 million worth
of transformers, 3^191 million worth of switchgear and control gear and
£132 million worth of other electrical machinery, including electric motors.
Exporters of electric power machinery (generators, motors, converters, trans¬
formers and rectifiers) amounted to ^92‘4 milh°n in I97I> ma^n purchasers
being Canada (£8-9 million), South Africa (£8-3 million) and Australia (£7-9
million). Switchgear, starting and control gear exports were valued at £69-4
million.
Almost 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, but recent mergers
have led to the creation of one of the leading electrical engineering groups in
Europe, while a number of smaller firms have been reorganised into larger
units. The total labour force numbers 169,500. Manufacture takes place in
many areas, including Birmingham, Manchester, Rugby, Tyneside, Stafford
and Larne (Northern Ireland).
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its products
include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of materials.
It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output of electric
2Q4 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
power in Britain (see p. 274). The value of deliveries in 1971 was £338 million.
Exports of electric cables, wires, and similar products, were worth £51'7
million; the main purchasers were Hong Kong and South Africa. Most of the
industry’s labour force of 50,000 are employed in five major groups.

and Domestic
Electrical

Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1971 included domestic electrical
appliances, ^250 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles and air¬
craft, ^126 million; batteries and accumulators, £90 million; electric lamps,
^55 million; and miscellaneous electrical goods, £153 million. In terms of
volume, deliveries included: 1-4 million electric blankets, 2-2 million vacuum
cleaners, 1 - i million domestic washing machines and 2-2 million electric irons.
In 1971 exports of domestic electrical equipment were valued at £50-3 million,
including washing machines and parts (^13'7 million), space heating equip¬
ment (^12-7 million) and vacuum cleaners (£7-5 million); the main markets
were the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany. Exports of
batteries and accumulators in 1971 were valued at £20-3 million. The industry
has a labour force of 209,000.
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, which made amplifica¬
tion possible, the development of radar, the first public transmission television
service, and the ‘printed circuit’, which has led to far-reaching changes in the
radio industry. Total deliveries in 1971, valued at £1,380 million, were 12-6 per
cent up on 1970; export deliveries totalled £330 million. The industry employs
447,000 people.
Capital Equipment Deliveries of electronic capital equipment in 1971 were valued at £629 million
(40 per cent of total output), including £234 million for export. (Indirect exports
incorporated in ships, aircraft and machinery are considerable.) Computers
are the most important item of capital equipment; Britain has the largest
indigenous computer industry outside the United States and has supplied over
one-half of domestic computer installations. A single British group is respon¬
sible for most domestic output. Total deliveries, which have more than doubled
in the last three years, were valued at £193 million in 1971 and exports at £90
million.
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valued at £112 million in
1971, over six times the i960 level, and almost half of total output was
exported. Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use
British equipment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American
continent. All-weather landing systems, inertial (automatic) navigation systems
and marine radar based on solid-state electronics are among recent develop¬
ments. Other important items of capital equipment include electronic control
equipment (£89 million), radio communications equipment (£68 million) and
electronic measuring and testing equipment (£49 million).
Components Deliveries of components (£264 million in 1971) comprised active components
at £122 million and passive components at £142 million. The industry’s
increasing emphasis on miniaturisation has led to the replacement of conven¬
tional valves by transistors, and, more recently, to the evolution of solid-state
and microcircuit technology.
Consumer Goods The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets, radiograms and tape recorders. The industry is dominated by several

852,000 colour television sets); the total sales value of .£180 million was almost
all in the home market. Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1 -6
million in 1971 and total sales were worth £20 million. Deliveries of tape
recorders amounted to over 250,000 worth nearly £5 million.
Only a part of the telecommunications industry is concerned with electronic
equipment, but it is normally considered as a sector of the electronics industry.
Britain is a major exporter of telegraph and telephone equipment with overseas
sales valued in 1971 at £56 million. Research and development work is done
by firms in the industry in co-operation with the Post Office. The industry
employs 92,700 people, and three firms are responsible for almost all the out¬
put.
The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft are an important
source of overseas earnings; exports of transport equipment in 1971, valued
at £1,273 million, formed almost 14 per cent of total exports. The labour force
numbers 993,000 and includes: 498,000 in motor vehicle manufacture,
213,000 in aerospace construction and repairing, 190,000 in shipbuilding and
marine engineering, 50,000 in the manufacture of locomotives and railway
wagons and carriages, 20,000 in wheeled tractor manufacturing and 22,000 in
the making of cycles and motor cycles.
In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the
manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles.
At one time located mainly in the Midlands and the London area, the in¬
dustry, during the last decade, has built manufacturing and assembly plants on
Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms—
British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Chrysler United Kingdom and
Vauxhall—which account for over 99 per cent of complete vehicle production;
the balance is in the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy commercial
vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade
association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT),
which holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor
Exhibition every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association carries
out collective research on vehicles and components.
Output of passenger cars in 1971 totalled 1-74 million units, compared with
1-64 million units in 1970. Exports in 1971 amounted to 725,000 cars valued
at £373 million. The United States (£87 million) was again the largest single
purchaser, followed by Belgium (£25-3 million), New Zealand and Canada.
About one-fifth (by value) of all exports went to EFT A member countries
and one-seventh to the EEC.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis (146,000 in 1946), totalled
456,000 in 1971, marginally less than in 1970. Exports in 1971 of new com¬
mercial vehicles (including chassis) numbered 206,000 worth £241 million.
South Africa (£33 million), Australia (£16 million), Nigeria and New Zealand
were the main markets. Since 1961 Britain has been one of the world’s largest
exporters of commercial vehicles. The prototype of a gas-turbine-powered
commercial vehicle is being evaluated.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles, including
bodies, chassis and engines, had a value of some £365 million in 1971;
caravan and trailer exports totalled £26 million.

The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 150,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1971, 117,000 (77 per cent) for export. In addition, some 12,000 small market
garden tractors were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying
tractors were valued at £136-8 million in 19715 South Africa (£i3‘3 miUior0>
Finland (£7-5 million) and the United States (£7-1 million) were the main
buyers. Production is dominated by two large organisations. Britain has one of
the heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 320).
Sales of bicycles amounted in 19711° 1 ‘8 million. Most of British manufactui-
ing capacity is in the hands of a single group of companies concentrated in the
Nottingham area. About 1 million cycles worth £14-1 million were sent over¬
seas in 1971; the United States (£6-4 million) was the largest single market.
Sales of motor cycles in 1971 amounted to 82,500. Manufacture is dominated by
one large group. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled £ 19 ‘2 million in 1971 >
with the United States (£11-4 million) much the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for export.
The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1971 was £17-2
million; South Africa, Canada and India were the largest purchasers.
In terms of sales to final buyers, the output of the aerospace industry in 1971
was valued at some £700 million; about one-half of this was accounted for by
complete aircraft and airframe parts, about 36 per cent by engines and parts
and some 11 per cent by guided weapons and space activities. The most notable
turbo-prop aircraft in current production and operation is the Hawker Siddeley
748, of which over 265 have been sold or are on order. A second generation of
jet airliners, the medium-haul Trident, the longer-haul Vickers VC10, and the
B AC One-Eleven, the world’s first jet transport designed to operate economically
on short-haul routes, have been in service for over seven years. Other civil
aircraft in production include the HS125 executive jet, the Skyvan all-purpose
light transport and the Islander, an economical feeder-line aircraft. Flight
trials of the Concorde, the world’s first supersonic airliner, developed jointly
by Britain and France, are in progress. _
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft, including the
Jaguar, in collaboration with France, and the Harrier vertical take-off strike
aircraft, 60 of which have been ordered for the United States Marine Corps.
Britain, the Federal Republic of Germany and Italy are jointly developing a
supersonic multi-role combat aircraft (MRCA) to meet the needs of their air
forces during the late 1970s and 1980s. The industry is producing or has under
development about 17 types of guided missile for use by the armed services
of Britain and several overseas countries. Its space activities include sounding
rockets, scientific and communications satellites and work on the United States
programme to develop a space shuttle craft.
Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. Almost 500 had been built in Britain
up to 1971 and a number of types, including a 170-ton version, the SRN 4, are
in production or under development. Designs for craft of 300-500 tons are
being considered.
In 1971 exports of the aerospace industry totalled £324 million, 21 per cent

more than in 1970. Exports of new aircraft and parts in 1971 (excluding
electrical equipment) had a value of ^158-3 million. Leading buyers included
the United States (^27-5 million) and France. In addition, exports of instru¬
ments were worth £11-5 million, and tyres ^1-4 million.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern; outside these groups are a few important
smaller companies. Besides extensive research work by the industry, research
on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out
by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the
National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal
Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. The industry has over 50 collaborative
agreements with overseas governments and companies.
Exports of aero-engines and parts have provided well over £1,100 million in
overseas earnings since 1946, and in 1971 were valued at £135-8 million: major
customers were the United States (£44 million), France (£20-7 million) and
the Federal Republic of Germany (£10-2 million). Thirteen different types of
British jet engines power over 30 types of aircraft currently in production
overseas. Famous engines include the economical Dart turbo-prop, the Spey
turbo-jet, the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off and
landing (VTOL) aircraft, and the Olympus, the power plant for the Concorde.
Almost all of Britain’s aero-engine manufacture is in the hands of Rolls-
Royce (1971) Ltd., a publicly owned company, to which the essential assets of
Rolls-Royce Ltd. were transferred in May 1971. The latter had encountered
severe financial difficulties in its contract to supply RB211 advanced technology
engines to the United States Lockheed Lion airbus. Development and pro¬
duction of the engines is proceeding under a revised contract negotiated
between Rolls-Royce (1971) Ltd. and Lockheed.
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts and harbour craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters on the
river Tyne.
Since the publication in 1966 of the report of the Shipbuilding Enquiry
Committee, many British shipyards have embarked on programmes of
modernisation and reorganisation. In many cases this has been facilitated by
assistance from the Shipbuilding Industry Board (SIB) which was in operation
from 1967 to 1971. Shipyard modernisation has been paralleled by major
structural changes. A series of mergers has led to the creation of two major
groups on Clydeside (one of which has been reorganised following its liquida¬
tion), three in north-east England, one in eastern Scotland and one in southern
England. Together with one group in Belfast—where the world’s largest
building dock is now operational—they accounted in 1971 for almost nine-
tenths by gross tonnage of the industry’s new orders for merchant vessels.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1-5 million gross tons
was halted in 1964, and launchings in 1971 totalled 1-24 million gross tons,
1,560 tons above the 1970 level. British launchings were the fourth largest in
the world in 1971 accounting for 4-7 per cent of the world total. Fourteen oil
tankers, totalling 368,600 gross tons, were launched in 1971. Launchings also
included 15 bulk carriers totalling 467,100 gross tons and 32 cargo ships

amounting to 296,000 gross tons. At the end of 197* orders on hand for mer¬
chant vessels of over 100 gross tons were 256 (336 in 1970) totalling 4-4 million
gross tons with a value of £678 million. Of these vessels, 59 (17 million gross

There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the larger
shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-fifth of ship-repairing
activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England. Repair yards and
dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm designs large low-speed diesel engines
and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of the
highest powers are also built.
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 604,200
in 1971; the main groups were engineers’ small tools and gauges (71,100
persons), bolts, nuts and screws (43,800), wire and wire manufactures
(41,400), cans and metal boxes (34,100), jewellery, plate, and the refining of
precious metals (16,900), hand tools and implements (20,400), cutlery (17,100),
and other metal industries (359,400). The total value of exports in 1971 was
about £110 million.
The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry, deliveries having doubled in value since i960. Totalling ^130
million in 1971, they included jigs and fixtures (£24 million), press tools,
moulds, etc. (£23 million), hard metal-tipped tools (£18 million) and other
metal cutting tools (£58 million). Export deliveries in 1971 totalled ^27
million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms are mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1971 was million,
including export sales of ^4-5 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, south
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1971 was £27 million, of which £3 million were sales for
export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades,
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was ^52'^ million in i97I> which ^17 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at ^49 million and ^16 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.

Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1971 was ^38-4
million, of which £7-9 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 458,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: general chemicals (132,000 employees), pharmaceutical chemicals
and preparations (77,000), toilet preparations (24,000), paint (32,000), soap
and detergents (20,000), synthetic resins, plastics materials and synthetic
rubber (58,000), dyestuffs and pigments (27,000), fertilisers (13,000), and other
chemical products (79,000). The industry is capital intensive, its fixed capital
expenditure, excluding mineral oil refining, amounting to almost £ 1,880
million during the eight years 1963-70, and totalling £365 million in 1971. A
significant proportion of this investment has been devoted to sectors with the
fastest changing technologies, notably petrochemicals and plastics. The value
of exports in 1971 was £885 million, or 9-6 per cent of total British exports.
Production in the general chemicals industries rose by 53 per cent between
1963 and 1971.
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 3 -4 million tons were produced in 1971. The remaining output of
this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About one-
sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 67 per cent between 1963 and 1971. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1971 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for over four-fifths of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 6 million
tons in 1971 compared with 0-3 million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1971 were ethylene (1-04 million metric tons) and
propylene (506,000 metric tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are
plastics materials, solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents.
Production of dyestuffs is geared primarily to demand by the textile industry;
about 28,600 tons of synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1971.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to .£231 - 6 million in
1971. Major purchasers were: the Netherlands (^34 million), the United
States (£21-2 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£12-5 million) and
France (j£n 7 million).
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expendi¬
ture totalled some £12 million in 1971.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir

Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently, the
isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several semi¬

pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas films.
In 1971 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products and goods rose
by 20 per cent to ^168 ’4 million, of which ^ 17 ■ 1 million worth were antibiotics.
The largest purchasers were Nigeria (£io-$ million), and the Republic of

The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has doubled since 1963 and total produc¬
tion in 1971 was 1-4 million tons including i-i million tons of thermoplastic
resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PVC and used for a wide
range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene (a cheap
non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many consumer
goods). One of the newer thermoplastic materials is polypropylene, which can
be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres. A new family of plastics materials
reinforced with carbon fibres is now in commercial production in Britain, they
are up to three times the strength but only half the weight of steel. Rapid
expansion of capacity for all the main types of plastics materials is planned.
Exports in 1971 amounted to about 575,000 tons, valued at ^160 million.
The main purchasers were Australia (£13 million), South Africa (£12-6
million), Sweden (£10-8 million) and the United States (£8-g million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 195^’ High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1971 amounted to 272,500
tons, most of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex were worth £22-2
million in 1971.
The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Production is
dominated by three firms and there are a number of firms marketing compound
fertilisers from the principal constituents—nitrogen, phosphorus and potas¬
sium. To encourage use, home sales are assisted by government subsidies to
farmers (see p. 322). Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen
content) has been increasing and in 1970-71 totalled 736,000 tons, while
531,000 tons (in terms of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were
produced; production of compound fertilisers amounted to 3 million tons in
1970-71. The use of ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium
phosphate, and, to a limited extent, urea (mostly 45 Per cen^ nitrogen) is
resulting in more concentrated fertilisers. The value of exports of manufactured
fertilisers, mainly nitrogenous, was £3‘6 million in 1971.

Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were provisionally
valued at £43 million in 1971, 10 per cent higher than in 1970; herbicides (£26
million) were the largest single category. Exports of insecticides, fungicides
and disinfectants in 1971 totalled £327 million.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1971 amounted to some 116
million gallons (including 26 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at £187
million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world; exports of
pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1971 amounted to ^46-6
million. Indirect exports in the form of surface coatings for finished goods are
considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, including
new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments, quick-drying paints and paints
needing only one application.
Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £154 million in 1971, including
export sales of j£23'9 million; home market sales of hair preparations totalled
about £37 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw materials
used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in detergents; the
other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic sources.
Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 468,000 tons in 1971, including
75,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 260,000 tons. Sales
of polishes in 1971 were valued at ^19 million, including floor and furniture
polishes worth £10 million. Exports of perfumery and toilet preparations, soap
and associated products were valued at £72-2 million.
Radioisotopes are processed and marketed by the Radiochemical Centre at
Amersham, now part of the Atomic Energy Authority (see p. 399). In the year
ended March 1971 sales of radioisotopes totalled ^4-5 million, of which over a
half was exported.
In recent years, the boundaries between the various fibre based sectors of the
textile industry have become indistinct and considerable vertical integration
has taken place, connected with the rapidly developing technology of man¬
made fibres. Large multi-fibre, multi-process groups have been formed, four
of which now control the bulk of spinning and warp knitting.
The industry has a labour force of 612,000, half of whom are women;
42,000 are engaged in the production of man-made fibres, 76,000 in the spin¬
ning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made fibres, 57,000 in the weaving
of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 123,000 in the woollen and worsted
trades, 123,000 in hosiery and knitted goods, 54,000 in textile finishing and
42,000 in carpets. The total value of textile exports in 1971 was £426 million.
Production of textiles rose by 0-3 per cent in 1971 and was 25 per cent higher
than in 1963. The industry’s main research body is the Cotton, Silk and Man¬
made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost competi¬
tion has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit was placed
on imports of cotton goods from most countries during 1966-70 and in 1972.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Output in 1971 consisted of: 234 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 184
million lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 187 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 213 million lb. of textured yarn, 611 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 525 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
mixture cloth. In 1971 exports of cotton yarn (excluding man-made fibres)
were worth ^io-i million, exports of woven cotton fabrics were valued at £25-i
million, with Zaire and the Republic of Ireland the most important markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool the chief port of entry for
raw cotton.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized
business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the west
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1971 output included 146 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 288
million lb. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted and semi-worsted yarn
amounted to 205 million lb. and of woven fabrics to 222 million square yards.
In addition, large, but declining, quantities of raw wool are scoured and
cleaned in Britain. Consumption of raw wool in 1971 was 311 million lb.
Exports in 1971 included wool yarns (£23-3 million), woollen fabrics (£37-8
million) and wool worsted fabrics (^21 -8 million). The main buyers of woollen
and worsted fabrics were Japan (j£n-6 million), the Federal Republic of
Germany and Hong Kong. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other
animal hair and tops exported had a value of ^34‘3 million. Research is carried
on mainly by the Wool Industries Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1971 total of 1,352
million lb. being 88 per cent more than in 1963. Output consisted of 742
million lb. of staple fibre and 609 million lb. of filament yarn in I971- Of
staple fibre, 366 million lb., and of the continuous filament, 422 million lb.,
were of fully synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1971 totalled 455 million lb. The
world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (north Wales), with an
annual output of over 250 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby and Preston. Almost all the rayon produced in Britain is made by a
single company and its subsidiaries.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity for nylon in Britain has increased
from 160 million lb. a year in 1964’ almost 325 milli°n lb- at the end of
1971.

Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second world
war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with wool.
Annual manufacturing capacity totals over 200 million lb. A group of fibres
of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British discovery)
and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex fibres, which are
man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch and recovery,
are now produced commercially.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of £75-y million in 1971, and
woven fabrics £21 million. The United States, Switzerland, Sweden and
Portugal were the most important purchasers of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. Although widely distributed, the industry is centred in the east
Midlands, the north-west of England and in Scotland. Sales of knitted goods
were valued at £421 million in 1971 including ^152 million worth of outer¬
wear and £99 million worth of socks and stockings. Sales of knitted fabrics
were worth £113 million in 1971. Exports of knitted or crocheted clothing
and accessories were valued at £51-2 million in 1971; the largest buyers were
the United States, Switzerland and the Republic of Ireland. Exports of knitted
and crocheted fabrics amounted to £54-4 million. The Hosiery and Allied
Trades Research Association, with laboratories at Nottingham, undertakes
collective research.
The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns and the lighter
types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of coarse linens and
canvas, although household types are also produced. Northern Ireland manu¬
facturers produced 22-2 million linear yards of cloth in 1971, while weavers in
Great Britain delivered 20-7 million square yards, including 12-3 million square
yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1971 included £6-4 million worth of
linen fabrics and ^4-2 million worth of flax yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and some 10,500 people are employed in all. Jute
is used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of applications in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and
motor car industries.
New uses for jute, as a plastics reinforcement for example, have been deve¬
loped. In 1971, 76,400 tons of raw jute were used, and exports of jute fabric and
yarn totalled £i‘j million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to £11-2 million in 1971. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at j£6-i million. Exports were worth £3-4 million in 1971.
In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor cover¬
ings other than carpets. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other
synthetic materials were valued at £36-6 million in 1971; just under one-sixth
was for export. The cordage industry is one of the largest in Europe. Exports
of ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1971 were valued at £47 million.

Almost 150 enterprises are engaged in the manufacture of carpets and rugs,
including several large groups. Total sales in 1971 amounted to some 145
million square yards worth about £200 million. Almost half of the volume of
sales is accounted for by tufted carpets, in the production of which the pile,
usually with a high man-made fibre content, is inserted into a per-woven
backing; woven carpets, such as Axminster and Wilton make up most of the
remainder of sales, and form about one-third of the value of exports ^43'5
million in 1971. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster
(in Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern Ireland.
About one-quarter of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made pre¬
dominantly of wool and a growing proportion of traditional woven carpets
contain some man-made fibre.
There are 513,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 366,000 are in the clothing industry, 96,000 in the footwear trade and
51,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1971 was £200 million.
The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 17 per cent since 1963. Exports in 1971,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at £57 million; Switzerland (£7-2
million) was the main purchaser. Substantial quantities of clothing are also
sent by parcel post. _ .
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry. The Clothing Export Council, representing some 300 companies,
organises promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1970 some 11,300 tons
of sole and other heavy leather and in 1971 about 415 million square feet of
upper, lining and other light leathers were produced. Exports in 1971 were
valued at £34-2 million. The United States (£77 million) is the largest single
market, followed by Canada (^4-5 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands an
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. Collective research is
carried out by the British Leather Manufacturers’ Research Association.
The British footwear industry is among the largest in the world. In 1971
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 186 million pairs. Exports of a
types had a value of ^36-3 million; the United States (£67 million), the
Soviet Union and Canada were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on pro¬
duction of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region of
Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on womens and girls
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.

The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 828,000 people in the pro¬
duction of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports in
1971 was £550 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for ^262 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £37-4 million; cereal
and cereal preparations for £38-5 million; fruit and vegetables for ^25-5
million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for ^48-9 million.
Many of the industry’s leading firms have been involved in mergers in
recent years.
The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 4 oz. (1-02 kg) per head per week in 1971. The trend is heavily towards
concentrating production in large mechanical bakeries; well over two-thirds
of the bread is made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped
loaves; four groups have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries produc¬
tion of cakes and other flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production.
There are 145,000 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry
and a further 33,000 in grain-milling.
There are 47,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 590,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 11-3 oz. (0-32 kg.) in 1971. British biscuits have
gained a world-wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restric¬
tions in several overseas markets, exports in 1971 were valued at ^13-7 million.
The cocoa, chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 81,000
employees, is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and
many medium-sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the
industry are sugar, cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of
chocolate and sugar confectionery was 698,000 tons in 1971. Consumption of
chocolate and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is among the
highest in the world, being equivalent to 7-7 oz. (0-22 kg.) per head per week.
The value of exports in 1971 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was ^24-2 million and of sugar confectionery, £21 -4 million. The United States
and Canada were the main markets for sugar preparations. An estimated 30
per cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Fruit and vegetable products include canned, frozen and dried fruit and vege¬
tables, jam, marmalade and pickles. The labour force numbers 65,000. Output
of jams and marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000
tons in 1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 172,000 tons in 1971.
Strawberry, raspberry, apricot and blackcurrant jams are the most popular.
Exports of jams and marmalade in 1971 were valued at ^2-7 million.
In 1971, 777,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Beans in tomato sauce (262,000 tons) and
processed and fresh peas (225,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand as
canned products. In addition, output in 1971 included 78,000 tons of canned
and bottled fruit. Strawberries, plums and rhubarb are the most important
fruits used for canning, followed by fruit salad, prunes and gooseberries. Sales
of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Nearly 207,000 tons of vegetables (of which peas accounted for 38 per cent)
and 1,000 tons of fruit were processed by quick freezing in 1971.

The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and pre¬
serving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the pre¬
paration of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 113,000. Output of
canned meat and canned meat products in 1971 totalled 132,000 tons, and the
quantity of bacon and ham cured was 287,000 tons. Quick-frozen fish output
amounted to some 101,000 tons in 1971; small quantities (10,000 tons in 1971)
are also canned. Exports of fish and fish preparations had a value of £26-8
million in 1971 and those of meat and meat products were worth £23-4
million.
The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 155,000.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) totalled 70 million proof
gallons with a value of £227 million in 1971; almost half went to the United
States (^112 million). Scotch whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century.
It is blended from 20 or more different types, some from malted barley and
some from other grains. Whisky requires several years to mature, and the
148 million proof gallons of Scotch whisky produced in the 1971 distilling
year will not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky amount to more than
800 million proof gallons, representing 10 years’ consumption. About four-
fifths of annual sales are to overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of 3^i2,6 million in ip?1.
There are 90,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. Recent
mergers have led to the creation of a few major brewery groups, marketing
their products throughout the country. In 1971, 34'7 million bulk barrels of
beer were produced, the highest since 1920, and consumers’ expenditure on
beer amounted to £1,416 million. Exports in 1971 of malt beer were 446,000
bulk barrels, worth £6 million. Firms have introduced new production
methods, including continuous brewing processes, and automated batch pro¬
duction plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1971 amounted
to 93,000 tons, worth £5-7 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be seasonal. Output in 1971 included 70 million gallons of
concentrated liquid, and 274 million gallons of unconcentrated drinks. Though
there has been some amalgamation in recent years, there are still several
hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two very large firms
among about 20 producing widely advertised brands which are marketed on a
national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by firms in the pro¬
duction of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based drinks, squashes
and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted drinks (in which the
whole fruit is used).
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other tobacco
goods sold in Britain. In 1971 consumers’ expenditure on these goods

amounted to £1,692 million (of which about two-thirds was tax revenue) and,
in addition, exports worth £41 -4 million (of which cigarettes accounted for
86 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas markets; Saudi Arabia,
the Netherlands and Belgium were the most important. The main centres of
production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London, Manchester,
Newcastle, Nottingham, Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest manufacturing
groups account for over 90 per cent of total output. The industry has 38,000
employees.
The tobacco industry used 288-5 million lb. (130-8 million kg.) of un¬
manufactured tobacco in 1971, all of which was imported. In 1971 the main
sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consumption of
tobacco in Britain in 1971 amounted to 236-8 million lb. (107-4 million kilos),
including 204-1 million lb. (92-5 million kg.) consumed in cigarettes, 26-3
million lb. (11-9 million kg.) in pipe and hand rolling tobacco and 6 million
lb. (2-7 million kg.) in cigars. In 1971 122,400 million cigarettes were con¬
sumed, 5,500 million less than in the previous year; 80 per cent of the total
were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 324,000 which includes 56,000 in
the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 80,000 in the glass industry
and 57,000 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabrica¬
tion to highly mechanised systems. In 1971 about 6,540 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 40 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use.
The pottery industry, supplying almost all home needs for domestic and
industrial pottery, is a long-established and complex industry, largely located
in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material is
indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall.
Domestic pottery, including china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rock¬
ingham, accounts for about half of the industry’s output; the other main
divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and such specialised
industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics and laboratory
porcelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of British pottery are
Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton, Minton, Coalport and
Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery were £68-7 million in 1971
including record export sales of £32-4 million; the United States and Canada
are the leading markets.
There has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns
have replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns, and new decorating techniques
and automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Glass
Britain’s glass industry is one of the largest in the world. The section of the
3°8
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.
Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of £48'6
million in 1971. Those of glass were worth ^27-5 million, the most important
markets being Australia, the United States and South Africa. The figure
included ^97 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
Cement The cement industry of the United Kingdom, with 16,000 employees, is chiefly
concerned with the manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph
Aspdin and patented in 1824, this material and the methods of its production
have been the subject of continuous technical improvement and intensive
research. The capacity of the industry has expanded substantially in recent
years. The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing
area. Output totalled 17-9 million tons in 1971.
PAPER, PRINTING The paper, printing and publishing industries have 630,700 employees,
AND PUBLISHING inciucpng 82,400 in the manufacture of paper and board, 81,600 in the
production of packaging materials, 101,600 in the printing and publishing of
newspapers and periodicals, and 258,000 in other types of printing and
publishing.
Paper and The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
Board 1678, but records show that some paper was produced as long ago as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the second largest in Europe. Total
production in 1971 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-2 million
tons. Of this, newsprint accounted for 581,000 tons and other printing and
writing papers for almost 900,00 tons; 1-08 million tons was board and the
remainder was made up chiefly of wrapping papers, industrial and special
purpose papers and tissues. Exports of paper and board reached a new iccord
level of over £60 million in 1971 and exports of manufactured paper items
were valued at £36 million. The main purchasers were the Republic of Ire¬
land, Australia, South Africa and Sweden.
Total sales of household paper products, including facial tissues, have risen
sharply to £64 million. In 1971, sales of cardboard boxes and cartons were
valued at £153 million while those of fibreboard packing cases totalled ^159
million; sales of manufactured stationery amounted to £182 million in 1971.
Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by two firms; a recent development
has been the introduction of plastics and plastics-coated wall coverings.
The main raw materials are woodpulp and waste paper. Woodpulp pro¬
duced in the UK is of increasing importance although it still represents only
a small percentage of total supplies (almost 600,000 tons per annum of home¬
grown pulpwood are used in its manufacture). The amount of waste paper

There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada, other parts
of the Commonwealth and Europe.
Research is undertaken by The Research Association for the Paper and
Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Three large firms each employ more than 20,000 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Book publishers’ turnover in 1970 is estimated at ^154 million, of which
export sales accounted for £68 million. Consumers’ expenditure on books,
newspapers and magazines totalled almost ^460 million in 1970. Book titles
published in 1971 totalled nearly 33,500, over 9,000 of them new ones.
Popularity of paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years.
Exports of printed matter, manuscripts and typescripts were valued at
^104-3 million in 1971, including books and pamphlets (£,S9'5 million), and
newspapers and periodicals million), but these figures do not include
parcel post shipments, which are possibly as large again as the recorded totals.
The United States, Australia and Canada are the most important overseas
markets. The Book Development Council, formed in 1965, promotes the
supply and use of British books overseas. Firms have introduced the latest
developments in high-speed printing equipment, including electronic engrav¬
ing machines and advanced processes of photographic reproduction, and
several newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
290,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 120,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures employs some 218,000 including 103,000 in
plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
output of the industry but firms also make a variety of goods, the most
important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting, cables, hose, latex foam
products and other vehicle components and accessories.
In 1971 the industry’s consumption of rubber totalled 452,400 tons, com¬
prising 174,000 tons of natural rubber, 258,000 tons of synthetic rubber and
20,400 tons of reclaimed rubber; the proportion of synthetic rubber used is
increasing. In 1971, 250,000 tons of rubber were used in the production of
tyres and tyre products. Tyre manufacturers include several subsidiaries of
United States and other overseas companies. The largest tyre group in Europe
came into being in January 1971, following the merger of Britain’s leading
tyre producing company and its Italian equivalent. Direct export of rubber
and rubber manufactures in 1971 were worth £103-6 million, with Sweden,
the United States and Australia as the main markets. This figure included

London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is important for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 30 per cent in volume between 1963
and 1971, and in the latter year their value was £224 million. Exports of all
furniture were worth ^30-2 million in 1971. Numerous enterprises manu¬
facture furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office, school
and other furniture) and the labour force numbers 89,000. The bedding indus¬
try employs 22,000 people; sales of new bedding in 1971 were valued at ^4^'7
million. Many firms are small but in recent years there has been a tendency
towards concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research Associa¬
tion. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the industry
and produces an annual statistical and economic review.
The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1971 was £28’9 million, of which ^3 '6 million was for export.
The timber industry employs 103,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £245 million in 1971) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber together with the output of home-grown pit-
wood totalled about 75 million cubic feet in 1971. Other products include
plywood and chipboard.
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
and children’s carriages in Britain is 46,000. Sales of toys and children s
carriages in 1971 were worth j£ioo million and exports had a value of £45
million. The Federal Republic of Germany and the United States were the
main overseas markets. Current trends are towards increased production of
dolls and soft toys, including those linked to television characters.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £8-3 million and that of
sports equipment ^28 million.

Size of Farms
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for nearly half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest
and most important industries. It occupies 651,000 people or 2-5 per cent of the
total working population, provides about 2-8 per cent of the gross national
product, and uses 47 million of the 60 million acres (19 million of the 24
million hectares) of land.
In 1973 Britain will adopt the Common Agricultural Policy of the European
Economic Community (EEC) subject to agreed modifications and transitional
arrangements (see p. 463).
The soils of the country are very varied (see p. 5). Land used for farming is
conventionally divided into land suitable for cultivation (crops and grass) and
rough grazing. In hill country the area of cultivated land is often small, but is
usually supplemented by grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
In the United Kingdom as a whole there are 30 million acres (12-2 million
hectares) under crops and grass. Cultivated land, rough grazing, woodlands
(ancillary to farming) and other land used for agriculture together represent
79 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain and forest, or put to urban
and kindred uses. The area available for farming is gradually decreasing to
meet the needs of housing and industry; so far, the loss has been offset by the
increase in output from what remains. The ratio of rough grazing—used for
stock, mainly sheep—to better quality agricultural land varies considerably
throughout Britain. In the southern half of England, for example, it constitutes
only about one-sixth of the total acreage but is as high as three-quarters in hill
areas such as Wales and Scotland.
There are about 303,000 significant farming units in Britain. Some 45 per cent
are very small units, mostly farmed part-time, and accounting for less than a
tenth of the industry’s total output. About half of the total output comes from
the 12 per cent of holdings classified as large farm businesses, capable of employ¬
ing four or more full-time men. There are estimated to be some 168,000 full¬
time farm businesses in Britain including about 5 5,000 medium-sized (two-three
men) and 76,000 small businesses. The number is falling by about 2 per cent
a year.
The average size of full-time holdings in Great Britain is 250 acres (100
hectares) of crops and grass. In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about
62,000 holdings, almost all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of
these holdings are either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops
or grazing), so that the number of effective farm businesses is about 36,000 of
which about half provide a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical farm
size is between 40 and 70 acres (16 and 28 hectares).
