Grassland
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Since the second world war the old concept of a general or mixed farm has
largely disappeared. There has been an increasing use of intensive methods of
production both in crops and animal husbandry and a tendency towards
greater specialisation as a means of maximising production. In England the
farms devoted primarily to arable crops are in the eastern part of the country—
in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire. In
Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast are also primarily arable. Potato
and vegetable growing on a substantial scale marks the farming of the Fens
(south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire), the alluvial areas around the rivers
Thames and Humber and the peaty lands in south Lancashire. Elsewhere,
horticultural crops are widely dispersed amongst agricultural crops.
Dairying and the rearing and fattening of beef cattle are widely followed,
predominantly in Scotland and western districts of England where the wetter
climate encourages the growth of good grass. The parts of England bordering
the Pennine hills and most of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good
deal of dairying, based on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there.
In Northern Ireland mixed farming is practised, the most important being
milk, fat and store cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill
areas. Oats and barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the
only important cash crop is potatoes.
The increase in production which has occurred over the past decades is a
result of the effort of individual farmers, of farmers’ organisations, of research
workers and advisers and of government action. The role of the Government
is described on pp. 320-23.
The steady expansion in production and in yield per acre of arable land which
has taken place since 1936 is summarised in Table 30. Apart from a slight
decline between 1961 and 1964 and another in 1968 total cattle stocks have
risen steadily each year since 1953. The milk-producing herd has been fairly
constant in size since i960. The beef herd is expanding steadily. Numbers of
sheep and lambs reached their highest level in 1966. They have since declined
appreciably but some expansion is now evident again. Numbers of pigs have
increased by over two-fifths during the past decade and those of poultry by
nearly one-third. Arable production has shown a greater diversification since
the second world war. Total cereals production has increased considerably
since i960 reaching a record of nearly 15 million tons in 1971-72- Potato pro¬
duction is very susceptible to weather conditions but on average adequate
supplies are being maintained from a steadily declining area. Between i960
and 1971 output of pigmeat increased by nearly two-fifths and eggs by about
one-twentieth and these, together with the increase in beef and milk output,
resulted in higher consumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources.
Between 5 and 6 million tons of concentrated feeds are imported each year
depending on the size of the home crop of cereals.
The index of agricultural net product (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. Based on the average of 1954-55 to 1956-57=100, it was an
average of 136 in 1964—65 to 1966—67. On a re-based index (all commercially
significant holdings), 1964-65 to 1966-67=100, 116 is forecast for 1971-72.
The British climate suits grassland farming, especially in the moister west and
north. Even in the regions devoted largely to arable cropping, grassland forms
an important section of the economy of most farms, whether as permanent
grass mostly occupying land less suitable for cultivation, or as sown grassland

BRITAIN 1973' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
(leys), often part of the arable rotation. A wide range of herbage species and
varieties are used.
Grassland production has been greatly enhanced over recent years by the
development and application of new techniques, notably the use of fertilisers
(especially nitrogenous), methods of grazing control, systems of herbage con¬
servation for winter feed and, on some farms, irrigation.
Rough grazings remain as semi-natural grassland used for extensively grazed
flocks and herds, producing young animals for fattening elsewhere.
Crops
Cereals
Fodder Crops
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Wheat is grown mainly in the eastern half of the country. About 47 million
tons were harvested in 1971, with average yields estimated at 35 cwt. per acre
(4-4 tonnes per hectare). Between one-third and one-half of the wheat crop
is used for flour milling, the remainder going mainly for animal feed.
Since 1961 the area under barley has increased by nearly 50 per cent and
in general production has risen faster due to improved yields. The malting
and distilling market currently absorbs about one-fifth of the crop.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also often
used on a co-operative basis.
In Great Britain the total area of fodder crops has fallen because in many
cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically by increased grass
production and improved methods of conservation. The principal fodder crops
are beans and kale in England and turnips and swedes in Scotland.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire under contract to the
British Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices
and also provides technical advice and assistance. More than three-quarters
of the crop is mechanically harvested.
Potatoes are grown in most parts of Britain. First supplies of early potatoes
normally come from Pembrokeshire, Cornwall and Kent at the end of May.
The lifting of main crop potatoes usually starts in September; the mam area
being the eastern side of the country. Seed potato production for Britain and
for export is chiefly centred in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
Britain is normally self-sufficient in main-crop potatoes. As yields are
gradually increasing, requirements can be met from a steadily declining acre¬
age. The area planted with potatoes has declined from 829,000 acres (335,000
hectares) in i960 to 634,000 acres (257,000 hectares) in 1971. A record yield of
11-i tons an acre for the 1971 crop resulted in a substantial surplus of supplies.
The growth of convenience foods has led to an increased demand for processed
potato; home production is expanding to meet the demand but some 18 ir^“
ported. Although potato production is becoming increasingly mechanised,
much hand labour is still needed.
Dairy Farming
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average consump¬
tion of liquid milk per head is 4-5 pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by
about 11 per cent and now average some 853 gallons a year. Freedom from
tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and a campaign to eradicate brucellosis
is under way. It is estimated that about two-thirds of Britain s total cattle are
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 315
bred by artificial insemination (AI) through AI centres operated by the Milk
Marketing Boards and other organisations. The Friesian breed is dominant in
the dairy herds of England, Wales and Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the
Ayrshire breed is the most numerous. Av erage herd size is 31 cows. Milk
production has been stimulated by advances in grassland management,
intensive grazing techniques and new methods of making high quality hay
and silage. Most dairy farmers practise some degree of intensive grass manage¬
ment, but hay or silage of the traditional type supplemented with purchased
concentrates remain the basic winter feeds.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards are prescribed by
regulations made by the appropriate ministers.
Livestock A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. Substantial sales of animals and semen are made to
overseas buyers seeking to replenish and improve their herds and flocks.
British breeds have recently been joined by continental breeds, such as the
Charolais, Limousin, Simmental, Maine Anjou and Blonde d’Aquitaine, in the
hope that these will, in due course, make a useful contribution to the British
livestock industry.
Beef Cattle In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the Galloway
and Welsh Black breeds and their crosses; in marginal land and lower areas
the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus and Hereford breeds.
About two-thirds of home-fed beef production derives from the dairy herds,
some females being mated to beef sires. There is a large and complex trade
in store cattle (increased by animals imported from the Republic of Ireland),
a typical movement being from the upland west to grazing areas in the
Midlands. The demand for lean tender beef at an economic price has stimu¬
lated the development of intensive and semi-intensive systems of production.
Sheep Britain has a long tradition of sheep production. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a particular area. Research has provided vaccine and sera protection
against nearly all the epidemic diseases.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages; first, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity. Fat lamb production provides the
main source of income for sheep farmers but wool is also of considerable
importance, especially to farmers in hill areas.
Pigs Pig production is carried on in most parts of Britain but is particularly
important in the eastern and southern counties of England and in Northern
Ireland. There is an increasing concentration into specialist units and larger
herds. The most frequently used breeds are the Large White and the Landrace
though considerable cross-breeding takes place. Pig improvements are fostered
through research by the Meat and Livestock Commission and by leading
commercial firms. Attention is focused on the size and weight of litters, and
on food consumed per pound of liveweight gain. AI is available nationally.

Horticultural
Industry
Fruit
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In terms of pig meat, about 30 per cent is used for bacon and 70 per cent for
pork and manufacturing into sausages and other processed forms.
The British poultry industry has expanded rapidly in recent years, largely
owing to the application of improved husbandry and management techniques
in intensive production units and to genetic improvements in stock. There are
about 80 flocks of over 100,000 birds and only a small proportion of total
production is in the hands of the smallest producers. About 85 per cent of the
laying birds on farms are in flocks of 1,000 or more. The average yield of eggs
per bird is well over 220 a year and nearly all eggs consumed in Britain are
home-produced. About 320 million broilers and other special table chickens
were produced in I971-
The horticultural industry produces a wide variety of fruit, vegetables and
flower crops which are together worth about ten per cent of the total from
agriculture as a whole—an estimated £282 million in 1971-72 out of a total of
£2,790 million.
At the June 1971 census the land on which these crops were grown amounted
to nearly 690,000 acres (280,000 hectares), some 2^ per cent of the land used
for crops and grass in Britain. Of crops in the open, fruit accounted for 197,000
acres (80,000 hectares), vegetables, excluding potatoes, for 451,000 acres
(182,000 hectares), and flowers, bulbs and nursery stock for 35,000 acres
(14,000 hectares). Crops under glass, including mushrooms, occupied 5,000
acres (2,000 hectares).
Horticultural crops are largely grown on specialised holdings where soil,
climate, skilled labour and water can produce maximum yields of high quality
crops and where access to markets or good roads enable them to be sold at
economic prices. With the exception of small growers producing crops for
direct local sales most horticultural enterprises are getting larger with the help
of improved planting material, new techniques of cultivation and environ¬
mental control and the widespread use of machinery. Some horticultural crops
form parts of general farm rotations but the returns from increasing specialisa¬
tion favour separate horticultural enterprises. Traditional market gardening
which once flourished around the large centres of population has declined over
the years, mainly due to the growth in the field-scale production of vegetables
which has accelerated to meet the demands of the processing industries.
Of the dozen or so kinds of fruit grown for sale in Britain dessert apples are
the most important. These are grown in Kent and neighbouring counties in
south-east England, in East Anglia and to the north and south of Bristol.
Recent plantings are largely of the autumn and winter variety of Cox’s Orange
Pippin; many of the new orchards consist of closely planted dwarf trees which
can be efficiently pruned, sprayed and picked. England and Northern Ireland
are among the few countries which grow varieties of apples which are used
especially for cooking, the best-known of which is Bramley s Seedling.
Varieties of cider apples are grown mainly in Devon, Herefordshire and
Somerset. # . .
Although pears thrive best in the warmer Continental climate, in the east
and south-east of England where somewhat similar conditions prevail the
Conference pear and a few high quality varieties are produced. Cherries and
plums are grown in Kent, and plums also in the Vale of Evesham and parts of
East Anglia. . . ,
Of the small fruit, blackcurrants are widely grown in Britain, mainly tor
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
317
the preparation of juice for the manufacture of soft drinks and flavours for
confectionery. There is a larger concentration of raspberry plantations around
Perth in Scotland than anywhere else in the world. The pattern of strawberry
production is of early cropping in May and June in the areas of south Hamp¬
shire and the Cheddar and Tamar Valleys. There are large areas of main crop
strawberries in Kent and East Anglia. Other fruits include gooseberries, red
and white currants, loganberries and blackberries. Almost all the nuts con¬
sumed in Britain are imported but a few cob nuts and filberts are still grown
in parts of Kent.
Hops for flavouring the beer which is a national drink in Britain are grown in
Kent and three counties to the west, and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire.
Much of the glasshouse sector of the horticultural industry has been re¬
equipped since the mid-1960s with the aid of grants under the Horticultural
Improvement Scheme and there are now, in many parts of the country, large
units with automatic control of light, heat, ventilation, water and the carbon
dioxide content of the atmosphere. The tomato is the most important glass¬
house crop and is either grown as a single crop or in rotation with others.
There is an increasing demand for lettuce at all times of the year, and for
sweet peppers and aubergines, two crops which were formerly hardly grown
or consumed in Britain. Cucumbers are extensively grown in the traditional
glasshouse area in the Lee Valley to the north of London. Mushrooms, with
an estimated farm-gate value of over £15 million in 1970-71, are grown in
specially constructed sheds in several parts of the country.
A wide range of trees, shrubs, herbaceous and alpine plants, once produced for
local sale only, are now sent long distances through the postal services. Many
nurseries concentrate on the production of popular plants in containers for
sale through the garden centres which have been established on the outskirts
of many towns.
The bulb fields of Holland in Lincolnshire are very popular with visitors by
coach and car. Britain now produces more daffodils than any other country,
on some 6,500 acres (2,630 hectares) in Lincolnshire and Norfolk, and in the
east of Scotland, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly where more than 50 per cent
of the cultivable land is devoted to bulbs which flower there from November
to May.
Vegetables and outdoor salad crops are still grown in the traditional areas of
the Thames Valley, north Kent, Vale of Evesham, south Lancashire and the
West Riding of Yorkshire, but many are also grown on soils and in climates
most suited to their production. West Cornwall, south Devon, Pembrokeshire
and Kent send winter cauliflowers and spring cabbage to most urban markets
while much of the summer and autumn cauliflower comes from the intensive
horticultural holdings in Lincolnshire. Most of the carrots are grown on light
soils in Norfolk and Cambridgeshire. Brussels sprouts are grown extensively
in Bedfordshire; their production has also extended from the Vale of Evesham
into Gloucestershire and well up the east coast of England wherever freezing
factories are sited for the processing of fish as well as vegetables. Peas and
dwarf beans are now largely sold frozen, canned or dried and are also therefore
grown close to factories in the east of England and further north in Scotland.
Celery is mainly grown on the deep soils of south east Lancashire and the fens
of Cambridgeshire and neighbouring counties. Watercress, a salad crop
demanding a supply of pure water of uniform year-round temperature is grown

have led to increased consumption of high protein foods. More recently the

Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 33). In June 1970 the scope of the agricultural census was widened
to cover holdings producing commercially significant quantities of agricultural
produce on one acre or less of agricultural land, previously excluded in Great
Britain. On the old basis the aggregate net income of farmers rose from ^392
million in 1960-61 to £561-5 million in 1969-70. Net income on the new basis
for 1970-71 is £611 million, rising to 3^668 million in 1971-72. The figures
given in Table 33 show that Britain’s farming is predominantly based on live¬
stock enterprises. Over two-thirds of total farm output is in the form of live¬
stock or livestock products.

Of farm expenses, purchased feedingstuffs amount to about one-third,
wages to about one-fifth and machinery (including depreciation) and equip¬
ment to about one-sixth. Since i960 male agricultural earnings have risen by
about 90 per cent, offsetting the manpower economies made possible by
mechanisation and increasing farm size, while labour productivity has risen
by about 6 per cent a year since 1964-65.
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.

Mechanisation

THE ROLE
OF THE
GOVERNMENT
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In 1971 ‘fixed capital’ totalling £139 million was added to the value of land
and buildings and £118 million was invested in new plant, machinery and
vehicles. The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms is pro¬
vided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of outside
capital, both fixed and working; about two-thirds of the total bank advances
to agriculture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural mer¬
chants are also an important source of short-term credit. Mortgage loans form
the chief source of long-term credit and are provided by specialised financial
institutions (see p. 323) and private sources.
Accounts of some 3,500 farms in Britain, collected by agricultural economists
in 1971, show average valuations of occupiers’ capital ranging from about £2
per acre (£7-4 per hectare) on hill farms with extensive rough grazings to over
£So per acre (^197-7 per hectare) on some lowland farms. On all types of
farms investment in machinery is a heavy item: on dairy and arable farms it
averages nearly £20 per acre (^50 per hectare); on stock-rearing farms it may
amount to £7 per acre (£18 per hectare).
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with 500,000
tractors in 1971 or one to every 35 acres (14-2 hectares) of arable land. Power-
take-off implements now characterise arable farming; and some 66,000
combine harvesters were in use in 1971. A wide variety of machines for
harvesting and preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are
installed on all except the smallest farms.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,700 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment with¬
out tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying
with the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types is mostly within
the range of £5 to £20 per acre (£12 to £50 per hectare) with the exception
of pig and poultry farms and horticultural holdings, which are more intensive
in their use of land. Net income per acre on dairy and arable farms has nearly
always been higher than on stock-rearing farms, which are generally larger
than the other types and are situated on poorer land.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretary of State for
Wales, for Scotland the Secretary of State for Scotland, and for Northern
Ireland the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, local aspects being the
responsibility of the Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture. In England
and Wales, the Agricultural Advisory Council and the Horticultural Advisory
Council advise the Minister on the experimental, development and advisory
functions of the Ministry.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food operates through func¬
tional divisions. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly
through its local offices, grouped in England in regions, with regional man¬
agers. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Secretary with similar
functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
321
Government
Policy
Annual Review
In 1966 an Economic Development Committee for agriculture was estab¬
lished, comprising representatives of farmers, workers and landowners, as well
as official and independent members.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
Commission (see p. 324) and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the
conservation and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple¬
menting agricultural policy. It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry
of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, for which it acts as agent in the administra¬
tion in Northern Ireland of United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In 1973 the main task of the agricultural departments will be to introduce
the EEC system of price support for the different commodities. An Inter¬
vention Board for Agricultural Produce will be set up to administer the
arrangements under the control of the agricultural ministers who will retain
responsibility for agricultural policy.
The main objective of government policy is to maintain a stable and efficient
agricultural industry capable of producing such part of the nation’s food and
other agricultural produce as in the national interest it is desirable to produce
in the United Kingdom, and of producing it at minimum prices consistent with
proper remuneration and living conditions for farmers and workers in agricul¬
ture and an adequate return on capital invested in the industry. To this end,
the Government is empowered to provide, for the main agricultural products,
guaranteed prices determined in the light of annual reviews (see below).
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers to
introduce minimum import prices and levy arrangements for agricultural and
horticultural products. Before 1971 these powers were used in the case of
cereals and for eggs and certain egg products. The basic method of agricultural
support is, however, being changed from a guaranteed price to an import levy
system with the aim of reducing the cost to the Exchequer of agricultural
support by transferring more of it to the consumer. In July 1971 import levy
schemes were introduced for beef, veal and milk products other than butter
and cheese. At the same time import duties were imposed on mutton and lamb
and the existing scheme for cereals was modified. On 1st February 1973, when
Britain adopts the common agricultural policy of the EEC which is based on
variable import levies together with support buying, production subsidies and
export refunds, Britain’s import levy schemes will end, but the system of
guaranteed prices and deficiency payments will continue for the time being.
In February each year, the agricultural ministers review the economic con¬
dition and prospects of the industry.
The ministers are required to consult with representatives of agricultural
producers—in practice, the three farmers’ unions in Britain—and they consider
such factors as production trends and market requirements, world market
prospects, the cost of subsidies, income trend in the industry as a whole, the
increasing efficiency of the industry and changes in production costs. The
ministers then determine guaranteed prices for the coming year for fat cattle,
fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs, wool, milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet.
The cost of government support to the industry in 1971-72 was about
£339 million; the estimate for 1972-73, including the 1972 review decisions,
forecast an increase to about £389 million.
322
Price
Guarantees
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In general, the present support system operates by means of deficiency pay¬
ments to stabilise prices to farmers at appropriate levels. These payments make
up the deficit between the open market price of a commodity and the price
guaranteed by the Government. To encourage orderly marketing of home
supplies the deficiency payments are in certain cases limited to the difference
between the guarantee and a target indicator price set by the Government.
The deficiency payments scheme for cereals is administered directly by the
agricultural departments, and payment is made on the acreage harvested or
available for harvesting as grain. It is proposed to introduce target indicator
prices in 1972-73. Deficiency payments for fatstock are made weekly to pro¬
ducers on certified sales on a liveweight or deadweight basis. For eggs, a sub¬
sidy, based on the difference between the guaranteed price and the estimated
producer price, is paid to producers through registered packing stations. The
Government intends to phase out the subsidy and remove eggs from the
guarantee by the end of March 1974.
For most of the remaining commodities and for fat pigs in Northern Ireland,
the Government operates the guarantee through the appropriate marketing
board, which takes account of any payments from or to the Government in
deciding what to pay producers for their produce. In the case of milk there
are five boards, and the full guaranteed price is paid only on a ‘standard
quantity’. Milk produced in excess of the standard quantity is sold for manu¬
facturing below the full guaranteed price. The retail price of liquid milk is
determined by the Government so as to cover the full cost of the guarantee and,
taking one year with another, there is no Exchequer subsidy. Support is pro¬
vided for main-crop potatoes (excluding new potatoes) through a system of
acreage limitation and the purchase of surplus potatoes, as many as possible of
which are then sold for stockfeed. The Potato Marketing Board undertakes
support activities in Great Britain and the Ministry of Agriculture in Northern
Ireland in order to bring the average market price for the season up to the
guaranteed price. The Government pays the greater part of the cost. If the
average price is less than the guarantee the Government makes a collective
deficiency payment to the Potato Marketing Board in Great Britain and the
Ministry of Agriculture in Northern Ireland.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to fix in
advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality, after
making allowance for the board’s marketing costs.
The British Sugar Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet
crop produced from a specified acreage—at present 443,000 acres (179,000
hectares)—at a scale of fixed prices, determined at the annual review and rela¬
ted to sugar content. Refined sugar produced by the corporation is sold, under
market-sharing agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world
P The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement (CSA) and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses
which result from the transactions of both the corporation and the board are
ultimately reflected in the board’s accounts which it balances, taking one year
with another, by making surcharges or distribution payments respectively
on all sugar entering the British market. Special arrangements have been made
with the EEC both to safeguard the sugar-exporting interests of developing
Commonwealth countries which are members of the CSA and to allow the
effective marketing of their sugar in Britain without prejudicing the marketing
of Community sugar, until the end of 1974 (see P* 4^4)-

The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity the Government offers to farmers a wide range of induce¬
ments, known as production grants. In 1971-72 production grants amounted to
£115 million of which ^62 million was provided as an inducement to maintain
breeding herds of cattle and flocks of sheep (particularly in upland areas). It
included a calf subsidy on animals suitable for beef production and incentives
for brucellosis eradication.
Grants are available under the Farm Capital Grant Scheme towards capital
expenditure incurred on a wide range of work and facilities for agricultural
businesses such as farm buildings, farm waste disposal systems, facilities for
the supply of gas and electricity, and field drainage. The standard rate of grant
is 30 per cent but higher rates are payable towards the approved cost of some
works; for field drainage the rate is 60 per cent with an extra 10 per cent for
drainage works benefiting hill land. In 1971-72 grants under this scheme and
earlier schemes which it replaced amounted to ^61 million.
Grants are available to encourage the voluntary amalgamation of small un¬
commercial farms with other land to form commercial units. They are given
to those who carry out approved amalgamations and lump sums or annuities
are paid to farmers who give up uncommercial holdings for amalgamations.
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Prior to the 1964 Act the principal means of support was tariffs on imports,
but greater emphasis has since been placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon tariffs.
To this end grants of 40 per cent are available to meet the capital cost of a wide
range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production, storage, pre¬
paration for market and transport of horticultural produce. Additionally, small-
scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a three-year programme for
improving the efficiency of their businesses may qualify for a grant of up to
£500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes together with horticultural
co-operation and credit is nearly £10 million a year.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agricultural
land and buildings is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation
Ltd. whose funds are derived mainly from public issues of stock, with some
government support. Loans for agricultural purposes secured on agricultural
land in Scotland are granted by the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corpora¬
tion Ltd. which works on a similar financial basis to the Agricultural Mortgage
Corporation Ltd.
Loans for carrying out improvements to agricultural land and buildings are
also available to landowners from the Lands Improvement Company, whose
funds are provided privately.
In Northern Ireland loans are available to farmers from the Agricultural
Loans Fund, administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and financed out of
public funds. Half of the loans issued are short-term for agricultural machinery
and the remainder are medium- or long-term loans for such purposes as the
purchase of livestock, the erection and improvement of farm buildings and
farm dwellings, and the purchase of land for amalgamation and subsequent
restructuring.
324 BRITAIN I973i AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Government can make loans in Great Britain to help finance the pur¬
chase of land acquired for approved amalgamations of small farms and appro¬
ved remodelling expenditure. These loans may be granted up to 90 per cent
(100 per cent for certain small amalgamations) of the valuation of the com¬
bined unit determined by the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation Ltd. in
England and Wales and the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd.
in Scotland, which acts as the Government’s agents.
Smallholdings In England and Wales, about 12,250 smallholdings are provided by local
authorities and about 800 lettable holdings by the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food. For financial assistance in improving smallholdings,
authorities can obtain the amalgamations and capital grants available to
farmers generally and these are supplemented for certain smallholdings. The
Minister and local authorities may make loans for working capital to their
smallholding tenants. In this way the tenants can be helped to obtain livestock,
machinery, implements and other necessary items; tenants must, however,
have available at least 25 per cent of the capital required.
Land settlement in Scotland has always been carried out by the central
Government, which now owns and maintains about 420,000 acres (170,000
hectares) of land settlement estates, comprising some 3,190 crofts and holdings.
Crofting In the seven Scottish crofting counties—Argyll, Caithness, Inverness, Orkney,
Ross and Cromarty, Sutherland and Shetland—much of the land is held by
crofters or tenants whose holdings are generally either rented at a cost of not
more than £50 a year or have an area not exceeding 75 acres (30 hectares).
The Crofters Commission, with headquarters in Inverness, is responsible
for the administration and regulation of crofting. The commission’s functions
are to reorganise, develop and regulate crofting in the crofting counties, to
promote the interests of crofters and to keep under review matters relating to
crofting. The commission’s statutory powers include supervising the letting
of crofts and collaborating with other organisations whose activities affect
crofting interests. It also acts as the Secretary of State’s agent in administering
grants to crofters for cropping and land improvement.
Arterial Land drainage (including flood protection) in England and Wales is currently
Drainage and the responsibility of 27 river authorities (see p. 282), two catchment boards
Sea Defence (which exercise the functions of river authorities) and about 350 internal
drainage boards. Local authorities also have general land drainage powers.
There are no comparable authorities in Scotland, where arterial drainage of
agricultural land is the owners’ responsibility. The work of river authorities is
concerned with the improvement of land drainage, the prevention of inland
flooding and the construction and maintenance of defences to protect low-
lying areas from tidal flooding, for example, a barrier is to be built across the
Thames at Woolwich to protect London from the effects of tidal flooding.
River authorities also have powers relating to water resources generally,
freshwater fisheries and river pollution.
Internal drainage boards are concerned with very much smaller areas and
their work is chiefly in low-lying agricultural districts.
River authorities and catchment boards obtain most of the funds needed for
drainage purposes from local authorities. The Government pays grants to¬
wards the cost of improvement schemes carried out by these authorities. The
grants vary from 10 per cent to 80 per cent according to the financial position
Land Tenure
MARKETING
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 325
of the authority, with an additional premium for sea defence works. Internal
drainage boards levy drainage rates on owners and occupiers and also receive
government grants at a flat rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities receive grants
ranging from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. In Scotland 60 per cent grants (70 per
cent if for the benefit of hill land) are available to owners or occupiers of
agricultural land.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Agriculture is the drainage authority in
respect of watercourses designated by the Drainage Council as main or minor
watercourses.
In Great Britain more than half, and in Northern Ireland almost all, farms are
owner-occupied. In order to protect the respective interests of landlords and
tenants and to eliminate uncertainty as to their rights and liabilities, a code of
landlord and tenant relationships has been written into legislation.
Legislation provides for any tenancy of agricultural land, with the exception
of certain short-term lettings, to continue in force from year to year until
terminated by a valid notice to quit. With certain exceptions the tenant can
contest it by serving a counter-notice; the notice to quit then becomes in¬
operative unless the landlord can satisfy an independent body (in England and
Wales the Agricultural Land Tribunal and in Scotland the Scottish Land
Court) that his claim for possession is in the interests of sound estate manage¬
ment or good husbandry or that the land is required for certain specified
purposes.
There is a code of compensation to which the tenant is entitled on termina¬
tion of the tenancy. Rent is a matter for negotiation between landlord and
tenant and may be varied by agreement at any time or, failing agreement, by
arbitration.
Agricultural products are marketed mainly through private trade channels or
through producers’ co-operative organisations. A fairly recent development
has been the growth of contract farming. For certain commodities marketing
arrangements are influenced by boards operating under the Agricultural
Marketing Act 1958. These boards are producers’ organisations with statutory
powers to regulate the marketing of particular products. The schemes under
which they are constituted and operate must be approved by Parliament and
confirmed by a poll of the producers. Most of the members of the boards are
elected by the producers but a minority are appointed by the minister or
ministers concerned. Further safeguards serve to protect consumers and other
interests affected by schemes and the public interest generally.
Marketing boards fall into two broad categories: first, those which are sole
buyers of the regulated product from all producers not specially exempted
or, alternatively, those exercising a comparable influence by controlling all
contracts between producers and first buyers; and, secondly, boards which
maintain only a broad control over marketing conditions, leaving producers
free otherwise to deal individually with buyers. The boards for hops, milk and
wool fall into the first category and the potato board into the second. Northern
Ireland has its own marketing boards, based on local legislation, for milk, pigs
and seed potatoes. For certain other commodities there are broadly based
organisations representing producer, distributor and independent interests.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority aims to improve the marketing of
home-grown cereals. It operates a scheme of bonuses to growers who make
forward contracts for the delivery of grain, provides market intelligence and
promotes research and development of value to the cereals market.
326
BRITAIN 1973' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Meat and Livestock Commission is charged with improving the pro¬
duction, marketing and distribution of livestock and meat in Great Britain. It
has a range of executive functions extending from breeding to retail distribu¬
tion, one of the most important of which is to evolve a general scheme of car¬
case classification. It is not empowered to trade in either livestock or meat.
Since April 1971 eggs have been covered by a broadly based Eggs Authority
which has the general duty of improving the marketing of eggs. It provides
market intelligence, carries out promotional work and operates support buying
on a limited scale.
Grants of up to one-third are available for the modernisation of major
wholesale horticultural markets; Covent Garden is being moved to a new site,
which is under construction, in south London.
National statutory grades have been introduced for apples, pears, tomatoes,
cucumbers and cauliflowers to improve the competitive position of home¬
grown horticultural produce as against imported supplies and to speed its
transit through distributive channels.
Co-operation
CONTROL OF
DISEASES AND
PESTS
Animals
The Central Council for Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation was
established to promote and develop co-operation in agriculture and horticulture
and to administer a scheme of grants. The Agricultural and Horticultural
Co-operation Scheme 1971 provides grants for co-operative production and
marketing of agricultural and horticultural produce, including capital grants on
the same terms as are available to individual producers under the Horticulture
Improvement and Farm Capital Grant Scheme.
The day-to-day work of treating animal disease is the responsibility of the
practising veterinary surgeon. Control of animal disease nationally in accord¬
ance with the Government’s policy is the responsibility of the State Veterinary
Service centred on London and Edinburgh, which is incorporated in the uni¬
fied Agricultural Development and Advisory Service.
For many years Britain has been free from many serious animal diseases
including rinderpest, contagious bovine pleura pneumonia, sheep pox, sheep
scab, glanders and rabies, except for two isolated cases of rabies in imported
dogs in 1969-70. The campaign to eradicate swine fever was successfully
completed in 1966 and although three cases of the disease occurred in 1971 the
infection was quickly eliminated. A major epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease
was experienced in 1967—68 but was eradicated successfully by a stringent
slaughter policy supported by other vigorous control measures. In i960 the
whole of the United Kingdom became a bovine tuberculosis attested area. The
incidence of bovine tuberculosis is now very low; cattle (except for certain
categories) are tuberculin tested at regular intervals and reactors to the test are
slaughtered, compensation being paid to the owners. Voluntary schemes for
the eradication of brucellosis have been in operation since 1967 and these now
cover about half the testable cattle in Great Britain. Compulsory eradication
started in three areas in 1971 and is being extended to further areas during
1972 and 1973. Fowl pest, which had declined considerably since 1963,
reappeared in epidemic proportions in a series of outbreaks in 1970 and early
1971 after which outbreaks declined.
The work of the service is backed by the extensive facilities of the Central
Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, and those of its subsidiary
laboratory at Lasswade, near Edinburgh. In addition, there are 24 investiga¬
tion centres with well-equipped laboratories in England and Wales. These
centres perform work requiring specialist knowledge and give advice on disease
Plants
Pests and Storage
Agricultural
Chemicals
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 327
problems to private practitioners. In Scotland a similar service is provided by
the investigation centres of the three Scottish agricultural colleges.
In Northern Ireland the veterinary services are organised similarly to those
in Great Britain but are administered separately by the Ministry of Agriculture.
Animal health control policies and the geographical situation have kept the
country free from nearly all the major epizootic diseases. A Brucellosis Eradica¬
tion Scheme has been successfully carried out and in December 1971 Northern
Ireland was declared a brucellosis-free country. The full-time veterinary service
is supplemented by the central veterinary laboratory at Stormont, Belfast.
The plant health services, operated by the agricultural departments, are
responsible for statutory controls designed to limit the spread of plant pests
and diseases present in Britain and prevent the introduction of new ones from
abroad. They also issue the health certificates required by other countries to
accompany plant material imported from Britain. Voluntary certification
schemes are operated to encourage the development of healthy vigorous and
true-to-type planting stocks. It is expected that a statutory scheme for seed
potatoes will operate from the 1974 growing season. The Plant Pathology
Laboratory at Harpenden, Hertfordshire, and the Agricultural Scientific
Services Station, East Craigs, Edinburgh, provide scientific and technical
advice on which statutory controls and certification schemes are based.
The Ministry of Agriculture’s Pest Infestation Control Laboratory provides
scientific and technical advice on harmful mammals and birds and on insects,
mites and moulds associated with grain and other stored food products. The
laboratory’s headquarters is at Slough, Buckinghamshire, where storage
problems are studied; vertebrate pests are studied at Tolworth, Surrey, and
Worplesdon, Surrey. The laboratory works closely with Regional Pest Officers
who advise farmers, local authorities and others on control techniques.
Safeguards against the dangers which could arise from uncontrolled use of
pesticides have been devised and are operating successfully. Regulations pro¬
vide protection for workers using the more toxic chemicals. The voluntary
Pesticides Safety Precautions Scheme ensures that new pesticides intended for
use in agriculture and the home garden, forestry and food storage, or new
methods of using existing pesticides, are not introduced until enough experi¬
mental work has been done on their possible hazards (including those to users,
consumers of treated produce, livestock or domestic animals and wild life) to
allow the Government to make recommendations for their safe use. Products
cleared for safety under the Pesticides Safety Precautions Scheme may then be
submitted through the Agricultural Chemicals Approval Scheme for efficiency
approval. The purpose of this scheme is to enable users and advisers to choose
efficient proprietary brands of agricultural chemicals.
A key role in the administration of the safety scheme is played by the
Government’s Advisory Committee on Pesticides and Other Toxic Chemicals
which also reports on topics of current concern. In 1969 it concluded that there
was no evidence that the use of certain persistent organochlorine pesticides
(including DDT, aldrin and dieldrin) had any adverse effects on human beings,
but it is recommended that certain uses of these chemicals for which adequate,
less persistent alternatives were available should cease in order to reduce
amounts of them in the environment. This recommendation was implemented
during 1971.

In 1971 controls were introduced to restrict the use of certain antibiotics in
animal husbandry and veterinary medicines. As a result the retail sale or supply
of feedingstuffs containing these antibiotics was prohibited except in accord¬
ance with a prescription or written direction of a veterinarian.
The Medicines Act 1968 provides for the control of both human and veterin¬
ary medicinal products (including those used in animal feedingstuffs) through
a licensing and certification system which is being brought into operation in
stages. When the Act is fully operative it will not be lawful for the products to
be manufactured, sold or supplied in, or imported into, Britain except in
accordance with the appropriate licences or exemptions. The licensing authority,
which consists of the British health and agricultural ministers, is advised by a
Medicines Commission and by expert licensing committees.
The Ministry’s Safety Inspectors advise farmers and workers about safety,
including their obligations under the Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare
Provisions) Act 1956 and regulations made under it; these cover such matters
as the guarding of field and stationary machinery, the safeguarding of work¬
places, and the fitting of safety cabs to tractors.
In England and Wales technical advice on all agricultural and horticultural
matters is available through the Agricultural Development and Advisory
Service (ADAS) which operates mainly from the Ministry’s regional and
divisional offices. The Service provides free and impartial advice to landowners,
farmers and growers, but charges are made for certain laboratory and other
services, such as drainage design work. When possible the ADAS concentrates
more on group than individual advice.
In Scotland the agricultural advisory service is provided by the three
regional independent colleges which are financed almost entirely by public
funds. The nature of service is similar to that provided by the ADAS and covers
all branches of advice.
In Northern Ireland advisory work is organised by the Ministry of Agri¬
culture on a county and district basis.
Agricultural research in Britain carried out by the Agricultural Research
Council and the universities is mentioned on p. 398. The Ministry of Agri¬
culture, Fisheries and Food also carries out research and development on
agriculture, fisheries and food at its own laboratories and on the 22 experimen¬
tal farms and horticulture stations operated by the ADAS, and makes grants
to outside research organisations. In England and Wales, research in agricul¬
tural economics is undertaken by 12 university departments of agricultural
economics. Ten of these conduct work on farm incomes and the economics of
particular products for the ministry (see p. 320)- Scotland, agricultural
economists are on the staff of the three agricultural colleges.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture has an Economics and Statis¬
tics Division and eight other research divisions.
In England and Wales full-time education in agricultural subjects is provided
at universities, non-maintained agricultural colleges and county agricultural
colleges and institutes. Some 11 universities provide degree and postgraduate
courses in agriculture or agricultural sciences. The National College of Agri¬
cultural Engineering at Silsoe, Bedfordshire, offers degree and postgraduate
courses. Seven agricultural colleges provide sandwich courses leading to a
Higher National Diploma and there are nearly 50 local authority and other
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
329
agricultural colleges providing full-time courses on different aspects of agricul¬
ture, horticulture, forestry and farm management. In Scotland the three
agricultural colleges which provide the advisory services are also teaching
establishments, associated with the agricultural departments of the neigh¬
bouring universities. They provide diploma and post-diploma courses, and
certain short courses; there are also national sandwich-type courses at both
higher and ordinary level. The only national diploma centre in dairy technology
in Great Britain is at the West College. In Northern Ireland degree courses in
agriculture and food science are provided at Queen’s University, Belfast.
Courses below this level are provided at three residential colleges run by the
Ministry of Agriculture.
Local education authorities in Britain also provide short courses, block-
release, day-release and other part-time classes for farmers, farm workers and
horticulturists, as well as an advisory service for domestic producers.
The Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board
provides a training advisory service and a system of grant payments to em¬
ployers providing training in agriculture and horticulture. The principal
grants are made for training new entrants to the industry, for attendance at
approved courses and for approved schemes of training at places of work.
Research and education on home-grown sugar beet is financed by the indus¬
try. A levy on each ton of sugar beet grown is paid into a special fund under
the control of the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, who draws up
annual programmes in consultation with the Sugar Beet Research and Educa¬
tion Committee.
FISHERIES
The industry falls into three main divisions, concerned respectively with white
fish, herring and shellfish. The major element of the catch (about 80 per cent
by weight) is white fish: the catches of herring and shellfish comprise about 15
per cent and 5 per cent respectively of the total catch. The principal white
fish (in terms of value) are demersal species which live near the sea bed, such
as cod, haddock, plaice, coalfish (saithe), whiting, soles and skate. Herring is a
pelagic species which lives mainly in midwater or near the surface and which
constitutes a separate fishery. Shellfish include Crustacea (such as lobsters,
nephrops and crabs) and molluscs (such as escallops, mussels, cockles, clams
and oysters).
The white fish section of the industry is made up of three main groups: the
distant water, the near and middle water, and the inshore fisheries. The distant
waters are those round Iceland, Greenland, Bear Island, the north coast of
Norway, the Barents Sea and in the west Atlantic; the middle water grounds
lie around the Faroe Islands; and the near water grounds are those in the
North Sea, the Irish Sea and in the coastal areas around Britain. The herring
fishing grounds are almost entirely in Scottish waters. The inshore waters also
yield considerable quantities of shellfish.
The Common Fisheries Policy of the EEC aims to promote the balanced
development of the fishing industry and the rational exploitation of resources.
Provision is also made for a system of market organisation, carried out largely
by the industry itself, to assist in the adaptation of supplies to market require¬
ments while ensuring a reasonable return to producers.
The negotiations on Britain’s entry to the Community resulted in a dero¬
gation for ten years (but subject to review before the end of 1982) from those
provisions of the policy which at present permit free access for the fishing
230 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
vessels of member states to the coastal waters of other member states. This
derogation enables Britain’s coastal waters out to the six-mile (9-7 km) limit
to be reserved exclusively to British vessels, and certain specified waters be¬
tween the six- and 12-mile (i9'3 km) limits to be reserved to British vessels and
those with existing rights to fish there for certain species of fish. Britain will
retain full fisheries jurisdiction out to the 12-mile limit.
Fishing Ports The principal fishing ports in England and Wales are Hull, Grimsby, Fleet-
wood, North Shields, Lowestoft and Milford Haven. In Scotland the chief
centres for white fish are Aberdeen, Granton, Peterhead, the Moray Firth, the
west coast and Shetland Islands; herring landings are made mainly at the east
coast port of Fraserburgh, the west coast ports of Ullapool, Mallaig, Oban and
Ayr and in the Shetland Islands. In Northern Ireland the main fishing ports
are Kilkeel, Portavogie and Ardglass.
Methods of The chief methods of catching fish are by trawling, seining, lining and ring
Sea Fishing netting. Trawling is carried out throughout the year in the distant and near
waters for all species of demersal fish. Seining is also used for catching demersal
fish all the year round, mainly in the North Sea, the Minches, the Firth of
Clyde and the Irish Sea. There are about 450 Scottish seiners, and about 175
operating from English ports.
The pelagic fisheries are seasonal. There is summer fishing for herring based
on the Shetlands, the east coast ports of Scotland and the north-east coast ports
of England. Other seasonal fisheries take place off the west coast of Scotland, in
the Isle of Man area and off southern Ireland.
The inshore fisheries comprise a great diversity of types of vessels and
methods of capture; in addition, there are extensive fisheries for crabs,
lobsters, shrimps, mussels, escallops, cockles and oysters, and, off Scotland,
north-east England and in the Irish Sea there are valuable catches of nephrops
(‘Norway lobsters’ or Dublin Bay prawns).
Distant water vessels, which operate mainly from Hull, Grimsby and Fleet-
wood, number about 160. They are over 140 feet (42-5 metres) in length and
most of them make voyages of 17 to 23 days to fishing grounds off Iceland, in
the Arctic Circle, Newfoundland, Labrador, Greenland and the Norway coast.
Freezer trawlers and factory ships, which spend from one to three months at
sea and freeze much or all of their catch, in some cases as fillets, have become an
important part of the distant water fleet in recent years and number about 37.
There are about 325 near and middle water vessels of between 80 and 140 feet
(24*5 and 42-5 metres) long and most of them work nearer home, making
voyages of from a few days up to more than two weeks, although some of the
larger vessels fish regularly off the Faroes and seasonally as far afield as Iceland.
Included in the near water group are vessels engaged in fishing for herring
which normally make daily landings. The inshore group consists of some 1,700
vessels of over 40 feet (12-3 metres) and over 3,500 smaller vessels, many of
which do not fish regularly. The majority are seldom at sea for longer than
two or three days and more usually make daily landings, often fishing within
sight of land although some seiners operate for eight days or more.
In the British fishing industry in 1971 there were about 17,000 fishermen
in regular employment and some 4,100 occasionally employed; about two-
fifths of the former and one-third of the latter were from Scottish ports. In
Northern Ireland there are about 550 regular fishermen and 200 part-time.
The Fishing
Fleet
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 331
In 1971 landings of all types of fish (excluding salmon and trout) by British
fishing vessels totalled 961,000 tons (704,000 tons of demersal fish, 203,000
tons of pelagic and 54,000 tons of shellfish), valued at £92-6 million. Cod
accounted for 47 per cent of the total value of demersal and pelagic fish landed
by British vessels; haddock (20 per cent) and plaice (9 per cent) were the other
most important sources of earnings to the industry.
Imports of all fresh, frozen and cured fish and shellfish totalled 107,000 tons
valued at nearly ^36 million. Imports of canned and preserved fish and shell¬
fish amounted to 66,000 tons valued at nearly £47 million making total fish
imports 173,000 tons worth just over ^82 million. Imports of fish meal
amounted to 297,000 tons worth £25-5 million and those of fish oils to 238,000
tons worth j£22-8 million. Exports of fish and fish products totalled 136,000
tons worth ^28-6 million.
Weekly disposals of fresh, frozen and cured fish (excluding shellfish and
imported canned fish) in Britain averaged about 16,000 tons landed weight
in 1970. Consumption has been declining slightly, on an edible (fillet) weight
basis; it was 147 lb. (6-6 kg.) per head in 1971 (see Table 32) in comparison
with a peak total of 287 lb. (13 kg.) in 1948.
Processing and packaging of fish are the subject of continuing research and
development. The growth of quick-frozen fish production has altered radically
the structure of the industry. With the increase in quick-freezing (which now
processes just over a quarter of all white fish landings), new export outlets have
opened up for white fish, which account for almost half the total exports of
fish and fish preparations.
A valuable by-product of the industry is the manufacture of fish meal for
animal food and, to a much lesser extent, for fertilisers. Home production of
white fish meal and herring meal in 1971 was 90,000 tons.
The most valuable freshwater fish are salmon and sea-trout, especially when
caught by rod and line. Sea fishing for salmon is prohibited in a wide area
around the British Isles outside national fishery limits. Within the limits drift
netting and certain other methods are prohibited off the coast of Scotland but
are permitted under licence off England, Wales and Northern Ireland. In
Scotland, where salmon fishing is a private right, the main commercial methods
are fixed nets on the coast outside estuaries and sweep netting within estuaries
and in rivers. River authority licences are required for the limited amount of
estuary and river netting carried out in England and Wales. In England and
Wales the landed value of the salmon catch is approximately £275,000 a year,
in Scotland it amounts to about £i-5 million, and in Northern Ireland to some
£230,000. In Northern Ireland, eels worth about £400,000 a year are captured
by long lines and by eel nets placed in river weirs.
The principal inland wholesale distributing centre for fish is Billingsgate
Market in London, which handles about 250 tons a day, but other large cities
also have central fish markets. The principal method of distribution is through
wholesalers, located at the ports, who buy at the auctions and sell to inland
wholesalers as well as directly to retail outlets; the port wholesalers prepare the
fish for onward shipment. Fish lorries, including insulated and refrigerated
vehicles, transport the catch daily from the ports to inland centres, although
rail transport is still used from some ports. Retail sales are handled by some
18,000 to 22,000 fishmongers and fish friers; the latter use about a third of the
landings of white fish.

Trawler-owning companies have entered into the marketing and distribu¬
tive system. This process has been encouraged by the growing popularity of
quick-frozen consumer packs, which are sold mainly by other retail outlets,
such as grocers.
The government departments mainly responsible for the administration of
legislation concerning the fishing industry are the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland
and the Ministry of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. The safety and welfare
of crews of fishing vessels and other matters common to shipping generally
are provided for under the Merchant Shipping Acts administered by the
Department of Trade and Industry.
The Herring Industry Board was set up to reorganise, develop and regulate
the herring industry and consists of a chairman and two other members, all
part-time and independent of the industry, who are appointed jointly by the
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, and the Secretaries of State for
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The board, whose activities are
financed partly by levies and licence fees and partly by government grants
and loans, is advised by the Herring Industry Advisory Council, consisting
of 32 members representing all sections of the industry and consumers.
The functions of the board include the promotion of sales of herring, both
at home and abroad, and the application of the benefits of technical progress
to the industry, including the adoption of new methods of catching, processing
and distributing herring. The board administers the government grant and
loan schemes which provide for assistance towards the purchase of new fishing
vessels, and the improvement of existing vessels. Fishermen may also obtain
loans from the board towards the purchase of second-hand vessels under
80 feet in length and towards the cost of new nets and gear. Up to 31st March
I972 jC2’? million in loans and ^,’2-7 million in grants had been advanced.
The function of the White Fish Authority is to reorganise, develop and regulate
the white fish industry, and that of its Committees for Scotland and Northern
Ireland is to advise the authority about the exercise and performance of its
functions in Scotland and Northern Ireland. The authority is composed of a
chairman and six members, and the Scottish and Northern Ireland Committees
of five members and a chairman who is a member of the authority; member¬
ship is by appropriate ministerial appointment. The White Fish Industry
Advisory Council advises the authority about the exercise and performance of
its functions. It normally consists of 53 members representing the various
interests of the fishing industry.
The White Fish Authority administers government grant and loan schemes
for the purchase of new fishing vessels and engines and the improvement of
existing vessels. It also administers loans for the purchase of nets and gear and
processing plants. Up to 31st March 1972, about £36 million in loans and £37
million in grants were approved. Its other activities are financed by levies on
first-hand sales of most white fish, and a government grant towards research
and development.
Subsidies are paid to the inshore fishing industry under the provisions of the
Sea Fish Industry Act 1970 at the rate of so much per day at sea according
to the length of the vessel or at so much per stone (6-35 kg.) of fish landed,
which varies according to the kind of fish, from certain vessels under 60 feet

(18-5 metres) in length. No subsidy is paid for shellfish. Subsidies for white

The White Fish Subsidy (Deep Sea Vessels) (United Kingdom) Scheme
came into operation on 1st April 1968 for a period of three years. Subsidies

by reference to the level of profitability of the industry. Payment was related
to the operating efficiency of vessels and not to their classification. These
arrangements replaced the previous policy of progressively decreasing operat¬

to the total maximum in the scheme.
FORESTRY
The estimated total area of productive woodland in Great Britain is 3-76
million acres (1-53 million hectares), or nearly 7 per cent of the total land area;
nearly half of the area is in England, two-fifths in Scotland, the remainder in
Wales.
The area of productive forest managed by the Forestry Commission, at
1-85 million acres (075 million hectares) represents 50 per cent of the total.
The annual rate of productive forest expansion is currently about 54,000 acres
(22,000 hectares) by the commission mainly in Scotland, and about 49,000
acres (20,000 hectares) by private woodland owners. The commission’s
programme includes considerable planting in upland areas, and consists mainly
of conifers because of the difficult site conditions encountered and because
over 90 per cent of industrial demand which the commission is primarily
charged with supplying is for softwoods. The major species used are Sitka
spruce, Lodgepole pine, Scots pine and Norway spruce. In the older wood¬
lands and taking the country as a whole, the most common coniferous trees
are Scots pine, Sitka spruce, Norway spruce and the larches, while, among the
broadleaved, beech and oak occur widely.
Total employment in state and private forests was 25,000 in 1971 and a
further 11,000 were engaged in the transport and milling.
Except for the period of the two world wars, when much over-felling took
place, home woodlands have until recent years made only a limited contribu¬
tion to the nation’s total requirements of wood and wood products—now some
10 per cent of national demand. Some 25 per cent of the commission’s wood¬
lands are now in production. Britain imports 92 per cent of its needs by volume
and a higher proportion still by value, the total import cost of wood and wood
products including pulp and paper being over ^777 million in 1971, of which
£245 million was accounted for by timber imports.
The Forestry Commission is the national forestry authority charged with
promoting the interests of forestry, the development of afforestation and the
production and supply of timber in Great Britain. As more and more of its
coniferous woods reach the production stage the commission, as managers
of the National Forestry Enterprise, has assumed an increasingly important
role as a timber seller and has encouraged the setting up of some 20 major
new timber-using industries since the mid-1960s. The commission consists of
a part-time chairman, a full-time director general, three full-time executive
commissioners and five part-time commissioners. The commissioners comply
with directions given by the forestry ministers, who are the Minister of
334
Finance
Private
Forestry
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and
Wales. Northern Ireland has its own separate organisation (see p. 335).
Following a review of forestry policy the Government published, in June 1972,
a consultative document and supporting cost-benefit analysis as a basis for
discussion and formulation of new policies for public and private forestry.
The commission’s total estate covers some 3 million acres (1-2 million
hectares) and includes 2,2 million acres (o-88 million hectares) of forest land,
of which nearly 1-9 million (075 million hectares) are under trees in 380
forests distributed throughout England, Scotland and Wales. All these forests
are covered by management plans, which provide for such work as planting,
road construction, thinning, fire protection and timber production, facilities
for public recreation, wildlife conservation and the landscaping of plantations.
As already stated, a substantial amount of the Forestry Commission’s new
planting is carried out in Scotland, much of it in the Highland counties, where
poorer types of land, such as sour, peaty soil which is unsuitable for agricultural
purposes, are used, having become suitable for forestry as a result of advances
in the technique of deep ploughing.
Production of felled and thinned timber from commission woodlands
amounted to 1-59 million cubic metres in 1971-72. Some of this produce is
meeting traditional requirements of the coal mines but much is taken by the
paper pulp industry and by factories established to make chipboard, fibreboard
and wood wool.
The Forestry Fund was constituted under the i9I9 Forestry Act; from it is
paid all the expenditure of the Forestry Commissioners and into it are paid
amounts voted annually by Parliament, together with the commission s
receipts from sales of produce, rentals and other sources. In the period ending
31st March 1971, drawings from funds voted by Parliament amounted to
^14-5 million, and receipts were ^9-1 million.
Privately owned woods comprise nearly 60 per cent of the total forest area in
Great Britain and contain most of the mature and semi-mature timber. The
size of woodlands in individual ownership ranges from a few acres to several
thousand acres, and a high proportion of the private woodland area is in small
ownership—that is, owners of up to about 250 acres (100 hectares).
The effective management of private woodlands is encouraged under the
Dedication of Woodlands Scheme under which owners are invited to put
their land permanently to timber production and to manage their woods in
accordance with a plan agreed with the Forestry Commission, in return for
the provision of planting and management grants and technical advice. By
March 1972 the total area dedicated was i-i million acres (443,000 hectares).
In addition, there are the Approved Woodlands Scheme and the Small Woods
Scheme under which a planting grant, but no management grant, is paid.
More than 1-3 million acres (512,000 hectares) are managed under the first
two schemes. Woodland owners are represented, in their relations with the
Forestry Commission, by the Forestry Committee of Great Britain, which
co-ordinates the work of two associations of woodland owners: the Timber
Growers’ Organisation (for owners in England and Wales) and the Scottish
Woodland Owners’ Association.
The Trees Act 1970 allowed for tree preservation orders to be imposed,
with the consent of the commission, on dedicated and other grant-aided
woodlands.
There are a number of forestry co-operative societies providing for land-
