owners and farmers the services of skilled staff, centralised purchasing facilities,
and a central agency for the disposal of forest produce. The Forestry Com¬
mission also co-operates with the principal forestry societies, such as the
Royal Forestry Society of England and Wales and the Royal Scottish Forestry
Society, in disseminating technical knowledge.
The Forestry Commissioners maintain national committees for England,
Scotland and Wales which act in an advisory capacity, particularly on the
social, recreational and amenity aspects of the commissioners’ activities and
relationships with other land users. The commissioners also maintain a
regional advisory committee for each conservancy.
Other bodies have been set up to provide for consultation on the marketing
and utilisation of home-grown timber. The Home Grown Timber Advisory
Committee (HGTAC) is a statutory body and includes representatives of
associations of landowners, timber merchants and processors and the trade
unions under an independent chairman. The Advisory Committee on Utilisa¬
tion of Home Grown Timber, a sub-committee of the HGTAC advises on
measures designed to promote utilisation of produce from British woodlands.
Forestry training is the responsibility of the Department of Education and
Science. Degree courses in forestry and associated studies are provided at four
universities and supervisory level courses are run at Newton Rigg, near
Penrith. A number of centres provide craft courses.
The Forestry Training Council advises the commission, private growers’
organisations and the forestry societies on training in forestry for private
woodland owners and the Furniture and Timber Industry Training Board
provides training in forestry for employees in the home-grown timber trade.
The commission’s Forest Research Station at Alice Holt Lodge in Surrey
was opened in 1946 and a new Northern Research Station near Edinburgh in
1970. Expenditure on research work in Great Britain amounted to ^i-i million
in 1970-71. This sum included grants for special forestry research work to
various institutions and to university departments including the Common¬
wealth Forestry Institute at Oxford, which is also financed by the university,
the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and overseas governments. Research
into the qualities of home-grown timber is carried out by Princes Risborough
Laboratory (formerly the Forest Products Research Laboratory), and also by
grant-aided research associations.
The Ministry of Agriculture is the forest authority for Northern Ireland. It
can acquire and manage land, and give financial and technical assistance to
private planting. It has introduced measures for the protection of all woodlands
against destruction by over-cutting, fire or depredation by animals.
The state forest area has grown steadily since the end of the second world
war. By 1972 over 155,000 acres (64,000 hectares) had been acquired, of which
almost 110,000 acres (46,000 hectares) had been planted. A target of 300,000
acres (120,000 hectares) of state and private forest has been set for the end of
the century.
Financial provision is made by sums voted annually by Parliament and from
receipts from forest produce and other sources. Nearly 1,400 people are
employed in the state forests. There are also about 36,000 acres (15,000 hec¬
tares) of privately owned forests, and private planting is assisted by schemes
for the supply of young trees from the Ministry’s nurseries at a low cost, by
grants towards the cost of the establishment of new plantations, and by free
technical advice.
15 TRANSPORT AND
COMMUNICATIONS
SHIPPING
Relations with
the Government
Inland and overseas transport and communications employed 7 per cent of the
total labour force in Great Britain in June I971- 1‘^ million persons
so occupied, 31 per cent were engaged in road passenger transport and road
haulage contracting, 17 per cent in railways and 30 per cent in postal services
and telecommunications; sea and air transport each absorbed 5 per cent; port
and inland water transport and miscellaneous transport services and storage
absorbed 12 per cent. Transport and communications contribute about 9 per
cent of the gross national product and are responsible for a rather higher
proportion of the nation’s gross fixed capital formation.
SEA TRANSPORT
Of the world’s active sea-going tonnage of 100 gross tons1 and over, some 11
per cent is registered in Britain, making the British merchant fleet, at 27-3
million gross tons, the third largest in active employment after those of Liberia
and Japan. The oil tanker fleet, at 13-4 million gross tons, is the world’s second
largest, and the ore and bulk carrier fleet at 4-3 million gross tons, the fourth
largest.
The British fleet has grown steadily, particularly over the last two or three
years; since 1968 it has increased by 25 per cent, much of the new tonnage
consisting of purpose-built container, tanker and bulk carrier vessels. British
shipping meets severe international competition and, with the fleets of other
traditional maritime nations, encounters difficulties from practices such as flag
discrimination and the use of ‘flags of convenience’.
The Department of Trade and Industry is the government department respon¬
sible for most matters connected with merchant shipping. Under the Merchant
Shipping Acts, it administers many regulations for marine safety and welfare,
for instance: certifying the load-line (or Plimsoll line) that shows that a ship is
not overloaded; ensuring that standards of safety are observed in ship con¬
struction; ensuring the provision of adequate life-saving, fire-fighting and
radio equipment; and dealing with the discipline, professional standards,
health and accommodation of seamen. Most of the work which these respon¬
sibilities entail is carried out by the staff of the Marine Survey and Mercantile
Marine Offices at the ports. There is also a Registrar-General of Shipping and
Seamen, in whose office at Cardiff a complete record of all British ships is kept.
The Merchant Navy Establishment Administration records information on
British seafarers actively employed at sea. Abroad, certain parts of the Mer¬
chant Shipping Acts are administered by British Consuls and by officers of
Commonwealth Governments.
1 One gross ton (g.t.) =100 cubic feet (2-83 cubic metres). One deadweight ton (d.w.t.)
= 1 long ton (2,240 lb. or 1,016 kilogrammes). Gross tonnage indicates the total capacity
of the enclosed space on a ship. Deadweight tonnage denotes the maximum load which
a vessel can carry before submerging the load-line.

THE MERCHANT

EMPLOYMENT OF
SEAFARERS
Qualifications
Much of the law relating to employment at sea is being revised under the
Merchant Shipping Act 1970; in particular some disciplinary provisions are to
be relaxed and arrangements for welfare and safety of seamen improved.
In June 1971, 24 million gross tons of trading vessels of 100 gross tons and
over were both owned and registered in Britain.1 These ships are usually
employed as follows: 6-4 million gross tons as foreign-going passenger and
cargo liners; 4-8 million gross tons as foreign-going tramps; 12 million gross
tons as foreign-going tankers; and o-8 million gross tons in coasting and trade
with ports between the Elbe and Brest (home trades). Over half of the fleet is
diesel driven. Gross tonnage of ships delivered to British owners in 1971 is
estimated at 3-2 million, about a third of which was built in British yards. The
largest and most advanced of Britain’s passenger liners is the Queen Elizabeth 2
(66,000 g.t.), designed for the transatlantic route and for cruising, which went
into service in 1969. Rapid technological change in the merchant fleet is
reflected in the current composition. Vessels are becoming obsolete over a
shorter period and as they do so are being replaced by larger ships, with
generally lower building costs per ton; labour-saving devices, greater speeds
and faster turn-round facilities are reducing operating costs. The tendency to
greater average size has been the most marked in tankers and dry bulk cargo
ships. Vessels are specially built to carry ore, cement, wine and various kinds of
chemicals. Many ships have been designed to carry fully loaded road vehicles,
pallets and containers. In particular the use of containers on door-to-door
journeys can result in speedier, safer and cheaper carriage of a wide range of
goods. Two consortia of British shipping companies are operating specially
designed deep-sea cellular container ship services; several British companies
are involved in international container consortia, and a few are operating
services of their own. Similar arrangements exist in bulk carrier services.
About 96,000 seafarers are employed by the merchant fleet, over half of whom
are United Kingdom nationals, and most of the remainder Commonwealth
nationals.
The Department of Trade and Industry holds examinations for, and issues
certificates of competency to, ship’s officers as master, first mate and second
mate of foreign-going ships, or master and mate of home trade ships and as
first-class engineer and second-class engineer. Officers may not normally
serve on board ships in these grades unless they hold the appropriate, or a
higher, certificate.
Radio officers are required to hold certificates of competency in radio¬
telegraphy issued by the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications on the
results of an open examination.
A seaman may not be rated as A B (Able Seaman) in United Kingdom
registered ships unless he holds a certificate of competency as A B granted by
the Department of Trade and Industry, or an equivalent certificate. To obtain
this certificate a seaman must, among other qualifications, have served three
years at sea on deck, have obtained a certificate of efficiency as lifeboatman and
have passed a qualifying examination. Seamen qualify by seniority for promo¬
tion to the rating of petty officer. Service as a deck rating qualifies for the pur¬
pose of admission to the examination for a second mate’s certificate.
1 The remaining tonnage included fishing vessels, tugs, river and estuary craft, Ministry
of Defence vessels (mostly tankers) not usually engaged in the commercial carriage of
cargo, and shipping registered in Britain but owned in other Commonwealth countries
(including over 1 million gross tons of tankers).

The Merchant Navy Training Board promotes the instruction and studies
of apprentices, cadets and ratings who are preparing for their examinations for
the various certificates of competency.
Wages and conditions of employment of the majority of seafarers are negotiated
by the National Maritime Board. Minimum wages and holidays with pay are
guaranteed for both officers and ratings. Moreover, the Merchant Navy
Established Service Scheme, introduced by the board in 1947, has removed a
great deal of the uncertainty formerly associated with a seafaring life. Officers
and men can now take contracts of at least one year’s duration, either with
individual shipping companies or with the Merchant Navy Establishment
Administration, and get special benefits between voyages in addition to the
normal unemployment insurance benefit.
About one-third of British-owned shipping registered in the United Kingdom
consists of foreign-going passenger-cargo and cargo liners, mostly the latter.
Practically all these ships are owned by large liner companies. Many operate
wide networks of scheduled cargo and passenger services which, between them,
cover every ocean. The 4-8 million gross tons of foreign-going tramp ships are
operated by a large number of private owners, some having only a small number
of ships and some only one ship.
Examples of major British liner shipping companies operating scheduled
services from the United Kingdom are: Cunard, to North America; Blue
Funnel, to Australia and the Far East; Peninsular and Oriental (P. & O.) and
the British India lines, to India, Australia and the Far East; Union Castle, to
South and East Africa; Elder Dempster, to West Africa; Furness Withy, to
North America and the West Indies; the New Zealand line, to Australia and
New Zealand; and Shaw Savill and Albion, to Australia and New Zealand.
These and the other major liner companies have for the most part amalga¬
mated to form a small number of major groups, of which the largest and best
known are the P. & O., the Furness Withy, the Ocean S.S., and the British and
Commonwealth groups.
Over two-thirds of the total tanker fleet belong to the oil companies,
although there are a few important independent United Kingdom tanker¬
owning companies.
The main organisations concerned with the activities, interests and common
problems of the industry are as follows:
Lloyd’s Register is an organisation (distinct from the Society of Lloyd’s, see
p. 219) which surveys and classifies ships with particular regard to their
safety and operational efficiency. It will accept responsibility for surveying
and giving technical advice on vessels of all flags from the initial stages of
building, at regular intervals during their service, and after casualties. A
satisfactory Lloyd’s classification is a guarantee to an underwriter that he may
accept the risk of a vessel, and this forms a strong link between the Register and
the Society of Lloyd’s.
The representative body speaking for shipowners generally (excluding, for
the most part, owners of fishing vessels) is the Chamber of Shipping of the
United Kingdom. There are a number of local associations of shipowners
centred around the main port areas. Other organisations represent companies
specialising in a particular trade or type of cargo.

SAFETY AT SEA
Sea Rescue
The British Shippers’ Council, formed in 1955, represents the shipping
interests of exporters and importers in matters of both national and inter¬
national concern.
The British Shipping Federation Limited is the employers’ organisation
concerned with labour relations and the regulation of employment. It is
responsible for the administration of the Merchant Navy Established Service
Scheme, under which shipowners engaging crews for ships of 200 gross tons
and above engage them through the Merchant Navy Establishment Administra¬
tion unless they are prepared to offer company service contracts.
The National Maritime Board is composed of equal numbers of representa¬
tives of the shipowners and seafarers’ unions and is responsible for negotiation
of wages and conditions of service.
British shipping companies operating liners have associated with each other
and with the companies of other countries operating on the same routes in a
series of ‘conferences’ designed to secure standardisation and stability of rates,
and to maintain frequency and regularity of services. The essential principle
of a conference is the establishment of a common tariff of freight rates or
passenger fares from each port of departure. Each conference meets from
time to time to review and revise existing rates, or to compile new ones. Some
of the conferences are connected by rate agreements, or have joined together
to form wider groupings. There are over 60 conferences dealing with trade to
and from the United Kingdom. The governments of 12 European countries
and of Japan have asked conferences serving their countries’ trade to adhere to
a code of conference practice; the eventual aim is the adoption of a world code.
The Baltic Mercantile and Shipping Exchange, which originated in one of
London’s seventeenth-century coffee houses, is the world’s largest market
for the chartering of ships of all nationalities. Shipbrokers and merchants’
representatives meet there to arrange the chartering of dry-cargo tramp ships
for the carriage of goods to and from all parts of the world. In addition sale
and purchase of ships, chartering of aircraft and trade in certain commodities
are carried on there.
The Department of Trade and Industry’s responsibilities for safety include
administration of the Coastguard Service, and certain administrative functions
concerning lighthouses and pilotage. The department makes regulations to
ensure safety of navigation and to prevent oil pollution, and conducts en¬
quiries into shipping casualties and accidents.
The Coastguard Service co-ordinates search and rescue measures for vessels in
distress off the coasts of Britain, and gives direct assistance where appropriate.
There are some 550 regular coastguards and about 7,000 part-time auxiliary
coastguards. Constant watch is maintained all the year round at certain main
stations and where necessary at a number of others. During the year ended
31st March 1972 life-saving action was taken on 3,518 occasions.
A Coastguard School was opened at Brixham, Devon, in October 1971.
The Coastguard calls upon shipping, the lifeboats of the Royal National
Life-boat Institution, and Service aircraft to assist as necessary. It has at its
disposal a civilian rescue helicopter based at Manston in Kent and may call
upon the services of long-range civilian helicopters based at Aberdeen in
Scotland. The Royal National Life-boat Institution is supported entirely by
34°
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
voluntary contributions, and depends for its operation on voluntary workers.
From its foundation in 1824 to the end of 1971 it saved 94,923 lives. Lifeboats
were launched 2,676 times in 1971 and rescued 1,439 people.
Lighthouses The general lighthouse authority for England and Wales, the Channel Islands
and Gibraltar is the Corporation of Trinity House, which received its first
Royal Charter in the sixteenth century and is administered by a Board of ten
Elder Brethren, elected from the Royal Navy and the Merchant Navy.
Lighthouses in Scotland and Ireland are the responsibility respectively
of the Commissioners of Northern Lighthouses and the Commissioners of
Irish Lights. These authorities control about 180 lighthouses, many minor
lights and buoys, and a number of lightships, some of which are being replaced
by unattended sea marks or by light towers.
Pilotage Trinity House is the chief pilotage authority, licensing some 700 pilots in
41 districts in England and Wales, including London, Southampton and
Milford Haven. In some cases the harbour authority or local council is the
pilotage authority. In Britain there are 48 pilotage authorities for the 92
pilotage districts and over 1,700 licensed pilots.
Traffic Every year some 150,000 vessels pass through the Dover Strait, one of the
Control most congested stretches of water in the world. The first traffic separation
scheme adopted by the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisa¬
tion (IMCO—a United Nations agency with headquarters in London) was
introduced in the Dover Strait on a voluntary basis in 1967. It was revised and
extended as from 3rd April 1972, and now stretches from the Greenwich
meridian in the Channel as far as other separation schemes operating in the
southern North Sea. It consists of inshore traffic zones on each side of the
Channel for coastal shipping, and main traffic lanes in the centre. On the
initiative of Britain IMCO recommended all states to enforce observation of
IMCO’s traffic separation schemes on their own ships. An Order in Council
enforces observation on British ships as from 1st September I972-
POLLUTION OF The discharge of oil into British territorial waters was first restricted in 1922.
THE SEA Britain is a party to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of
the Pollution of the Sea by Oil which came into force in 1958. Under amend¬
ments made in 1962 and put into force in 1967 the nations ratifying this con¬
vention (now numbering over 40) agreed to prohibit their national fleets from
discharging persistent oil or oily mixtures within 100 miles (161 kilometres) of
any coast, or in some cases more; ships of 20,000 gross tons and over, built
after 18th May 1967, were prohibited from discharging persistent oil or oily
mixtures anywhere at sea. Amendments agreed upon in 1969 prohibit the
discharge of persistent oil or mixtures containing any oil anywhere at sea
except at a rate which has been shown not to cause harmful pollution; no oil
whatever may be discharged from cargo spaces of tankers within 50 miles (80
kilometres) of land. Britain enforces these restrictions on British ships through
the Oil in Navigable Waters Acts of 1955, 1963 and 1971, now consolidated
within the Prevention of Oil Pollution Act I971- -^n Britain signed the
International Convention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases
of Oil Pollution Casualties, clarifying the rights of a state to take action on the
high seas to prevent pollution of its coastline by oil from a damaged tanker, and
the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage,
facilitating the obtaining of compensation for damage by oil pollution. Britain
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
PORTS
National Ports
Council
Development
34i
is giving effect to the latter convention under the Merchant Shipping (Oil
Pollution) Act 1971. In December 1971 Britain also signed the International
Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation
for Oil Pollution Damage (designed to provide additional compensation).
In February 1972 Britain signed and is now implementing a convention
aimed at preventing dumping of piosonous wastes from ships and aircraft in
the North-East Atlantic, including the North Sea.
There are some 250 port authorities or public wharf operators in Britain, and
about 1,400 other undertakings engaged in various harbour operations, such as
stevedoring, towage, warehousing and lighterage. Port authorities are of four
main types: nationalised bodies, public trusts, local authorities and private
companies.
Since 1948 over a quarter of total port capacity has been owned by the
Government; the majority of these ports, including Southampton, PIull,
Immingham, Cardiff and Swansea, are owned by the British Transport Docks
Board. In 1971 shipping arrivals and departures at the board’s docks totalled
nearly 114-8 million net registered tons (including fishing vessels) and total
cargo handled was 79-4 million tons. The British Railways Board controls cer¬
tain ports, which are largely used for the cross-Channel services of the railways
(for example, Folkestone, Holyhead, Heysham, Stranraer and Parkeston Quay
at Harwich) while the British Waterways Board owns Sharpness (Gloucester)
and Weston Point (Manchester).
The constitutions of public trust port authorities vary considerably. Many
consist of representatives of shippers, importers, exporters, shipping com¬
panies, local authorities and trade unions. Examples of such public trusts
are the Port of London Authority, the Tees and Hartlepools Ports Authority,
and the Belfast Harbour Commissioners. Local authorities own about one-
third of Britain’s ports, including the major port of Bristol, and Preston and
Sunderland. Ports owned by private and limited liability companies include
Manchester, the Mersey (Liverpool) and Felixstowe. Many private ports deal
with the traffic of individual industrial firms in commodities such as petroleum,
china clay and paper pulp.
Port authorities, in the main, operate with statutory powers and responsibili¬
ties set out in private Acts of Parliament. Most are members of the Docks and
Harbour Authorities Association, formed in 1917 to further the common
interests of port authorities in their relations with the Government, ship¬
owners and traders.
The National Ports Council, set up as a statutory body under the Harbours
Act 1964, is financed by a levy on port authorities. It advises the Government
on major port developments and has various responsibilities in relation to
research, training, statistics and charges. It has encouraged the amalgamation
of harbour authorities in certain estuaries into single port authorities, as on the
Forth, Clyde and Tees, and is at present engaged in drawing up, in co¬
operation with the port authorities, a programme of financial, commercial and
management improvements.
Large-scale modernisation of the port transport industry has been taking place
in recent years, as a result both of the increase in Britain’s trade, especially
with other European countries, and of technological changes affecting sea¬
going traffic. The growing size of tankers and bulk carriers has necessitated
more deep-water berths, while development of mechanical handling methods.
342 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
packaging of general cargo, containers and ‘roll-on, roll-off’ services has created
a demand for new types of port facilities. Capital investment in ports has risen
from about £18 million a year in the early 1960s to some ^38 million in 1971.
A major development at Tilbury, port of London, costing £30 million over
a number of years, has provided 12 deep-water berths, including a riverside
grain terminal, four of them for container traffic. Another major scheme
has been the construction of the new Seaforth docks at Liverpool, costing £50
million; the first stage, on completion, will provide ten deep-water berths,
four to handle containers, two to handle bulk grain and meat carriers, and
others to handle computer-controlled general cargo and packaged timber.
Container facilities are being expanded at a cost of some ^14 million for the
Far East traffic at Southampton, where a computer-linked harbour surveillance
and shipping information system is being installed to provide radar and VHF
radio coverage over 20 miles (32 kilometres) of port area. Deep-sea container
facilities have also been constructed at Felixstowe, the Clyde, and Manchester.
In addition over 40 specialised container roll-on berths have been constructed
for the short-sea trades with continental Europe, including Scandinavia and
Ireland. A ^20 million deep-water harbour at Port Talbot, south Wales, serves
as an ore terminal for the British Steel Corporation. Other ore terminals are
to be built at Redcar, Yorkshire, and possibly at Hunterston on the Clyde.
Labour About 90,000 people are employed in the port transport industry of the
United Kingdom. At the end of 1971 43,000 dock workers were registered
with the National Dock Labour Board. They were responsible for the physical
and mechanical handling of cargo. The remainder included administrative,
technical, clerical and commercial staff.
The system of casual labour common among dock workers in the past has
gradually been superseded. A start on ‘decasualisation’ was made in 1941 when
war-time controls were imposed. In 1947 the National Dock Labour Board
was established, with members appointed by the then Minister of Labour and
representing both employers and employed, to administer a scheme under
which registered dock workers received a minimum wage for attendance even
when no work was available. In September 1967 each registered dock worker
was placed in employment on a permanent basis with an employer licensed by
the port authority, under the provisions of the Docks and Harbours Act 1966.
Port Traffic Some 350 million tons of cargo a year pass through the ports of Great Britain.
Of this total coastal traffic of over 100 million tons consists mainly of petroleum
and coal. Of over 190 million tons of imports from overseas some 120 million
tons consists of petroleum and petroleum products. Manufactured goods form
about two-fifths of exports.
A large proportion of the general cargo traffic through British ports is
handled by unitised transport methods in containers and roll-on goods
vehicles, which carried i6’6 million tons of goods in I970, British ports handle
more containers than the rest of northern European ports together and account
for the largest share of the container traffic across the North Atlantic. London,
with traffic rising by over 50 per cent to over 2 million tons, was the leading
port for this type of traffic in 1971; Liverpool, Preston and Felixstowe also
handled large amounts.
Principal Ports Britain’s largest port is that of London. In 1971 some 57 million tons of goods
were handled, including 28 million tons of petroleum and over 6 million tons
of coal.

343
Tanker
Terminals
HOVERCRAFT
Liverpool is the second largest port and Britain’s major export outlet,
especially to deep-sea trading areas. Some 30 million tons of goods are handled
annually, about one-half consisting of dry cargo—grain, chemicals, iron and
steel, and other manufactures.
Southampton is the chief port for ocean passenger traffic, and has a growing
general cargo trade. In 1971 it handled over 29 million tons of goods, including
petroleum, fruit and vegetables, cereals and manufactured goods. It has the
advantages of deep water and double tides. Bristol, with Avonmouth, has a
large traffic in grain imports, and is Britain’s main port for imports of animal
feedingstuffs. The south Wales ports import much of Britain’s requirements
of iron ore, especially through Port Talbot and Newport (Monmouthshire).
Swansea is important for the export of coal, iron and steel and tinplate and oil.
Milford Haven, handling over 40 million tons, has now become Britain’s major
oil port. The inland port of Manchester, reached from the Mersey via the 36-
mile (58-kilometre) Manchester Ship Canal, has at Eastham Britain’s largest
oil dock, covering 19 acres (8 hectares), and exports manufactured goods and
chemicals.
In Scotland the Clyde is the principal port, serving the central industrial area
and possessing a crude oil terminal at Finnart. On the Forth, Grangemouth
is associated with petroleum, petro-chemicals and timber, while Leith is the
port for Edinburgh.
Newcastle and other ports on the Tyne serve England’s industrial north¬
east, and the port of Tees and Hartlepools handles iron ore, steel and engineer¬
ing products, and chemicals, especially fertilisers. Hull and Grimsby on the
Humber handle nearly half the wet fish landed in Britain and are among the
largest white fish ports in the world. With Immingham they serve the industrial
areas of Yorkshire and the Midlands, especially in trade with Scandinavian and
Baltic ports. Belfast is the principal port of Northern Ireland and with Larne
handles the main traffic across the Irish Sea.
Most of the oil tankers coming to Britain to discharge crude oil are berthed at
special tanker terminals owned and operated by the oil companies to serve
their own refineries.
British ports offer the deepest water access in Northern Europe for fully
laden tankers to pipe crude oil direct to refineries. Milford Haven in Wales,
after a £12 million dredging scheme, can accommodate fully laden vessels of
250,000 deadweight tons on all tides at four private oil company terminals.
Finnart on the Clyde will also accept vessels of this size and can be readily
adapted to accept the half-million-ton tankers of the future; it is frequently
used in lightening operations to allow part-laden vessels to proceed with
shallower draft to other ports in Northern Europe.
Pipelines connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the Firth
of Forth, Angle Bay with the refinery at Llandarcy (near Swansea) and Stan-
low (Merseyside) with the refinery at Heysham (Lancashire).
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. Services are run by several privately owned firms, these
include Hoverlloyd Ltd., which has a purpose-built hoverport at Pegwell
Bay in connection with its car and passenger ferries between Ramsgate and
Calais, and Hovertravel Ltd., which operates across the Solent to the Isle of
Wight and has a subsidiary which does training and charter work. Two
publicly owned bodies, the British Railways Board and the Scottish Transport

RAILWAYS

Group, have hovercraft interests. British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail
Hovercraft Ltd. (‘Seaspeed’), was set up in 1966, and is the world’s largest
commercial hovercraft operator. It runs regular services across the Channel
between Dover and Boulogne, and Dover and Calais, using two 165-ton
Mountbatten (SRN4) hovercraft, the largest in the world, carrying passengers
and accompanied cars. It also operates two services across the Solent, and
takes on charter work.
INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain is carried mainly by
road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, pipelines and
inland waterways are important in carrying certain types of freight, particularly
bulk goods. A small proportion of freight goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is publicly owned:
the railways, a large proportion of road passenger and some road haulage
services, most of the inland waterways and some of the vessels on them. Road
haulage is largely, and coastal shipping almost entirely, in the hands of private
enterprise.
In the third quarter of 1971 there were 15-5 million vehicles licensed for
use on the roads. Of these 12 million were motor cars, 1 million motor cycles
and i-6 million road goods vehicles; about two-thirds of the 75,000 public
road passenger vehicles (excluding taxis) were publicly owned.
In 1971 about 63 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage,1 travelled by
road, 18 per cent by rail, 17 per cent by coastal shipping, and 2 per cent by
pipeline and inland waterway.
Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing
congestion problems of increasing severity, especially in cities and towns, and
the changing pattern of demand for transport services have led successive
governments to undertake or commission fundamental studies of probable
trends in transport and problems which may arise therefrom. The Buchanan
report, published in 1963, was the result of a study group set up to examine the
problems of traffic in urban areas. It estimated that Britain would have 40
million vehicles on its roads by A.D. 2010 and proposed radical measures to
rebuild and adapt cities and roads to handle the growth of traffic. It is expected
that the number of vehicles on the roads will double by 1990.
Total passenger mileage is expected to grow by over 50 per cent during the
next ten years with demand for public transport diminishing and travel by
private transport still rising fast. Total freight ton-mileage is expected to
increase substantially, although fuel traffic will fall as a result of structural and
technological change.
Research is being carried out into new forms of inter-urban travel, such as
high-speed passenger trains, tracked hovercraft, and vertical take-off aircraft.
The railway network has been reduced by over a third in the past decade
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
(17,700 route-kilometres) for modernisation and development.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
1 Ton-mileage is calculated by multiplying the tonnage carried by the actual distance
it was transported.
Operations
Development
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 345
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways. Under the Transport Act 1962 the British Railways Board
was set up and came into existence in 1963 with sole responsibility for manag¬
ing railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the board’s financial position
remained unsatisfactory and, following a detailed review of railway policy,
the 1968 Transport Act made far-reaching changes. Capital debt was written
down from ,£1,627 million (of which ,£705 million had already been suspended
under the 1962 Act) to ,£365 million. Grants were introduced for loss-making
rail passenger services which it was considered desirable to maintain for social
or economic reasons; ,£63-1 million was so paid in 1971. Grants not exceeding
a total of ,£50 million may be paid to the board on a gradually diminishing scale
during the years 1969 to 1973 towards the cost of maintaining surplus track
and signalling equipment pending their elimination; ,£7-5 million was paid
in 1971. Deficit financing ceased and the board was then expected to pay its
way. Other provisions of the Act removed certain restrictions on the board’s
powers to manufacture and to run hotels, and reduced the size of the board.
During 1972 the board’s financial position again deteriorated following a
dispute with the railway workers, resulting in a substantial pay award, and a
miners’ strike which severely reduced carryings of coal. Passenger fares and
freight charges were raised in September, and the Government is to provide a
substantial grant.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 6,500 miles (10,461 kilometres) to
11,643 miles (18,737 kilometres) of standard-gauge route since 1961. A total
of 816 million passenger journeys was made and 189 million tons of freight
traffic conveyed on the railways in 1971; total receipts amounted to £595-2
million. The board made a loss of £15-4 million following interest payments of
£45-6 million. At the end of 1971 it employed 264,000 people.
In 1971 a subsidiary, British Transport Hotels Ltd., owned 33 hotels of
which it managed 32. It also managed the catering facilities on trains and
station refreshment rooms.
A subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., runs regular hovercraft services
(see p. 344).
British Rail’s Shipping and International Services division has a fleet of
about 60 vessels, providing passenger and freight services on most of the
important routes between Britain and the Republic of Ireland and on the
short-sea routes to the continent of Europe, as well as on some domestic routes.
Ownership of domestic services in Scotland was transferred to the Scottish
Transport Group under the Transport Act 1968; its two shipping subsidiaries
own some 40 vessels between them.
The board’s second five-year corporate plan was produced in February 1972.
Plans are revised annually and provide a comprehensive analysis of the perform¬
ance and investment requirements of all sectors of the business. In recent
years the most important developments have been the replacement of steam
by diesel and electric traction completed in 1968; the improvement of inter¬
city passenger services with the emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort;
the introduction of express freight services (‘freightliners’) enabling freight
to be handled throughout transit in standard containers (the responsibility
of Freightliners Ltd., see p. 347); and increased mechanisation in the carrying

of coal and other bulk commodities. Capital expenditure in 1971 amounted to
^70-3 million.
At the end of 1971 there were 3,806 diesel and 318 electric locomotives. In
addition there were 3,591 diesel and 7,261 electric passenger-carrying multiple
unit vehicles.
The board’s current programme includes the replacement of old passenger
coaches by new stock with improved amenities, and the construction of new
electric multiple unit stock to replace old vehicles. On certain sections of the
London-Bristol-South Wales line and of the London-Edinburgh line pass¬
enger trains are permitted to run up to 100 mph (161 km/h). Similar speeds
are also in operation on the London Midland Region’s services on the electrified
line between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool. This electri¬
fication scheme, costing some £160 million and completed in i967> was the
largest individual capital investment project ever undertaken by the British
Railways Board and included station reconstruction, bridgeworks, a new
colour-light signalling system and new rolling stock. An approximate increase
°f 75 per cent in numbers of passengers has followed. Electrification is being
extended by 235 route-miles (378 route-kilometres) to Glasgow at a cost of
£25 million; a £30-4 million route rationalisation and resignalling scheme is
associated with it. A £10 million scheme, due for completion in 1974, is to
provide an extension to the Mersey underground railway in central Liverpool.
Motorail services (carrying both passengers and cars) increased their
revenue by 15 per cent in 197* a^d have a current capacity of 120,000 cars on
29 services. Turnover is now worth £i’6 million a year.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new vehicles come into
service and as facilities for concentrating traffic at fewer and better equipped
and sited marshalling yards and terminals are completed. The freightliner
services, the responsibility of Freightliners Ltd. (see p. 347)> serve a network
of over 20 main terminals. Services are operated throughout the country and
to the Continent. The first freightliner ran in 1965.
The London International Freight Terminal, opened in 1967, links the
British Railways Board container port of Harwich with the main freightliner
network. The first fully cellular container ships built in a British yard are
being used in the board’s container services between Harwich and Zeebrugge,
opened in 1968.
The most important freight commodities are coal and steel. The long-haul
carriage of many products in bulk is increasing. Long-term contracts are in
operation for the carriage of cars, oil, china clay, milk, grain, newspapers, steel,
chemicals and other goods. Coal is fed direct from collieries to power stations
in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which coal is loaded and discharged automatically
from high-capacity wagons.
British Railways Board’s subsidiary, British Rail Engineering Ltd., had in
1971 14 main workshops, employing some 35,000 people, mostly on repairs
and construction of rolling stock, locomotives and containers.
The Railway Technical Centre at Derby covers 20 acres (8 hectares) and
employs about 1,900 people. Work is proceeding on a large number of projects,
a major one being the development of a 150 mph (241 km/h) advanced
passenger train’ to run over existing tracks. Like the associated train control
system and some smaller projects, it is being given government financial help.
The National Freight Corporation was set up under the 1968 Transport
Act to provide and promote the provision of integrated road and rail freight

services, making the maximum economic use of rail. The corporation took
over all the road haulage and most of the shipping interests of the Transport
Holding Company, disposing of its shipping interests in 1971, and from the
Railways Board the depots, vehicles, warehouses, containers and other equip¬
ment, though not the actual trains used, in the freightliners and sundries
services, and also the board’s road haulage vehicles. It has a capital of about
£100 million, and employs 55,000 people; annual turnover amounts to some
5^210 million.
Freightliners Ltd., a company jointly owned by the Freight Corporation
and the Railways Board (with 51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares
respectively), is responsible for the marketing and management of freight-
liner services. The Railways Board makes a charge for providing and hauling
the trains, and profits are divided between the board and the corporation in
proportion to their holdings. In 1971 some 500,000 containers were carried on
65 routes.
A Freight Integration Council, set up under the 1968 Act, advises the Depart¬
ment of the Environment and the Secretary of State for Scotland on the
provision of integrated freight services by publicly owned bodies. It consists
of several independent members with an independent chairman, the chair¬
men of the Freight Corporation and the Railways Board, and members
representing union interests.
The British and French Governments have chosen an international group of
banking and other interests with which to pursue the project for a rail tunnel
between Britain and France under the Channel. Final studies for the project
are in progress. The tunnel would provide ferry train services for road
vehicles in addition to through rail services.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress
since 1955. Public expenditure on new and improved roads in Great Britain
is estimated at over £570 million in 1972-73.
Roads are classified according to their traffic value. Trunk roads provide
a national network of routes for through traffic; other roads are divided for
grant purposes into principal and non-principal roads. Motomays are roads
specially designed for high-speed traffic only.
In June 1972 Great Britain had nearly 211,000 miles (339,000 kilometres)
of public highway. There were 9,000 miles (15,000 kilometres) of trunk roads,
of which 1,006 miles (1,619 kilometres) were motorways; 20,412 miles (32,849
kilometres) of principal roads, of which some 36 miles (58 kilometres) were
motorways, and 181,000 miles (291,600 kilometres) of other roads, including
unsurfaced roads.
At the end of June 1972 in England 904 miles (1,455 kilometres) of motorways
had been opened for traffic and construction had started on a further 159 miles
(256 kilometres). Schemes for an additional 299 miles (481 kilometres) were
being prepared. In Wales 23 miles (37 kilometres) were in use. In Scotland
about 140 miles (225 kilometres) of motorway are planned, of which 79 miles
(127 kilometres) are in use. (See map on p. 348.)
A government programme aims to complete by the early 1980s a comprehen¬
sive network of 3,500 miles (5,633 kilometres) of strategic trunk routes, including
2,000 miles (3,219 kilometres) of motorway, serving the major ports, airports
and industrial centres and linking remote regions to the motorway network.

In the interests of improvement of the environment, long-distance and in par¬
ticular heavy goods traffic is being diverted from many towns and villages.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The bridges include the suspension bridge across the Firth of
Forth, the Severn Bridge incorporating major advances in suspension bridge
design, the 7,000-ft (2,134-metre) bridge across the Firth of Tay and the
3,200-ft (975-metre) Weaver Viaduct in Cheshire. A £7 million bridge over
the Clyde at Erskine was opened in 1971, a ten-lane bridge at Glasgow was
opened in 1970, and the new £4 million London Bridge over the river Thames
is to be completed in 1972. The Western Avenue extension in London, a
motorway viaduct 2^ miles (4 kilometres) long, was opened in 1970. A .£10
million bridge and trunk road scheme is in progress at Teesside.
Among several major tunnel schemes is a second Mersey crossing of which
the first of the twin tunnels was opened in 1971; the second is due for comple¬
tion in 1974. A second crossing of the Thames at Dartford, Kent, is also under
construction.
The Government has central responsibility for roads. Since its inception in
1970 the Department of the Environment (see p. 51) has exercised this
responsibility.
The Secretary of State for the Environment is the highway authority for
trunk roads in England and on these roads he administers expenditure, which
is provided wholly from central government sources, although for many pur¬
poses he employs local authorities as his agents. The Secretary of State for
Scotland has corresponding responsibilities for roads in Scotland and the
Secretary of State for Wales for roads in Wales. Work on major trunk road
schemes in England, including motorways, is controlled by regional road con¬
struction units, manned jointly by Department of the Environment and county
council staff. The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the
council of the county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The
Secretary of State makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on con¬
struction and major improvement of these roads and contributions from public
funds towards maintenance and other expenditure is made through grants to
local authorities. Roads other than trunk and principal roads are entirely the
responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
Research on roads is carried out at the Transport and Road Research Labora¬
tory (see p. 389). The laboratory provides technical and scientific advice and
information to help in formulating, developing and implementing government
policies relating to roads and transport, including their interaction with urban
and regional planning. Work is concerned with planning, design, construction
and maintenance of roads and structures such as bridges and tunnels; safe,
efficient and convenient movement of people and goods, including road layout
and transport networks, control of traffic flow, study of road accidents and
methods of reducing their frequency and severity; assessment of existing and
projected passenger or freight transport systems and investigation of technical
developments and their environmental effects.
In 1971 there were 15-5 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great Britain’s
roads. Of these, i-6 million were goods vehicles and 106,000 were public road
passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Road Traffic Act 19301 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas
each under the control of three traffic commissioners. The commissioners are
responsible for ensuring the fitness of vehicles used in public road passenger
transport, and for licensing services in order to secure proper co-ordination
and to eliminate unnecessary competition; to this end they may fix routes,
timetables and fares.
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs.
A new goods vehicle licensing system, aimed solely at improving safety, has
been introduced as provided under the Transport Act 1968. Those operating
vehicles of over 3-^- tons gross weight now require an operator’s licence,
obtained on showing ability to maintain vehicles properly and control loading
and hours worked by drivers. It may also be necessary to demonstrate adequate
financial resources for compliance with these conditions. Licences are granted
by independent, quasi-judicial licensing authorities, and may be revoked,
suspended or curtailed if necessary. Regulations concerning the fitness and
loading of vehicles have become more stringent under recent legislation.
Holders of operators’ licences may carry their own or other people’s goods and
are free of statutory control over their charges. Over 900,000 goods vehicles
not exceeding 3^ tons gross laden weight are exempt from operators’ licensing.
The statutory limit on hours which may be worked by drivers of goods and
public service passenger vehicles were reduced in i970- They are to be reduced
further following Britain’s entry into the European Economic Community; a
mileage limit is to be imposed on drivers of certain large goods vehicles.
Changes in the system of written records to be kept by drivers of goods
vehicles subject to operators’ licensing will also be necessary.
From 1956 to 1963 the nationalised road haulage services were controlled by
British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British I ransport Commission,
and operated through five companies, which together owned about 16,000
vehicles. Under the Transport Act 1962, these organisations operated com¬
panies incorporated under the Companies Act, with their own boards, and
were grouped together under the Transport Holding Company, responsible
to the then Minister of Transport. The road haulage interests of the Holding
Company have been transferred to the National Freight Corporation (see p.
346), which operates some 26,000 vehicles.
The 1968 Transport Act enables Passenger Transport Authorities (PTAs) to
be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of transport in any
particular area. The first PTAs were set up in 1969 in south-east Lancashire-
north-east Cheshire, Merseyside, the west Midlands and Tyneside. The
constituent local authorities appoint most of the members, but up to one-
seventh may be appointed by the Secretary of State for the Environment (or
by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales). Each appoints its own
chairman, with the relevant Secretary of State’s approval. The P TAs control
policy and finance, and appoint professional executives Passenger Transport
Executives—to be responsible to them for day-to-day operations. The execu¬
tives may operate services themselves and enter into agreements with other
bodies, such as the British Railways Board or the National Bus Company, to
operate others; they have taken over all the former municipal bus undertakings
in their areas.
1 Consolidated in the Road Traffic Act i960.
Road Safety
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 351
The National Bus Company was formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and operates through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group has been set up to control bus and
some shipping services in Scotland, and has taken over the relevant interests
of the Transport Holding Company, operating through subsidiaries.
The National Bus Company and the Scottish Transport Group operate
about 21,000 and 4,500 vehicles respectively. The PTAs control 6,100 vehicles.
The remainder of the industry, excluding London Transport, comprises 4,800
operators owning 35,000 vehicles; 69 of these operators are local authorities
outside PTA areas operating 11,000 vehicles, and 3,500 are small concerns
operating not more than five vehicles.
Capital grants may be made by the Government towards the cost of invest¬
ment in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost. Eligible
schemes include improvements or extensions of railway lines, new fixed track
rail and bus systems, interchanges, stations, car parks, urban and suburban
railway rolling-stock, resignalling, train control systems and automatic fare
collection. Grants at the rate of 50 per cent are available towards the cost of
new buses complying with specifications approved by the Department of the
Environment. Local authorities may assist unremunerative bus services in
rural areas.
Britain has one of the highest densities of road traffic in the world. Road
accident statistics are compiled and published by the Department of the
Environment, the Scottish Development Department and the Welsh Office
from reports made by the police. In 1971, 7,700 people were killed on the
roads and about 90,000 seriously injured. The fatal accident rate per vehicle
is lower than that in most other European countries.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 mph
(48 and 64 km/h) in built-up areas and 50 mph (80 km/h) on certain trunk
and important classified roads in rural areas; a 70 mph (113 km/h) speed limit
on all motorways and on all other roads where no lower limit applies; the
provision of pedestrian crossings; and the system of road markings and traffic
signs which are being replaced by improved signs in accordance with general
European practice. A new centrally controlled, computerised signalling system
is being installed on motorways to warn motorists of advisory speed limits in
certain conditions and of lane closures. The Road Safety Act 1967 made it an
offence to drive with more than a prescribed level of alcohol in the blood, at
present 80 milligrammes of alcohol per 100 millilitres of blood.
The design of vehicles, their use on the roads, and the maintenance of their
mechanical condition are controlled by regulations. The regulations are kept
under constant review, and amended whenever necessary in the interests of
safety or for control of pollution and noise. Private cars and light vans which
are three or more years old must be tested annually at private garages author¬
ised as test stations. Heavy goods vehicles are tested annually at government
test stations. Public service vehicles must be specially approved before being
licensed to carry passengers, and are tested at regular intervals. Any vehicle
may be stopped on the road at any time by the police and examined.
All drivers of motor vehicles, unless they have either held a full British
licence or passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the
352
Control of Traffic
LONDON
TRANSPORT
BRITAIN I973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
test before being granted a full licence to drive. Until they pass the test they
must obtain a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’
(Learner) plates on their vehicle. With the exception of solo motor-cycles and
motor-cycle combinations, where vehicles are constructed to carry passengers,
learner drivers must be accompanied by a qualified driver. (Newly arrived
residents of Britain may drive under their overseas driving licences for three
months before becoming subject to these rules.) A learner driver of a solo
motor-cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a machine not
exceeding 250 cc. Professional driving instructors must be approved by the
Department of the Environment. A scheme for special licensing and testing of
drivers of heavy goods vehicles, which lapsed in i939> was reintroduced in
February 1970.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law is set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code. A failure
to observe the code does not of itself render a person liable to criminal pro¬
ceedings but may be taken into account in any such proceedings.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads are
conducted by the Department of the Environment and the Royal Society for
the Prevention of Accidents with assistance from the local authorities, which
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 empowers traffic authorities to make
orders regulating traffic and imposing parking control. With the exception of
trunk roads, which are the concern of the central Government, traffic is the
responsibility of local authorities. Extensive schemes are being undertaken
for the improvement of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion. These
include: ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and traffic
management measures, including comprehensive control of street parking,
‘one-way’ systems, peak hour ‘clearways’ prohibiting waiting on busy roads,
and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements. A Traffic Advisory Unit within the Department
of the Environment advises local authorities. In most town centres street
parking is permitted for limited periods only; in London and many other towns
schemes for payment at parking meters or residents’ parking spaces are undei
the supervision of traffic wardens. Disc schemes providing free but limited
parking facilities are in operation in some towns, including Cheltenham,
Devizes, Harrogate and Ripon. Off-street facilities are being increased, includ¬
ing multi-storey car parks. The Government has embarked on a scheme to buy
sites, for leasing to commercial operators, to provide a network of lorry parks
in England. A computer-controlled system to regulate traffic was installed in
west London in 1968. Similar systems are operating in Glasgow and Liverpool.
London is one of the world’s largest cities. The area known as Greater London,
within a radius of about 15 miles (24 kilometres) from Charing Cross, contains
7-4 million people.
Under the Transport (London) Act 1969, which came into effect on 1st
January 1970, the Greater London Council (GLC) became the overall
transport planning authority for London and assumed responsibility for the
central bus and Underground rail services formerly operated by the London
Transport Board (LTB). These services are managed and operated by the
London Transport Executive, appointed by and responsible to the GLC.

The LTB’s country bus and Green Line coach services were transferred to
London Country Bus Services Ltd., a subsidiary of the National Bus Company
(see p. 351). Under a financial reorganisation the Government wrote off the
entire capital debt of the former LTB, some £270 million.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of the British Railways Board, the Green Line coach services and the taxicabs.
Some 8,250 taxicabs that ply for hire in the streets are privately operated by
companies or owner-drivers and are licensed annually by the Metropolitan
Police. There are about 13,300 licensed cab drivers.
London Transport’s railway network stretches over 20 miles (32 kilo¬
metres) from north to south and 35 miles (56 kilometres) from east to west. In
March 1972 the total length of the railway over which London Transport
trains operated was 257 miles (414 kilometres), of which 104 miles (167 kilo¬
metres) were underground. London Transport trains serve 278 stations and its
buses travel over 1,705 miles (2,744 kilometres) of roads. To carry traffic over
all this area London Transport owns 4,350 railway cars and 6,273 buses. The
total staff employed is over 59,000.
Improvements being carried out by London Transport have included
extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground system, and the
introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic trains. One-man
operation of buses is being steadily extended over a period of years. The
first one-man-operated double decker buses were introduced at the beginning
of 1971; there are to be some 2,000 of these by 1975.
Work on a new 14-mile (23-kilometre) underground railway—the Victoria
Line—between Walthamstow in north-east London and Brixton in south
London was completed in 1971 and work begun on a scheme to link Heathrow
airport with the Underground railway system. Construction of the first stage
of a new Fleet Line began early in 1972.
London Transport set up an international advisory service for city transport
in 1969.
Since 1963 control of inland waterways has been vested in the British Water¬
ways Board. Under the Transport Act 1968 a grant-in-aid is being paid pri¬
marily to enable the board to maintain an extensive network of amenity
waterways; in 1971-72 £2-5 million was paid and a further X°'7 million for
improving bridges. It is proposed as part of the reorganisation of water services
in England and Wales (see p. 282) that in 1974 control of the waterways should
pass to the new Regional Water Authorities and that the board should be
abolished.
There are about 2,500 miles (4,023 kilometres) of navigable inland waterways
in Great Britain, some 2,000 miles (3,219 kilometres) of which belong to
the British Waterways Board; the remainder are mainly in the hands of
local authorities or private companies. Many of the board’s canals are narrow
waterways which can generally be used only by boats not exceeding 7 ft
(2-13 metres) in width; the remainder are broad waterways and canalised rivers,
some of which can be used by craft of up to about 750 tons capacity. The
Caledonian and Crinan Canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the
inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways Board some
340 miles (547 kilometres) are commercial waterways. A substantial additional
mileage (1,100 miles—1,770 kilometres—known as cruising waterways) is being

maintained for recreational purposes; a statutory Inland Waterways Amenity
Advisory Council advises the Secretary of State for the Environment and the
British Waterways Board.
Engineering, commercial and estate work is directed from the board’s
headquarters in London and Watford, and through regional offices at Leeds
and Gloucester. In Scotland the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is
run by a manager) are, for engineering purposes, under the control of the
engineer-in-charge at Glasgow; estates work is supervised from London.
In 1971 traffic on the board’s waterways amounted to just over 5-4 million
tons, of which 2 million tons were coal, 1 -3 million tons liquids in bulk and
2-1 million tons general cargo. Some 95 per cent of the traffic is carried on
340 miles (547 kilometres) of commercial waterways, which are mainly
canalised river navigations.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying operator,
most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders in their
own craft. The board at the end of 1971 owned 499 freight-carrying craft
(including tugs) with a carrying capacity of 22,555 tons. It operates 2 docks
and 25 warehouses.
In Northern Ireland, the only inland waterway which is still used for com¬
mercial transport purposes is the Lower Bann Navigation.
The British Waterways Board is developing its cruising waterways for purposes
of recreation and amenity. These include the Llangollen branch of the Shrop¬
shire Union Canal, the Oxford Canal, and the Leeds and Liverpool Canal.
The principal commercial waterways are the river navigations and broad
canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area, the Trent Navigation, and the
Gloucester and Sharpness Canal. Freight traffic is declining, but some im¬
provements to facilities are being carried out. The board has devised and is
already operating on some of its commercial waterways a specially designed
interlocking modular barge system. A European consortium is building a
mother-ship to carry the barges between Britain and the rest of Europe.
The total turnover of the British Waterways Board in 1971 amounted to
£5-4 million, of which £0-2 million arose from the board’s own freight¬
carrying activities, j£i'3 million from warehousing and terminal services, and
j£i million from the docks. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural
purposes brought in j£o'9 million. Receipts from pleasure boating were
£194,617. The number of pleasure craft licensed in 1971 was 13,948.
Reorganisation of public transport in Northern Ireland was completed in
1968. Under the Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 the Ulster Transport
Authority was wound up and its assets and liabilities transferred to a new
company, the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company. Responsibility
for operating services on the 200 miles (322 kilometres) of railway track was
given to the Northern Ireland Railways Company Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Holding Company. The Act also provides for a licensing system for road
passenger operators.
Ulsterbus Ltd., another subsidiary of the Holding Company, has taken over
the road passenger operations of the authority, which formerly provided
all public road passenger services, apart from those of the City of Belfast. A
number of privately owned bus companies now operate in addition.
In 1966 the authority’s monopoly of road carriage of freight was replaced
by a licensing system. About 1,9°° operators and 4>I5° vehicles have been
licensed, the biggest single operator being Northern Ireland Carriers Ltd.,

On 31st March 1972 there were 14,168 miles (22,800 kilometres) of public
roads in Northern Ireland, comprising 381 miles (613 kilometres) of trunk
roads, 1,018 miles (1,638 kilometres) of Class I roads, 1,736 miles (2,794
kilometres) of Class II roads, 2,883 miles (4,640 kilometres) of Class III roads
and 8,144 miles (13,107 kilometres) of unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and construction work on
these roads. In addition to major construction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway system
in Belfast. About 58 miles (93 kilometres) of motorway were in use by the
middle of 1972.
The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds of
motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees and other statutory payments),
from which grants are made to the local authorities (county, county borough,
borough and urban district councils) which are responsible for the other roads.
The rates of grant range from 90 per cent for major improvement works on
Class I roads to 25 per cent for maintenance work on the unclassified roads.
Gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to 31st March
1971 was ^21 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor improve¬
ments was about ^8 million. Gross capital expenditure in the five-year period
1970-74 is expected to be about £100 million, compared with about £62
million in the five-year period to 31st March 1969. Expenditure on main¬
tenance and minor improvements in the five-year period to 31st March 1971
was ^35 million.
CIVIL AVIATION
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation (BOAC), a public corporation,
took over the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways
Limited in 1940. British European Airways (BEA) was established under the
Civil Aviation Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United
Kingdom and Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, 46
independent air transport operators hold Air Operators’ Certificates.
Under the Civil Aviation Act 1971, a Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and
British Airways Board (BAB) have been set up involving a major reorganisation
of the control of British civil aviation. The new bodies became fully operative
on 1st April 1972.
Following the establishment of the Civil Aviation Authority the Secretary
of State for Trade and Industry remains responsible for international matters
(including negotiation of air service agreements with other countries, the
licensing and control of public transport operations into Britain by overseas
operators and British participation in the activities of the International Civil
Aviation Organisation and other international aviation bodies), amenity
matters such as aircraft noise, and investigation of accidents. The Secretary
of State appoints the chairman and other members of the CAA, and is
356
Civil Aviation
Authority
Licensing
Safety
BRITAIN 1973' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
empowered to give written guidances on the general policies to be followed. The
guidances must be approved by both Houses of Parliament, and the CAA is
then bound by them. The first of these guidances was issued in a report in
February 1972 (see Bibliography p. 482).
The Secretary of State may also give directions, after consultations, to the
CAA, concerning Britain’s relations with other countries, membership of
international organisations or adherence to international agreements, or to
deal with problems of noise, vibration, pollution or other disturbances arising
from the activities of civil aviation. He may also give directions, after consulta¬
tion, to the British Airways Board (BAB) concerning matters affecting the
public interest. The BAB may in turn give directions to the air corporations.
He has powers to make loans to the BAB, with the approval of the Treasury
and within limits laid down by Parliament (see p. 358).
The Civil Aviation Authority has taken over functions previously performed
by the Air Transport Licensing Board and the Air Registration Board (which no
longer exist) as well as a wide range of functions previously performed by the
Department of Trade and Industry. It is separate from and largely independent
of the Government, and responsible for the economic, technical and operational
regulation of the industry, the provision of air navigation services and the
operation of Aberdeen Airport and the Scottish Highlands and Islands aero¬
dromes. It issues licences and certificates to airlines, aircraft, aerodromes and
personnel, including pilots, air traffic controllers and maintenance engineers.
The CAA has been given the objective of recovering, by 1977-78, the whole
of its costs and a reasonable return on capital from the users of its services.
Because it does not itself fix charges for navigation services and because inter¬
national agreement is necessary on charges for navigation services made during
the course of a journey it will take some time to reach this objective; meanwhile
the Government is to pay a progressively reducing grant to meet its deficit on
revenue account, to be assessed annually in advance, and expected to amount
to some £24 million in the first year.
The Civil Aviation Authority operates an air services licensing system, within
which British operators, both state-owned and independent, apply on an equal
footing for licences for scheduled and charter services, or for revocation or
variation of existing licences. It determines categories of licence, content of
applications, and conditions and tariff provisions of licences. It also has power
to exempt particular flights or categories of flights from licence requirements.
In issuing licences the CAA must consider the applicants’ financial resources,
staffing and organisation, the need for the proposed services, their adequacy
and possible effect on existing services, and any representations made by
interested parties. Appeals may be made to the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry.
The CAA is responsible for ensuring the safe operation of civil aircraft, and
initiating relevant preventive measures and research. To this end it has absorbed
the former Air Registration Board, now known as the Airworthiness Division
of the CAA, which is responsible for the code, British Civil Airworthiness
Requirements, with which all aircraft built in Britain must comply. Continued
airworthiness is ensured by regular inspection and by requiring aircraft to
be maintained in accordance with a schedule approved by the CAA. The
authority is advised by an Airworthiness Requirements Board representing
the users.

Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the CAA when
it is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure the safe operation of his
aircraft. It is advised by the flight operations inspectors (who are experienced
airline pilots).
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to supplement the diminishing supply of well-trained pilots for civil
airlines from the Royal Air Force, the College of Air Training was set up at
Hamble in i960. It is sponsored by the Government and the two airways
corporations. Commercial pilots must attend a course of training approved by
the Civil Aviation Authority. Such courses have been approved at the training
schools at Carlisle, Oxford and Perth, in addition to Hamble. The corporations
set up a new engineering apprentice school at Cranebank, near Heathrow, in
I97°-
An Air Transport and Travel Industry Training Board has been established
under the Industrial Training Act 1964.
Responsibility for policy planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Services, under the joint control of the Civil
Aviation Authority and the Secretary of State for Defence
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements. There are three
main air traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston
for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the
Atlantic Ocean to 30°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic. During
the next few years, under a scheme (Mediator) which will eventually cost some
£50 million, virtually the whole of the airspace over Britain above 5,000 feet
(1,524 metres) will be brought under surveillance by the latest types of primary
and secondary radar equipment, which will provide data to be used in two air
traffic control centres, located at West Drayton (near London) and Prestwick.
The first stage was introduced in February 1971. A subsidiary centre will be
located at Manchester to deal with traffic in the Manchester terminal control
area. Extensive use will be made in these centres of automatic data processing
and other advanced electronic techniques. The Civil Aviation Authority
provides radio navigational aids to help pilots to navigate in all weather con¬
ditions, and has installed the Instrument Landing System (ILS) at all its
major airports.
Britain has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully automatic land¬
ing. Both BOAC VCios and BEA Tridents now make regular automatic
landings on scheduled flights.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
