high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating accor¬
ding to civil procedures.
From 1st January 1971 all new types of subsonic aircraft using British airports
are required to hold a ‘certificate of quietness’. The noise standards laid down
in the certificate follow the recommendations of the special meeting held by
the International Civil Aviation Organisation in Montreal in 1969.
Noise abatement measures in force at various airports include limitations
on noise levels at take-off, route restrictions, procedures designed to lessen
noise on the ground, and limits on the number of jet movements during
summer nights.
The chairman and members of the British Airways Board are appointed by the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry. The BAB controls all the activities
of the two publicly owned air corporations, BOAC and BEA, and their sub¬
sidiaries, as a group in the interests of efficiency. The BAB appoints the chairmen
(with the approval of the Secretary of State) and members of the corporations
(formerly appointed by the Secretary of State). It has powers to provide
air transport services anywhere in the world, and to form and acquire sub¬
sidiaries.
The liabilities of the two corporations in respect of Exchequer loans and
Public Dividend capital were extinguished on the creation of the BAB. Loans
and capital issues equal to the amounts then issued to the corporations were
made to the BAB on 1st April 1972. The overall borrowing and investment
limit has been fixed at £560 million; it may be increased up to £joo million by
an order approved by the House of Commons.
The constitution and functions of BOAC and BEA are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act i967> which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 1966, and in the Air Cor¬
poration Act 1969, modified by the provisions of the Civil Aviation Act 1971
setting up the British Airways Board. This Act requires the BAB to review the
affairs of the corporations, and to report to the Government on its findings. A
report published in July 1972 recommended reorganisation with a view to
closer integration of the group’s activities. Reorganisation is expected to
involve several of the subsidiaries of the corporations becoming instead sub¬
sidiaries of BAB.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services by British airlines has more
than trebled since 1959, and had risen to 4>77^ million capacity-ton-miles in
1971. In 1955, 2-5 million passengers entered or left Britain by air, compared
with 5’7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the
first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1971 figures had risen to
24-9 million by air and 11-7 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul operations. Its scheduled services link Britain
with continental Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in seven companies operating local and
regional services in the various parts of the world adjacent to BOAC s main
routes, and in a number of hotel companies in areas attractive to business and
holiday travellers.

The capacity offered on BOAC’s own scheduled services reached 2,325
million capacity-ton-miles in the year ended March 1972 having risen by
17-8 per cent over the previous year. Nearly half of this capacity was on the
western routes to North and South America. The overall load factor in
1971-72 was 47-8 per cent; the break-even load factor (the figure at which
operating costs are covered) was 47-4 per cent. The corporation’s fleet, made
up entirely of pure jets, consists (June 1972) of Super VC 10s (16), VC 10s
(11), Boeing 707-436S (16), Boeing 707-336$ (11); and 12 Boeing 747s with
another one on order. Five Concordes are to be ordered, for service from 1975.
The Boeing 747, introduced into service in 1971, and the VC 10, introduced
into service in 1964, operate alongside Boeing 707s on world-wide routes.
Cargo versions of the Boeing 707 took over transatlantic all-freighter operations
in 1966.
The corporation is making a substantial investment over a period of ten
years in one of the most advanced airline computer systems in the world
(BOADICEA). Applications include seat reservations, departure, cargo, and
stock control, message switching, payroll and costing.
In 1971-72 BOAC earned an operating surplus of ^2 million and a net loss of
£1-4 million after interest on borrowings and taxation. Of its gross traffic
revenue (£212 million), £140 million was earned in foreign currencies.
BEA and its associates operate services to some 100 destinations in 35 countries
in Britain and the rest of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Its
services in Britain include a number which cannot be operated on a commercial
basis but which meet a vital social need, mainly the services to the Highlands
and Islands of Scotland. BEA also co-operates with other airlines in order to
create ‘through travel’ facilities. It has a financial interest in several associated
companies, most of which collaborate with BEA in providing a network of
services. Two major subsidiaries are British Air Services, operating secondary
domestic services, and BEA Airtours Ltd.
For the year ended 31st March 1972 the increases in capacity offered and
passenger-miles flown on scheduled services were 11 per cent and 7 per cent
respectively over the previous year; freight-ton-miles flown rose by 6-2 per
cent. In the same year some 9-1 million passengers were carried.
BEA’s fleet consists (March 1972) of BAC One-Elevens (18), Trident Threes
(17 with 9 on order); Trident Twos (15), Trident Ones (21), Viscounts (20),
Vanguard 951s (4), Vanguard 933s (6) and Herons (2). BEA is converting the
Vanguard aircraft into the Merchantman used solely for freight, of which 8 are
now in service. The first Merchantman service opened in February 1970.
In 1971-72 the corporation earned over £178 million in revenue and made a
net profit of ,£181,000.
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated by the independent operators. As well as domestic and international
services they provide vehicle ferry services; specialised cargo facilities; and
enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays abroad. The independent
companies compete with BEA over several domestic routes, including the
busiest internal route in Europe, from London to Glasgow. In 1971 they
carried some 2-4 million passengers on scheduled services. British Caledonian
Airways, the ‘second force’ airline, has a fleet of some 30 aircraft, used on
360 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
chartered and scheduled passenger and freight services, and carries some
780,000 scheduled service passengers a year. It was formed in 1970 by a merger
of British United Airways and Caledonian Airways. The Government intends
British Caledonian to continue as the principal independent scheduled airline,
and the CAA is required in exercising its licensing functions to provide it with
adequate opportunities to build up its route networks.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction. About 30 companies
carry out air-taxi operations.
The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 17 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1971 the corresponding percentages were 14 in both, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £2,646 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports.
Air Freight Recent rapid growth in freight traffic, especially at Heathrow airport, London,
was checked in 1971, due to unfavourable economic conditions, but the total
still amounted to over 530,000 metric tons, 329,000 tons of it at Heathrow.
Scheduled services of British airlines handled some 238,000 tons in I971-

Trade by Air
Private Flying The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 1,000, while approximately 860 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 15,000 private pilots hold
licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and some 80 companies are
members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association. There are some 4,000
glider pilots.
Aerodromes The Civil Aviation Authority has a general responsibility for licensing civil
aerodromes. It controls directly Aberdeen and eight small aerodromes in the
Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Aerodromes which are municipally or
privately owned and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/
or flying instruction are subject to licensing, inspection and regulation by the
authority, which is also responsible for navigation facilities at a number of
main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority (BAA), an independent statutory body
operating on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and
management of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick),
Prestwick in Scotland and Stansted in Essex. In April 1971 ^ t0°k over
Edinburgh airport. At these airports the Civil Aviation Authority is responsible
for the provision of navigation services; the Department of Trade and Industry
directs the BAA to take measures to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 140 civil aerodromes in Britain; in addition, 50
Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under civil control include
9 directly controlled by the Civil Aviation Authority, 3 Channel
Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island governments,
and 41 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 22 are owned by munici¬
palities. Most of the remainder are owned privately. Two of the CAA’s aero¬
dromes and 32 others are designated customs airports; limited customs facili¬
ties are available at a further 36 aerodromes.

Organisation

A third London airport is to be built at Maplin, on the Essex coast; the first
runway should be in use by 1980.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in recent years, and in 1971 United Kingdom civil airports handled
36 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft engaged on
commercial transport operations was 630,000.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the main
airports, and Heathrow is the busiest centre of international travel in the
world. The number of passengers handled at Heathrow, 14 miles (22 kilo¬
metres) west of central London, has increased from 5-4 million in i960 to
16-4 million in 1971 of which most were international passengers. The
shorter of the two main Heathrow runways was extended to 12,800 feet (3,900
metres) in 1971. An £11 million passenger terminal primarily for British
short-haul airlines and Aer Lingus was completed in 1969, and extensions
have been made to several other buildings. To accommodate the rapid
expansion expected in freight movements, £25 million has been invested in
a new cargo terminal and associated developments, which came into use in
1969. New facilities costing some ^13 million have been provided for handling
Boeing J4J (jumbo jet) aircraft, which began to use the airport early in 1970.
Work is proceeding on the extension of London’s Underground railway to
Heathrow. The London Airport Cargo Electronic-data-processing scheme
(LACES) came into full operation at Heathrow in 1971, making Britain the
first country to control incoming cargo by computer.
The airport at Gatwick, 28 miles (45 kilometres) south of London, was
opened in June 1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built along¬
side the main London to Brighton railway and the A23 road, Gatwick airport
was the first in the world to contain road, rail and air transport in one unit.
In 1971 it handled 4-7 million passengers. The existing runway has been
extended; a further extension is under consideration.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft. Already one of the best equipped freight airports in the world, a
new cargo terminal is being built there. The airport at Abbotsinch, owned and
run by the Glasgow Corporation, handled i-8 million passengers in 1971.
A new main runway and other improvements are planned for Edinburgh.
Luton airport handled 2-7 million and Manchester airport handled 2-2 million
passengers in 1971; while Belfast handled over a million passengers. Birming¬
ham, Edinburgh, Prestwick, Stansted and Liverpool each handled over
500,000.
THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides postal, public telecommunications,
data processing and Giro services. It was set up as a public authority under the
Post Office Act 1969, having previously been a government department.
The Post Office is headed by a chairman and board, appointed by and respon¬
sible to the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications. It has some 420,000
employees and approaching 25,000 post offices.
The Post Office has authority to borrow up to £2,800 million. At 31st March
1972 it had borrowed £2,460 million. Over 90 per cent of total expenditure
Finance
362
Postal Services
Counter
Services
Telegraph
Services
Telex Service
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
on fixed assets is accounted for by telecommunications. The postal, tele¬
communications and data processing services are now managed separately.
Approaching 10,550 million items of correspondence and 189 million parcels
are carried annually by the inland postal services. An increasing amount of
correspondence is sent by air, reaching 418 million items in 1971-72; 2-6
million parcels were sent by air in that year.
New highly mechanised sorting office buildings are being opened in Britain.
Letter segregating and facing machines have been installed at over 30 centres.
Postal address coding (Postcode) has been introduced. Some £50 million is
being invested in an improved parcels service.
A ‘Datapost’ special delivery service for computer data and important
packages was started in 1970; it has been expanded to provide some 5,000
services each week.
The British Postal Consultancy Service offers professional advice on all
aspects of postal business to overseas administrators and to business organisa¬
tions. Subjects covered include management methods and systems, postal
circulation systems, containerisation, planning of buildings and mechanisation.
Work was done in 1971-72 for ten overseas postal administrations.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, a person can draw a pension or a family allowance, buy a licence for
his dog, a licence for his television receiving set, renew a car licence, buy
national insurance stamps, use the savings and investments facilities (see p.
214) and the money transmission services of the National Giro. In much of its
counter service the Post Office acts as agent for government departments and
local authorities.
Britain has one of the most up-to-date telegraph systems in the world and gives
direct connection between any of the 320 or so larger telegraph offices. The
international telegraph services were shared until 1950 between the Post
Office and Cable and Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public
ownership in 1947. The Post Office operates all telegraph services from Britain
except those offered by foreign telegraph companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd.
continues to operate its cable and wireless services in many dependencies and
foreign countries.
Telegraph services to countries overseas are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from eleven other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France,
Federal Republic of Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway
minimises delivery delay. In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the
development of telegraph message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service combines the speed of the telephone with the accuracy of
the printed word. Calls may be made direct between the rapidly increasing
number of telex users in Britain (about 38,000 by the end of 1971) and als0 to
well over 400,000 subscribers throughout the world. Britain is linked to over
170 countries by telex. The United Kingdom telex service is fully automatic
and immediate connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber within
the country, and to many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand, the United
States, Canada, Australia and South Africa. Calls to countries without an auto¬
matic service are connected through the International Telex Exchange in
Datel
Services
Telephone
Services
Special Telephone
Services
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 363
London. International telex traffic is growing annually by about 20 per cent;
the Post Office is planning for a system of about 100,000 United Kingdom
subscribers by 1980. A radioteleprinter service extends the use of telex to ships
at sea (see p. 365).
The demand for facilities enabling digital data for computers to be transmitted
over telephone and telegraph lines has greatly increased; to meet it the Post
Office has developed a range of datel services providing for transmission at
speeds of up to no bits per second over telegraph-type circuits and up to
2,400 bits per second over speech-type circuits. Speeds of 48,000 bits per
second can be accommodated by special arrangement. Most of the datel
facilities are available internationally and over telegraph or speech-type
circuits. In the year ending March 1972 the number of British Post Office datel
terminals amounted to some 19,000.
At the end of March 1972 there were 6,167 l°cal telephone exchanges and
nearly 15 million telephones. During 1971-72 1-3 million new lines were in¬
stalled. All London’s exchanges are now automatic. Trunk dialling by sub¬
scribers (STD) began in Bristol in 1958; by March 1972 the facility had been
extended to 3,861 exchanges, serving 93 per cent of subscribers, all of whom
should have STD by 1974.
Hull Corporation is the only municipality to exercise its option of operating
its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this service is
connected to the Post Office trunk network.
The first operational electronic exchange in Europe was opened at Amber-
gate, Derbyshire, in 1966. There are now over 100 such exchanges in Britain.
Large electronic exchanges with capacities of up to 40,000 lines are due to come
into service in major cities by the mid-1970s.
Pulse code modulation systems are being used to increase the circuit
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Over 2,640
should be installed by the end of 1972. A new time-division electronic
switching system for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code modu¬
lation systems has been used experimentally. Research is proceeding into a
new digital transmission and waveguide system to increase capacity.
International subscriber dialling operates from London, Edinburgh,
Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool and Manchester, and to most of western
Europe and the United States. Britain has two automatic international
telephone exchanges in use and a third under construction. It is expected that
by 1975 75 per cent of international calls will be dialled by the subscriber,
compared with 62 per cent in 1971.
Operator-connected calls are handled at London international exchanges,
from which almost 3,000 direct telephone circuits provide service to European
countries. Direct links via transatlantic and Commonwealth cable networks,
communications satellites and high frequency radio provide service to over 50
countries outside Europe. Almost every country can be reached from the
international exchanges, via intermediate points where necessary.
A radio tower, 620 feet (189 metres) high, in London provides microwave
radio links for carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There
are over 100 Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a
tower of 500 feet (152 metres) in Birmingham.
Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the ‘999*
emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
364
Private
Telecom¬
munications
Services
Submarine
Cables
Satellite
Communica¬
tions
BRITAIN 1973'. AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services. A public radiotelephone service operating in London and south
Lancashire enables users of vehicles fitted with suitable equipment to make
or receive calls to or from any telephone in the United Kingdom network.
Recorded information services include: the speaking clock, weather forecasts,
motoring information, recipes, ‘Test match’ cricket scores, Financial Times
share index and business news summary, and ‘Dial a Disc’. In London a
recorded service provides details in five languages of events taking place, and
a similar service, in English only, is provided in Edinburgh during the summer.
There are over 100,000 private circuit stations not connected with the public
exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for private use
for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo-telegraphy, tele¬
vision, music, or for the transmission of signals which represent data for
computers or operate other devices.
There are some 385 underwater cables in the national network, totalling over
2,000 miles (3,218 kilometres). To help meet rapidly expanding demand for
communications between Britain and the continent of Europe three new
submarine cables with capacities exceeding 1,200 circuits have been brought
into service recently and six more will be added over the next four years.
Cable systems using transistors in place of thermionic valves have been
developed by British manufacturers in consultation with the Post Office
Research Station and are used in many new systems. A comprehensive
Commonwealth telephone cable plan was agreed upon in 1958 and carried out
by Cable and Wireless Ltd. in co-operation with the Post Office. The plan
covered the construction of three long-distance telephone cable systems:
CANTAT 1 (2,100 nautical miles), from Scotland to Canada, was opened in
1961; COMP AC (8,130 nautical miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New
Zealand and Australia, opened in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles),
connecting Australia, New Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singa¬
pore, was completed in stages from 1965 to 1967. The submarine cables are
linked overland across Canada and Australia by radio microwave systems.
CANTAT 1 was the first single-cable ocean telephone system to use the new
lightweight cable and rigid two-way repeaters, both developed by the Post
Office.
Since CANTAT 1 was laid between Britain and Canada telephone calls
have risen sevenfold. CANTAT 2, for which a contract was announced in June
1971, will double telephone links across the Atlantic, with its 1,840 circuits.
It will cover 2,700 nautical miles between Cornwall and Nova Scotia.
The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was brought
into operation in 1962, and took part in the first experiments in satellite
communications using the Telstar and Relay satellites. The station now
provides commercial telephone and television circuits via high-capacity, geo¬
stationary satellites positioned over the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. By May
1972 Britain had satellite links with 35 countries via 29 earth stations. A third
large aerial at Goonhilly came into service in August 1972. The satellites
used in the global communications systems are provided by INTELSAT
(International Communications Satellite Consortium) of which Britain is the
second largest shareholder. The number of satellite circuits used by Britain,
30 at the end of 1965, is expected to reach 770 by the end of 1972.
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
Radio
Communica¬
tions with
Ships at Sea
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has 11 coast radio stations in the United Kingdom which provide
radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea at
ranges of up to some 500 miles (805 kilometres) and 250 miles (402 kilometres)
respectively. There is also the long-distance radiotelegraph and radio¬
telephone station, Portishead Radio, which communicates with ships in all
parts of the world. Traffic handling capacity is being increased under a six-
year modernisation programme due for completion in 1974.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for any vessel in
distress. During 1971-72 the stations handled 796 urgency and distress calls.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone calls between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast naviga¬
tional warnings and weather bulletins.
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropriate medical authorities
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. During
1971-72, 458 medical cases were dealt with in this service.
Data
Processing
Service
Since the Post Office in 1957 set up an installation to process payroll, pensions
and statistical work, it has become one of the largest users of automatic data
processing equipment and techniques in Britain. Its computer organisation is
divided into two parts: the Post Office Data Processing Service for its own
internal services, and the National Data Processing Service for services to
business firms and other external users.
In addition to stock control and telephone billing, computer systems are
used for large-scale document and information retrieval systems, the Giro
system, scheduling of mail vans in London, the LACES import-handling
system at Heathrow airport (see p. 361), and control of revenue collection from
television licences. In its 14 regional computer centres the Post Office Data
Processing Service operates over 30 computers and is processing over 120
projects. Techniques and equipment employed by the staff of over 3,500, of
whom some 650 are systems analysts and programmers, include optical and
magnetic ink character reader/sorters; direct keying of data on to discs and
magnetic tapes; and the direct recording of data from magnetic tapes to micro¬
film.
‘Confravision* The world’s first purpose-built system of conferences by television, ‘Confra-
vision’, was introduced by the Post Office in September 1971. Using Post
Office video circuits the service allows private communication between studios
in London, Birmingham, Bristol, Glasgow, and Manchester.
Research The Post Office is spending over £18 million a year on research and develop¬
ment, in collaboration with industry and the universities. A new £8 million
research centre is being built at Marti esham Heath, Suffolk, to replace
eventually the laboratories at Dollis Hill.
16 EMPLOYMENT
The Department of Employment is principally responsible for industrial
relations, pay policy, employment, training and related manpower questions
(see p. 51). In Northern Ireland employment matters are among the
responsibilities of the Ministry of Health and Social Services.
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1971 was
24-8 million, about 46 per cent of the total population, and included some 73
per cent of people of normal working age (15 to 59 years for women, 15 to 64
years for men). About 90 per cent of the men of working age are today in or
seeking gainful work. The remaining 10 per cent consist mainly of those con¬
tinuing their education, of the severely disabled and of some people of private
means. The proportion of women of working age in or seeking gainful work
is much lower, about 54 per cent, as many housewives do not undertake paid
employment outside the home. Nearly 63 per cent of the women at work are
married. Besides those of normal working age, there are over a million older
men and women still at work. The great majority of the working population
work for a wage or salary, but about 1 -7 million are employers or self-employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 2-8 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2-3 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 38 per cent, and
farmers and smallholders working their own holdings account for about one-
twelfth of the working population.

age in 1972-73 is expected to result in a sharp fall in the working population
during the following year.
Though successful development policies in the less prosperous regions may
raise the working population above the levels forecast, any increasing demand
for labour must in general be met by better deployment of manpower, im¬
proved productivity and more training. Non-employed married women form
the only substantial reserve and the Government is studying how to overcome
the obstacles hindering the employment of married women who are willing to
work.
The industrial distribution of employees is shown in Table 35. Of all employees
about 40 per cent are employed in the manufacturing and mining industries
and only about 1 -6 per cent in agriculture and fisheries. Over 57 per cent of
those in manufacturing are in the metal, engineering, vehicles and chemicals
groups of industries.
Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the

The numbers given in Table 35 as working in an industry or service include
those engaged on administrative, technical and clerical work, so that the totals
given for the production industries are greater than the numbers on productive
processes. It is estimated that in April 1972 in manufacturing industries in
Great Britain 27 per cent were administrative, technical and clerical em¬
ployees (the ratio ranged according to industry from 13 per cent in clothing
to 40 per cent in chemicals and allied industries).
As an aid to government manpower policies the Department of Employment
maintains a continuing study of manpower resources and requirements by
occupation over a period of five to ten years ahead for both the whole economy
and for some particular industries and occupations.
The Department of Employment also co-operates with industrial training
boards (see p. 372) on technical problems of forecasting. Its forecasts are
designed to help with industrial and manpower planning, recruitment, training
and careers advice.
Unemployment The general unemployment rate in Britain as a whole was among the lowest in
the world during the 20 years prior to 1967—usually between 1 and 2 per cent
—but has been rising since then. It has been relatively low in the south-east of
England, and consistently higher in those parts of the country which have the
greatest dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and certain branches of the
heavy engineering and metal manufacturing industries, notably parts of Scot¬
land and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside. These areas have
been the subject of a series of measures of selective assistance to stimulate
industrial expansion; and counter-measures have been taken to limit expansion
in areas of manpower shortage (see p. 262). The general unemployment rate in
Great Britain in July 1972 was 3-6 per cent; the areas with the highest rates
were Merseyside, Wales and Scotland.
Northern The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
Ireland self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 598,300 in
March 1972 (390,600 males and 207,700 females). The number of insured
employees was 523,700* The largest productive industries are agriculture,
engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in Northern
Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In July 1972 ^ was ^"7 Per cent °f insuied
employees. The Northern Ireland Ministry of Commerce has wide powers
(similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the development and diversification
of industry. It is using these powers vigorously in an attempt to improve the
situation (see p. 264).
EMPLOYMENT SERVICES
The main government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the country-wide network of local employment offices of the Depart¬
ment of Employment. The services in Northern Ireland are run on similar
lines by the Ministry of Health and Social Services but there are some varia¬
tions related to the much smaller area of administration.
Specialised
Employment
Services
Professional and
Executive Register

Youth
Employment
Service
EMPLOYMENT 369
In December 1971 the Government announced plans for reorganising and
modernising the employment service over the next few years (see p. 370).
The employment offices provide a comprehensive service for employers
needing staff and for people, whether or not already in employment, seeking
jobs. Information and advice on any employment problem is available to all.
Use of the service is voluntary. Employers and individuals alike remain free
to use general or specialised fee-charging private employment agencies and
direct recruitment by advertisement or personal introduction.
The employment offices handle the full range of occupations and deal with
full-time, part-time and temporary vacancies. Details of unfilled vacancies (or
of people seeking jobs) can be circulated quickly in the ‘travel to work’ area,
or more widely if necessary. Local employment committees, on which em¬
ployers, workers and other local interests are represented, are attached to the
employment office network as advisory bodies to secure the full benefit of local
knowledge and the close co-operation of employers and workers.
A commercial employment service (office and shop work) is available at all
employment offices and also at a number of commercial employment offices. In
the hotel and catering industry a specialist service is based on the Hotel and
Catering Trades Exchange in London.
The Regular Forces Resettlement Service, in which the Department of Em¬
ployment collaborates with the Ministry of Defence and the voluntary organisa¬
tions concerned with ex-regulars, helps members of the Forces to achieve a
satisfactory transition to civilian life.
In areas where there are large groups of hospitals, there are specially trained
officers in the employment service to deal with the employment problems of
nurses, midwives and those in related occupations or who wish to enter those
professions. Elsewhere nursing employment work is done as part of the general
employment service.
Special teams of Department of Employment officials plan the redeployment
of large groups of redundant workers to new jobs.
The Professional and Executive Register provides a recruiting service for pro¬
fessional occupations, general administrative, managerial and executive cate¬
gories, and for technical and scientific posts. The service is available at offices
located in the main centres of population.
The Occupational Guidance Service is available in 44 centres of population. It
is available free to anybody over the age of 18 who has left school and who
wishes to take expert advice before choosing or changing his occupation.
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is available to all young
people up to the age of 18, or older if they are still at school. Its main functions
are to work with careers teachers in schools in providing young people and
their parents with information on educational and employment opportunities;
to give vocational guidance to young people in their later years at school; to
help young people to find suitable employment and employers to find suitable
workers; and to follow up the progress of young people in employment and
give them any further help or advice they may need. The Secretary of State for
Employment has responsibility for the service and is advised by a National
Youth Employment Council. Central administration is the responsibility of
the Central Youth Employment Executive which consists of senior officers of
the Department of Employment and the education departments.
Local education authorities have the option of operating the service in their
37°
Disablement
Resettlement
Service
The Future of
the Employment
Service
Mobility of

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
own areas. Where an authority provides an approved scheme, 75 per cent of its
expenses is reimbursed from state funds. Some 143 local authorities covering
approximately 80 per cent of the school population operate the service based
on their own careers offices. In the remaining parts of the country the service
is provided from careers offices of the Department of Employment.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that the
service is operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local
education authorities and other educational and industrial interests.
The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled people
to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving age
who is substantially handicapped. The Department of Employment is
responsible for the administration of the service and is assisted by the National
Advisory Council on the Employment of the Disabled.
Vocational guidance and help in finding employment is given at local offices
by specialised disablement resettlement officers (DROs) who, where necessary,
arrange for a course of industrial rehabilitation or training or both. A Register
of Disabled Persons is maintained and all employers of 20 or more persons are
required to employ a quota (at present 3 per cent for all industries, except
shipping in respect of the manning of ships) of registered disabled persons.
Industrial rehabilitation is provided at 25 units (including one combined
medical/industrial rehabilitation unit) run by the Department of Employment.
Attendance at a unit is voluntary and maintenance allowances are paid. The
Department of Employment also gives financial assistance to seven voluntary
and other organisations operating eight rehabilitation centres.
There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government
Training Centres (see p. 372), educational institutions and employers’ estab¬
lishments. For the more seriously disabled there are special residential training
colleges run by voluntary organisations with the help of the Department of
Employment. Grants are available to disabled people qualified to undertake
study or training for professional or comparable employment.
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making company, partly supported by public
funds, provides sheltered employment for over 7,600 registered severely dis¬
abled people who are unlikely to obtain work except under special conditions.
The Department of Employment helps local authorities and voluntary
organisations with the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment for
2,860 severely disabled sighted workers and for 2,650 blind workers.
Plans for reorganising and modernising the employment service were announ¬
ced in December 1971. These include the setting-up of a self-managing
departmental agency within the Department of Employment to administer the
employment service; a rapid increase in the number of ‘self-service employ¬
ment offices; a separate management for the Professional and Executive
Register; an expansion of the Occupational Guidance Service; changes in the
structure of the Youth Employment Service, so that local authorities could in
general become responsible for all those still in education outside the uni¬
versities ; the reorganisation of the service for the disabled; and the increasing
use of computers and other modern equipment and techniques, particularly as
an aid for matching the requirements of jobs and job seekers and for vacancy
circulation.
As part of the policy of assisting geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the department also makes grants

unemployed workers moving to new employment, and therefore settling, in
another area; to key workers transferred by a firm into a development or inter¬
mediate area to inaugurate a new plant; and to local unemployed workers
recruited to new plants in areas of high unemployment and sent to the parent
works for preliminary training.
The Government offers incentives specifically to encourage industrial expan¬
sion and thereby increase employment in the assisted areas (see p. 262). The
incentives include grants towards the cost of new building and equipment and
wage and salary costs; training grants (see p. 373); and a regional employment
subsidy. Some of this assistance is tied to the creation of more jobs.
In general, people coming to Britain for employment (including Common¬
wealth citizens who do not have the right of abode, see p. 12) need a work
permit issued by the Department of Employment. This must be obtained by
the prospective employer and issued for a specific job and for a fixed initial
period not exceeding 12 months. People admitted may change their jobs with
the approval of the department and normally their stay is extended if they
remain in approved employment. After four years’ approved employment
conditions of admission may be cancelled; a worker’s stay is then no longer
subject to a time limit and he may change employment without restriction. The
issue of work permits is controlled by the department in the light of the
availability of suitable manpower from the resident population and subject to
certain conditions regarding wages.
Nationals of the European Economic Community countries do not require
permits (see below) but for other foreign men permits are issued only for
skilled work in industry and commerce. Subject to an annual quota, unskilled
and semi-skilled may, however, be admitted for work in the hotel and catering
industry. Single men, and married men coming for joint employment with
their wives, are admitted for resident domestic work but permits are not issued
to those known to have dependants. Foreign nationals may also enter Britain
as student employees on a short-term basis to enable them to improve their
English and widen their experience.
Permits for Commonwealth citizens are generally issued only to those holding
professional or other specialised qualifications, skills or abilities, and to those
coming to do work considered valuable to the country. Commonwealth
citizens are also admitted for limited periods (fixed in advance) for in-service
training.
In Northern Ireland employment permits are required for non-Northern
Ireland workers. Legislation defines Northern Ireland workers and makes
certain occupations exempt.
Under the European Communities’ regulations regarding the free movement
of workers, which Great Britain is due to implement on 1st January 1973,
nationals of member countries may, without special permission, enter the
territory of another member state to look for or to take a job already arranged.
In Northern Ireland there will be a transitional period of about five years before
this applies.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements for
assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in other
member countries.

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
INDUSTRIAL TRAINING
Most industrial and commercial training has always been carried out by indivi¬
dual employers, but in recent years the Government has taken a number of
measures based on the economic need to provide trained manpower to sustain
future economic growth and the social need to offer to teach a trade to workers
who missed the chance of an apprenticeship when they left school.
Under the Industrial Training Act 1964 some 27 industrial training boards have
been appointed to be responsible for the quantity and quality of industi ial train¬
ing in the industry concerned; over 15 million employees or about 85 per cent of
those in industry and commerce to whom the Act applies are covered. Each
board raises a levy from undertakings within its scope (small undertakings are
exempted from the levy), and makes grants to those whose training programmes
it approves. Some boards also provide their own training courses, or arrange
for other organisations to provide training. The Department of Employment
meets the initial administrative costs of each board and makes grants towards
certain other expenditure: for example, for capital expenditure on new semi¬
skilled training places in development and intermediate areas. To advise the
Secretary of State on the administration of the Act and on industrial training
questions generally, there is a Central Training Council (CTC) consisting of
employer and trade union members, representatives of nationalised industries,
educationists, selected chairmen of training boards and others with a special
interest in industrial training. It also advises on the running of the Industrial
Training Service (ITS), an independent non-profit-making body sponsored
by the Department of Employment and the CTC. The ITS helps companies,
employers’ associations and industrial training boards in any industry in the
identification of training needs, the formulation of training policy, job analysis
for any occupational categories, training programme design and the assess¬
ment of training effectiveness.
The Government Training Opportunities Scheme (TOPS), administered by
the Department of Employment, is intended to meet the training needs of both
employers and individuals. Training is carried out at 54 Government Training
Centres (GTCs) which are within easy reach of the main industrial areas of the
country. Courses are available in over 50 different trades. Most courses last for
six months but a few are longer. Training under the scheme is also provided in
colleges and employers’ establishments. For severely disabled people training
is provided at four residential training colleges run by voluntary organisations
with government financial assistance. Trainees are paid allowances which vary
according to the number of their dependants and their former earnings.
Allowances are substantially higher than unemployment benefit.
Over the next few years the Government plans to expand the scheme
substantially. The range of courses will be made much wider and more training
places will be provided, so that by 1975 not less than 60,000-70,000 people a
year will receive training, thereafter increasing as soon as possible to 100,000.
The Government also offers industry a wide range of training facilities outside
the scope of the TOPS. The Training Within Industry Scheme (TWI) is in¬
tended to develop the skills of supervisors in instructing and communicating,
in improving methods and in preventing accidents. Special courses are avail¬
able for supervisors employed in offices, retail distribution and hospitals, and
also an in-plant training development service to aid selection and further the
EMPLOYMENT
373
Training Aids in the
Assisted Areas
New Training
Body
Legislation and
Conventions
training of operatives as instructors. Training officers of the Department of
Employment either give these courses or train employers’ nominees to enable
them to run TWI courses in their own concerns. Other Department of Em¬
ployment training services for employers include courses for operators and
clerks on how to train new employees and training in export office procedures.
In addition, two-week and one-week courses in basic and advanced instruc¬
tional techniques for the training of individual instructors are available to
outside firms (as well as GTC staff) at the Department of Employment’s two
Instructor Training Colleges (one in England and one in Scotland), and at six
Instructor Training Units attached to GTCs. Where the number of instructors
to be trained warrants it, these courses may be conducted on the employer’s
premises. In 1971 about 23,000 people received training under the Department
of Employment schemes for industry.
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWI courses, and courses at In¬
structor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the International Labour Organisa¬
tion or technical assistance provided jointly by the Department of Employment
and the Overseas Development Administration of the Foreign and Common¬
wealth Office).
The Department of Employment provides additional training aid specifically
for employers in the assisted areas (see p. 262). New and expanding firms may
obtain grants towards the cost of training workers for additional jobs (in 1971
these grants assisted the training of about 50,000 workers), and free depart¬
mental courses for supervisors and industrial training instructors as well as the
loan of departmental mobile instructors to conduct in-plant training. Grants
are also available for any employers who engage and retrain for permanent
employment workers aged 45 and over who have been unemployed for at least
eight weeks. In addition, the department provides grants through the indus¬
trial training boards to promote craft and technician training and to provide
equipment needed for training to semi-skilled level.
In August 1972 the Government announced its intention of setting up a
training services agency within the Department of Employment to administer
the department’s training services, co-ordinate the work of the industrial
training boards, and provide training services in those areas of industry not
covered by the training boards.
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
Though Britain has been a pioneer in the introduction of protective legislation
for the safety, health and welfare of employees and in providing certain legal
immunities for trade unions, until recently there were relatively few legal
restrictions on the right of an employer to hire an employee on any terms which
he would accept and to dismiss him at will. The employee in general looked
to his trade union to protect him. The determination by statute of minimum
wages, holidays and holiday pay was in principle confined to those trades and
industries where the organisation of employers or workers, or both, was inade¬
quate to negotiate collective agreement and to ensure their observance (see p.
382). However, both the 1971 Industrial Relations Act (see below) and other
recent legislation provide considerable safeguards for the employee in his terms
of employment as well as working conditions. The Terms and Conditions
of Employment Act 1959, as amended under the 1971 Industrial Relations
374
Wage Rates
and Earnings
BRITAIN 1973' AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Act, provides machinery for enforcing on an employer the observance of terms
or conditions established by collective agreement in his industry. The Con¬
tracts of Employment Act 1963, also amended by the 1971 Industrial Relations
Act, requires an employer to give an employee comprehensive information on
terms and conditions of employment, including information about his right
to choose whether to belong to a trade union and the procedure available to him
where he has a grievance about his employment; it also lays down the right of
both employers and employees to minimum periods of notice when employment
is to be terminated. Under the Redundancy Payments Acts 1965 and 1969
employees with a minimum period of service of two years are entitled to lump
sum payments if their jobs cease to exist (for example, because of technological
improvements or because of a fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer
suitable alternative work, the cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to
by industry as a whole. The 1971 Industrial Relations Act gives protection
against unfair dismissal by providing machinery under which an employee may
bring an action against an employer for unfair dismissal, and seek re-engage-
ment or compensation; gives new legal support to the right to trade union
organisation by requiring an employer to recognise a trade union in certain
circumstances, and by making it an unfair industrial practice (see p. 382) to
refuse to employ, or to discriminate against, a person because he is a trade
union member; and lays down that written collective agreements between
trade unions or other organisations of workers on the one hand, and employers
or organisations of employers on the other, are to be considered legally binding
unless they contain express provisions to the contrary. The Race Relations Act
1968 (see p. 147) makes it illegal for an employer to discriminate on the grounds
of race, colour or ethnic or national origin in the engagement, dismissal or
employment of workers.
Other legislation prescribes minimum standards of safety, health and welfare
in most places of employment (see pp. 377-81). However, it is recognised that
the causes of many accidents are not amenable to statutory control. Therefore,
voluntary action taken by employer organisations, often in association with
trade unions, is encouraged.
The code of industrial relations practice, which came into effect in February
1972 (see p. 383), interprets industrial relations in the widest sense, offering
guidance not only on procedural matters such as collective agreements and
negotiating machinery but also on good human relations and policies directly
affecting the individual in the performance of his job.
Minimum or standard time rates for the lowest-rated manual workers, as
determined by agreements or by statutory orders, vary between £0-28 and
£0-58 an hour for men and between j£o-2i and ^0-50 for women, although
many employers pay higher rates. Higher rates are also usually paid for shift¬
work and overtime, and weekly earnings may be further increased by piece¬
work rates and other incentive schemes. Piecework rates are of declining
importance in a number of industries, where methods of production tend to
dictate the output of a worker.
On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted regularly by the
Department of Employment into earnings and hours of work in manufacturing
industries and some non-manufacturing industries throughout Britain, the
average earnings of full-time male adult manual workers in October 1971 were
£0 69 an hour and £30-93 a week. Full-time women manual workers at the
same date earned an average of £0-42 an hour and £15-80 a week.
Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be lower than the
EMPLOYMENT
375
EARNINGS, WAGE RATES, RETAIL PRICES,
corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually closing. Women’s
earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly because on average they
work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at premium rates, but also because
a smaller proportion of women do skilled work. The Equal Pay Act 197°
provides that from 29th December 1975 a woman doing the same or broadly
similar work to a man will qualify for equal pay and conditions of employment.
Between October 1962 and October 1971 average weekly wage rates in¬
creased by 73 per cent and the average weekly earnings of manual workers,
before tax and national insurance deductions, by 95 per cent. Part of the in¬
crease has been offset by a rise in prices of about 54 per cent and by larger
national insurance contributions and income tax. The trends of earnings, wage
rates, retail prices, wages and salaries per unit of output from 1963 to 1971 are
shown in the diagram above.
Salaries and
Fees
Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of ^800-^1,200 (lower for trainees
376 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of full-time non-manual workers in April 1971 were found
by a Department of Employment survey to be about ^39-10 for men and
£19-80 for women. On average, salaries doubled between 1961 and 1971.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £3,000 to £12,000 a year. Ihe posts with salaries in the
range of £10,000 to £25,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £50,000 a year.
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. As civil servants, Ministers of the Crown,
Members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and solicitors, and in journalism,
broadcasting and architecture they are paid the same salary as men for doing
the same kind of work. Women in independent professions are not expected
to charge lower fees than men. In the private sector generally, however, and
especially in manual work, the principle of equal pay is still exceptional. It will
be enforced under the Equal Pay Act 1970 in all occupations from the end of
1975-
Hours of Work The normal working week in Britain is in the range 39-40 hours for manual
work and 37-38 for non-manual work; a five-day week is usually worked.
Actual hours worked by men in manual occupations are usually somewhat
longer than their normal hours, on account of overtime; in October 1971 they
were 44-7, compared with 37-7 for women. Men and women in non-manual
occupations generally work little or no overtime, although senior salaried staff
may from time to time be required to work substantial (unpaid) overtime.
National legislation limits and defines permissible hours of work for women
and young people in a number of industries or trades the maximum, with
limited exceptions, being 48 hours a week and 10 hours a day (9 hours a day for
6-day-week workers) in premises covered by the Factories Act (see p. 377) f°r
adult women over 18 and young people between 16 and 18; young people under
16 are limited to 44 hours a week. The employment of women and young
people at night is prohibited in industrial undertakings, except for young men
over 16 working in some continuous-process industries (subject to certain
conditions). The Department of Employment can make exemptions from these
restrictions on grounds of public interest. In general the hours of work of
adult men are not restricted by statute.
Holidays with With few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus-
Pay and Bank tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
Holidays of at least two weeks and over three-quarters have basic entitlements of at least
three weeks, in addition to public holidays. Non-manual workers generally
have higher entitlements than manual workers. Some agreements, particularly
in the non-manual sector, provide for extended holidays related to length of
service, or status, or both.
Payment is made for public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to
Good Friday and Christmas Day there are public holidays in England and
Wales on Easter Monday, the last Monday in May or first in June, the last
Monday in August or first in September and the first weekday after Christmas

(Boxing Day); and in Scotland on New Year’s Day, the last Monday in May or

Ireland observes all the English holidays and, in addition, has a holiday on St.
Patrick’s Day (17th March) and on 12th July; the Tuesday after Easter is also
a customary holiday for industry and trade.
A variety of additional benefits exist in varying degree. It has been estimated
that in 1970 15-7 million employees were covered by occupational sick pay
schemes, and about 11*5 million by occupational pension schemes (additional
or complementary to the State schemes, see p. 128). A smaller number are
covered by schemes for redundancy payments above the statutory minimum
(see p. 374). Such benefits are more usual among clerical and professional
employees receiving a standard salary than among manual workers with a
chance to earn overtime and other additions to their pay. Senior members of
firms may use a company car and some firms provide profit-sharing schemes.
The Office of Manpower Economics was established in 1971 as an independent
non-statutory body, with three functions: to act as secretariat for the three
review bodies set up to advise on the remuneration of certain groups in the
public sector for which negotiating machinery is not appropriate, such as
Members of Parliament, the judiciary, the armed forces, and doctors and
dentists; to service enquiries on particular pay structures and related problems;
and to carry out research on more general matters affecting pay and manpower,
either at the request or with the approval of ministers.
Employers have a duty at common law to take reasonable care of their em¬
ployees and provide a safe system of working, while employees have a duty of
care towards each other. In addition, minimum required standards of safety in
certain kinds of workplaces or work are laid down under a number of statutes;
some of these also deal with health and welfare.
A Committee on Safety and Health at Work, appointed by the Government
in 1970, reported in July 1972 and recommended a radical reshaping of the
nation’s occupational safety and health organisation, with streamlined legisla¬
tion to be administered by a single authority.
About 250,000 industrial premises (factories, warehouses, shipyards, docks and
construction sites) come under the Factories Act 1961 (consolidating earlier
legislation), which is administered by the Department of Employment and
enforced by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories, which forms part of the
Department of Employment. About 750,000 premises are subject to the Offices,
Shops and Railway Premises Act 1963, which is also administered by the
Department of Employment; enforcement is shared by Her Majesty’s In¬
spectorates of Factories and of Mines and Quarries, and local authorities.
The Acts and regulations made under them are designed to secure the
health, safety and welfare of employees, and deal with such matters as the
fencing of machinery; precautions against fire and special risks; the safe
condition of the premises; and cleanliness, lighting, temperature and ventilation.
Anyone intending to employ other people in industrial or commercial premises
to which the Acts apply has to notify the enforcing authority of his intention
before he begins to employ people and every fatal accident and every accident
1 The appointed dates for the spring and autumn public holidays in 1973 are 28th May
and 27th August.

Other Measures

of Safety

BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
causing more than three days’ incapacity must be reported. The Factories Act
includes provisions for the compulsory notification and investigation of certain
dangerous occurrences, for precautions against dangerous substances and about
the employment of women and young people.
Comparable provision with appropriate variations covers mines and quarries
under the Mines and Quarries Act 1954; two statutes are concerned with
agriculture—the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 and the
Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare Provisions) Act 195^ > &nd specialised
statutes and delegated legislation are concerned with transport—the Railway
Employment (Prevention of Accidents) Act 1900, the Merchant Shipping
Acts, the Road Traffic Acts and the Air Navigation Order and Regulations.
As with the Factories Act these other provisions are, with some exceptions,
enforced through inspectorates—the Mines and Quarries Inspectorate (part
of the Department of Trade and Industry, which is responsible for safety
in mines and quarries), the Agricultural Inspectorate of the agricultural
departments, and, for railways, the Railway Employment Inspectorate of the
Department of the Environment. The Department of Trade and Industry is
responsible for administering the Merchant Shipping Acts and for safety in
air transport (most of the powers in respect of airworthiness are delegated to
the Civil Aviation Authority, see p. 356), and the Department of the Environ¬
ment is responsible for road and rail transport safety matters. Safety require¬
ments in hotels, places of entertainment or educational establishments are
covered by the 1971 Fire Precautions Act or (in respect of their offices and
shops) by the Offices, Shops and Railway Premises Act. The Department of
Employment has no statutory responsibility in regard to safety in workshops
or laboratories in educational establishments, though it keeps in touch with
university authorities and the education departments.
Transport operators and ministries concerned with road and air travel give
high priority to safety measures affecting crews and passengers. Every effort is
made to counter the higher risks resulting from rising traffic densities by
improving the design of vehicles, transport plant and equipment, by traffic
regulation and control of standards of maintenance and by training crews in
competency and safety awareness.
To safeguard the many interests which might be adversely affected by the
use of chemicals in agriculture and food storage, a voluntary scheme is operated
by the Government with the help of an advisory committee and with the full
co-operation of the chemical industry.
The National Coal Board has its own safety organisation—a Standing Com¬
mittee on Safety, a chief safety engineer, and safety engineers at divisions,
areas and the largest collieries.
The Department of Employment encourages the development of voluntary
central organisation within each industry at national level for the consideiation
of safety matters and the formulation of policy and accident prevention. Its
Factory Inspectorate, besides enquiring into notified accidents and safety
aspects of machine design and specification, circulates expert advice by personal
exhortation, lectures and literature, and encourages the appointment of safety
officers and the formation of works safety committees, and maintains an
industrial health and safety centre in London, at which various types of
machinery demonstrating the effectiveness of guards are displayed, as well as a
wide range of protective clothing and equipment.
Organisations in industry participate also in joint standing and advisory
Training and
Research in
Safety
HEALTH AND
WELFARE
EMPLOYMENT 379
committees appointed by the Secretary of State. Representatives of the Trades
Union Congress, the Confederation of British Industry, the nationalised
industries and other interests meet on the Industrial Safety Advisory Council
under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State. The Royal Society for the
Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) and the British Safety Council are two major
national bodies concerned with accident prevention. A number of local
accident prevention groups are affiliated to either RoSPA or the British Safety
Council. These groups serve as forums where questions of industrial safety
can be examined and knowledge of accident prevention exchanged.
Training is important in accident prevention and the Department of Employ¬
ment provides a safety course in its TWI scheme and the industrial training
boards include specific provisions for safety training in their general training
recommendations (see p. 372).
RoSPA provides a variety of safety courses for special needs mainly at its
Industrial Safety Training Centre in Birmingham and also helps the accident
prevention movement by providing publicity and organising conferences; its
regional industrial safety officers work to promote safety activity among top-
level managers. The British Safety Council also offers safety training courses.
Other courses are organised by local accident prevention groups and organisa¬
tions such as the Federation of Civil Engineering Contractors.
A substantial amount of research is being done by industry, universities and
other academic bodies, and government research organisations into problems
of guarding machines, ergonomics, safe handling, electrical hazards, protective
personal equipment, construction methods, fires and explosions, psychological
factors and causes of accidents, both generally and in particular sectors of
industry. A register of research into industrial health and safety matters has
been compiled by the Department of Employment to give an indication of the
scale and nature of research being undertaken. Industrial research associations
include among their more purely economic research projects the improvement
of working conditions and the reduction of hazards.
The National Coal Board conducts courses of safety training for workmen
and officials. Its research programme includes a number of projects with a
direct bearing on safety. In addition, the Department of Trade and Industry
has a statutory responsibility for research concerning the safety and health of
coal miners. This responsibility is largely exercised through its Safety in Mines
Research Establishment.
The University of Aston has established a Chair in Safety and Hygiene. The
new department is intended to meet the need for academically trained safety
officers and engineers whose careers will be concerned with the technical
aspects of insurance and forensic work.
Local authorities have power, under the Public Health Acts, to regulate the
provision of suitable sanitary accommodation at places of work and to treat
workplaces which are dirty or badly ventilated or overcrowded as nuisances
the abatement of which can be enforced. Factories, certain other industrial
premises, offices, shops and railway premises must comply with the health and
welfare requirements of the Factories Act or the Offices, Shops and Railway
Premises Act. These include: the cleanliness of workrooms, adequate ventila¬
tion and suitable temperature and lighting, the avoidance of overcrowding and
the provision of sanitary accommodation, and the protection of workers against
inhaling harmful dust or fumes; and the provision of washing facilities, lockers
38°
Health Services
in Industry
Advice and
Research
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
or other accommodation for outdoor clothing, drinking water, first aid and
seats. Appropriate measures concerning safety in other types of work, for
example, agriculture, are also prescribed.
Legislation, besides forbidding employment of children under 13 years of
age, forbids the employment of children who have not reached the statutory
minimum school-leaving age (see p. 149) in any industrial undertaking; of
women and young people underground in mines and in certain other danger¬
ous occupations (for example, certain processes connected with lead manufac¬
ture); and of women in factories and workshops within four weeks after
childbirth. It also limits and defines the permissible hours of employment for
women and young people (see p. 37b)- Local authorities, moreover, have wide
powers under the Children and Young Persons Acts 1933-63 as well as the
Education Acts 1944-48, to regulate hours and conditions of employment of
children under 15 years within their areas.
There are some 1,500 appointed factory doctors appointed for districts whose
duties include the initial and periodic medical examination of all young people
entering industry, and certain other medical examinations required under the
Factories Act for workers in particular hazardous trades. Some 800 works
medical officers, appointed to the factories in which they are employed, assist
in these duties.
The Medical Services Division of the Department of Employment is
responsible, through its medical advisers, for advising Department of Employ¬
ment employment services such as the Youth Employment Service and the
industrial rehabilitation service on the medical aspects of employment; it also
maintains close liaison with the work of the appointed factory doctors. Its
medical laboratory provides for the investigation of industrial hazards and
undertakes research and development work. The service also arranges epi¬
demiological surveys.
The Employment Medical Advisory Service Act 1972 provides for a new
Employment Medical Advisory Service to replace the appointed factory doctor
service. Its nucleus will be the Medical Services Division of the Department
of Employment, and it will have a staff of about 100 doctors specialising in
occupational medicine who will be based in the country’s main industrial
centres.
Many employers voluntarily maintain medical services for their employees over
and above the statutory requirements. It is estimated that there are about 650
factories with doctors providing full-time medical cover and about 4>300
factories with part-time medical cover. In addition several thousand nurses are
employed in industry. The big employers, including the State and the boards of
nationalised industries, have taken the lead but a number of smaller factories
also provide medical services and in a few cases have joined together in group
medical services. The Secretary of State is advised on measures to further the
development of health services in workplaces covered by the Factories Act by
the Industrial Health Advisory Committee, which includes members nomi¬
nated by the Confederation of British Industry, the Trades Union Congress,
the nationalised industries, the British Medical Association, the Royal College
of Nursing and other organisations closely concerned with the promotion of
industrial health.
The Factory Inspectorate gives advice on occupational hygiene problems and
has an industrial hygiene unit, with laboratory facilities. There are some six
centres in Great Britain (including the TUC’s Institute of Occupational
