and voluntary organisations for sports facilities, playgrounds, overseas visits
and coaching schemes. Voluntary bodies and private concerns also make
substantial provisions for sport in Britain, but the greatest provision is made
by local authorities; expenditure by local authorities on sport amounted to
some £14 million in 1970-71.
The law requires all publicly maintained schools in Britain to provide for the
physical education (gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of
their pupils. Schools in the national systems (except those solely for infants)
must have a playing field, or the use of one, and most secondary schools have a
gymnasium and other amenities such as swimming pools, sports halls and halls
designed for dance and movement: in an increasing number of areas, physical
education facilities in schools are being expanded to meet the recreational
needs of the whole community. Facilities for, and instruction in, many kinds of
sport are likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public schools
and at the universities (some of which have departments of physical education).
Local authorities are the main providers of land and large-scale facilities to be
used by the community for recreation—they establish, for instance, playing
fields, gymnasia, tennis courts, golf courses, boating lakes, swimming baths
and sports centres and many arrange further education classes in various
physical education subjects. Large industrial firms often provide sports facilities
for their employees and, in many cases, make them available for the public.
Among the national voluntary bodies most closely connected with the general
development of sport are the British Olympic Association, the National
Playing Fields Association and the British Sports Association for the Disabled.
The British Olympic Association, founded in 1905, organises the participation
of British teams in the Olympic Games. The association’s council is composed
of members of the International Olympic Committee, representatives of the
controlling bodies of some 25 sports, representatives of the armed services’
sports organisations and of certain other affiliated bodies concerned with
sporting activities, and a few co-opted members. It determines the overall
size of the British team; raises funds; makes all the arrangements for the
team’s travel and comfort at the games; organises the provision and transport
of clothing and equipment; and provides a headquarters staff for the overall
management of the team.
The National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) aims to stimulate the provi¬
sion of playing fields, playgrounds and recreation centres by publicity and
technical and financial assistance. Since its inception in 1925 it has distributed
over £2 million in the form of grants for playing field, playground and recrea¬
tion centre schemes and over £600,000 in the form of loans. It assists more than
400 schemes a year. With a council composed of representatives of the govern¬
ing bodies of sport, a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisa¬
tions, physical education associations, local authorities and individuals, the
NPFA gives advice on the provision and layout of sports facilities, including
small recreation centres, on matters relating to the recreational needs of children
from their earliest years, and on the establishment of playgrounds and play
leadership schemes. The NPFA is a national charity established by royal
charter. It derives its funds mainly from voluntary contributions, but it also
receives a small Sports Council grant towards administrative costs. It has
branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland and in nearly every English and
Welsh county.
442 BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The British Sports The British Sports Association for the Disabled, founded in 1961, encourages
Association for the sporting activities for the physically handicapped. The association, which
Disabled receives an annual government grant, provides advice on physical recreation
for the disabled, arranges sports meetings at the Stoke Mandeville Sports
Stadium for the Paralysed and Other Disabled, and encourages the provision
of facilities (including sports clubs) for disabled people.
p0rts The policy of establishing sports centres bringing together people of all ages
lentres and different recreational interests is regarded as an important part of the
provision for physical recreation in Britain.
National centres, some of which were initially financed by funds from volun¬
tary sources, provide recreational facilities and a wide range of courses for
instructors and performers in many recreational activities. As well as making
residential courses available for enthusiasts from all over Britain, the national
sports centres are used extensively by local clubs and the local community
generally: it has been estimated that some 450,000 a year use the Crystal
Palace centre (see below) in this way. • -t
One centre has been developed as a national sailing centre, two are primarily
used as training centres for mountain activities, including climbing and rescue
techniques; and a fourth provides training for outdoor activities such as walk¬
ing, climbing, sailing and field studies. A national water sports centre is being
built. Combined facilities for ranges of sports are provided at the other centres
which include the Crystal Palace National Sports Centre in London and the
National Sports Centre for Wales in Cardiff. The centre at Crystal Palace
has a main stadium seating 12,000 spectators, a sports hall seating 2,000
spectators, a swimming hall with pools meeting Olympic requirements, a
teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators, an indoor cricket school,
practice rooms for all indoor activities, a hostel for 140 residents and staff
housing: these facilities are available for international competitions as well
as for training purposes, and are supported by a grant from the Greater
London Council, in addition to the Sports Council grant. The Cardiff centre is
supported by local authorities, as well as by Sports Council grants.
As well as the national sports centres, other centres—such as the Meadow-
bank Sports Centre administered by Edinburgh Corporation cater for a wide
range of recreational activities and often attract more than purely local interest.
Some 35 indoor sports centres serve local rather than national needs; many
more are planned, some as ‘dual’ projects on school sites. There are also several
national centres catering for specialised interests and generally administered by
the sponsoring organisations; these include the National Equestrian Centre,
run by the British Equestrian Federation, and the Stoke Mandeville Sports
Stadium for the Paralysed and Other Disabled, run by the British Sports
Association for the Disabled—the first sports centre of its kind in the world.
POPULAR SPORTS Some of the most popular sports in Britain are listed below in alphabetical
order. Each has its own governing organisation to promote and protect its
interests and to prevent infringement of agreed rules and practices. Some of
the organisations cover the whole of Britain; others are concerned individually
with the different constituent countries of Britain. A number of sports also
have separate bodies governing the participation of women and girls.
Aero Sports
Aero sports—including private flying, gliding and parachuting—are becoming
increasingly popular in Britain. Private flying is promoted by the British Light
Aviation Centre, founded in 1966, to which are affiliated some 225 clubs.
SPORT
Archery
Association
Football
443
There are over 18,000 pilots active in Britain (many of whom fly for business
purposes as well as for pleasure) and more than 2,000 light aircraft are registered.
Air-racing, rallying and aerobatics are controlled by the competitions depart¬
ment of the United Service and Royal Aero Club. Gliding attracts about 8,000
people to some 80 gliding clubs in Britain. The clubs organise flying activities,
including regional and national championships, and are members of the British
Gliding Association, founded in 1929. Parachuting is a popular sport, with
30 clubs affiliated to the British Parachute Association, formed in 1962. The
association, which has about 3,000 members, organises national champion¬
ships, prepares teams for international championships, and regulates the safety
aspects of the sport.
Target archery has a following in Britain of some 11,000 members from over 600
clubs and societies. The governing body is the Grand National Archery Society,
founded in 1844, to which are affiliated regional and county organisations.
Although football of a kind was played in the Middle Ages or even earlier,
as an organised game it dates from the nineteenth century; association football
was adopted at Cambridge in 1848. Nowadays, the game (often called ‘soccer’)
is controlled in England by the Football Association (FA), formed in 1863.
The FA promotes the interests of the game; prevents infringement of the
agreed rules; arranges for instruction of promising young players (some
£50,000 is spent annually on coaching); organises matches and competitions,
including the international matches played by England, the Amateur Cup
competition, the FA Sunday Cup competition, two national youth competitions,
and the competition for its own leading trophy, the FA Challenge Cup; and
chooses and manages English international teams. Over 360 clubs are registered
with the FA and some 37,000 clubs are affiliated to district or regional associa¬
tions. The FA derives its main income from subscriptions and admission
charges to international and cup matches, and ploughs back a large portion of
the money into the game. Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales have their
own controlling bodies: the Scottish Football Association, the Irish Football
Association and the Football Association of Wales.
The principal professional matches in England and Wales (played once or
twice weekly) are controlled by the Football League, comprising 92 professional
clubs. The league’s funds are derived largely from a levy of 4 per cent of the
net gate receipts from league matches, after allowable expenses have been
deducted; from annual payments from football pools promoters for the use of
league fixture lists; and from television rights. In Scotland the Scottish Foot¬
ball League comprises 37 clubs; Northern Ireland has its own league. Clubs
belonging to the English and Scottish Leagues are organised in divisions, the
members of which compete against one another for the respective league
championships. During the season attendances at Football League matches
total about 30 million and gate receipts amount to about £10 million. Several
million people stake small weekly sums on the results of league matches in a
form of pool betting operated by commercial companies.
The annual competitions for the FA Challenge Cup and the Scottish FA Cup
are organised on a knock-out basis, and the finals—two of the most important
football matches of the year—are played at Wembley Stadium, London
(which can accommodate some 100,000 spectators), and at Hampden Park,
Glasgow (which can accommodate about 135,000 people). International
matches, including those between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland, also excite great interest.

Athletics

Badminton
BRITAIN 1973" AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Amateur footballers greatly outnumber the professionals (there are nearly
a million amateurs, including schoolboys and members of the armed forces,
to 7,000 or 8,000 professionals), but their teams rarely compete on equal terms,
since professional teams are more systematically and intensively trained.
Amateur teams compete against each other for the FA Amateur Challenge Cup.
In England and Wales, amateur athletics, which include running (track, road
and cross-country), relay racing, jumping, vaulting, hurdling, steeplechasing,
throwing and race-walking are governed (for men) by the Amateur Athletic
Association (AAA), founded in 1880 to encourage the sport, to establish
uniform regulations, and to promote annual championship meetings. The
AAA is now organised from club to national level by honorary officers and
managed by representative members appointed by the Northern, Midland,
Southern and Welsh areas and by affiliated clubs and associations (amateur
athletic clubs, schools and youth organisations), of which there are hundreds
throughout England and Wales. Women’s athletics in England and Wales are
promoted by the Women’s Amateur Athletic Association, founded in 1922.
Scotland and Northern Ireland have their own amateur athletic associations,
with similar functions; there are also separate women’s AAAs for each country.
Track meetings are held throughout Britain from April to October. The
main events in England and Wales are: the national championships for men
and women and international matches usually held in London; area and county
championships; and the universities, armed services, business houses and
schools championship meetings. Clubs usually compete in cross-country run¬
ning from October to March, and county, area and national cross-country
championships are held. Scottish events follow a similar pattern.
International athletics and the selection of British teams are dealt with by
the British Amateur Athletic Board (BAAB), composed of representatives of the
national associations for men and women and affiliated to the International
Amateur Athletic Federation. Teams from Britain compete in the Olympic
Games, and separate teams representing England, Wales, Scotland, and
Northern Ireland compete in the Commonwealth Games, held at four-yearly
intervals between the Olympic Games. The BAAB administers a coaching
scheme under which nine full-time national coaches lecture and coach in
schools, youth clubs, evening institutes, training colleges and universities and
at special courses organised by the BAAB or by regional associations. Some o
the coaches’ work is directly concerned with coaching athletes but their mam
duties are to instruct men who wish to qualify as coaches, over 1,600 of whom
give voluntary service throughout the country.
The Highland Games, traditional gatherings of local people in the Highlands
of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the weight,
and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions take place,
are unique spectacles which attract large numbers of spectators from all oyer
the world. Among better known Highland Games are the Braemar Gathering
(traditionally attended by the Royal Family), the Argyllshire and Cowal
Gatherings and the meeting at Aboyne.
The origins of badminton are not clear, but the Badminton Association of
England—which together with the Scottish and Welsh Badminton Unions
today organises the sport in Great Britain—was formed in 1893 and the first
tournament was promoted five years later. By 1914 the game had spread to
many other Commonwealth countries and it is now played throughout the

445
world (the national bodies in Great Britain were among the founder members
of the International Badminton Federation).
Basket ball is played in Britain both indoors and outdoors, primarily by men
and boys. There are about 1,000 senior clubs and the game is played in many
schools. The Amateur Basket Ball Association, organises championships and
is affiliated to the Federation Internationale de Basket Ball Amateur.
Although references to billiards in England survive from the sixteenth
century, the character of the present game was acquired at the end of the
seventeenth century. The Billiards and Snooker Control Council is the game’s
controlling body (for professionals and amateurs) and holds the copyright of
the rules. In the early i93os snooker (a shorter game offering more diverse
incidents) began to acquire popularity, often at the expense of professional
billiards, and today, although both games are played widely at amateur levels,
snooker forms the essence of the professional game.
Bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century. Nowadays the
game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling Association (EBA, founded in
1903) is concerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB). The Bowling
Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also play to the IBB’s laws, but
there are other bowling associations in England—the English Bowling Federa¬
tion, the Crown Green Association and the English Women’s Bowling
Association—which are not under the IBB’s control. During the summer
bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in winter it is played on indoor
greens, which are increasing in number. At one time regarded as a pastime for
the elderly, the game is now played by people of all ages. Over 2,640 bowling
clubs are affiliated to the EBA. International, inter-county matches and national
championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and fours are played.
Boxing as an English sport probably originated in Saxon times. Its modern
form, which has been adopted in many overseas countries, dates from 1865
when the Marquess of Queensberry drew up a set of rules eliminating much of
the brutality that had characterised prize fighting, and making skill the basis
of the sport. Nowadays, many boys learn to box at school and in boys’ clubs,
and there are various amateur boxing competitions carried out according to
the rules of the Amateur Boxing Association, which controls all amateur
boxing, including schoolboy boxing, club and association boxing, and boxing
in the armed services.
Professional boxing is covered by the British Boxing Board of Control,
founded in 1929. The board’s strict medical regulations provide for an
examination of boxers before and after each contest, an extensive annual
medical examination and the appointment of inspectors to ensure that the
regulations are observed and to guard against over-matching and exploitation.
Championships at fixed weights have been the rule in boxing contests since
the presentation of the Championship Challenge Belts by the late Lord
Lonsdale in 1909. Amateur championships are decided at n weights: light
flyweight, flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight, lightweight, light welter¬
weight, welterweight, light middleweight, middleweight, light heavyweight
and heavyweight. In professional boxing there are no light flyweight, light
welterweight or light middleweight categories.
Canoeing, the world’s oldest type of boating, dates as a modern sport from the
mid-nineteenth century; a canoe club was founded in 1866, and in 1867 a canoe

Croquet
Cycling
BRITAIN 1973* AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
regatta was held on the Thames. The International Canoe Federation was
formed in 1936; in Great Britain, the British Canoe Union (a member of the
federation and established in 1936) promotes canoeing in all its forms and
assists the interests of its members. There are about 400 canoe clubs in
Britain, with about 100,000 devotees.
Cricket, sometimes called the English national game, has uncertain origins,
but it is known to have been played at Guildford Grammar School in 1550,
and after the Restoration (of 1660) it became fashionable with the nobility,
who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very large sums of
money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth century was the
famous Hambledon Club in Hampshire, whose members supported the most
brilliant players of the day. Towards the end of the century the Marylebone
Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and reframed the ‘Laws of
Cricket’. It has since had considerable influence on the development of the
game in Britain. Its headquarters, Lord’s (named after Thomas Lord, who
rented the first headquarters), were opened in 1787, and moved to the present
site in 1814. Nowadays, cricket in Britain is governed by the Cricket Council,
made up of representatives of the MCC, the Test and County Cricket Board
(representing first-class cricket) and the National Cricket Association (re¬
presenting club and junior cricket). The MCC retains its world-wide responsi¬
bility for the laws of cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages
(as well as industrial sports clubs) have teams which play at least one match a
week from late April to early September. In the London area a large number
of pitches are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned
by clubs. In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of
League cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced
by professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and Australia
in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly between
countries of Test status, which now number seven. The matches last 30 playing
hours spread over five days and arouse great popular interest.
In addition to the Test matches, a First-Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is contested by 17 counties, each playing 24
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. The univer¬
sity teams of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
match at Lord’s. The counties also compete in a knock-out competition with
one-day matches and in a Saturday and a Sunday League. _
Cricket is also played by women and girls in Britain, the governing body
being the Women’s Cricket Association, founded in 1926.
Croquet originated in Britain in the middle of the nineteenth century and has
developed into a game played by people of all ages on the lawns of local
croquet clubs and private gardens. Some 70 clubs are registered with e
Croquet Association—formed in 1896—which promotes the sport in Britain
and maintains links with croquet associations in other countries.
In Britain the internationally recognised body for cycle racing is the British
Cycling Federation which has 727 affiliated clubs and provides third-party

insurance and a legal aid and touring service for its members. It controls
track and massed-start road racing in Britain, and is concerned with the
cycling events in the Olympic and Commonwealth Games and the annual
world championship. Time trials are organised by the Road Time Trials
Council.
The principal organisation promoting touring by bicycle is the Cyclists’
Touring Club (CTC), the oldest touring club in the world, with a membership
of some 20,000. CTC representatives in all parts of Britain offer help to touring
cyclists; its 50 district associations arrange holiday and week-end tours and
competitions, rallies and rides of all kinds; and its travel department provides
touring itineraries for members both at home and overseas, and maintains a
full travel agency service. Other benefits include a touring magazine, a members’
handbook, legal aid and third-party insurance.
Fencing as a sport has made considerable progress throughout Britain during
the past 25 years. The Amateur Fencing Association (founded in 1902) has
over 600 clubs, and many classes are organised and financed by local authori¬
ties. Fencing is also practised in most universities and an increasing number of
schools. Under the auspices of the association, national championships and
international tournaments are held every year.
The most popular field sports—hunting, game shooting and fishing—have a
long history, and still play a considerable part in the life of the countryside.
The British Field Sports Society looks after their interests.
In Britain hunting means primarily fox hunting on horseback with a pack of
hounds; but it also includes stag hunting (in Devon and Somerset), hunting
the hare, either on foot with beagles or with harriers when the followers are
mounted, and otter hunting along river banks. Hunting depends not on right
but on the goodwill of small landowners and farmers, most of whom support
their local hunt by allowing it to ride over their property.
Fox hunting became a widespread activity in the English countryside some
200 years ago. Originally a sport mainly for the landed gentry and local farmers,
it has gradually widened its appeal, in spite of the fact that it is an expensive
pastime for those who ride to hounds. The sport is not without its critics, but
an ever-larger number of people, including many townsmen, take a keen interest
in it. Most hunts meet two or three times a week and an estimated 25,000 to
30,000 people ride to hounds weekly, many others following in cars, on bicycles
or on foot. The fox hunting season starts in early November and lasts until
April; it is preceded by cub hunting (the hunting of young foxes) when young
hounds are trained. At the end of the season most hunts organise steeplechases
(point-to-points) which attract large crowds. There are over 200 packs of
hounds in England and Wales, 17 in Northern Ireland, and 10 in Scotland.
Hunts are financed mainly by the subscriptions of their members (^15 or less
to £50 or more), by ‘caps’ (contributions paid by non-subscribers), and by the
proceeds of such annual events as the point-to-points and the hunt ball.
Sometimes the Master of Fox-hounds, who is in charge of the hunt, bears a
proportion of the cost.
Game shooting as an organised country sport may be said to date from the
early part of the nineteenth century; nowadays, game consists mainly of
grouse, partridge, pheasant, snipe and woodcock. There is virtually no free
shooting in Britain. A certificate (for which a fee is payable) must be obtained
from the local police by anyone who possesses, purchases or acquires a shot

Golf
BRITAIN 1973- AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
gun1; and it is necessary to have a licence to kill game. Nearly all game birds
are found on privately owned land, shot over either by the owner and his
friends or by syndicates which have leased the shooting rights. However, in
some parts of the more remote countryside, rough shooting may be enjoyed in
a less formal way. Much of the country’s wild-fowling is controlled by the
Wildfowlers’ Association of Great Britain and Ireland, through its numerous
clubs. The Game Conservancy, formed by landowners, farmers and others
interested in game conservation and research, collects information on a
national scale and studies factors controlling game population.
Grouse, partridge, pheasant and certain other birds are protected by law
during a ‘close season’ and allowed to breed in security, often under the care of
privately employed gamekeepers on numerous estates. Grouse shooting takes
place mostly in Scotland, northern England and north Wales; partridge and
pheasant shooting in nearly all regions of Great Britain, the former mainly
over farm land, and the latter in or near woodland; and wildfowling on the
marshes and fenlands of the coastal areas.
Deer stalking is mainly a sport of the Highlands of Scotland. The deer are
preserved in privately owned ‘deer forests’, covering 9,000 to over 30,000
acres (3,642 to 12,140 hectares), and are protected during close seasons.
Fishing is the most popular of the country sports, being within the reach
of everyone in some form or another (from the small boy with his hook and
line to the experienced fly-fisherman). There are some 3 million anglers
in Britain. The outstanding forms of the sport are salmon and trout fishing.
There are trout streams in most parts of the country, and in Scotland many
hundreds of lochs also provide good sport. Salmon fishing may be enjoyed in
many regions of Britain, but the best salmon rivers are in Scotland. In England
and Wales the most widely practised form of fishing is for coarse fish such as
pike, perch, carp, roach, dace, tench, chub and bream, and the National
Federation of Anglers (NFA) has some 450,000 members in over 3,000 clubs
comprising 170 associations. Match angling—competitive fishing for coarse
fish by weight—is a feature of the many angling clubs affiliated to the N FA,
particularly in the Midlands and north of England. A national angling cham¬
pionship, composed of teams of 12 anglers, is organised annually by the NFA,
and the NFA enters a team in the International Angling Competition. As a
rule, freshwater fishing has to be paid for and local enquiries made about any
permit or licence required. Most coarse fishing is let to angling clubs; trout
and salmon fishermen either rent a stretch of river, join a club, stay at an hotel
with its own fishing rights, or pay for the right to fish by the day, week 01
month. The cost of salmon fishing is often high. Coastal fishing and deep-sea
fishing for shark and tunny are growing in popularity and are free to all (except
for salmon and sea trout fishing, which is by licence only).
The National Anglers’ Council is a central consultative and co-ordinating
body, representative of the various national bodies concerned with angling.
Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in other
parts of Britain until towards the end of the nineteenth century. Since then,
however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly since the mid-
1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many towns and

villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities, but the

The main event of the golfing year is the British Open Golf Championship,
first played in i860; other important matches include the Walker Cup (for
amateurs) and the Ryder Cup (for professionals), both played between Britain
and the United States; the Amateur Championship; the World Amateur Team
Championship; and the Ladies Championship.
Gymnastics involving bodily exercises and disciplines were originally de¬
veloped as a sport in ancient Greece; nowadays in Britain the sport is a non-
seasonal activity for both men and women and is controlled nationally by the
British Amateur Gymnastics Association (affiliated to the Federation Inter¬
nationale de Gymnastique and the British Olympic Association). The asso¬
ciation’s activities include the promotion of international and national
programmes (including the national tournaments at the Royal Albert Hall,
London) and of proficiency award schemes for people of all ages.
Variants of hockey (as distinct from ice-hockey) have been played in Britain
for at least five centuries, and some, like hurling in Ireland and shinty in
Scotland, are still played extensively. Modern hockey, however, dates from
the formation (in 1866) of the Hockey Association of England. The Inter¬
national Hockey Rules Board controls the rules of the game. There are some
2,000 men’s hockey clubs throughout Britain with at least 30,000 male adult
players; some 600 boys’ schools also play the game. A county championship is
held annually in England; in Wales there is a cup competition; and in Scotland
there is a cup competition and six local league competitions. Regular amateur
international matches are also played. Men’s hockey is an Olympic sport, and
team arrangements are made by the Great Britain Hockey Board.
The controlling bodies of women’s hockey are: the All England Women’s
Hockey Association (founded 1895) to which are affiliated some 900 clubs and
2,200 schools, representing a membership of about 72,000 adults; the Irish
Ladies’ Hockey Union; the Scottish Women’s Hockey Association; and the
Welsh Women’s Hockey Association. The first international women’s hockey
match took place in 1896. Nowadays such a match is played annually at
Wembley Stadium (in addition to those played in other parts of the country)
and attracts over 60,000 spectators.
Judo, an Olympic sport originating in Japan, has a large and growing follow¬
ing in Britain and is governed by the British Judo Association, which is
affiliated to the International Judo Federation under the rules of which judo
competitions are conducted. There are some 580 clubs in the association,
which has coaching schemes for some 30,000 registered members.
Lacrosse, adapted from the game played by the Iroquois Indians of North
America, is played mainly by women—in girls’ schools, at lacrosse clubs, and
at universities. Women’s international and regional matches are played under
the auspices of the All England Women’s Lacrosse Association, the All Wales
Women’s Lacrosse Association and the Scottish Women’s Lacrosse Association.
The men’s game, controlled by the English Lacrosse Union, is played in ten
universities, several colleges of education and by clubs and schools, mainly in
the London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield and Nottingham areas. Matches
played include county matches, an annual fixture between the North of

The forerunner of modern lawn tennis (the game known zsjeu de paume) was
introduced into England from France in the fifteenth century and a tennis
court’, built by Henry VIII, is still in use at Hampton Court. The modern
game, first played in England in 1873, quickly became very popular; in 1877
the first championships were played. The Lawn Tennis Association, the
game’s controlling body in Britain, was founded in 1888. The international
governing body of the game (the International Lawn Tennis Federation, with
headquarters in London and Paris) was founded in iQtS*
The number of tennis players has greatly increased during the present
century, particularly since the game has spread to practically every country in
the world. In Britain the game is played in almost all girls’ and in many boys’
secondary schools, on private courts, in parks and recreation grounds and at
several thousand tennis clubs.
The annual Wimbledon fortnight, held during the summer, is the main
event of the lawn tennis season in Britain, and, in fact, in the world. T. hese
championships, for players of many nationalities, draw large crowds; the
grounds at the All England Club at Wimbledon can accommodate over 30,000
spectators, including 14,000 round the Centre Court where the finals are
played. Other tournaments which attract a good deal of attention are. the
British Hard Court Championships, the British Junior Championships, and the
County Championships. There are also national competitions for boys’ and
girls’ schools. The most important international events are the Davis Cup (for
men) and the Federation Cup competition (for women). Women players from
Britain and the United States also compete for the Wightman Cup.
Motor racing is one of the most popular spectator sports in Britain; more
racing and sports cars have been built in Britain than in any other countiy,
and British drivers (including women drivers) have an international reputation
second to none. The Royal Automobile Club (RAC) is the governing body of
motor sport in Great Britain, and the 750 motor clubs registered with it
organise each year 5,500 motor sporting events, 230 of which are race meetings
held on 17 different racing tracks licensed by the RAC. The RAC also issues
yearly 24,500 competition licences covering all events from hill climbs and
autocross to full international race meetings; and it organises the British Grand
Prix which counts towards the Formula One World Motor Racing Champion¬
ship. Kart racing also comes under the RAC’s jurisdiction.
In addition to motor car racing, there is motor cycle racing the most
important contest of the year is for the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy—for
which the controlling body is the Auto-Cycle Union (founded in 1903 and
represented on the Federation Internationale de Motorcycliste), with over 700
affiliated clubs in Great Britain. Motor cycle speedway racing, introduced into
Britain in 1928, is governed by the Speedway Control Board.
The popularity of mountaineering has greatly increased in recent years. Clubs
in the British Mountaineering Council (BMC) and the Mountaineering
Council for Scotland, the representative bodies of the sport, number over 190,
ranging from national clubs, such as the Alpine Club (founded in i857> ^ e
oldest mountaineering club in the world) and the Scottish Mountaineering
Club, to small regional clubs with 20 to 30 members. A number local
education authorities, and national bodies such as the Sports Council and the

Outward Bound Trust have established mountaineering training centres.
Training courses are run jointly by the Sports Council, and BMC, the Youth
Hostels Association and other bodies, and many universities and schools have
mountaineering sections. Membership of the known clubs is about 15,000
but several times this number take part in climbing and mountaineering.
British mountaineers have taken a leading part in exploring and climbing
most of the great ranges of the world, for example, the first ascent of the
Matterhorn in 1865, of Everest in 1953, and of Kangchenjunga in 1955. In
recent years frequent expeditions have gone to Greenland, Alaska, the Andes,
Patagonia, the Caucasus and the Pamirs, as well as the Himalayas.
Netball is a popular game for girls and women. The controlling body in
England is the All England Netball Association to which clubs, colleges and
schools are affiliated through county netball committees. The women’s armed
services and national youth, university and college organisations are also
affiliated. National tournaments for counties, clubs, colleges and schools and
international matches are organised each year; and inter-Commonwealth tours
are also arranged.
Orienteering involving competitive wayfinding across country (usually on
foot) was introduced into Britain on a national basis in the early 1960s,
although similar activities had been promoted in the past (the armed forces,
for instance, often use wayfinding in training programmes). Both men and
women participate and the sport is organised for team and individual competi¬
tions by the British Orienteering Federation. Several schools have taken up
the sport, combining outdoor exercise with practical geography.
Polo, of which the earliest records are Persian, was first played by the British
in India, and brought to England in 1869. The sport’s governing body is the
Hurlingham Polo Association, to which many overseas polo associations are
affiliated. Polo players are a very small section of the community, for the cost
of keeping polo ponies is high. However, many clubs now own trained ponies
for hire to members at moderate cost. About 470 players receive handicaps
from the association, but many less expert players take part in club games.
Public interest in polo has increased in recent years and spectators attend
inter-club tournaments and matches between high-handicap teams with players
from several countries, including other Commonwealth countries, the United
States and Argentina.
Racing is a term which, in Britain, is taken to mean, first and foremost,
horse-racing. Other forms of racing include greyhound racing, coursing (a
form of hunting with greyhounds), pony racing, trotting races and pigeon
flying.
Horse-racing has been known in England since Tudor times and even earlier.
The Jockey Club (originally formed about 1750) controls all horse-racing in
England and its rules are the basis of universal turf procedure.
Flat racing is carried on from late March till the end of October and national
hunt racing from August to June. The classic flat races are: the Two Thousand
Guineas for colts and fillies, and the One Thousand Guineas for fillies only,
both run at Newmarket; the Derby for colts and fillies and the Oaks for fillies
only, both run at Epsom; and the St. Leger, for colts and fillies, run at
Doncaster. The Derby is the outstanding event in the racing calendar; it takes

Racing
Riding
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
place annually in late May or early June and is one of the most colourful and
exciting events of the sporting year. The most fashionable race-meeting of
the season is held at Ascot in Berkshire, in mid-June, and is known as ‘Royal
Ascot’, being traditionally attended by the Sovereign.
The most important national hunt meeting is the National Hunt Festival
Meeting at Cheltenham in March. The best-known single steeplechase is the
Grand National at Aintree, near Liverpool, run annually since 1839.
In England and Wales there are 56 racecourses (which must be licensed by
The Jockey Club) and Scotland has six racecourses. There is a total of about
900 days’ racing annually. There are some 11,000 horses in training in Great
Britain, at an average cost of about £30 a week each.
The racing of greyhounds after a mechanical hare started in Britain in 1926,
when the first modern greyhound track was opened at Belle Vue, Manchester.
There are now about 125 licensed tracks in operation, nearly all of them near
large towns, and meetings are held two or three times a week. The licensing
authorities for greyhound racing tracks are the county and county borough
councils. Some 9 million people a year watch greyhound racing, the rules
of which are drawn up by the National Greyhound Racing Club. The 51
greyhound racecourses which accept the rules of the club are the largest in
the country and account for approximately 92 per cent of the total attendance
and totalisator turnover.
Greyhound racing can be conducted only at a licensed greyhound racecourse
and only on 130 racing days in a licensing year (1st July-30th June). There
are some 10,000 greyhounds in training under the National Greyhound Racing
Club Rules, and the average cost for their upkeep including training is about
^3'75 a week each.
Betting on racing is allowed for people of at least 18 years of age, subject to a
government betting duty (see p. 209). ‘Bookmakers’ (who must hold personal
permits) provide betting facilities both on and off racecourses and greyhound
tracks (bets laid off course in Great Britain comprise about 87 per cent of the
betting turnover, mainly through some 14,000 licensed betting offices). For
horse-racing, the Horserace Totalisator Board (HTB), a statutory body, runs
totalisator betting (a form of pool betting), both on and off the courses; for
greyhound racing there is no statutory body, but some 70 tracks are allowed to
run their own totalisators under strict control by local authorities. Book¬
makers and the HTB have to contribute a ‘betting levy’ to the Horserace
Betting Levy Board which promotes the advancement of veterinary science
and education and the improvement of horse breeding (including the work of
the National Stud at Newmarket) and horse-racing in general.
The British Equestrian Federation, the authority responsible for equestrian
activities (other than racing) in Great Britain, co-ordinates the work of the
British Horse Society and the British Show Jumping Association (see below),
and runs the National Equestrian Centre at Stoneleigh, Warwickshire.
The British Horse Society is responsible for promoting the interests of horse
and pony breeding, furthering the art of riding, and encouraging horse-
mastership and the welfare of horses and ponies. It provides tests, lectures,
publications, a film library, courses and examinations, and employs a national
instructor who, together with riding schools approved by the society, helps to
promote horsemastership throughout the country. With some 18,000 members,
the society is also the parent body of the Pony Club and the Riding Club
SPORT
453
Rowing
Rugby Football
Movement. The Pony Club (35,000 members) runs its own national champion¬
ships, arranges conferences, instructors’ courses and efficiency tests, and pub¬
lishes information on riding techniques and horse management. The Riding
Clubs (24,000 members) also hold national championships each year and the
Riding Club Horseshoe Long Distance Ride—a test of stamina for horses and
riders, held annually in different parts of Britain.
Under the auspices of the society, horse trials are held throughout Britain
during the spring and summer. The three-day events held each year—in April
at Badminton, Gloucestershire, in May at Tidworth, Hampshire, and in
September at Burghley House, Lincolnshire—are among the outstanding
equestrian events of the year. These trials include dressage, cross-country
riding and show jumping; some 50 one-day trials on similar lines are held
annually.
Affiliated dressage competitions are held throughout the year, many of them
as qualifying rounds for championships held at the Royal International Horse
Show and the Horse of the Year Show (see below) and for dressage champion¬
ships at the National Equestrian Centre.
Showjumping is promoted by the British Show Jumping Association, which
is responsible for drawing up the rules for the judging of jumping competitions
and prescribing the general standards and height of obstacles for show
jumping. It encourages showjumping events and keeps a register of horses and
ponies taking part at affiliated shows. The association seeks to improve the
standard of jumping and to provide for the representation of Great Britain in
international competitions. More than 800 shows are affiliated each year to the
association, which has a membership of over 9,000. The two major show
jumping events each year are the Royal International Horse Show and the
Horse of the Year Show.
Rowing is enjoyed by participants from all sections of the community and
attracts considerable spectator interest. The art of oarsmanship is taught in
many schools, universities and rowing clubs (including women’s clubs)
throughout Britain, where the governing bodies of the sport are the Amateur
Rowing Association and the Scottish Amateur Rowing Association and the
Ulster Branch of the Irish Amateur Rowing Union. Since the late 1940s, the
number of rowing clubs has doubled. The first rowing course in Britain to
Olympic 2,000-metre standards has been opened at the National Water Sports
Centre in Nottingham.
The University Boat Race between eight-oared crews from Oxford and
Cambridge originated in 1829 anc^ has been rowed on the Thames almost every
spring since 1836. The Head of the River Race in March (also on the Thames)
is the largest assembly of racing craft in the world—more than 350 eights row in
procession. At Henley Regatta in Oxfordshire (founded in 1839) crews from
all over the world compete each July in various kinds of races over a straight
course of 1 mile 550 yards (about 2-1 kilometres). Many other riverside resorts
arrange summer regattas. The oldest annual event in the English racing
calendar is Doggett’s Coat and Badge, founded in 1716 and organised since
by the Worshipful Company of Fishmongers; originally for professional water¬
men and limited to six entrants, the race (along the Thames in London) is now
open to amateurs (who must still be apprentice watermen).
Rugby football is played according to two different sets of rules. Rugby Union
football (‘rugger’—in which there are 15 players in a team) is played (in
England) under the auspices of the Rugby Football Union, established in
454
Sailing
Shooting
(Target)
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
1871. International matches between England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and
France are played regularly at the leading rugby football grounds of each
country, including Twickenham, London—the headquarters of the Rugby
Football Union—and there are tours by international teams. Other important
rugby matches are the county championship competitions, the annual match
between the universities of Oxford and Cambridge, the Hospitals’ Cup Final,
and the Inter-Services tournament. Membership of the Rugby Union is
confined to amateur clubs of which there are over 1,600 in membership, with
over 1,100 schools.
Rugby League football—a 13-a-side game for professionals as well as
amateurs—is played mostly in the north of England. The game’s governing
body, the Rugby Football League (instituted in 1895) has its headquarters
at Leeds and regularly sends touring teams to Australia and New Zealand.
Annual international games, professional and amateur, are played against
France. The major match of the season—the Rugby League Challenge Cup
Final—has attracted crowds of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium in recent years.
Sailing has always been popular on Britain’s inland and coastal waters but in
recent years the sport, and in particular small boat sailing, has greatly widened
its appeal. The Royal Yachting Association (RYA), the national governing
body for both sailing and power yachting, has over 1,500 clubs and 32,000
personal members. The RYA has approved sailing schools giving courses for
novices, a National Sailing Centre where instructors are coached and tested,
and is responsible for the selection of Great Britain’s Olympic team. One of
the world’s main regattas takes place from Cowes in the Isle of Wight annually
during the first week of August. Other major events are held at such sailing
centres as Poole, Lowestoft, Harwich, Burnham-on-Crouch, Plymouth,
Falmouth and the Clyde. Racing is subject to the rules of the International
Yacht Racing Union, founded in 1907.
The Joint Shooting Committee for Great Britain, founded in 1955, represents
its member associations—the National Rifle Association (NRA), the National
Small-Bore Rifle Association (NSRA) and the Clay Pigeon Shooting Associa¬
tion (CPSA)—in the International Shooting Union and the British Olympic
Association. The committee sponsors all entries to international competitions.
Full-bore (7-62 mm and -303 in.) rifle and pistol (high power) shooting is
organised by the NRA, founded in i860. Some 80 county rifle associations, 90
schools and more than 600 rifle clubs are affiliated to the NRA. The annual
Imperial Meeting at Bisley Camp, Surrey—attended by some 2,500 competi¬
tors from Britain and other Commonwealth countries, including cadets from
schools—comprises (for individuals and teams) competitions for members of
the armed services and for schools, and target rifle competitions at county,
national and international level, concluding with the Queen’s Prize, which
attracts about 1,000 entries. The NRA also organises postal matches for British
and overseas teams, and sends teams to other Commonwealth countries.
Small-bore (-22 in.) rifle and pistol shooting—carried out either on indoor
ranges of 15 to 25 yards (14-23 m) in length or on open ranges up to 200 yards
(183 m)—and air rifle and pistol shooting (‘177 nn) at 6 yards and 10 metres
(both indoors and outside) are also widely practised in Britain. Some 3,500
clubs are affiliated to the NSRA, which arranges inter-club and inter-county
competitions for teams and individuals. Clubs also compete in county and local
groups. The NSRA organises a National Bisley Meeting (usually attended by
more than 2,000 competitors), a Scottish meeting (some 600 competitors),
SPORT
455
Skating
Skiing
Squash Rackets
Swimming
and the British Pistol Championships (some 600 competitors) at Bisley.
International small-bore rifle and pistol matches are held with teams from
overseas. The NSRA provides coaching and advisory services.
Some 300 clay pigeon shooting clubs are situated in all parts of Great Britain;
the sport is governed by the CPS A which represents Great Britain in major
international events.
The world’s first skating club was formed in Edinburgh in 1742 and the first
mechanically refrigerated ice rink was built in London in 1876. There are
now 37 artificial ice rinks in Britain, and where facilities exist many local
authorities provide skating tuition for school children. Over 70 ice clubs are
affiliated to the National Skating Association of Great Britain (which also
promotes roller skating), formed in 1879—one °f the associations which in
1892 established the International Skating Union to supervise and standardise
ice figure, ice speed and (later) ice dance skating regulations.
When there is sufficient snow, skiing takes place in several parts of Britain.
The governing bodies of the sport are the National Ski Federation of Great
Britain and the Ulster Ski Federation. Skiing in Scotland has become very
popular, especially at the winter sports centres established in the Cairngorms,
Deeside, Glencoe and Glenshee, where ski-runs equal to those in other areas
of Europe have been developed, and ski-lifts, ski-tows and professional instruc¬
tion are now available. There are some 55 artificial ski-slopes in areas other
than the Scottish centres.
Squash rackets is thought to have originated at Harrow School in the 1850s;
the Squash Rackets Association, formed in 1929 to promote and organise the
game, was a founder member of the International Squash Rackets Federation.
The game, which is both amateur and professional, is played mainly by men
and boys (it is very popular in many boys’ schools and universities), although
an increasing number of participants are women. There are national inter¬
county championships. With some 700 clubs in England alone, squash rackets
is one of the fastest growing sports.
Many children in Britain learn to swim at school, or during holidays at the
seaside, and swimming as a summer pastime is enjoyed by millions of people.
The existence of indoor swimming baths (mainly provided by local authorities)
makes all-the-year swimming possible, and instruction and coaching is
provided in some places by qualified teachers who hold certificates for
elementary or advanced teaching awarded by the Amateur Swimming Associa¬
tion (ASA). The ASA’s objects are to promote the teaching and practice of
swimming, diving and water polo and to stimulate public opinion in favour of
providing proper accommodation and facilities for them; and to draw up and
enforce uniform laws for the regulation of amateur swimming, diving and
water polo and synchronised swimming (a form of water ballet) champion¬
ships and competitions in England.
Underwater swimming (sub aqua), one of the fastest growing sports in
Britain, is governed nationally by the British Sub Aqua Club, wdiich promotes
underwater exploration, science and sport. Formed in 1953, the club has
become the largest in the world, with some 15,500 active members and 500
branches in Britain and overseas. A training programme for members forms
one of the club’s main activities.

Table Tennis

Weightlifting
Wrestling
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Table tennis had its origins in Britain in the late nineteenth century and was
then often referred to as ‘ping pong’ (the name is derived from the sound of the
ball hitting the bat). In 1902 the Ping Pong Association was formed to organise
championships, and in 1927 it was reconstituted as the English Table Tennis
Association—the body which today controls the game.
Types of bowling are thought to have been played in ancient Egypt and have
been known in Europe for over 700 years. Tenpin bowling was re-introduced
in its present form from North America in i960 and rapidly became a popular
sport in Great Britain where the controlling body is the British Tenpin Bowling
Association, founded in 1961.
Volleyball, introduced into Europe from the United States, is growing in
popularity in England and Scotland where it is promoted by the English
Volleyball Association and the Scottish Volleyball Association. There are some
150 clubs affiliated to the English Association, and both associations are
members of the British Olympic Association. National championships are
held annually and leagues function at national and regional levels.
The popularity of water skiing in Britain, both during the summer and at
suitable times in the winter, is increasing. The British Water Ski Federation,
formed in 1951, represents over 70,000 water skiers, several of whom have
won world and European titles. Over 100 clubs are affiliated to the federation.
The main competitive events are: figures, slalom, jumping and grand prix
racing.
Modern weightlifting with bar-bells and dumb-bells became popular towards
the end of the nineteenth century; the first championships open to the world
were held in London in 1891. The sport is regulated on a world-wide scale by
the International Weightlifting Federation, formed in 1920, and in Britain
by the British Amateur Weightlifters’ Association.
Wrestling is one of the oldest sports in the world. The style most commonly
used in Britain is the ‘free’ style, which evolved from the Catch-as-Catch-Can
or Lancashire style, but Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling is still
practised in the north of England and in Scotland, and Cornish style wrestling
(in which the contestants wear rough canvas jackets by which all holds must
be taken) takes place in Cornwall. Wrestling in the free and Graeco-Roman
styles features at the Olympic Games; in the Commonwealth Games only
free style is wrestled. Amateur wrestling in Britain is governed by the British
Amateur Wrestling Association, which is affiliated to the International
Amateur Wrestling Federation, under the rules of which all wrestling is
conducted. Professional wrestling is usually in the ‘all-in’ or ‘free’ style, which
is not the same as the free style used in amateur wrestling.

BRITAIN AND THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES
On ist January 1973, Britain, together with the Irish Republic and Denmark
will join the original six countries—Belgium, France, the Federal Republic of
Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands—in the European Com¬
munities.1 The enlarged Community will form a trading area of over 250
million people and account for some 40 per cent of world trade, offering a basis
not only for the continued economic development of the member countries,
but also for the emergence of a wider unity, enabling Europe to play a more
effective international role in economic and political affairs.
There are three Communities in what is often known as the ‘Common
Market’. The European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was established
in 1952, by bringing together the coal and steel resources of the six member
countries, and formed the model for the ‘community’ approach to economic
integration. The Community is designed to ensure an orderly supply of coal
and steel to member countries, to promote the rational expansion and moderni¬
sation of production and to provide better conditions of employment and
living for the employees in the industries. The Treaty of Paris which esta¬
blished the ECSC provided for the abolition of duties and quantitative restric¬
tions (or charges having the same effect) on trade in coal and steel between
member states; of discrimination by producers in prices, delivery terms or
transport rates; of any measures which hampered free choice of supplier; and
of restrictive practices resulting in the collusive sharing or exploitation of
markets. The ECSC established common markets in coal, iron and steel
during 1953-54, although some tariffs and price controls remained operative
for a transitional period which ended in 1958. The treaty provided, moreover,
for action by the Community over a wide field of activity in the coal and steel
industries, the work of the Community being financed by a levy on production.
The Community may provide funds for capital investment, research and other
programmes, as well as loans to help create new jobs in declining coal areas or
where restructuring of the steel industry is taking place. Grants to assist
redundant coal and steel workers until they find new employment, or while
undergoing retraining, may also be made. An agreement between the ECSC
and Britain in 1954 established a Council of Association for the exchange of
information and for consultation on matters of mutual interest.
The European Economic Community (EEC) was created by the Treaty of
Rome signed by the six countries in 1957, and aimed to promote the con¬
tinued and balanced expansion of the members’ economies by their progressive
harmonisation and integration. The preamble to the treaty included among
the basic objectives of the EEC the establishment of the foundations for a
growing unity among European peoples, the improvement of their working
and living conditions, the progressive abolition of restrictions on trade, and the
1 Norway completed negotiations at the same time as the other three applicants and
signed the Treaty of Accession (see p. 462). However, in a referendum held on 24th-
25th September a majority opposed entry. Certain passages in this appendix are based
on the assumption that the enlarged Community would be a Community of Ten.
460
The European
Atomic Energy
Community
Institutions
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
development of the prosperity of overseas countries. The initial steps towards
the attainment of these objectives were the creation of a customs union, aboli¬
tion of internal tariffs and other barriers to trade and establishment of a
common external tariff, the development of a common policy for agriculture,
and the introduction of measures to establish the free movement of labour,
capital and services. At the same time, provision was made for the overseas
countries which had special links with the member countries to have an asso¬
ciate status with the EEC, with preferential treatment in aid and the develop¬
ment of trade. The EEC is now moving from a customs union towards an
economic union, and the member countries are working gradually to align their
economic and monetary policies and to evolve a common approach to industrial,
regional, technological and social development.
The third Community, the European Atomic Energy Community (EURA-
TOM), was set up by a second treaty signed in Rome in 1957 which provided
for the co-ordinated development of members’ atomic energy industries and of
their other peaceful nuclear activities. EURATOM has worked to develop a
co-ordinated research programme (for power production, industrial and
medical purposes) and to ensure the dissemination of technical information, to
facilitate the co-ordination of investment in the nuclear field, to ensure a
proper supply of nuclear ores and fuels and wider commercial outlets. A
common market for all nuclear materials and equipment came into effect at the
beginning of 1959, with a common external tariff on imports of nuclear
materials, while the Community has established common nuclear legislation
and a common control system for nuclear materials to prevent their diversion
to purposes other than those declared. An agreement for co-operation between
EURATOM and Britain was signed in 1959.
Community institutions were established by the treaties to formulate and
administer the common policies. Originally the three Communities had
separate institutions, but in 1967 these were merged; the member countries,
however, have retained their national institutions and identities.
The Council of Ministers is the decision-making body for all major questions,
and is the only institution whose members, usually the foreign minister or other
ministers appropriate to the subject of discussion, directly represent each
member country. Although provision is made in the Treaty of Rome for
certain matters to be decided by a qualified majority, using a system of weighted
voting, in practice decisions are taken on the basis of consensus. On all matters
of major importance, affecting vital national interests, decisions are in practice
taken on the basis of unanimity.
The Commission is responsible for formulating policy proposals for sub¬
mission to the Council of Ministers, for promoting the Community interest
and attempting to reconcile national viewpoints and for implementing the pro¬
visions of the treaties and Community measures. On enlargement the number
of commissioners—each of whom is basically responsible for one or more of
the main Community activities—will be increased from nine to fourteen; they
are appointed by agreement between the member countries and will include
two members from Britain. The Commission is pledged to act in complete
independence of national or sectional interests and to formulate its proposals
and administer policy in the interests of the Communities as a whole. Its pro¬
posals are made only after extensive consultation with officials of the national
governments and with such organisations as producers, trade unions, em¬
ployers’ associations and many others.
