APPENDIX 2 461
The Court of Justice interprets and adjudicates on the meaning of the
treaties and of any measures taken by the council and commission under them,
hears complaints and appeals brought by or against the Communities’ institu¬
tions, member states or individuals and gives preliminary rulings on questions
referred to it by courts in the member states. As a court of final appeal its pro¬
cedure in such cases is broadly similar to that of the highest courts in member
states; its rulings are binding on member countries, Community institutions
and individuals. On enlargement the number of independent judges—appointed
for six-year terms by agreement of the member states—will be increased from
seven to eleven.
The Assembly or European Parliament is composed of nominated members
of the parliaments of member states, sitting according to party affiliation and
not nationality. The parliament is consulted on and debates all the major
policy issues of the Communities. It also examines and approves the Com¬
munities’ budget. Members of the parliament may question the council and
commission and have the power to dismiss the Commission by a two-thirds
majority. The Committee of Permanent Representatives consists of representa¬
tives of the member states, of ambassadorial rank, whose task is to prepare for
the meetings of the council and perform whatever additional functions it might
delegate. The Economic and Social Committee is a consultative body repre¬
senting a cross-section of economic interests. Its members—representing
employers’ organisations, trade unions and other groups—are consulted by
the council and commission during the formulation of policy.
Other Community institutions include the European Agricultural Guidance
and Guarantee Fund (see p. 463), the European Social Fund (see p. 463) and
the European Investment Bank. In 1971 over 6,000 people worked for the
Communities’ institutions, largely recruited by the institutions themselves and,
like the members of the Commission, charged to act independently in the
interests of the Communities as a whole.
By the late 1950s although the desirability of close economic co-operation
between the countries of western Europe was generally accepted, a political
basis for agreement between the Communities and the other European coun¬
tries did not exist. In early i960, therefore, the signature of the Stockholm
Convention by Britain, Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal, Sweden and
Switzerland set up the European Free Trade Association (EFTA), designed
to create an industrial free trade area and to facilitate the establishment of a
wider association between its members and the Common Market countries
(see p. 459). By late 1966 the EFTA countries, with a population of almost
100 million, had successfully eliminated protective tariffs and quotas on their
trade in industrial goods, creating the first completed free trade area in the
world. Finland became an associate member of EFTA in 1961 and Iceland
joined in 1970, by which date trade between the members had trebled.
In mid-1961, however, Britain had formally requested the opening of nego¬
tiations to determine whether it would be possible for it to join the European
Communities, as had Denmark, Norway and the Republic of Ireland; several
other EFTA members—Austria, Sweden and Switzerland—applied for asso¬
ciation. The British negotiations opened in late 1961 and continued during
1962 with some degree of success, only to be broken off in January 1963 at the
French Government’s request. The British and other applications were
renewed in early 1967; during the subsequent consideration of the applications
462
ARRANGEMENTS
FOR ENTRY
Institutions
Industry
BRITAIN 1973; AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by the Council of Ministers the French Government indicated that while it
was not in principle opposed to the admission of new members, it considered
that enlargement would bring about fundamental changes in the Communities.
No negotiations followed, but the applications were not withdrawn. In mid-
1969 the Council of Ministers, at the suggestion of the new French Govern¬
ment, decided to hold a summit meeting to discuss the completion and
strengthening of the Communities, and their enlargement; the meeting, held
at The Hague on ist-2nd December 1969, agreed, among other things, to
open negotiations with the four applicant states. These formally began on
30th June 1970 and proceeded—in the form of separate meetings between the
four applicant states and the Council—during 1971, the majority of the main
questions in the context of the British application being settled by July 1971.
The decision to join the European Communities on the basis of the terms
negotiated was approved in principle by the British Parliament on 28th
October 1971 and on 22nd January 1972 Britain, the other three applicant
countries and the six original member states signed the Treaty of Accession in
Brussels.
The Treaty of Accession provides for entry into the EEC and EURATOM;
accession to the ECSC—which, since it was established by a different treaty,
involves a different procedure—is effected by a decision of the council. The
treaty documents consist of one multilateral Treaty of Accession, signed by
the original six member states and the four applicants, and the decision of the
council to which extensive documents setting out the terms of accession are
annexed as an integral part of the treaty. The documents thus incorporate the
conclusions reached during the negotiations, which include arrangements for
the progressive abolition of tariffs and the elimination of quotas between the
original six and the new member states, for a progressive adoption of the
common external tariff (GET), a progressive movement towards the Common
Agricultural Policy, provisions on fishing, the gradual liberalisation of move¬
ments of capital, the extension of the EEC’s association policy to the develop¬
ing Commonwealth countries in Africa and the Caribbean, and for the con¬
tinued import of Commonwealth sugar and New Zealand dairy produce. The
tariff and agricultural pricing arrangements will be introduced over a five-year
‘transitional’ period; the arrangements for Britain’s contribution to the Com¬
munities’ budget involve a slightly longer period of adjustment.
In the following sections a brief outline is given of the main arrangements
for entry.
Immediately upon entry Britain will have a position in each of the institutions
equal to that of France, the Federal Republic of Germany and Italy. In the
enlarged Council of Ministers Britain will have a vote weighting of 10 out of a
total of 61; two members from Britain will serve in the enlarged Commission;
Britain will send 36 members to the 208-strong European Parliament; and in
the Economic and Social Committee Britain will have a representation of 24
out of 153. English will become an official language of the Communities.
Tariffs on trade in industrial products between Britain and the Community
countries will be eliminated in five equal stages over the transitional period,
with an initial 20 per cent reduction to take effect from 1st April I973’ Britain
will apply the common external tariff to all countries neither belonging to, nor
having any special arrangements with, the Communities, subject to special
arrangements for a limited number of industrial materials and to a transitional
Agriculture
Fisheries
The Community
Budget
APPENDIX 2 463
period for adjustment, rates to be adjusted in four stages starting one year after
accession.
Britain will implement the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and its pricing
system, subject to a transitional period and special arrangements for New
Zealand dairy products and Commonwealth sugar.
The objectives of the CAP, as described in the Treaty of Rome, are to
increase agricultural productivity, to stabilise markets and to provide adequate
supplies at reasonable prices to the consumer. A structural reorganisation of
the industry is envisaged, but the more immediate objective has been to remove
tariffs and other barriers to trade in agricultural produce, to replace them by
levies to offset internal price differences, and to create common price levels
(by fixing ‘target’ prices each year) within the Community which would give
producers an adequate return. Under the policy the level of market prices for
the main agricultural products is maintained in two ways. The price of im¬
ports is kept up to a minimum or ‘threshold’ price by means of variable import
levies; and the internal market is supported by an ‘intervention’ price, slightly
below the threshold price, at which any surpluses are bought by the Com¬
munity’s agricultural fund. The fund also compensates Community exporters
when their sales to third countries are made at prices below Community levels.
Britain will adopt the Community system of support—though not Com¬
munity prices—in 1973, and introduce appropriate threshold and intervention
prices, which will gradually be increased to full Community levels by six equal
steps, subject to a 10 per cent tolerance, over the five-year transitional period
(see p. 321). There will be free trade with the Community countries (in the
products concerned) subject only, throughout the transitional period, to
arrangements to compensate for the difference in price levels—fixed levies on
Britain’s exports to the other Community countries and fixed compensatory
payments on their exports to Britain. The levies and export payments will be
gradually reduced by six steps over the five years, as prices come into line.
For those agricultural products for which the Community has a common
external tariff instead of, or in addition to, levies, the transitional arrangements
will take the form of tariff adjustments similar to those agreed for industry;
there will be a slower rate of adjustment for horticulture.
On 1 st February 1971 the EEC instituted a common fisheries policy based on
the establishment of a common market and free access for all members to
Community fishing waters. During the negotiations the applicant countries
indicated that they regarded the policy as regards access to be unacceptable,
and it was not until December 1971 that agreement was reached for suitable
access arrangements. The agreement provides that member countries of the
enlarged Community may restrict access in specified areas of their coastal
waters until 31st December 1982 (see p. 329), prior to which the Community
will review the situation and examine future arrangements. Britain will apply
the common marketing arrangements for the fisheries section and progressively
institute the common pricing system after 1st February 1973.
All member countries contribute to a common budget for certain specific
purposes, such as agricultural support (administered by the European Agri¬
cultural Guidance and Guarantee Fund, often known by its French initials,
FEOGA), the European Social Fund (used for occupational re-training and
re-adaptation programmes and programmes designed to further manpower
mobility), and administrative costs. Under the direct income system, which
4<M
The
Commonwealth
Economic and
Monetary Union
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
came into effect for the present members on 1st January 1971, the Communi¬
ties will progressively draw a greater proportion of the finance for this budget
directly from the revenue of customs duties and of levies on agricultural
imports. Except for a 10 per cent rebate to cover collection costs all levies on
agricultural imports are handed over to the Communities; in the case of
customs duties, an increasing proportion will be handed over, until from 1st
January 1975 all customs revenue, less 10 per cent for collection, will go to the
Community budget. Until 1975 the remaining proportion of the necessary
income (taking into account the new members’ contributions, which in
Britain’s case are described below) will be made up by contributions from the
(six original) member states according to a fixed scale (‘key’); after 1st January
1975 this will be replaced by a proportion (equivalent to up to a 1 per cent
rate) of the proceeds of the Value Added Tax (see p. 206).
Britain will adapt to the Community system over a series of years. A per¬
centage (or key) has been set, broadly corresponding to Britain’s present share
of the total gross national product (GNP) of the ten countries in the enlarged
Communities and representing the proportion of the budget which Britain
would nominally be expected to pay in the first year of membership. Over the
five years of the transitional period, Britain will pay a proportion of this
nominal contribution, increasing in annual steps, so that Britain will pay some
8-64 per cent of the Community budget in the first year, rising to 18-92 per
cent in the fifth year (1977), the latter being broadly comparable to Britain’s
share of the total GNP of the Ten. Arrangements have been made for the
two-year period after 1977 so that Britain’s contribution will not increase by
more than a limited amount. In 1980 and subsequently Britain will contribute
on the full basis of the direct income system.
For all British dependent territories, with the exception of Hong Kong and
Gibraltar, and for all the independent developing Commonwealth countries,
with the exception of those in Asia, arrangements have been made which
provide the opportunities of association, or in the case of the independent
developing countries the alternative of a trade agreement, with the enlarged
Community, permitting these countries access on favourable terms to the
enlarged Common Market. Provision has been made to safeguard New
Zealand exports of dairy products; the sugar-producing countries of the
developing Commonwealth have the assurance that, within the framework of
an association or trading agreement, it will be the Community’s firm purpose
to safeguard their interests. Until the end of 1974 Britain will fulfil its con¬
tractual obligations to buy agreed quantities of sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement (see p. 322). The independent Asian Commonwealth coun¬
tries will benefit from the Community’s generalised preference scheme and
have been given an undertaking that it will be the enlarged Community’s con¬
tinuing objective to expand and reinforce existing trade relations.
The Communities envisage a movement by stages towards economic and
monetary union, and as a first stage the countries which will form the enlarged
Communities have agreed on arrangements to keep the fluctuation of rates
between Community currencies within narrower margins,1 and for consultation
on short-term economic policies. After accession Britain envisages a gradual
1 When the British Government announced on 23rd June 1972 that, as a temporary
measure, sterling would be allowed to float (see p. i95)> h stated its intention of return¬
ing as soon as conditions permitted to the maintenance of normal IMF margins round
parity and participation in the special EEC currency arrangements.

465
and orderly run-down of official sterling balances; in the meantime, Britain
will manage its policies with a view to stabilising official sterling balances in a
way consistent with the longer-term objectives.
The Treaty of Rome provided for the progressive abolition of restrictions on
movements of capital between member countries, and subsequent directives
applied this to most of the main categories of capital movement. Britain will
make the necessary adjustments in exchange control policies by stages over the
transitional period, beginning with direct investment. Portfolio investment
will be dealt with later in the transitional period.
The Communities envisage the eventual harmonisation of indirect taxes, the
major step so far taken being the adoption of the Value Added Tax (VAT)
which Britain will introduce during 1973 (see p. 206). The members of the
Community are at present free to determine their own rates and coverage for
VAT, although it is envisaged that in due course harmonised rates and coverage
will be agreed. During the transitional period the present customs duties on
hydrocarbon oils, beer, spirits, wines and tobacco will be converted into in¬
ternal taxes to conform with the Treaty of Rome. As with VAT, members are
at present free to determine the rates of these duties.
Under the Community’s regulations nationals of member countries may freely
enter another member state to look for work or to take a job already arranged.
It has been agreed that there should be a five-year transitional period before
this system is applied to Northern Ireland.
The Community has negotiated association or preferential trade agreements
with Greece, Turkey, Tunisia, Morocco, Israel, Spain and Malta. Britain will
accede to these arrangements, subject to transitional provisions and any other
adaptations that may need to be made in consultation with countries concerned.
Britain has accepted the Treaty of Paris and the regulations made under it,
and will bring legislation and practices in line with these. The rules of the
treaty provide for free trade in coal and basic iron and steel products within
the Community. There is a pricing system which provides for controlled
competition by requiring producers to publish all their prices at selected basing
points; transport charges also have to be published or notified to the Com¬
mission. These pricing practices will be adopted by the National Coal Board,
the British Steel Corporation (BSC) and independent steel producers; the
Government’s powers to give directions on prices to the BSC will thus be
repealed. The present relationship between the Government and the coal and
steel industries will continue, although the Government’s powers to give
general directions will need to be modified. Community trade in coal will
be free from restrictions; tariffs for the relevant steel products will be adapted
at the same rate as has been agreed for industrial products generally (see above).
Britain has agreed to accept the treaty creating EURATOM and the rules
made under it without any transitional period, except in the case of tariffs,
where the necessary changes will be made one year after accession (1974).
Britain will play a full part in the future of the Community and its research
programmes; will accept the EURATOM control system; and in return for
the access to the stock of nuclear knowledge acquired by EURATOM will
deposit knowledge of equivalent value immediately after accession.

The European
Free Trade
Association
The European
BRITAIN 1973: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Britain’s withdrawal from the European Free Trade Association (EFTA)
becomes effective on 31st December 1972. The six EFTA countries which
have not, like Britain, Denmark and Norway, applied for full membership of
the Communities have negotiated various trade agreements with the European
Economic Community, based on the principle of free trade in industrial goods.
A European Communities Bill was presented to Parliament on 26th January
1972, and was passed by the House of Commons in July 1972 and by the
House of Lords in September.1 The Bill makes the legislative changes neces¬
sary to comply with the obligations entailed by membership of the Communi¬
ties, to make provision for the application of future Community decisions and
to exercise the rights of membership.
The basic requirements of membership are dealt with in the first part of the
Bill, which gives the force of law in Britain to that present and future Com¬
munity law which, under the Community treaties, is directly applicable to
member states and provides for subordinate legislation in connection with the
implementation of Community obligations or the exercise of rights under the
treaties.
The second part of the Bill contains the detailed legislation—in part repeal¬
ing or amending existing statutes—needed on or shortly after accession to
implement Community obligations. The main purposes of this part of the Bill
are: to provide for the charging of customs duties in accordance with the
treaties; to set up an intervention board for agricultural produce to operate the
Common Agricultural Policy and to provide for the collection of levies; and to
amend the law in connection with cinematograph films, companies, restrictive
trade practices, customs procedures, coal and steel, seeds, food, horticultural
produce, fertilisers and feedingstuffs, animal health, plant health and trans¬
port, so as to comply with obligations which arise from Britain’s accession.
Other Community obligations will be met by using existing powers to make
subordinate legislation, introduced as the measures become applicable.
1 It is expected that the Bill will become an Act in October 1972.

Most of the organisations concerned with sport publish year books covering results and
records of the previous season and future prospects; many weekly or monthly periodicals on
sport are also published. In addition some newspapers issue annual surveys of sport.
INDEX
Bold type in a sequence of figures indicates main references.
As the main purpose of this book is to inform readers overseas about Britain, organisa¬
tions and societies are generally indexed under their subject matter rather than under
Association of, British, National, Royal, etc. {that is. Accidents, Royal Society for the
Prevention of; Archives, National Register of). In cases where the first word is not
separable, however {for example, Royal Air Force, Royal Society), entries will be found
appropriately.
Items are indexed under England, Northern Ireland, Scotland or Wales only where
they are matters peculiar to these countries; otherwise they are indexed under the
relevant subject headings.

BRITAIN 1973 - published by Her Majesty's Stationery Office — is the twenty-fourth official handbook
in the series prepared and revised each year by the Reference Division of the Central Office of Informatiqi
with the co-operation of other government departments and of many national organisations. It is designei
to answer questions about Britain which are continually being asked both abroad and at home. This j
edition covers events up to September 1972.   |
